Definition: In this task, you will be given an Amazon customer review and you have to give a title for the review.

Positive Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Positive Examples.explanation: The review is positive and the user liked the product very much based on the given review, and the title correctly resembles to review.

Positive Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Positive Examples.output: None of them worked.  No functionality at all.
Positive Examples.explanation: The user did not like the product as it was not having any functionality and the title also states that the product was not useful.

I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Negative Examples.explanation: Here review states that the user has liked the product but the negative title of one star is in contrast to the review body.

Negative Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Negative Examples.output: The "M" key fell off after three days of light ...

Instances.input: Bought two for a 5 and 7 year old. They love it!

Overall, not very impressed. This is the 2nd ASUS monitor I have, I have the VE228 as well in a dual monitor display. The colors on this monitor suck, plain and simple. Every time I sit down I think it looks too red, too washed out, too green after I adjust the red, the colors are not consistent at all, and the brightness suffers because of it. Meanwhile, the other ASUS monitor I have that's 3 years old is exactly what I wanted this one to be.

The monitor wobbles while I'm typing, it's not secured to the base very well. I can tap the sides of both monitors, there is much more "shake" on this new monitor than the older one.

It also seems to have a problem "waking up" when the computer has sat for a while. I have to turn the power off and back on to get it to recognize, while the old monitor (currently set as monitor #2) works fine.

I'm not very impressed, I am thinking of upgrading my ASUS motherboard to a newer one, but now have to exercise caution.

While the seller it was purchased from was superb, going way beyond what was fairly required, the product was a great disappointment. This is the perfect keyboard for anybody who prefers to do their computing in a dark cave. After messing around with various lighting schemes for my desk, I just couldn't find the right balance.  What I really wanted was a back lighted keyboard like I have grown accustomed to on the [[ASIN:B007473X6A Apple MacBook Pro]].  This keyboard is exactly what I was looking for.  The lighting is gentle on the eyes and I am no longer struggling to find those seldom used keys on the fringes of the keyboard.  I chose this keyboard over the back lighted gaming keyboard because I wanted a quieter keyboard with less key travel with a feel similar to what I have on the laptop.  Again, this keyboard did not disappoint. For many years I have been using the Microsoft Natural Ergonomic Keyboard 4000. I was concerned that going back to the standard shaped keyboard would aggravate my carpal tunnel syndrome, however the shortened key travel and pressure seems to help mitigate the symptoms.  I highly recommend this keyboard.

I tried this on my Lenovo running XP and my Android phone.  What is supposed to happen is that when you are connected to the expander no matter where you homepage is it re-directs you to the NetGear site for further configuring.  Well it didn't work on my notebook and my smartphone attempted to connect but dropped because of internet quality.  So I figured this is going back!  I sat back in my recliner with my Android tablet to arrange an Amazon return when I thought I would try it on my tablet.  Well It Worked!  I was able to configure it so ALL devices that wish to connect can connect.  I'm not sure why the notebook (XP?) and Android phone would not connect but the Android tablet would, except for maybe since the tablet is the newest device, maybe it needs a Very recent OS?  You're guess is as good as mine but don't return until you try several different devices, and maybe a device or two from your friends/neighbors. By the way I'm using an AT&T modem/wifi router AND a LinkSys wifi router.  I need the AT&T for my internet service and the LinkSys for the T-Mobile Home Phone for $10/month, so I'm used to having much more difficulty with IP Cameras or any other Newtwork Accessory...

Bought this so i could use my Nexis 7 as a gps,and it works perfect so far. It shipped really fast. Holds my nexus 7 perfectly.

The monitor I received as an A0 version but manufactured in July of 2014. I ordered it in October of 2014 so clearly this is current product. I suspect the versions indicated the plant where the monitor was manufactured not the technology in the unit. My monitor has an excellent picture and no buzzing. The only area that I feel needs clarifying is that the monitor can only display WQHD (1440) graphics on Dual Link DVI graphics interfaces with the Dual Link DVI cable or the Displayport. The VGA and HMDI interfaces cannot go past HD resolution. This resulted in my needing to get a suitable graphics card and cable. This can be harder than it seems as most DVI are single link. I found an EVGA card with an Nvidia GeForce GT610 GPU with 1 GB of ram works fabulously with my standard HP Pavillion power supply and delivers excellent performance. However, I am not gaming full screen and full resolution most of the time but instead doing Photo editing and CAD work.

Bottom line: This is an excellent monitor with a minor restriction.
output: My monitor has an excellent picture and no buzzing

First, I want to thank Amazon.com for providing a web site that allowed me to review what others said about this router, and others, before I made my purchase. This info is invaluable.

I just installed this router today to replace a D-Link WBR-2310 on my home network. We have two computers using Ethernet connections to the router, a wireless notebook PC, and the Xbox 360 which is connected via an Ethernet cable. With the WBR-2310, despite hours of screwing around with the configuration, the Xbox live connection would disconnect frequently; so, most of the time we had it connected directly to the modem, thus preventing simultaneous use of the internet on our PC's.

The DGL-4300 was a dream (comparatively) to install. I couldn't believe that it sniffed out the Xbox and the other computers automatically. I didn't have to do a thing on the Xbox. And, we have been able to play the Xbox live and use the internet on our PCs all day without any problem.
output: Get this one for Xbox 360 Live

Instances.input:
I bought this product back in Aug 2012. As a computer it's awesome. Fast, light, awesome display and a decent battery life (about 5 hours with mixed usage).

However, I gave it a 1 start because of a problem that happens with the models that have the LG display. The wireless antenna (located adjacent to the display cable) interferes with the display. The screen flickers all the time. At the begging, it used to go away when I restart the machine so I though it was a software bug. However, it got worse and now every time I connect to 2.4Ghz wireless network it flickers. Look it up in youtube and google (rMBP screen flicker).

2 other minor issues:

- LG display ghosting problem.
- It gets hot.

My advise:
- Before you buy it, make sure you get the model with the Samsung screen not the LG model. If you get the model with the LG display return it. It will give your hard time.

- Get apple care. Aside from the display, the fan seems it's about to fail. So having an applecare will protect your investment. I contacted apple regarding the wirless antenna issues since it's a design issue and my warranty expired. However, they don't have any plans to recall the defective units even though it's a wide spread issue.
output: Bad QA for a 2200$ Product. LG display model problems

I just love this sort of pointing device. less wrist movement, fine control etc.
People fall into 4 camps for pointing devices.
> don't care /mouse users.
> touch screen/ touch pad users.
> index finger track ball users.
and
> thumb track ball users.
This is for that last category of people . This trackball works decent at a range, and works great on the desk- no cables to get in the way and small usb dongel. Cleaning the ball and socket is easy and intuitive. Multiple falls from desk height to the floor and it still works well (as long as you don't loose the ball!). And, in my experience, easy on the batteries (maybe 2 or 3 times a YEAR at most with using it 8+ hrs a day 5 days a week).

Instances.input: I just received this product today and I love it so much, I had to do a review immediately! Actually, I'm writing the review from the keyboard right now. I have the iPad 2 and the case fits like a glove. All the proper "cut outs" line up fine. I don't really use the camera much on my iPad, but the cutout is perfect in case i do. A HUGE thanks to Sinjon Vision who uploaded the photos. Honestly, those images are what sealed the deal for me. I met someone who had this case in red, which I had considered, but I wanted something a little different. The white stiching is a great contrast to the light brown color. The best part, as other reviewers have mentioned, is the velcro on the bottom of the part that holds the iPad. It's GREAT for positioning the iPad to many different angles, and it actually stays. My previous case (with no keyboard) has grooves to position the iPad but there are only two options and it kept slipping all the time: quite annoying. The ability to move the keyboard out is awesome! it gives you much more flexibilty so that you don't feel too cramped when typing. The keyboard is a little small to me, but that's not a big deal. I have fairly small hands. If you have larger hands, typing may be a little challenging unless you're accustomed to smaller keyboards; but if you really need a larger keyboard, my guess is that you'd be on a desktop or laptop and getting this case would be a moot point.  The only thing that could make this case even better is if the part that holds the iPad would pivot. Currently, the case is designed to hold the iPad in landscape mode only. This is great for typing with the keyboard, but when I read books or magazines, I prefer the portrait mode and it would be great to have the velcro feature in portrait mode. All in all, I love this case! And the price point is excellent. I paid half of the retail price. Can't beat it!
output: Fantastic! (review for Kensignton KeyFolio Pro2 in light brown)

Built products are put together well and use quality materials, which you'd expect because they're expensive. But this bag has problems that make it less than ideal.

I bought this to be a minimal bag, small, slim, and sleek. But it's wider than it needs to be. The straps attach in a way that flairs out of the top of the bag, making it wider than needed. It also makes the bag an odd trapezoid shape.

The second problem is, it's too tight. If your MacBook Air has a slim plastic case (like a Speck case). A Speck case is very thin, yet its little extra size makes it very difficult to get the computer into and out of the Built bag.

Another problem is the bag flap. It's too long. It adds weight. It makes the bag harder to open and close. If you put a computer power cord in the bag's front pockets, then the long flap won't stick and the flap sticks out unattractively.

For me, this bag wasn't worth the high price.

Instances.input: I was afraid it was a bad case because of the reviews. But I was surprised. Case arrived in a week, and the back is good, hard plastic. The front is soft, but definitely not flimsy. It's flimsy only because it's foldable, like the picture. At first I couldn't get it to stand, but then I realized I folded it incorrectly and it stood up well. Magnet also keeps the folds together. I recently had to contact Amped Tech Support and was helped by Andre (Concierge #165).  Andre was very patient with me. He helped me update the firmware on our Amped Range Extender, and he helped me successfully connect to our new wireless gateway.  It was a pleasure having him assist.

The foam material is pretty durable and strong. I have a soon to be 2 yr old who drags around the ipad by the handle and so far no damage. He steeps on it and even sits on it and it's a strong product.

The display image itself is very nice with very sharp images and vibrant colors. No complaints on the actual display (5 stars for the image). I use this monitor for work, and it is outstanding for viewing documents and web pages. I have not used it for gaming or watching movies, so I can't comment on the image quality for those uses. I really like the fact that this monitor uses a scant 27 W.    The display's physical housing however, is a major disappointment (1 star for the housing):   - The display is wobbly on the base.   - The tilt adjustment is super stiff. It takes 2 hands and more force than I'd like to apply to the wobbly base to adjust the tilt (one hand to hold the base and one hand to hold the bezel).   - The bezel and base are gloss black, so they show every single fingerprint and smudge. Samsung seems to be aware of this issue because they included a cleaning cloth with the monitor that is NOT for the display area, but for the bezel and base! Hey Samsung, skip the cleaning cloth and use a finish that does not highlight every fingerprint and smudge! Another downside of a gloss black bezel is that it reflects light from adjacent light fixtures and windows, which I find to be a distraction. I have half a mind to get out some 400 grit sand paper and take care of the gloss finish once and for all.  - The base is some stylish post modern curved design that cannot be used to put anything on (e.g. won't hold a pen, a note pad, a paperclip, or my reading glasses), and is therefore a useless waste of my desk space.   - The touch controls on the lower right side are exactly where I grab the monitor to adjust its position. Every time I do this, I accidently shut the monitor off or activate some on-screen adjustment. I prefer buttons in the lower middle to avoid this issue and show deference to our left-handed friends.  - There are no VESA mounts on the back (in case that matters to you).    Finally, the power cord includes a power converter brick in the middle ofthe cord, which is an inconvenience.    So, I love the display image and hate the housing on this monitor, resulting in 3 stars overall. If my complaints about the housing are not things that would bother you, go for it. If you prefer a housing with a stable and useful base, an easy tilt adjustment, a non-reflective bezel, and/or VESA mounts then you should pick a different monitor.
output: Love the display image, hate the housing.

The price point for this battery was a significant bonus, as the the HP version (if you can find one) is upwards of $70.  All things considered, this was the right purchase for me, and if I'm still using this laptop when this battery wears out, I would purchase again.

Instances.input:
There's a lot to like about this case in terms of its aesthetics and overall design. I should start by saying I haven't personally experienced this issues some customers have reported with the Kindle coming free of the case. The Kindle and case secure to each other magnetically and, at least on the one I got, it's a secure fit. I also haven't dropped my Kindle, so I can't speak to how well the case would protect the device in a fall, althogh it seems like it would probably be adequate in most cases.

Some things I like about the case (in addition to the previously mentioned aesthetics) are the loop for a stylus, and the clever folding back that allows the Kindle to stand either horizontally for media viewing or vertically for reading. I also like the way the Kindle keyboard fits into the case completing the set. BUT...

The devil's in the details, and some of the details end up being problematic. The folding stand can't be used whiile the keyboard is in place, which isn't a huge deal, but might be a consideration for some customers. A larger issue (which I also mentioned in my review of the keyboard itself) is the way in which the keyboard attaches to the case. In order for the keyboard to magetically lock to the case, it is placed with the keys facing OUT, away from the case. So, if you're using your Kindle as a reading device, or holding it on a plane, for example, and you have the keyboard attached, the case is folded open in such a way that your fingers are constantly pushing keys on the keyboard. Naturally, this wakes the keyboard and can cause all sorts of problems. Since the keyboard can't easily be used while it is in the case anyway, it's too bad they didn't make it mount (or at least ABLE to mount in a position that would leave the keys inaccessible when it is mounted.

That issue asiide, the case looks good, works well and has been a good companion to my Kindle.
output: Good Case that could have been almost perfect

Instances.input: Seems to be a strong battery

Bought two of them. One stopped being recognized after about 8 months (powers Dell laptop but not recognized so doesn't charge battery). Got my full money back since it was still under warranty.

I believe the problem is in the third (innermost) wire inside the plug that sends the digital signal ID telling the DELL laptop that the charger is valid. Either their is a break somewhere in the wire or the chip that generates the ID inside the adapter is fried. The problem is mostly DELL's fault for requiring an ID to charge which is more about increasing the sales of DELL-branded adapters than providing any type of added (protection).

So while I blame the adapter manufacturer in part for making a cheap adapter (but hey I only paid about 6.50), I blame Dell just as much for their anti-competitive tricks.
output: Stopped being recognized by DELL laptop after 8 months

Instances.input:
I haven't had the drive long enough to write a proper review but I felt I could help by clearing some things up. #1, this drive does NOT have a power button on it. To the person who says it does, did you actually look in the manual and/or push the button? It's not power, it's the Maxtor One Touch button. Maybe you have a different model.
And to the person who claimed that the drive isn't USB 2.0, I'm sorry but that's completely wrong. The drive is 2.0 and backwards compatible to 1.x. To get 2.0 performance you need a USB 2.0 port in your computer!!! They put an asterisk on the box to inform you that if you have 1.1 and want to ugprade to 2.0 they have a card (PCI USB 2.0) they will sell you. I'm sure it was frustrating for you to discover that your PC only had a 1.x USB port and you needed to buy something additional. But a good portion (I would say most) of folks know that to get USB 2.0 speed you need to have a USB 2.0 port. If a company sells you a UDMA 133 IDE drive and you're on UDMA 66 or 100 you're going to get reduced speed until you upgrade your IDE. The person said they replaced it with a Western Digital Drive, but unless that box came with a USB 2.0 PCI card included the results would have been the same.
I've had the drive 1 week so far it seems good and the transfer speed at USB 2.0 is good. Hopefully it will last.
output: some people doing reviews are crazy....

I just received the TP-Link AC 1200 Dual Band Wireless Router nicely packaged from Amazon. I opened the box, laid out all the gear inside, and began the process of installing the router.

Other reviewers have mentioned how easy it is to set up this router and they are correct for those people who are replacing an existing router with the new TP-Link reviewed here. For those folks new to using a router, TP-Link makes your task easy by providing you with a Resource CD which takes you step by step through the installation process.

Even though I have a router already in place, I decided to use the CD just to be sure that I got the maximum benefit from this new router. I was pleased with the systematic and clear directions given on the installation Wizard. In about ten minutes or less the Wizard told me installation was complete.

Now to test the router, which is located in a third floor office in my home. I went down to the first floor and turned on a HP Laptop with a Windows 7 operating system. After initializing the computer to accept the new router, I opened Google first and then AOL. Both browsers opened quickly, not quite as fast as the desktop computer that I am using to write this review, but fast nonetheless. Good start.

I decided to first bring up a video from YouTube - John Denver playing \\"The Bells of Rhymney.\\" Perfect picture and excellent sound. Next I went to NetFlix and clicked on \\"Grand Hotel,\\" a new Spanish film. Again, excellent picture quality and sound. The TP-Link works just as advertised.

What about customer service? Often it is difficult or impossible to get anyone on the phone to help if difficulty with new equipment is encountered. Not so with TP-Link. I was quickly connected to a tech adviser who talked to me about various features of this router. He was competent and friendly. I decided that if I ran into any problems with the router, help would be easily available.

Bottom line. Fast and easy to install, the TP-Link AC 1200 Dual Band Wireless Router works as advertised. How will it hold up over time? I will come back and update this review in a couple of months to discuss reliability issues with Amazon readers./>Bottom line. Fast and easy to install, the TP-Link AC 1200 Dual Band Wireless Router works as advertised. How will it hold up over time? I will come back and update this review in a couple of months to discuss reliability issues with Amazon readers.
output: Fast and easy to install and works just as advertised.

Instances.input:
This kit consists of an indoor camera/transmitter, a USB receiver for your PC and software. I'm a PC expert, but a security system novice. Here are my observations:

Setup:

Setup requires the following steps:
1) Find a place to mount the indoor camera. It must be within 10 feet of a power outlet, no exceptions. Mount the camera, plug it in the wall.
2) Load the software on your PC. The PC must be running Windows XP (any variety) or Vista. The installation is relatively painless.
3) Plug the receiver module into the wall and connect the receiver to your PC via USB.

Comments:

A) The requirement that the camera be within 10 feet of a wall outlet will create issues for some. It certainly did for me: There was no convenient outlet near the front door, which is where I would have preferred to mount the camera. (Remember that even if you have a convenient outlet, the cord is only 10 feet long, and you may not want the cord draped along the floor or whatever). As a result, I mounted the camera on the second floor to look down on the entryway porch--not my favorite choice, but good enough for now.
B) Because this system uses power-line ethernet (it uses the power lines in your home to do the networking), it is subject to the standard bugaboos of that approach, namely the connection can become flakey if you use certain appliances on your line (hair dryers are bad, for example), and the quality of the connection can also vary depending on where the transmitter and receiver are relative to the wiring.
C) The installation was relatively painless, but does require reboots and downloads to update the software.
D) You should plan for the PC to which you attach the receiver to be on 24/7, or at least at any time you want the camera system to work. If you expect to use this as a security monitoring system when you are gone, I would strongly recommend you put your PC on a good quality uninterruptable power supply (note that the receiver unit MUST be plugged directly into the wall, not the UPS, so if your power goes out, you will NOT get any camera feed until power is restored. But at least if your PC is on a UPS, transmission can start up again automatically when the power is restored).

Use:

Pros:
1) I was surprised at the good quality image I was getting from the camera, given the inexpensive nature of this kit and the relatively low light in the area to which it was pointed. Thumbs up.
2) The control software is relative easy to use. Thumbs up.

Cons:
1) This kit promises you can view your camera's output remotely. To me, that was probably the coolest thing. You could be in another city and keep an eye on your home. HOWEVER, it turns out that the only thing you can do without spending more money is watch the camera real-time. You can adjust the camera, and you can't review the video that your camera has captured remotely without paying $80/year to unlock additional features. I hate hidden cost software unlocks that are required to obtain the full usefulness of a product. This, in my opinion, pushes this kit down a full star (at least) in usefulness.

2) No sound. I am not sure why I expected this kit to capture sound, and I am not even sure if it matters, but it was disappointing to discover that the camera is video only. I consider this a minor nit.

Overall, I found that this kit exceeded my expectations in terms of the quality of the video that it captures, but that the powerline networking (with the limitation of a 10 foot power cord for the camera) and the $80 unlocking fee before remote operation is useful considerably reduce my overall happiness with the device. If they were to introduce a camera that used standard 802.1g wireless networking (either battery operated or capable of using a longer power cord), that would considerably increase the usefulness of the camera. If they would also stop with the $80 fee and just include all the features with the package (even if the package was priced higher), that could address the second issue.hat could address the second issue.
output: Good product if you can live with the limitations; aggrevating $80/year extra charge for certain options

I purchased this as a gift for my brother and his wife. The purpose was for them to be able to back up their pictures of their new born child. They were just storing all of their pictures on a desktop and the camera memory cards.

I suggested that they follow the same routine that I do with all of my pictures. They can save the pictures to their computer and then organize them by year then month. Every couple of weeks they plug this drive in a back up their pictures. While they are not using this drive they should keep it unplugged from their computer and in their safe. (Another tip I gave them was that every year they should buy a USB thumb drive and save the previous calendar year to it as well).

Using this drive in this fashion does not take advantage of any of the software features that it comes with nor does it touch on the life expectancy of it. What it does though is allow for you to back up a ton of priceless pictures that would be devastating to lose.

For us, the cost is great for what you get. I have used many WD Passports and have never had a problem.

-One tip that I will offer and you can take it if you wish... I would not leave this (or any) USB drive plugged into your computer all of the time. When you are not using the data that is on it it is best unplug it. These drives have moving parts in them and the more they are used the more wear they take on. Doing this will prolong their life.
output: great for backup (if you don't leave it plugged in all of the time)

I tried using an external ESATA box I had laying around with a hard drive, and it worked for a while, but even after trying two drives, they would eventually failed after a couple months causing the UI to stutter and pause and make even going to the guide almost impossible- and playback was a slideshow. So now, after months later of 24/7 use, I can say this recommended solution of the MyBook DVR Expander has been flawless and there have been zero problems. I don't know if these DVR's require a special firmware on the drives or if I just had really bad luck with two drives go bad right after the other, but I do know using this DVR expander has given me zero trouble and works just as advertised - plug and play. Highly recommended.
output: Highly recommended - Rolling your own DVR expansion isn't worth it

Instances.input: My situation is special.  I ordered quantity of 3 because I knew the chances were good there were going to be 2 bad ones.  It seems the seller over-shipped in my situation, and I wound up with six Bluetooth adapters.      I just plugged in three in a row, and when they refuse to work, basically Window 7 does not recognize the device being plugged in.  I threw all malfunctioning ones into the garbage.  The 4th one I tried worked (for now)    These little Bluetooth devices are made more than likely by the tens of thousands, and I bet 1/4 of what is manufactured is a malfunctioning Bluetooth device from the get go.  Seems that way in my situation.  I started with six, threw three away, and the fourth one tried worked.    Go Figure.    I would spend a little more money and get a branded Bluetooth adapter if I need to repeat this again.
output: These adapters are a dime a dozen...1 out of 6 might work

Instances.input: The Asus 1000HA Netbook is a cute little device that provides all the essential tasks I need as a college student.    - I needed something light   - Something I could bring to lectures and type up notes   - Something that wouldn't put a damper on my wallet (one of the main reasons I purchased this one)   - And something that would make transfers to my desktop as easy as possible  The Asus did all these things    Everything is pretty easy to use (still getting the hang of the extra Eee features the netbook came with).  The keyboard is nice and big compared to most netbooks and the zoom feature on the touchpad is pretty niffty.    I have had a few 'issues' with the netbook though...   I was kind of irked about the fact that the battery life is more like 6 hours than the advertised 8.. I also had to reinstall the Synaptics Mouse driver because after installing my AT&T AirCard the touch pad just crapped out and refused to work. I also had to reinstall The APCI driver (works the keyboard) because the function keys stopped working. Both were easy to fix though.. just went to the Synaptics and the ASUS website and they had repair drivers there and easy to find.  Also, The webcam didn't come with any software? What's with that?      One thing I did really like though is the battery life-- I was going to purchase the same make and model from BestBuy for $299 but it came with 4 hours less of batter life- 4 HOURS! For $30 more and the sacrifice of a megapixel in the webcam I got this one. I'm still happy with my purchase, but we'll see what challenges this little PC will conjure up down the road.
output: Nice little netbook, but had some promblems recently

Instances.input:
I've owned about 3 different ACER laptops. All of them were great, but this one takes it to the next level.
------------------------------------
Windows 8:

This laptop, when I first received it was very good. It worked, keyboard is very accurate, touchpad takes some getting used to. Windows 8 is OKAY. But the changes from windows 7 are a bit disappointing. It just doesn't have that "windows feel" anymore. I think Microsoft should rethink/rework the Windows 8 operating system a bit. It's too much to take in, and quite frankly, I think Microsoft is trying to 'copy' what Apple is doing; they're taking it way too far.

Immediately, I was disappointed with Metro. I absolutely cannot manage without the start menu! As well, with this laptop, using metro is kind of difficult. The touch pad is kind of all over the place sometimes, and takes you some place you don't want to go. Basically, I'd just tap the touch pad gently and end up clicking something in metro accidentally. This caused me so much frustration!!!

Overall, Windows 8 was just a huge disappointment to me. I don't know about anyone else, but I need more leeway when I use a computer.
-------------------------------

Linux Mint:

So after about 2 weeks, I tried Linux. I put Linux Mint on it, and surprisingly, it worked really well!! However, the brightness and touchpad were not working properly. I managed to fix the brightness, but the touchpad was a bit buggy still. The problem with the touchpad was scrolling and right click. Right Click wouldn't work unless you used 'two fingers'. Which meant I had to tap the touch pad with two fingers. It was a minor annoyance. The wireless was another major issue. For some reason in Linux, the wireless card would constantly drop. And it also would take for ever to reconnect. The only way to reconnect fast enough was to restart the whole system.

So pretty much, Linux needs a bit of updates for this laptop. The touchpad really works against you and does what ever it wants from time to time in Linux. And the wireless issue was just a huge turn off.

--------------------------------

Windows 7 downgrade:

And finally, 2 days ago, I downgraded back to windows 7. And guess what? IT WORKS FLAWLESSLY!!! It wasn't an actual downgrade, I had an OEM copy of windows 7 with a key to use. The performance difference between windows 7 and 8 on this laptop are VERY noticeable. Windows 8 kind of lags in desktop mode. But on Windows 7, I get no more lag, and everything runs smoothly.

Acer is such a great company when it comes to drivers. Most companies will not provide Windows 7 drivers. The reason for this is because they want to force you to use windows 8. Acer however, understands a users preference, and offers Windows 7 drivers in case you feel uncomfortable with windows 8. SO ACER GETS MY THUMBS UP!

All the drivers work, and I find the touch pad responds a lot better in Windows 7, compared to Windows 8 and Linux. Windows 7 works very well on this laptop, and I do recommend it if you want to downgrade to windows 7.

All I did was plug in an external USB cd-rom, and installed windows 7 pretty much that way. It's very simple.

-----------------------------------

PROS AND CONS

-----------------------------------

PROS:

1)Sleek
2)Runs decent
3)Intel HD 4000 can actually run some games. I'm not saying on high settings. Played Guild Wars 2, Left 4 dead, Killing Floor, etc; and they all run pretty well on this on low-med settings. But this isn't a gaming laptop, so don't expect anything like eye-candy gaming experience. This laptop serves it's purpose for me quite well.
4)i5 processor is SO GOOD!!!
5)USB 3, Bluetooth and HDMI
6)Overall Sexy silver look

CONS:

1)A bit flimsy (try not to rest anything heavy on it)
2)Network NIC (not the wireless). For some reason, an RJ45 cable refuses to fit properly in it. Don't know if that is a design flaw, or maybe I need better network cables.
3)Keyboard will betray you a few times. But this isn't a major con, it just takes some getting used to if you have big hands.
4)Battery could be better
5)....Wait stop. There are no more cons!

Yeah this laptop is too good for any big cons. It's a very decent semi-Ultra Book.

Other thoughts:

One more thing I noticed with this laptop, is it cannot get dirty! I usually leave my work spaces kind of messy after use. But this laptop has such a clean feel to it, you can hardly notice if there is a mess on it. I've had dust, pieces of hair, even some potato chips fall on it. It comes off very easily. Also, the Keyboard is fitted in a way, where it is impossible for any mess to get inside the laptop. Acer designed this so well, it's almost Dirt-Resistant!

I don't normally make reviews on Amazon, so please consider getting this laptop. It will not disappoint you, even if you like windows 8!
output: Acer is so GOOD, they even allow you to downgrade to windows 7. Linux works too!!

I put off setting this system up because in reading the manuals and the reviews it was apparent that there are a lot of details to consider in getting the most out of it, many of which require some knowledge of the technical workings. It's a flexible system with lots of options. For now I just want top use it for backup, but it can do much more.

I finally went with the simplest option to start with, the basic setup with default settings and, for my Mac, a Time Machine backup. Even that had a few wrinkles, such as deciding how much space to allocate for Time Machine. (For those who use Time Machine, ReadyNAS helpfully automatically sets up a portion of the drives of the size the user specifies. By default Time Machine would use all the space available on the drives.)

The setup and Time Machine backup went smoothly, no glitches. I needed to consult the ReadyNAS software manual (available online), and in some cases had to hunt a bit for the right button to click next.

The fan that operates whenever the unit is on has a soft but quite noticeable sound.

The two 1-TB drives that came with this system are [[ASIN:B008LA60NW Toshiba DT01ACA100 7200 RPM drives]] (from November and December 2013). User reviews at Amazon and NewEgg suggest these aren't the ultimate in reliability, though they generally perform well. They make the redundancy of the default X-RAID configuration desirable. (In that configuration, the total data that can be stored on the two 1-TB drives is only 1 TB because of the redundant storage. If one drive fails, all the data can be recovered from the other.)

The Toshiba drives are supposed to be energy efficient, which is good, because the ReadyNAS keeps them spinning continually when the unit is on. You can schedule times for the unit to power up and down, and you can remotely shut it down fairly easily. Remotely powering it up is a little trickier, but can be done via Wake on LAN. NetGear says they're working on a disk spindown option for their next software update (6.2.0).

Screws are included to mount 2.5\\" drives.

The power cord is helpfully long, a little over 11 feet, in two pieces with a power brick in the middle.

The construction is solid.working on a disk spindown option for their next software update (6.2.0).

Screws are included to mount 2.5\\" drives.

The power cord is helpfully long, a little over 11 feet, in two pieces with a power brick in the middle.

The construction is solid.
output: As simple or complicated as you like, works fine with Time Machine

I'd like to start off by saying I've previously owned both the Logitech G930 and Corsair 2100 Wireless Headsets.

Both of those headsets had their own flaws. The G930 would constantly disconnect and reconnect and after normal daily use the mic would physically break at its weak point since half of the mic was made out of hard plastic and the other half soft bendable plastic, boy oh boy that was a huge mistake. The 2100 on the other hand didn't suffer from these connection problems or cheap mic construction, but the sound isolation wasn't as good as the G930's due to the ear cups being made out of cloth instead of leatherette. The 2100 was also less comfortable due to an unusually strong clamping force which never really lessened.

I'm incredibly glad to say with the utmost joy that the SteelSeries H Wireless Headset doesn't share ANY of those faults and is the best headset I've ever owned by FAR. Not only is it exempt from those flaws, it outperforms in other areas as well. The sound quality is noticeably better, even only by a little, it is better than either previous headset. In addition, my favorite thing about this headset is the interchangeable battery! I NEVER have to go wired again... I just LOVE it!

My review is only based on PC use as I don't use it on consoles. If your wondering whether or not the price is justified and if it is worth it only for use on the PC, let me tell you right now it IS worth it.
output: My search for the perfect headset is over.

Overall I'm satisfied with the computer. It gets the job done. The weakest aspect of the device is the screen - it has a very narrow viewing \\"sweet spot.\\" I constantly fidget with the screen to find the right viewing angle. For comparison: my old HP DV9000 from 2007 had a much better viewing angle. Mind you, this isn't a deal breaker. As I said, it gets the job done. Although I'm glad I got it at a substantial discount on Black Friday 2012. I wouldn't pay full retail price, primarily because of the weak screen. For this reason alone, I've deducted one star. Perhaps for a laptop under $1,000, I was expecting too much?
On the plus side, the computer features 2x USB 3.0 ports and 1x USB 2. Despite this, I really wish there were 4 total USB ports. My previous laptop had 4 and I used them all. I'm not deducting any stars for this. I'm nitpicking.
There is a SD card reader, inconveniently placed anterior and underneath the device. In practice you'll likely have to lift the laptop up just to see the slot. Placing it on the side seems more practical. Again I'm not deducting a star, it's nitpicking
The computer is sufficiently fast although it's not a gaming laptop.
Upon first boot, you'll notice Windows 7 prompting you to burn your own backup disc. While not entirely necessary (a backup partition has this data), it's still a prudent thing to do. I realize ASUS is probably saving money, but I'd really like an official Windows 7 installation disc. You'll need 4 blank DVD's to accomplish the backup.
Overall I'm satisfied with this budget-grade laptop. It does everything I need it to, despite some questionable design choices and weak screen.

Instances.input: This is my first tablet, so I wasn't really sure what size to get.  I went with the largest one I thought was affordable.  As it turns out, this was more than enough for my 22\\" wide screen monitor(1680x1050 res).  It could easily handle two of my monitors(unless, you're a fan of using really large brush strokes).  When you consider the ability to zoom in and out on your work, it becomes obvious that you can get away with having a much smaller tablet.  Personally, I consider my brush strokes to be about average(though a bit heavy handed, apparently) and I probably only use about roughly 1/4th of my tablet surface at a time when drawing/painting due to zooming in and dragging the image around.  Anyone who's used a laptop touch pad can easily see how little space is needed to mouse around.  In other words, if you don't plan to do any real drawing or painting, you can get away with the smallest tablet you can find.  People who simply want to ditch their mouse can go with a Bamboo but anyone planning to do any type of photo editing or graphic work should stick to the Intuos(for the accuracy).  With all that said, I can easily shrink my tablet in the settings if I wanted to just use part of it instead of the whole thing.  However, I am getting used to taking advantage of the extra space.    It did take me a while to adjust to using the tablet.  I've been using a mouse and keyboard for over a decade.  I didn't really think about the fact I hadn't written or drawn much of anything with a real pen or pencil for so long would cause such a learning curve but it did.  However, I did adjust after about a week of use(I expected it to only take one or two afternoons since I normally adapt quickly).  I have to say, for drawing or working on photos, this is a lot easier.  I still prefer my mouse for everything else though.  This is partially because I can't fit both the tablet and my keyboard on the desk at the same time(I usually hold the tablet in my lap when I use it).    I don'tuse the Express Keys that much but after a little customizing and getting used to it, I'm finding them to be faster than relying on my keyboard.  I figure that with time I'll use my keyboard less and less.  I also spend less time clicking tool buttons and more efficiently spend my time just using express keys.  Being able to switch tools by simply pressing an Express Key really saves a lot of time.  Though, I wish I could find a way to resize the eraser without selecting it first.  From what I've seen of the previous generation Express Keys, I don't see all that much of an advantage to the new ones.  The improvement is nice but seemingly unnecessary.    My actual drawing skill is not that great, yet, so I don't get much use out of the pressure sensitivity.  Instead, I manually control the opacity.  I figure that as my skills develop, I will probably learn to take advantage of the pressure sensitivity.  I'm just not there yet.  That said, even if I'm not using the pressure sensitivity, it's still a lot easier to draw with the tablet than a mouse.  Since I've never tried the Intuos 3, I can't really compare the sensitivity.    I've noticed that the nibs seem to wear down fairly fast.  Also, I hear the surface sheets don't last very long either compared to the previous generation.  I don't know if this was intentional to increase sales of replacement parts or a sacrifice to gain something else.  It does make the Intuos 3 seem more desirable in that sense.    Probably my biggest complaint with the whole thing is the pen itself.  It's just too fat for me.  It makes me feel like I'm using one of those fat pencils from Kindergarten.  I've more or less adjusted to it but I'll probably end up buying that slimmer version that doesn't have the rubber grip.    Ultimately, if I had it to do all over again, I'm not sure whether I'd get a smaller tablet.  I could very easily be happier with a smaller tablet, if for no other reason than being able to fit it on my desk.  However, the extra tablet space makes a dual monitor setup more comfortable.  I normally find the extra screen space unnecessary but when drawing/painting, there's a certain amount of advantage to being able to focus one monitor on just the painting and put everything else aside to the other monitor.  I could have saved money by getting an Intuos 3 but Wacom doesn't really seem to be supporting them anymore.  The advantages of the Intuos 4 over the Intuos 3 just don't seem necessary, this is especially true in the case of someone, like me, who doesn't take full advantage of the pressure sensitivity.
output: More than I need but I think I could grow into it

Instances.input:
I was looking for a replacement for my old Belkin Nostromo n52te and stumbled upon this seemingly awesome device. I'd always been a huge fan of logitech products and the G13 looked like the perfect keypad for me.

I'm a professional designer and use a keypad for all my hotkeys in Photoshop. Depending on the freelance job, I have to move around and jump onto different computers. That's why I really loved having the onboard memory on the n52te. Program your macros and you can plug it into any computer and away you go! I was *specifically* looking for a keypad with onboard profile storage which is why I picked the G13.

Unfortunately I was totally mislead...This is the information on the amazon page:

"Onboard Memory
A handy solution for the laptop gamer, the G13 gameboard includes onboard memory, letting you program up to five ready-to-play profiles and take them with you to your next LAN party. The G13 gameboard also offers pre-configured settings for many popular games, including World of Warcraft: Burning Crusade, Lord of the Rings Online: Shadows of Angmar, Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare, and many others."

Nowhere does it say that you need the LGS software to run any of the profiles. It only mentions it when describing how to program your keys.

I do have to admit though, everything else on the keypad works flawlessly. The software is very useful and the hardware is up to logitech standards. I just can't believe they advertised this as a portable keypad when you need to install the Logitech Gaming Software to even run it. The worst part is that there are other logitech products such as the G series gaming mice that DO have the ability to use the set profiles without a driver. Makes me really wonder: why was the G13 omitted this awesome feature?
output: Disappointing. Not portable as advertised...Profiles do not work without LGS software.

On first release these cards were $400. But now since their price drop I was more easily able to justify the cost, that being said since owning the card I would have happily paid 400 for it. I had a dual tuner card prior to this for just OTA/ClearQAM cable, and I was always re configuring, tweaking, and adjusting the thing. Very frustrating, and the wife was not too happy with the situation either. I was absolutely shocked at how easy it was to set up the Ceton InfiniTV4. A few things:

First - I have Comcast, dont let them charge you to swap out your current equipment, or have a tech come out to do a \\"professional\\" install. Go to the store PHYSICALLY and get your cable card. This saves you 50 bucks.
Second - MAKE SURE, you upgrade the devices drivers AND FIRMWARE before trying to configure it. I didn't update the firmware and couldn't get the card to work until I did so.
Third - There may be some signal quality issues that weren't previously noticeable with your old receiver box. In my case the comcast tech had to run a whole new length of cable from my house to the node.

After all that - this card is everything I hoped and dreamed my HTPC would be initially. I also have an xbox that is set up as a media center extender, and I can stream live or recorded TV to that as well (ie. can watch two different channels at the same time on both my HTPC and Xbox).

The only issue I've had is that occasionally I get the message \\"No tuners available\\" or \\"All tuners in use\\" in WMC when trying to stream TV. A reboot of my machine fixes this every time, but it hasn't been enough of a nuisance to warrant much troubleshooting yet.

I purchased this computer because my thinkpad T61's screen had become dim after 18 months of use. I did all kinds of searches for about 1 week then finally bought the Toshiba P505D.    The computer has a large screen with pretty good brightness, Toshiba describes it as \\"True Bright\\", I think it's bright, but not \\"very\\" bright, it probably is around 200nit-250nit, but it won't give you \\"stunning\\" visual experience. Anyway, it's a lot more comfortable to staring the screen for 2hours than the old Thinkpad T61's.     The sound card of this computer is terrible,if you listen to FLAC through the audio jack using a headphone like the Sennheiser HD 280 pro, you would find a lot of mids in the music are lost, and of crouse, many details are lost as well, if I have to use headphones on this computer I would use a USB soundcard instead.    The speaker is very loud, and contains a lot of distorted bass, I think there is a 6dB boost in the 60HZ to 100 HZ range, I don't quite mind the distortion though, because it's not very possible to find a speaker as loud as this in a 15.4\\" or 14.1\\" model from any manufacture in the market.    And the performance, the P505D is noticeable slower than my Thinkpad T61(2.0GHZ T7300, 3GB RAM, 100GB
output: good for the price, but the CPU is a bottle neck

I used this caddy to put an extra hard drive in my Dell Latitude 6520. It works great -- I mounted the drive, inserted the caddy, and instantly had SATA access to my drive. It has embedded set screws that mount into the hard drive to keep it securely in place.

A couple minor cons:
(1) There is NO BEZEL on the outside of the unit to make it form up with the curved outside of the laptop. This doesn't really bother me, but it might annoy most people.

(2) There is no handle or mechanism to hold the caddy in the laptop chassis similar to the push-to-eject handle on the DVD unit. This means (a) you will not be able to pull the drive caddy out, and (b) there's nothing stopping it from falling out if you give the laptop a good jolt while it was vertical. I solved this problem by dismounting the push-to-eject handle from the DVD unit and attaching it to the new caddy. This has a locking mechanism in it to keep the hard drive locked in and allows me to pull it out. It also leaves the DVD with a small gap that I can grab with my finger to pull the drive out. Problem solved.
output: Good, inexpensive way to add second hard drive to Dell Latitude E6520

Instances.input:
I purchased this case for my iPad 4th generation after going through the myriad options on Amazon. I received it today, and have to say it is quite nice. The materials are good, and the build quality appears to be a notch about many of the cheap products I've seen.

The problem is, it just doesn't fit right. The case appears to be just ever so slightly too narrow. With the iPad fully inserted, the far left edge hangs a bit off the edge into the spine. This causes the top cover not to line up properly. This in turn causes problems with the clips on the cop and bottom of the case that are meant to clip onto the iPad and hold the cover in place. The bottom clip will snap in eastily, but the top clip absolutely will not snap into place unless you forcibly bend and contort it into place.

I've contacted Marware support about the issue, and hope to hear back soon. I'll update when I do, but, for now, I would avoid this case if you have a 4th generation iPad.

Update 12/12/12: I did get a response from Marware. They claimed that my issue wasn't a known problem, but agreed to send out a new cover.

In the interim, I noticed that my existing cover was beginning to loosen up a bit. After a few days, the pressure needed to close the case had diminished greatly. I did finally receive the replacement, and it does seem to fit marginally better than my original did out of the box. Unfortunately, the replacement has other build issues that the first did not. The replacement has a great deal of extra material sticking out around the stitching. It makes the cover feel very poorly built. In the end I decided to keep my original cover. The stitching on it is much cleaner, and it has loosened up enough that I don't have issues opening and closing it now as I did initially.

I will say that I do like the case. It is light, looks good, and provides very good protection. It's unfortunate that build quality does seem to be a bit of an issue. I'm raising my initial 2 star review to a 3 star, which is probably more like 3.5 stars. The truth is, even with the Marware case's flaws, I've not found an iPad case that I like any better.
output: Does not seem to fit the iPad 4th generation. Update: It gets better

Instances.input:
The Lenovo IdeaCentre Q190 meets my requirement. It's slow, compared to what I'm used to, but not any slower than most mainstream mid-level laptops. I'm using it exclusively as an HTPC, hooked up to a Pioneer A/V receiver and an old 60\\" LG plasma TV. It plays all audio and video files I tried (of course, this depends on the software used). 4K videos works well on my monitor but the TV can't handle it reliably (TV is not 4K). Noise is a non-issue. The VESA mount works well for hiding it behind the monitor/TV. From my router in the living room at the rear of the house to my home office at the front is 55 feet and I'm getting 5-bar WIFI signal strength. If your expectation is realistic, it should work well for you. It's a good HTPC or secondary desktop PC.

One serious Issue:

At first I could not update to Windows 8.1. It got stuck on downloading loops with each loop lasted about one hour, then it started over without actually downloading anything. I tried several times on different days with the same result, so I decided to forget about it. Then a week later it updated to Windows 8.1 automatically. However, after the update LAN ports and WLAN were dead. Lenovo tech support did not help at all. Since Windows troubleshooting indicated it was having problems with the drivers, I went to Lenovo web site and downloaded the Windows 8.1 LAN and WLAN driver files and installed. Still didn't work. I decided to start clean and uninstalled the drivers, downloaded the Windows 8.0 files and installed. To my delight, LAN and WIFI worked with 8.0 driver files. Out of curiosity, I installed 8.1 files again. And yes LAN and WIFI were dead again! Finally, I uninstalled and reinstalled 8.0 files and left it at that. Bottom line: DO NOT use the Windows 8.1 driver files; you need the 8.0 files.

Comments:

I don't like or care for included funky remote. I'm using the Microsoft Wireless Keyboard 800 and mouse combo, which works very well from a distance of 12 feet. It still works at 14 feet but becomes a little jumpy.

It becomes warm to the touch after running for a while. Exhaust feels hot but it's nothing to be alarmed. Again, it's not any worst than some laptops. It needs air circulation, so it's definitely not a good idea to wedge it between books on your bookshelf.

I've had my KlearKase for Kindle 3 for a few days now and I'm pretty close to completely satisfied. For protection I think it's great (haven't tested it, but it feels pretty solid and safe). For weight, it's good. Yes, it nearly doubles the weight of the kindle package, but that's still pretty light. For ease of using the Kindle while in the case it's excellent. All the controls are quite reachable and audio books are still quite audible, though perhaps the sound is a little blurred. I haven't tested the splashproofness, but I think I'd be confident to read in the bath with the KlearKase on.

My gripes with it are all small things. The biggest would be that it's far more reflective than the kindle screen. Considering the non-reflectivity is a major advantage of the kindle, this is the big thing that makes me less inclined to keep the kindle in the KlearKase all the time. That said, it's see-through enough that it doesn't detract from visibility any more than reading a book through a glass window does. The other three small disadvantages are a) I think the surface might scratch quite easily, eventually resulting in a less clear viewing, b) you need a quarter (or a 10c piece if you're Australian) to be able to open the case and take the kindle out, which can be a bit tedious, and c) the silicone sections pick up dust and hairs really easily, which means I had to put in-take out-put in-take out-put in just to get the inner side of the silicone parts hair-free (I have a fluffy cat at home).

Overall, it's like Mary Poppins - \\"practically perfect in every way\\" :-)

If your plan is to buy this card, attach it to a laptop, and then attach it to a GoFlex USB 3 Hard Drive, prepared to be disappointed. This card does not provide enough power on its own to run USB hard drives. Although it comes with a cord that allows for additional power to be provided to the card from a spare USB port on your laptop, something about the power output causes the drive to simply stop working after a while. I initially thought it was my supplemental USB port turning off power, so I tried an external power source that I knew would not turn off and had the same result. Tested the same drive using USB 2.0 directly, and no issues.

This appears to be an OEM card that has multiple brands, and is based on the Renesas USB chip, so I suspect any of the cards that look exactly like this one and use the same driver will have the same result. Works for probably 5-10 minutes, then stops. Very disappointing.

My only criticism is that the stand is about 16.5" wide between the legs, and my keyboard is 17.5" wide, so I have to angle the keyboard in order to store it underneath the stand as it does not slide directly underneath. However, I have a keyboard with the 10 key numberpad, so if you just have a small keyboard it would be perfect. Overall, really good value here in my opinion.

Rather than put off purchasing a tablet until she had saved enough for a more reputable brand, my ten-year-old decided to take a chance on this budget device. She is sorry she did.

The display was inferior, but it was good enough for the price, and she was happily using it for games and pictures. (The camera is front facing ONLY.) But during the first day of normal use (I was there--she was not rough on it), the power and volume buttons on the side of the device no longer sprang back when depressed, making them unusable. She was disappointed but decided to live with it since the device could still be turned on by plugging it in, and since there was a volume control on the screen as well. But by day three, the tablet would no longer power on at all.

The seller offered to exchange the device, but we had no confidence that a new one would last. In the end, my daughter was able to get a full refund, so she was only out the cost of shipping. But the whole experience has put her off the idea of owning a tablet at all.

I cannot recommend this device. You have been warned.
output: Don't say I didn't warn you.

Instances.input:
Normally, when you buy a screen protector, they include a little plastic squeegee thing to help you push out all the bubbles. You don't need it with this screen protector. They DO provide you with two cleaning cloths (a wet and a dry one) to prepare your screen before you put on the film.

After I cleaned the screen, it was amazing that the film just went on smoothly with absolutely NO bubbles. It took a few seconds to apply the film and I was done! What a difference from the time I've spent pushing bubbles with other films; and no cursing!

I am so pleased with the product. It is virtually finger print proof, unless your fingers are a dirty. But they provide a lint free cleaning cloth for that! The film also cuts down the glare quite a bit. It is hard to see any loss of clarity of the display between when the film is applied and with no film.

I would highly recommend this product!
output: Wow - When they say no bubbles...

My neighborhood is full of WiFi networks. Some of my neighbors' routers jump from channel to channel, causing intermittent interference.

I have a lot of devices in my house. Any device that is relatively stationary (printer, Z-wave controller, PC, IP camera) is plugged into one of these little gems, as they are immune to WiFi interference. Set up is easy. Just follow the directions. I have found that they will not work if plugged into surge suppressors (the instructions said so, but I had to try) or z-wave controlled outlets (these create interference).

The only reason I don't give these adapters five stars is that they have to be unplugged and replugged periodically (monthly, quarterly?) to keep the network up and running. That's my first shot at troubleshooting if a Powerline AV connected device loses network connectivity. Start by unplugging the one connected to your router, then go around and unplug/replug the 'client' adapters.
output: In a world gone mad with WiFi signals...

I initially purchased this monitor for an attorney who needed a second portrait-oriented monitor for drafting documents that would put most of us to sleep. Because it was intended to match the right hand (second) monitor it needed to be 20\\" and due to the Ergotron mount, it needed to be light.

Before purchasing this monitor, please note that there are no VESA mounts on the back. You must use the stand that comes with it and that stand elevates the screen just under three inches. This is going to be a very important consideration for a lot of people.

As a monitor, the unit performs as expected. Color reproduction runs a little heavy into the blue spectrum and will need to be calibrated if you are a graphic designer... wait hang on. Why are you looking at a 20\\" screen, designer? Moving on. The back light isn't especially bright and the menu has four default settings (movie, photo, gaming, text) in addition to \\"custom\\". After a couple of hours, I'm finding the monitor a bit hard to look at due to the fact the anti-aliasing on fonts looks terrible. At this point, I've further reduced the brightness to level 25/100 to deal with it.

Finally, the power cable is non-standard. If your power conversion box goes, you'll have to buy a new one. While it's not likely to happen, it does represent an extra part to lose or break. On the other hand, if you haven't lost or broken the charger attachment for your phone, printer, tablet, or... well you get the idea. People who take good care of their things will probably be fine. People who don't may not want the extra part attached.

In short, the monitor that came with this Gateway vastly out-performs the HP monitor that arrived at the office this morning.

Pros:
+ Price is right
+ Slim, light,
+ Shiny finish, modern looking case
+ Energy efficient

Cons:
+ Limited brightness & color adjustment
+ No mounting bracket
+ Very short non-adjustable stand
+ Non-standard power input
+ Shiny surface will scratch easily
+ Not as bright as expected from an LED screen
+ Gamma is heavily blue, even in warm light mode (cheap LED backlight)
+ Poor anti-aliasing, especially on fonts. Edges look chunky.
output: Half-way decent budget monitor, lots of limitations

The Joy Factory is the best of both worlds, a rubber tip stylus that is thin. It does come with it's issues as well.

The actual pen is thicker than most stylus , which can be a tad cumbersome. The tio is a captive tip controlled by a battery. The battery is a AAAA, which is available at any Walgreens or CVS. The problem is that the pen sucks the battery power. I have had the own for 3 weeks and I have gone through 4 batteries. I found that I have to unscrew the top , to preserve battery power.

With all that said, for the price it is a decent stylus .

Not much needs to be said about computer RAM specifically for laptops, but I can say that the upgrade was quick, easy, and painless.
Simply release the retaining latches on each side of the old RAM module, gently remove the (being sure to avoid any static discharges, of course) old module, then insert this new RAM module, gently seating it until the latches click fully into place.
Turn the computer on, and just like that, my laptop goes from 4GB to 8GB of RAM.
Everything works perfectly, and the computer's performance is improved dramatically.
One note to anyone using a 32-bit OS, such as all Windows XP editions except for "Professional X64" or "Itanium," will not benefit from this upgrade, since the maximum amount of RAM those can address is 3.2GB or 4GB of installed RAM.
This is not just a Microsoft limitation, but inherent to all 32-bit operating systems, including older version from Apple and even 32-bit Linux and other Unix-like systems.
Once you upgrade to a proper 64-bit OS (Windows 7, Windows 8.x, 64-bit Linux, etc.), you will be able to use well beyond 8GB of RAM.
Does your motherboard have room for nearly 17 billion gigabytes of RAM?
No, I'm not joking with that last sentence.
output: Good quality memory upgrade for laptops

Instances.input:
Works great
I wish it were smaller

The Kindle 2, like the K1 before it, is a great product for the heavy recreational reader.  Unfortunately, many of the changes made in design aren't necessarily better, just different.    The increase in screen resolution is a very welcome change.  Simple diagrams that were illegible on the K1 are just fine on the K2.  As I'm finding though, progress on the Kindles does not come without some negative, in this case the screen contrast on the K2 seems a little lower then on the K1.  Also, I think they got that page turning speed up by hobbling the screen refresh: when taking the K2 out of sleep, ghosting from whatever picture was on the splash is clearly visible and doesn't go away until doing an <alt-g>.    The buttons.  We've all heard more then we care to about the buttons.  Again, I have to go back to the two steps forward one step back kindle design.  Yes, the big, easy press buttons on the K1 could be a pain and the inward pressing buttons were a great solution to the perceived problem.  Unfortunately, they went too far by making the edge buttons so much smaller.  Long reading sessions can now become uncomfortable for those with large hands as you tend to place your thumb either right on or next to the next page button (basically, holding the Kindle by its very edge).  This certainly cramps my thumb up.    The memory and battery changes are a mixed bag I guess; I'm not a fan of the changes but certainly don't consider them deal breakers, either.  The first charge on my K2 was no better than the K1 though that seems to have improved with use.    One last point that's more a publisher gripe then Amazon gripe is the tendency to offer ebooks based on trade paperbacks, pricing them at $9.99 and still claiming a discount.  If a book's been out for a few years, there's no reason for the ebook to cost $9.99.  Reevaluating that policy would be good for everyone involved.    Overall I'd call the K2 a good purchase but as an upgrade to the K1, not so much.  If you think aK2's right for you, it probably is.  Whispernet alone puts the Kindle beyond all other readers (if you're in a coverage area).
output: Good for a new adopter but for the Kindle 1 owner, not so much

Instances.input: Bought this to upgrade my GoFlex desk external from USB 2.0 to 3.0. I toyed around with the idea of going with the thunderbolt adapter, but quickly chose this since it's performance isn't that far off from thunderbolt, I don't need to daisy chain any devices, and it's significantly more affordable. It took me less than 2 minutes to pop off the old and replace with the new and now I'm enjoying being able to transfer large amounts of data (800 GB) at much faster speeds. I saw some reviews that stated theirs didn't come with any cables, I can report that mine came with a cable and and a new power supply for what that's worth.

Pros:  - Good concept    Cons:  - Weak signal strength  - Battery Life is only about 2 hours; likely long enough for continuous remote use.  - They don't distinguish between two very different devices (the 3G and 4G).  It's the luck of the draw which one you get because they are both called \\"PHS300\\". If you get the one pictured here with the logo on the unit, you have the older 3G version.  If you get the unit without the logo, you have the newer 4G version.    My first unit (a Version 2 4G unit) died within 2 days.  RMA'd it and the 2nd unit I received was a Version 1 unit.  Cradlepoint swapped the Version 1 for a Version 2 at no cost.  I was at first frustrated by Cradlepoint customer service.  However, in the end they did come thru and I changed my rating accordingly.  Thanks Mike at Cradlepoint; good customer service.
output: Frustrated at first but Cradlepoint Customer Serive Came Thru

The computer in my daughter's room is about 60 feet away from our broadcast point and there were several walls in the way. She could never get more than one bar(poor) reception and her connection often dropped totally. I had purchased a USB adapter that was supposed to have a \\"power boost\\" that increased the signal strength, but if it helped at all it wasn't enough to notice.
I received this new adapter just a few days after ordering. It included a mini-CD and instructions on how to set up and access the driver for the adapter. The print on the instructions was very small and it didn't explain that you need to look at the numbers on the CD sleeve to know which driver to choose when the menu came up. These are the only complaints that I have! The driver loaded swiftly, I attached the antenna to the adapter(it simply screws on), plugged it into my USB port, and was online in no time. The connection is now full strength!
I am very pleased with this inexpensive and easy solution to a serious problem (after all, I didn't want her hogging MY computer).
output: BIG Difference for such a little product!

Amazon got everything right with the Kindle 3. The ability for my library to sync across all my reading devices makes it easy to start reading at home, and pick it up on my phone later at the office or on a computer or elsewhere. I feel like my entire collection is just a moment away no matter where I am! With this edition the load times have become trivial and the price more-than reasonable. I picked up the white 3g+wireless because I do a lot of traveling, and I can attest that the 3g works great over-seas for getting my Amazon.com fix. I downloaded over 100 free out-of-copy-write titles the day I got my Kindle - amazing works of literature for free! My only complaint is that more titles aren't available as Kindle editions, but I feel this is more a sign of the times and not any reflection on Amazon - I suspect Nook and other comparable e-readers have similar availability limitations. The Amazon site allows you to request publishers make certain titles available on Kindle, so they obviously recognize this limitation on the e-reader market. Hopefully most publishers will soon embrace the future. I know I for one have repurchased several titles I already owned just to have them on Kindle where I can have quick and easy access to them, so I'm confident the future will be rich with e-books!

Instances.input: I use this router at home and connect via the VPN to a SnapGear at the office.  The VPN took about 10 minutes to get setup and has not failed once since.  The main issue with setting up the VPN was finding a protocol that both the router and the SnapGear had in common.  The EnGenius router has several different protocols to choose from and not being a true network guru it took a few minutes to go through them.    On the local network I have a consistent 1 Gbps connection.  There is no lag when streaming from my computer to my PS3 or XBOX.  I also stream straight from the internet and have never had a problem.  I also learned that you need all 8 wires to get 1 Gbps.  I had split my cat 5 into 2 connections using 4 wires each and could not get 1 Gbps connections.  Once I \\"unsplit\\" the connection it worked like a charm.  I was using a Linksys VPN router before and if I had the log file option turned on it would crash when hitting web sites like Amazon (google Amazon crash Linksys) and Fandango.  This router has no issue when any websites that I have found.    The wireless does work well.  I have the router in the basement and had an 80% signal when upstairs and 50-60 feet away.    I really only have had one issue with the router and that is the DNS relay.  After a reboot of the router I was not able to access the internet.  DHCP was assigning the router's IP as my DNS server but it was not working.  I set the router to assign a DNS server from my ISP and everything worked again.  The interface is different from other routers as well and takes a minute to find what you are looking for.  Also, when assigning a static IP via DHCP there is not a comment section only a MAC and IP field.  This isn't a big deal but it would be nice to have a comment field saying 00:00:00:00:00 192.168.1.50 Office, or something to that affect.  These are minor issues and nothing that I care greatly about.    Overall I do love this router it is exponentially better than routers that cost 2 or 3times as much.  Being an unknown brand, at least to me, I was a little concerned.  It has proven to be a great router and I'm very happy with it.  I would recommend this router for anyone needing a VPN router.

I received my kindle as a birthday gift eight months ago and I love it, but I didn't always think that I would. Before I got the kindle I swore I would never get one because I saw it as an assault on my much loved paper books. The portability of this thing, the e-ink and the instant access to free books (more on that in a minute) really won me over though. Reading text on a regular screen makes my eyes tired and I usually just don't prefer to do it, but reading the kindle feels just like reading words on paper. And being able to carry the contents of huge books with me without the bulk of an actual book which may be 100's of pages long means I can find time to do a lot more reading.   That all being said, my kindle contains mostly free downloads and just a few books that were on the cheaper side. I'm not super fond of the idea that I could purchase an e-book (which sometimes is more expensive than an actual paper book) and then I'm limited with what I can do with it.  When I'm done with the book, why can't I give my digital copy away to someone else? If I can sell or give away my regular books why shouldn't I be able to do the same with my e-books? Just like if I can lend regular books to my friends and let them keep them for more than two weeks, why can we only lend out kindle books for two weeks? Some people are busy and two weeks isn't enough time.  Reading free books though has let me find some really good new authors who self-published. And being able to download books whenever I want is convenient for those instances where I find myself with some free time but the library isn't open, or just enough time that I'd like to read something but not enough time to get to the library even if it is open. I took my Kindle with me when I went on vacation to Europe and was able to use WiFi at the hostel to download the next book in a series so that I'd have something to read on a train ride. And again, being that the Kindle is so small bringing it with me on a trip whereI only had one small carry on sized suitcase and a backpack (for a two week trip) was not a problem.
output: Swore I'd never have an e-reader
