Santa left me a brand new Kindle under the tree and I've barely put it down since!    Being a voracious - some may say obsessive! - reader since I was just a young tot, I got used to making room for yet another bookcase as my collection continued to grow.  I'd been eying the Kindle and other ebook readers as they've entered the market over the last few years but held off on buying one; I wasn't sure that the reading experience could be comparable.    That all changed several months ago when I saw someone reading a Kindle at a restaurant.  She gladly gave me a brief 'demo,' and once I spent a couple minutes trying it out I knew that I'd sure like to have one of my own.  Come Christmas morning - there it was.  My very own Kindle!    It was simple to get started from zero, so to speak.  Within a few minutes I'd downloaded a book I'd been wanting to read, and very quickly I added a number of 'classics' and other public domain books.  My Kindle's been within arm's reach ever since.    The long battery life has been the biggest surprise; even with heavy use I've only had to charge it once so far.  Another surprise came as I read and read and read - the eInk screen has been much easier on my eyes than a paper book.  I'm not as young as I used to be, and in recent years I've been distressed to find myself with eyestrain after a couple hours of reading a paper book.  That just isn't happening on the Kindle and I couldn't be happier about it!      I'll never give up my paper books.  Some books just won't 'translate' quite as well to the Kindle - my cookbooks, for example, with their full color photos, are definitely paper book only material.  The Kindle renders black & white photos quite well, but I wouldn't want to use it to read/view any book that's richly illustrated.    For my everyday reading habits, however, I'm absolutely thrilled with the Kindle.
output: Kindle is my new best friend

Instances.input:
Purchased to upgrade an old Compaq laptop from 512M to 1Gig of RAM. Wanted to upgrade a few old laptops so I can play around with various Linux distros without messing up my main computer.

Seemed to work well from the start, but noticed a few odd behaviors. Some Linux software seemed to work OK, others didn't even install correctly, though they should on a Pentium 4 with 1Gig of memory. Ran Memtest 86 that came with a Ubuntu Distro disk, and found repeatable consistent failures at a specific memory location. Swapped the two memory DIMMs around and got even more frequent consistent failures now at another memory location. Put the original 512G of RAM back in and it's passing the same tests with zero issues.

Went back to the Amazon site and requested to return this memory, which they agreed to immediately, printed the UPS return info, aranged for UPS pickup, and to refund the price.

Disappointed this didn't work, but glad Amazon was so cool about the return. Will try to do this again, perhaps with another vendor.
output: Great price, but persistent RAM test failures.  Returning for credit.

My poor desk! I have 3 external hard drives (4 now) not to mention speakers and head phones and other usb gadgets all about. In any case, I must say that this new My Book Elite is my new favorite of the hard drives at least. Much like others like it, it is a separate memory bank from your computer or laptop so that should your pc fry, you can still have your files safely tucked away.

As some of you know, your external hard drive can also fry, so it's good to have a backup of the backup (hence I have 4 laying about) but they're still very handy. Unlike others, however, the My Book does a few other nifty things its competition can't. For example, it comes with software that easily backs up your computer files without your having to hunt for you and even categorizes them by type (Pictures, music, movies, etc). It also allows password protection which makes my privacy needs happy, and has a view screen that lets you know how much memory is remaining and a title if you wish. For example, if you had 6 of these guys you could name one \\"Home Videos - 2001\\" or something so you don't have to put masking tape on it or something as a label. It also comes with a 3 year warranty which is much more than my other hard drives.

Overall - External Hard Drives are kind of tricky. They all run the risk of breaking and they all typically do the same thing. I was more impressed with the My Book than others because of its extra goodies and extended warranty, but it also came in a cheaper container - plastic, instead of some which are rock-hard metal. It's a little more expensive, too, but it also runs absolutely silent whereas some of the others are about as annoying as a snoring spouse. Personally, as long as you don't expect the guy to undergo some kind of mega damage that might crack it's plastic coat, I think it's worth the few extra bucks to have the software and extra warranty.

PS: If you are simply wondering whether or not you need an external hard drive - YOU DO. With laptops that burn out all the time, you need a safer spot to store your precious memories and files. I recommend this one more than any other, but if you don't like the look or whatever, still buy an external hard drive. They make your computer run so much faster and makes everything so much cleaner and nicer. They're like super massive usb drives!ve - YOU DO. With laptops that burn out all the time, you need a safer spot to store your precious memories and files. I recommend this one more than any other, but if you don't like the look or whatever, still buy an external hard drive. This model is about as simple as one can get. A box with a hard drive in it that stores
a multitude of docs, photos, recordings, or whatever you can digitize. One draw back
is that there is no backup software. You will have to drag and drop all your files initially
and subsequently whenever you update any of those files. Nothing is automatic.

In the box is the hard drive, a USB 2.0 cable, a AC adapter power cable and set-up
instructions. This drive is designed to turn on and off with your computer as well.
Set-up is very simple with plug-and-play technology: plug in to power strip, plug the
USB cable into a receptacle on your computer. Your computer will recognize your external
hard drive and assign it a letter. You are all set to drag and drop your precious files.

I have had this model for three years and If I had my druthers I would have spent the
extra money and gotten the WD hard drive with the automatic backup software. I
purchased one for a friend and set it up and it works like a dream. The only time it
took was to initialize the first backup onto the hard drive. After that it only adds what
it needs to do update the backup. Simple.

Some people would say, why not use the backup software that comes with your Windows 7
operating system. I did. I don't like it. It was not as simple to set up and maintain as the
WD HD; and not as efficient. Why? Because every time my Windows 7 backup program
backs up, it back up the whole computer hard drive, again. It is much simpler to buy
the external hard drive with the dedicated backup software.

After 3 years I have had absolutely no problems with this passive Western Digital hard
drive. So I can absolutely recommend buying it, but with one caveat; get the model with
the back up software. Your life will be easier and more secure with auto back up. Believe
me you will be glad you did. I am going to purchase another one real soon and it will
have the software included.ng to purchase another one real soon and it will
have the software included.
output: Good Storage: 1 TB Western Digital  USB External HD

I'm a computer technician and I've had to deal with a plethora of issues concerning computer based blu-ray set-ups. I was very familiar with many of the common problems people deal with when setting up a blu-ray for their machine, but I felt that my technical skills would help me surpass these issues. I knew that the firmware would need to be updated and that window did not support blu-ray playback and thus I would have to use a 3rd party software to actually watch blu-rays. After reading a few of the other reviews I saw that this unit came with software and I figured that although I am not a fan of cyberlink software, I could deal with it if it would work. As it turns out my specific set-up does not work with the provided Cyberlink software and like many other reviewers I would need to purchase the latest Cyberlink DVD 12 software for eighty bucks. To hell with that i said and decided to do some research on freeware that would allow one to view blu-rays without having to pay for the software. After exhaustive research I was able to configure my computer with the aid of 4 different software 1 to enable to codec, 1 to play it, 1 to remove copy protection, and 1 to configure all of the micro settings between the various programs. When all is said and done the blu-ray's play but will skip and sometimes audio/video will de-sync. Now considering the number of solutions required to get the blu-ray to play its difficult to say if the problem is software or Hardware(my machine was top of the line 4 years ago so it might not be powerful enough to decode a 1080p image properly).

To sum it up, the drive appears to be excellent. The problem is that it is more convenient to download video's from your favorite P2P site than it is to get a real blu-ray movie to play from your device.

I bought one of these for my Kindle Fire and when considering a Nexus7 tablet, being able to find an Executive cover was a must.
The fit is great.
The quality of the real leather, not that knock off plastic stuff, makes the cover very professional looking and appropriate in just about any setting.
The dual zippers are large enough to grip easily but not overly large to look like a charm is attached. Zip action is smooth and easy.
Removing the sleeve that holds the Nexus7 inside the case takes a few tries of practice to get Velcroed back in just the right spot but for me being used to one for my Fire it didn't take but 2 tries to find the sweet spot
The added weight doesn't seem as much as it did with the the Fire but the Fire is already heavy for its size by today's standards. The extra girth, though noticeable, doesn't prevent the tablet in its cover from fitting comfortably in my cargo or Kaki pants pockets
All in all, another excellent product by rooCASE.

I bought this flash drive within the same order that also contained a Silicon Power T06 flash drive of the same capacity. As both were intended for use in my wife's car's audio system, the read speed is immaterial. My primary factors included exposed profile height, apparent quality of construction, brand reputation, and warranty. SanDisk's product warranty is notably shorter than Silicon Power's warranty. I've had to use the warranty on a flash memory product TWICE (once with SanDisk, once with Transcend), so I am a believer in a good exercisable warranty program.

When writing the same 34 mp3 test files totaling 312.63 MB to both drives, the Silicon Power flash drive completed the task in 72% of the time that this SanDisk required. Okay, so this drive is a little slower during my unscientific test, but it really doesn't matter all that much to me. Once the content is loaded I won't monkey with it for quite some time.

Diminutive physical sizes of these flash drives can present some inconvenience when trying to remove them from a USB port, and I found that the SanDisk Cruzer Fit was more difficult to grasp than was the Silicon Power T06 flash drive. I did not attach a lanyard to either drive, but I know that is a viable option to aid removal.
output: Works well in car's audio system

I have had this for 8 days.  My first chrome experience was the LG Chromebase, which I love!  Bought that a month or so ago.  Was hooked.  Gave up my Windows laptop for this Chromebook.  I love it.  It is light, typing is great, normal... no issues with keyboard.  Feels high quality to me.  I don't quite like the exterior but I don't see it when I am working on the laptop.  My daughter thought that I had bought a Mac Book Air.   The screen is beautiful.  I guess the 1080 doesn't scale so there is tiny tiny font.  Was an adjustment after the BIG BEAUTIFUL screen on my Chromebase, but I am getting used to it.  I have read there are ways to increase the font but I haven't figured all of that out; it's legible though. I am good for now especially just zooming in.  Processing speed seems fine to me. I do everything on the net... banking, remote desktop to my work computer, email, you tube, etc. I am not a power user, so I never stream 10 things with 20 tabs open.  I might have 5 tabs max and maybe music, but rarely.  Works perfectly fine for my use.   Sound is nice.  Sounds better than the big LG Chromebase (but I still love the Chromebase.)  Has all the necessary ports.  Also it is LIGHT. My goodness.  My hubby just a bought an Windows 8 laptop that is beautiful (but heavy), but boy I can log on soooo much faster.  He hates when his laptop powers all the down.  This thing is quick!   Oh, it does get warm.  Not as bad as my old Windows Thinkpad, but it is certainly noticeable on my lap when I am wearing shorts. The warmth and the tiny font are why I am giving this 4 stars. It's not perfect.  But, it is good enough... certainly for the price!  My hubby's Windows 8 laptop cost more than 2x as much.  10/14/15 UPDATE.  Had this a year now.  Was great.  Loved it. But NO LONGER!!!!  Hate it.  The screen stopped working.  It see gray lines when I open it up.  Lasts for about 5 minutes, then it slowly fades to normal. I moved the few things off the hard drive that I had there incase I totally lose the screen which I expect to happen at any moment.  Also,  occasionally, the colors start to change, bright pink, fuzzy, shadows, etc.  It's annoying and weird.  I am currently searching for a new chrome laptop.  I see other reviews here with screen problems, so be careful.  I bought mine right after they came out so I could not have known about the screen issue.  Now YOU know. DO NOT BUY IT.  Getting only one year of use out of it is unacceptable.
output: SCREEN WENT BAD AFTER ONE YEAR. DO NOT BUY IT!!!

I have no idea how many \\"mice\\" I've owned since 1993 when I bought my first computer, but I'm guessing there must have been a dozen or more. That said, I've never had a mouse I \\"didn't like.\\" ...they always did what I expected them to. Not this one. I'll list the problems from \\"least annoying\\" to \\"most.\\"

1. I had read the other reviews about the \\"side buttons\\" being positioned in a way that made them easy to \\"bump\\" by accident. Well, the reviewers were right. I thought I'd get used to them but after over a month, I still bump them regularly.

2. This mouse does not track as well as any of the others I've owned. (Sure, the old \\"ball tracking\\" mice would get haired up and stop working from time to time, but that was easy enough to fix.) No \\"easy fix\\" with this thing. ...I even mounted the receiver about 8 inches away from it (level line of sight) with no luck. Sometimes it does OK, other times it takes a while for it to \\"pick up and go.\\"

3. The \\"left click\\" button simply doesn't work about 30 percent of the time. ...it requires two, three, four, or sometimes more attempts before it responds. (So, imagine you're trying to close a window, or open an email, or launch an application...it's frustrating beyond words to \\"click\\" and get nothing. \\"Click again, nothing, click again, nothing CLICK, nothing, CLICK!...you get the idea.)

4. When typing in an email, word document or online form, the cursor gets \\"stuck\\" wherever it was last (like it is \\"holding its place\\") and the only way to move the cursor somewhere else is to first move the pointer to the old position and \\"release it\\" with a left click.

5. The most annoying thing this mouse does is it \\"locks on\\" to whatever you've tried to click (say a hyperlink or maybe a shortcut icon...or an email, or a scroll bar) and it won't \\"let go\\" of it. You end up dragging things all over your screen or \\"scrolling\\" away from where you intended to be. (I'm sure this is an example of some \\"great new feature\\" that nobody asked for...I've tried turning \\"click lock\\" both ON and OFF repeatedly, but it hasn't worked. I don't know if the driver is messed up or what...I only know that, after a month, I'm going to \\"eat\\" the $30 I paid for this thing (waited too long to send back) and look for another mouse.sked for...I've tried turning \\"click lock\\" both ON and OFF repeatedly, but it hasn't worked. I don't know if the driver is messed up or what...I only know that, after a month, I'm going to \\"eat\\" the $30 I paid for this thing (waited too long to send back) and look for another mouse.
output: The first mouse I've ever had problems with

Instances.input:
I'm not sure what the negative reviews are all about. I have 3 netgear R6300 Wireless AC routers and I'm getting around 700 mbs to the computer with this USB adapter on it. I installed the lasted driver from the Netgear website and it's perfect. I will say, much like the Asus internal Wireless AC adapter I have on another computer, it's important to use the antenna extender if you want full speed. If you move the adapter around a little, the speed can change significantly. However, I should also say that when the adapter is plugged directly into the computer (as you might do on a laptop) it's still getting a least 300 mbs - and since my fastest Comcast speed is 55 mbs, that's more than enough for surfing the web or downloading video.

I use apple TV (I have 5) to stream from a server, and I can use this adapter to turn my iTunes (on this computer) into an apple TV.

Very pleased. I think the negative reviews are coming from people with old routers.
output: You guys know that you need an AC router to take full advantage right?

I connected a Sony DSR-45 DVcam videotape deck to my Lenovo T440 PC using this adapter and the laptop image immediately displayed a vertically rolling Venetian blind image superimposed over the normal PC desktop image. Then Windows7 displayed the following warning: \\"Power Surge On Hub Port - A USB device has exceeded the power limits of its hub port...\\". I had purchased two units, so I tested the 2nd copy as a precaution, with the same error.

Knowing that a vertically rolling Venetian blind effect is common to a ground loop between two AC powered video devices, I then tested the same scenario by connecting a Panasonic AG-DVX100B camcorder powered by battery to the Lenovo T440 PC, and got the same error message without the rolling Venetian blind visual image. Sony Vegas Pro video editing software did not recognize the connection to be compliant with IEEE-1394 firewire protocol. I cannot recommend this adapter unless the manufacturer can issue a software upload bug fix.
output: This device failed two bench tests using industry-standard video equipment

I started with a 2GB a few years ago, then over time bought two other 4GB units.  I just now ordered an 8GB unit because it's only $19.97 with prime shipping - cheaper than the 4GB right now which is still at $39.99 - go figure.  MAIN SELLING POINT:  If this drive were to drop out of your pocket or purse, etc. onto the sidewalk (scenarios), or be burglarized from your house, the finder/stealer cannot see your data even though he/she has physical possession of the drive.  They could reformat the drive and use it for other purposes but they would NOT get access to your data.  After 10 failed login attempts the drive is programmed to lock out any access attempts and MUST be reformatted.  (Kingston has a built-in process that forces you to choose a decently complex password so bad guy is never going to guess your password in 10 tries.)  These have worked for me on both Windows 7 and the dreaded Windows Vista (I got rid of my one Vista PC about 6 months ago).  I now have Windows 7 on all PCs.  I have turned off autorun for security reasons.  Instead, I trudge down through Windows Explorer to find the DTPrivacy launcher file on the drive in the file tree.  It works, it's just some extra effort that's all.  I only dock this drive when I need to.  If it's not plugged in, it's less likely to be hacked.  Common sense.  Some people ( a few) might run into issues with the E: drive being blocked or in use because Explorer shows the E: drive letter is taken up by the CD/DVD optical drive (which is common).  It is not hard to get around this.  Either try taking the disk out of the Optical drive unit or you could go to Computer, Manager, Disk Management (IF you know what you're doing, be careful here) and reassign the drive letter of the Optical drive to a "higher" letter to remove the conflict.  ADDENDUM / OBSERVATIONS: I find that while doing a file save of CHANGES to a 28Megabyte using Microsoft Word to the Kingston drive of a particular .RTF file with a lot of mixed tables, graphics, custom text formatting can be dog slow (like 45 seconds to 1 minute) .  The hourglass for that save process takes over the entire computer.  Fortunately, I don't have to save that file very often.  I'm just used to it.  Yes I have tons of space  remaining (over a Gigabyte or more) on my Kingston drive and hard drives - that's not what's causing this.  I'm not worried about it.  I figure it's encryption processing that is parsing the entire content of the file for changes.  Just a guess.  My Text file and PDF file saves go quickly.  Years ago, in the early XP days, I did own an earlier 1GB gray colored predecessor of this drive which - it was eventually discovered - had a security flaw intrinsic to the firmware of that particular earlier series.  Kingston was aware of the flaw and discontinued that series long ago.  Back then these were like (trying to remember) $80 dollars(?) for 1GB.  I have deliberately passed on Windows version 8.X up till now so can't speak to usability.  I wasn't up for the aggravation although I'm told it runs faster.  Microsoft has recently announced (April 2014) that they will finally "fix" Windows 8.1 usability issues in two separate passes.  When they will drop the shoe on part 2 of the fix, I don't know.  I just know it's been announced.  In the meantime, I'm happy with Windows 7.  While I would be disappointed if my current blue DataTraveler drives didn't work in the revised Windows 8.X (or even future Windows 9), it wouldn't break my heart.  To have simple, reliable, off-line, self-contained security ( I leave one of these at work in case my home had a catastrophe) is a small price to pay for the peace of mind these relatively cheap backups bring.  If worst comes to worst I'll purchase the new iteration and be out max $80 - $100 for 4 drives that work with the latest greatest.  I doubt if it will come to that but if it does, no big deal.  ____________________________  UPDATE  Jan 2016  - none of these have ever failed me.   They also work fine with Windows 10 - no hassles or needed updates.  Can still recommend highly.
output: I own 4 blue Data Traveler Vault Privacy USB drives in various sizes, they work great on Windows 7

Pros:  * large memory (4GB) is great for high-res gaming, especially if you use high-resolution texture mods (Skyrim, Mass Effect, Fallout etc.) as these require a lot of video memory.  same goes for multi-monitor setups, but I am only using one monitor (1920x1200).  * surprisingly quiet and cool - you can read reviews, but with the three large, lower-RPM fans, this card is pretty quiet and is one of the best performers in it's class for temperature.  which means lots of temp headroom for overclocking ;-)  * good build quality - thick circuit boards, solid feel, nice heatsinks, HEAVY  * one of the fastest single-GPU cards on the market today.  great if you ever play old games that don't work will with multi-card setups or multi-GPU cards.  Cons:  * it's big big big big big.  Because it takes up three expansion slots, if you are using two of these together, you need a really big motherboard that can fit them both properly and get them into the right slots.  Know your case.  Know your motherboard.  * it's long long long long long - In my Antec 1200 case (a large, 12-bay case) I can't fit a standard 3.5" HDD (non-solid-state drive) in front of the card (in a straight line with the card basically) and still use the Antec HDD cage with the built-in fan.  Just make SURE you have the space in your case, and room for the expansion slots on your motherboard, before you buy this card!!!  Measure!  It is long!  Details: The Antec 1200 comes with three, 3-drive cages, and then three empty slots for DVD drives.  Because there is a fan in front of the drives, the drives are moved closer to the video card than they would be if there was no fan.  So, I moved my DVD drive down from the top bay so that it is in-line with the card (since it is not as deep as a HDD), and moved the middle HDD cage to the top.  A bit of wiring to move around, but not the end of the world.  * Kind of expensive relative to the 4GB version of the GTX 670.  The 670 4GB (the one made by Gigabyte) is the same size, and has the same awesome three-fan cooling setup, but costs a lot less.  If you are OK with slightly lower performance of the 670 spec vs 680 spec, the 670 is a LOT better value.  2015 UPDATE: Retiring this card after years of faithful service, upgrading to a Gigabyte GTX 980 TI of similar design.  The three-fan setup rules them all.  Still highly recommended if you find one used.  Great card.
output: Solid single card, great for high-res gaming

Pros:
-cheap PCI 4 SATA-port card
-good quality & sturdy SATA ports (but not super sturdy) which is excellent for this price range
-installed out of the box under ubuntu 10.04 LTS without its crappy drivers
-Recognized my Hitachi 3TB HDD [[ASIN:B004E9SGPY Hitachi Deskstar 3.5 inch 3TB 7200RPM SATA III 6Gbps 64MB Cache Internal Hard Drive 0S03086]] (which really made my day) beside my other Hitachi 2TB
-SATA ports are designed with locks for cable latches (also compatible with non-latch SATA cables)

Cons:
-speed is kinda crappy (12 MiB/s) ... but I think it's cuz of my old Pentium 4 Motherboard (intel D850MV), my NIC 10/100 MiB/s & my bus speed...anyway, it's just a backup & a file server for 24/7 torrenting & LAN movies
-------------------
UPDATE : July 27, 2011
-------------------
It appeared that I was using a 100M NIC ethernet PCI card in my Pentium 4 which was the bottleneck, I believe it would've given me more boost transferring lots of Gigs if I had used a 1000M NIC in the first place.

Other:
-I'm using this card just to add SATA ports to my old PC since it only has the old PATA ports
-I had to install windows xp to flash it to the latest bios after installing the driver. The bios update can be found under the card properties in the windows hardware section or whatever it's called (2008 was the last time I used windows.... only Mac & Linux)
-You need to download the bios from Silicon Image website & choose either r###.bin(r indicates for RAID I guess) for RAID setup or b###.bin (b=base) for non-raid setup
-can't comment on RAID performance since I have a dedicated NAS for that [[ASIN:B002KOWDAE QNAP 4-Bay Desktop Network Attached Storage TS-419P]]
output: Recognized my 3TB Hitachi HDD in ubuntu 10.04 LTS

These are a great set of derive enclosures. Please be careful when reading the reviews since the product page allows you to choose from 5 different models. And those models may change over time. Yet all the same reviews show for all the models with the same value for the "This review is from" line above the review. Also, I've noticed that some of the specifications people are stating in their reviews completely contradict the information in the product description and from the manufacturers website. This is likely due to newer models coming out since they did their review. For example, at the time I am wiring this, the most useful review states as a con that it "doesn't fit drives with > 9.5mm height". Well... that's only true for the models that specific say "fits drive up 9.5mm" or "fits drive up to 7mm". It's certainly not true for the model that "fits drives up to 12.5mm". So that review is for a very specific review. The same review also lists a lack of SATA-III (6GB) as a con. Yet when I went to the manufacture's site, all the drives list SATA I, II, and III support. That review is a year old at this time, so SATA III support may have been added (and the model number may or may not have changed) since that person wrote the review.

I strongly recommend that potential buyers rely on the product specifications from the description and from the manufacturers website rather than those in the reviews to ensure accurate and up to date information. After you chose the size and interface options, scroll down to the Product Details and take a look at the Item model number and then visit the manufacture's website (the address is in their name) to get up to date product specifications. At the time of this review (Sept 2014) the following options are available:
USB 3.0 With UASP
up to 7mm S2510BPU337 Amazon ASIN: B00JQJURMM
up to 9.5mm S2510BMU33 Amazon ASIN: B00E1JAB3M
up to 12.5mm S2510SM12U33 Amazon ASIN: B00GYR75GK
USB 3.0
up to 9.5mm SAT2510BU32 Amazon ASIN: B007019HJW
up to 12.5mm SAT2510B12U3 Amazon ASIN: B005G2JFFI

I personally purchased the model S2510SM12U33 - 12.5mm USB 3.0 With UASP. My review will focus on that enclosure, but I will also talk about all the enclosures in general. I'll be sure to highlight when talking about a feature specific to the model I purchased.

When choosing one of these enclosures, the first choice is whether to get one of the USB 3.0 or the USB3.0 with UASP enclosures. In general, I'd recommend people purchase one of the the UASP (USB Attached SCSI (UAS) Protocol). Even if your control USB 3.0 does not have UASP support or your OS does not support it, the enclosure will still work as a standard USB 3.0 enclosure (which is backwards compatible with USB 2 but at a reduced speed.) But you will have a more future proof enclosure for when you do get a UASP compatible system (or use if you use the portable drive with one "out on the road"). UASP can provide a significant improvement in read/write speeds while reducing CPU utilization. And it does not add much to the cost of the enclosure.

The next choice is maximum height of the drive. However, I personally recommend you look at the other features between the differnt enclosures since the difference is not merely in the maximum drive height. For example, the 12.5mm w/UASP (S2510SM12U33) that I bought is an all aluminum enclosure that uses the ASMedia 1053E chipset where as the 9.5mm w/UASP (S2510BMU33) is an Aluminum & Plastic enclosure that uses the ASMedia 1053 (rather than the 1053E) chipset. And the smallest of the three, the 7mm w/UASP (S2510BPU337) is an all plastic case (also with the ASMedia 1053 chipset).

The smaller 7m (S2510BPU337) is also a tool-less installation design. While some might consider that a plus, I see it as a negative. The reason being is the tool-less design relies on afoam pad to be attached to the end of the drive with sticky tape for installation. This limits the ability to swap drives out in the future. Also I just like the security that my hard drive is security attached in the case. I do not consider having to tighten 6 to 8 small screws a major hassle. It literally took me 3 minutes to install my drive and assembly the case. Thus, I do not think it is worth sacrificing security, durability, and (long term) re-usability in order to save a minute or two in installation.

Another factor to look at is the placement of the led power and activity light. For example, on the 9.5mm w/UASP (S2510BMU33) drive, the LED is on the same end that the cable attaches. This assumes you are using a USB port on the front of your PC and thus both the cable port and the LED will point towards you when you place the enclosure on the top of your PC. However, if like me, you use a cable attached to the rear of your PC, this would make seeing the LED difficult. Granted you do not need to look at it often. But when you do, it's nice to be able to just glance at it. For the 12.5mm w/UASP (S2510SM12U33) model that I purchased, it is on the top of the case.

Here's how I selected the model I ended up getting: I knew I wanted UASP support, so that left me with 3 of the 5 options. I ruled out the 7mm since it was tool-less installation for the reasons I described above. Plus, why limit to such a small drive. An extra 9mm in overall enclosure height is not a big deal. I liked that the 12.5mm was all aluminum, that it had the LED on top, that it used the slightly better 1053E chipset, it gave me the space to hold a 12.5 mm drive if I ever needed to, and as a bonus, it has an external DC power connector. All of these enclosures will get enough power via the USB 3 channel. But having the power connector is a nice "just in case" bonus. (Sometimes you get a system that either does not deliver the power is should over the USB bus, orits over taxed with a million things plugged into it.)

I've used a number of different drive enclosures over the years. (I carry a portable drive between home and work.) This is my first StarTech enclosure. But I've used a number of StarTech add-on cards (and cables) over the years and have always been happy with their products. When looking for a USB 3.0 enclosure, I decided I wanted to get one with UASP. Many of the other USB 3.0 enclosures out there by other manufacturers do not have the UASP support. And I also wanted one of decent quality. There are a lot of portable drive enclosures out there. You'll see many are aimed at the magic ten, fifteen or twenty dollar price points. But to hit that, something has to give. I've always found the good 2.5" portable enclosures are in the twenty-five to thirty-five dollar range. These enclosures hit that tier and are of nice quality. I am very happy with the build quality and performance of the enclosure I got.

I used mine to hold a brand new 1TB Samsung 850 Pro SSD drive. It fit in to the case without any hassles. (As I said, total install was under 3 minutes). Everything worked fine the first time I connected it, and has every time since. Overall, you can't go wrong with one of these StarTech enclosures, especially the 12.5 mm w/UASP (S2510SM12U33) model.
output: A great set of enclosures. Read reviews with some caution (for reasons I explain).

This is my second Compaq in the past two years. I was very pleased with my other one, but I downloaded too much on it, which makes it my fault for breaking it. I had to get another computer for school, so after much search I came upon this one.
I've only had this computer for a week, but I have been very pleased with it. I think the only problem with it is Windows XP, which doesn't include Microsoft Word, Powerpoint, Excel, etc. I've used it as a DVD player and I've attempted to burn a CD with it too.
It has a built in wireless card, so access to the internet at home and at my middle school is very easy and without cables. The large 60GB hard drive is wonderful to have and the multiple USB ports are helpful. The mouse pad can be turned on and off and it also has a scroll bar on the mouse pad. I haven't had any problems with the amount of sound it makes, for it only is loud on the first few seconds of start up. It also stays fairly cool for it has quite a few vents on it.
There are a few problems though. This is a thicker computer then most new ones, which is because it has a Floppy Disk drive, which most newer laptops don't have. Also, it is quite heavy, heavier then my older 1212CL model. I also very much dislike Windows XP. I even set my laptop's toolbar and such back to the basic windows style. I'd much rather have Windows ME, like my other computer.
Overall this is a great computer for a decent price. I recommend getting an extended warrenty on it though. Even with HP around, Compaq still isn't the best computer on the market.

I've had this bluetooth radio for about a year now, and it's really worked just like it's supposed to. The software that comes with it fights a little with Windows XP, if you have all of the XP patches (including SP2)... I ended up uninstalling the software that came with it, because XP wouldn't relenquish control. No matter, XP controls the device great, and it's easy enough to set up new devices.

I use it with my phone and a few other trinkets that pass across my desk, and the bluetooth technology is still pretty inconsistent. There are too many standards and too many gateways that can be implemented per device (or not). Example, the audio gateway would be great for my phone, and would allow me use my headphones and mic for phone calls--except that the audio gateway service doesn't exist on my phone, so that's no joy.

Keep in mind that every device manufacturer can implement any one of many (nearly 100) bluetooth services, or they can devise their own and then release their own hardware to support it. This technology needs more standardization and that 'gotcha' can cause frustration for many people unfamiliar with the standard.
output: The device gets 5 stars... but the technology doesn't

I purchased an iPad about a month ago and instantly fell in love with it! I found myself spending lots of time with it on my lap propped on a throw pillow trying to play games and read books and it was just awkward so I decided I needed some sort of stand. I did very thorough research for an iPad stand before making a purchase. (It seems many people have purchased several different stands because they end up being poor quality, not what they thought it was and or it breaks. I literally read hundreds of reviews about dozens of stands and decided on this one because of the great reviews. It may seem pricey but it is well made and works perfectly. I love that I can prop my iPad horizontally or vertically. The iPad does not lock into place (I don't jump up from sitting position without holding in anyway) but after reading reviews for ones that did, I determined that those seem poorly made and the locking mechanisms were breaking. Since it doesn't have clips it is more versatile for other e-readers. My son has a kindle and I borrow that to take advantage of Prime's free monthly books.
If you are looking for a way to prop your iPad (or kindle/nook/etc) on your lap while being a couch potato or lounging in bed this is perfect for that! You can adjust to the perfect angle and relax without getting cramps in your hands while holding it! (My husband is jealous and wants one too so I will be ordering a second one soon!) I'm actually thinking these would make excellent gift ideas for my extended family. (Now I'm off to mark the reviews about this as helpful!)
output: EXACTLY what I was looking for!

In this review: an in depth comparison of Klipsch Pro Media 2.1 THX, Logitech Z-2300 THX, Bose Soundock, Bose Companion 3's, Bose Companion 5's and Altec Lansing t-612

Thank you for taking the time to read this. I'd like to offer a review somewhat different than what you've read before. It's a long one so if you're looking for something quick, you may want to stop here. Otherwise hopefully you'll enjoy the perspective. My thanks go out to those who let us know who you are and what you do in your review, and how you use the system, it really makes a difference. It's important to know the story behind why someone is buying something and what they are looking to do, otherwise you get mismatched needs and solutions. My story begins during the first month of 2008, when I got myself into a bit of a speaker craze while searching for a sound solution for every room of my house. Three years ago I put my life's music collection in digital format on iTunes to the tune of over 5000 songs with perhaps the widest array of music than anyone else I know: Jazz, Hip-hop, R&B, trip hop, electronica, techno, country, audio books, Tony Robbins, metal, rock, dub, enigma type stuff, lounge, new-aje, world music, caribbean, Latin and on the list goes. So, when I say I've tested these speakers over a wide variety of music, you can take my word for it.

My demographic: Male, business owner (custom Italian leather journals, guest books and photo albums: see epica . com ) and hip-hop dancer choreographer, 30 years old, Southern California. Creative, very into pleasing the senses.

After growing up with stereo systems that catered to more bass than clarity, my initial goal was to discover what would be the most clear, best, space filling rich sound I could in each room of the house while still being incredibly aesthetically pleasing and unobtrusive at the best price. I wanted to turn up the volume and be amazed at what I heard without any distortion and I wanted to be thrilled at the lowest volumes as well. I wanted to feel like I was there, to have a music experience every time I turned something on. The best price part went out the door rather quickly.

So here's what I did: Apple sells a device called an Airport Express that among other things such as being a wireless router, also allows you to stream iTunes music to it wirelessly. All you have to do is plug in a stereo mini plug to one end and an audio source to another. Give it a name like living room and it appears in iTunes. you can have several of these devices all over the house. In the past I have always hooked up big stereos or shelf systems to it for sound but now in the age of tiny computer speakers and iPod doc systems, I've realized you can connect anything to it and have taken the experience to a whole new level. There are now 4 airport expresses in the house in different rooms along with an apple TV which also features this Airtunes feature in the living room, bedroom, second bedroom, kitchen and hallway... yes the hallway.

After having spent hours in the Apple Store and Best Buy listening to different sound docks and speakers with my iPhone and collection of music, I just decided to purchase and used every single unit that caught my interest with the decision that those which didn't give me everything I was looking for, I'd just return. (The manufacturers must love me.) Because what can you really tell about a speaker or sound system in a 30,000 foot warehouse with sound and people all around you? Are you kidding? Nothing. You've really got to setup these systems in your environment.

It's also important that you test your purchase in different places and positions all throughout your house. You won't believe the difference in sound from having say, a SounDock in your bathroom vs. a bedroom. Move the subwoofer around, adjust the bass on it, move the speakers, be creative. you'll surprise yourself.

Finally, a word about Bose. Of all the sound companies that I read reviews for, and I read about 400 before making a purchase, I have never seen such a contrasting fan base. You've got people who detest anything Bose and people who would buy it without listening to anything else. For the record I am neither of these people. I have owned Bose products in the past and enjoyed them as I have with other companies but was not biased towards or against them prior to purchase.

The Systems:

The Klipsch Prop-Media 2.1 speakers were my purchase. I was attracted to what I knew about the Brand, the subwoofer control on the actual satellite speaker and the $150 price point. I got them home and aesthetically I was just never really attracted to the speaker. My place has a very Asian-Zen and modern feel and these just kind of stood out in the wrong way wherever I placed them. But we're talking about sound so I looked past that. It's got a pretty large subwoofer, and the satellites where small enough to go anywhere. Klipsch does a great job with their horn tweeters and it really let's the highs soar. I tried them in my home office and bedroom for a week before I returned them. Why?
I loved that they were THX, which means there was no hissing whatsoever and they were dead quiet when music was shut off. I was also pleased and could not believe the power. These speakers have so much gain and get so loud, that I don't think full volume would even be tolerable to the human ear. But that was the thing. They seemed to distort at the higher volumes I tend to enjoy and didn't seem to fill a room at low volumes. The subwoofer is recommended to be set at 8 o'clock (very low) and if you adjust that any higher the bass is quite over powering. The sound coming from the Klipsch speakers was not a bad or poor sound, it was great, it was ridiculously powerful but it just wasn't the best sound I had heard for music. They ultimately went back to the store, and I give them a 4 star rating, but I'd be open to trying them in again in a different setting. I think I found them to be to cumbersome as well.

To their credit, RoomGroove wireless for $300, is their latest version of what I am doing with the airport express where you can link multiple room grooves up and they'll wireless send sound to each other. Points to them for finally getting something like this on the market.

Logitech Z-2300 THX: WOW. I was a little biased at first because I thought, Logitech? Really? The people who shine at making wireless mice and keyboards? How can they compare to these other big sound companies? What can they possibly bring to the table? Five stars no question. Here I had nothing to go on other than the $150 price point. I brought them home and unpacked. Ok, the subwoofer with this speaker set is not for the faint of heart. It is absolutely enormous and well suited for a larger office or larger room. It's got two attractive enough (without the grills) aluminum speakers, and a similar wired remote to the Bose only this has the subwoofer control on it (fortunately) and a headphone jack. (no external auxiliary mini plug)

Where to begin. This system has started off in and remains to this day in my office. At low volumes it is rich, deep, clear, and not overpowering in any respect. The music soars no matter what you're listening to. It's an absolute pleasure to sit before these speakers and I should start leaving them playing some sort of music more often because it really really sounds tremendous. And that's only the beginning.

Once the staff goes home and I can crank these up, every wall in the building shakes. The other bathrooms sound as though there is an earthquake and we should evacuate the building. I know it sounds like I'm a big bass person but this is the least of my desires. The clarity, much like the companion 5's just keeps getting richer and richer as you turn the volume up. Artist's vocals scream out at you and this system is the loudest of any I have heard. Interestingly it's also the most tolerable at high volume that I have heard as well.

I love the fact that it's got RCA jacks for speaker cables which allow you to easily extend them if you want them more than a few inches apart or want to place the subwoofer farther away than right at your feet. I love the power and clarity of these speakers, I love that the remote has the bass on the module and you don't have to adjust it behind the subwoofer. Five golden stars are easily awarded. Go Logitech.

Altec Lansing T-612 and Bose SounDock Portable:
Having tested the Harmon Kardon Sound Sticks, JBL On Stage, Klipsch iGroove, the Zeppelin monster, iHome, logitech pure fi and many others, these are the two I wound up bringing home.

Technology is great. We give birth to new ideas which create new ways we listen to music like iPods and iTunes, and that stimulates thought to a new level and we create devices made especially just for these things like the wide array of docking stations, something we had no need for in the past, and then we give birth to new ideas again and say wouldn't it be great to have our music collection on our phone and eliminate devices, and that get's created, and one company wins out over all the others and soon that creates a new problem: cell phone interference and shielding and that gives birth to the first of a new line of products: the iPhone safe Altec T-612. The first docking station to not be affected by sound interference from cell phones.

It worked well. I give it 5 stars for innovation, sound, it's own bass and treble controls on the unit that can be controlled by the remote control, size and a pretty unique look. (Which I am personally not attracted to) This purchase lasted 24 hours before it was returned. It was going to be used as a hallway speaker and so probably would not get much use out of the iPod Dock. It goes for $200 which seems reasonable. Ultimately though it did not have the fullness and richness, or spaciousness that the Bose did, and the bass cracked on several songs. This is perfect for a teen, or college person or someone who just listens to music here and threre at reasonable volumes in the kitchen or around the house.

Bose SounDock Portable. FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS, and no sale or special pricing. Certainly you have to have a unique perspective on money to purchase one of these for yourself. One now resides in my bedroom and another in the hallway so certainly I'll share mine. Are there alternatives on the market that you will be happy with? Absolutely. $400 is a lot of money to spend on a device like this. Or is it? I sell a $10,000 journal on the Epica website, I have seen $12,000 pens, $400,000 automobiles, $200 for torn up jeans (and that's just a normal brand), $12 to see a movie, $50 for a tank of gas, $4000 for a high end washer and dryer... look at the world we live in. Certainly dollar for dollar you are not paying for the product itself or the metal, cotton or components, EVER, but the value it brings to you. The features and luxuries and benefits it brings. The feeling. And that always has a price.

How many times have you shopped for the best deal on something, bought it, and then later wished you had purchased the better version, or gotten the special optional features, or wish you had just splurged after the fact. How many times have you not been able to do it like when you purchase a car? I have just gotten myself used to two things. One: happiness comes from your thoughts and your ability to keep your mind and focus on things that please you, not from objects you buy, and two, the fact that if contrast has caused me to give birth to a desire for wanting something, and I think in the obtaining of it I will be more pleased in owning it than the less expensive version, I am going to buy the one that brings me the most pleasure and gives me personally, the best feeling.

Need, purpose, design, size and functionality all coalesced with the SounDock and so I spent 200 more dollars after I returned the Lansing for something that would be kept in my hallway which pointed into the bathroom. But it was more discreet, it had a revolving iPod dock that I could hide from view when not using it, a remote control that let me change my playlists (that most remotes do not do), a look that was much more attractive and streamline, and a sound that was just richer and fuller.

And while it pains me immensely to know that I took the two-hundred heart pounding watts of Klipsch out of my bedroom, the amazing, clear, spacious and dynamic sound of the Bose Companion 3s out of my bedroom and now have replaced those with another SounDock, portable, it certainly does create magic in the bedroom. Aside from two lamps, it is the ONLY other wire in the room. It's small, and doubles as my alarm clock. I LOVE the fact that I can wake up to any song or play list in the world. using an iPod (I am very put off by Apple's decision to not have a snooze button on iPod alarm, while it is on the iPhone, however on the iPhone you can only wake up to a ringtone! Silly) I love how it fills a room and how if you're not in the room you hear it loud and clear and would have no idea something so small is producing all that sound.

I have really come to appreciate Bose. They create the best sound they can possibly engineer by pouring 100% of their profits back into research and deliver the best product they can that generally takes years to release. They think their sound sounds best flat, with no adjustment. That's what the EQ is for on the iPod or iTunes or whatever source you're using. They realize you shouldn't have to tweak all the treble and bass if the sound is just amazing to begin with. It's all about the feeling you get when you listen to it. The SounDock does not sound as good as a system like the Companion 3's or any other subwoofer driven device but you have to look at it's purpose and size.

SounDock gets five stars for listening to customer requests and making their successful SounDock portable even better by adding the aux in port so I can hear music wirelessly, a great remote with lots of functionality, discreet touch volume buttons, a hideaway revolving dock door to make it look even cleaner than it already does, a great room filling sound, a battery that lasts, a slimmer design, a power cord that wraps around the transformer and an overall sound that makes you feel very good when listening to it. Try placing one of these things in your kitchen, hall, bathroom, closet or smaller room and listen to the rumble and sound. Amazing.

Bose Companion 3's: When I first set these up in my office I was absolutely amazed by the quality and quantity of sound coming out of these speakers. They are gorgeous, discrete and fit the bill for big sound. I was impressed by the fact that I could turn them up to full volume, with any kind of music and here no distortion of any kind. That one fact is so rare, that made them a winner for me right there. When listening to Diana Krall, I felt as though her lips where inches from my ear as she sang only to me. These speakers really sing out.
For some reason when I tried watching movies on them, the volume decreased significantly and so even at full blast the sound was not that loud. Over time these speakers have moved from office to bedroom to ultimately being returned to the store but not because I was dissatisfied. I kept these things in my closet for 3 weeks because I didn't want to return them, I wanted to find a use for them or somewhere to enjoy them. They went back because I didn't want 5 cords in my bedroom and a subwoofer at the foot of my bed.

Like the companion 5's, I like the puck volume control (would be nice if it was wireless, wouldn't it? Especially if everything else on your desk is). It's very sensitive and feels good to touch. One gentle tap and sound is muted, another and it comes back on. It's also nice to be able to increase or decrease the bass that pours out of these units on the back of the subwoofer by virtually a full 360 degrees. I am also pleased with the RCA jacks used to connect each speaker. Initially I was put off and wondered why they did it but when I realized how EFFORTLESS (one of my favorite words) it was to extend the speaker cable, i.e. just plug in another video cable, I was thrilled. Five stars to the Companion 3s

Bose Companion 5's: It's funny how when you don't know what you're missing, you don't miss it. I tell people that in my business that when you buy this $185 journal and you haven't seen the $265 version, you think you're in heaven. It's perfection. Then you see the top of the line and you just can't imagine it gets any better. The Companion 5's are nearly triple the size of the Companion 3's (Yet still rather small and attractive), look absolutely gorgeous next to my iMac, have the same puck with mute, headphones, volume up and down and auxiliary input just like the Companion 3's (which will play something at simultaneously as what you have going on your computer).

BUT there are two major differences in these speakers vs anything else I have heard, ever. One is it connects to your USB port, not your stereo mini plug in port which requires 2 minutes of configuring, and two, the sound that comes out of these speakers is the most delicious, exquisite, full, wide, spacious, rich, detailed sound I have EVER heard come out of speakers in this class. Anyone I have shared them with leaves with their jaw on the floor. As I turn up the volume we just stare at the computer and say WOW. It just sucks you in. Where before I did not enjoy spending time in front of the computer for very long, I can literally spend hours in front of this one or in the room where the Companion 5's are playing. The sound is that unbelievable. The cables as of this writing are proprietary and cannot be extended, however for the `surround effect' it's not recommended that you extend them anyway.

I enjoy barely audible volume levels in the morning but come nighttime, I love to crank up the sound and speakers can take it at a volume so loud you can only take it for a short period. It's as though with each increment you raise the volume, you experience a new dimension to sound. The Bose Companion 5's for this purpose get 5 stars, 10 if I could, for looks, size and for a sound like no other.

Finally, don't be led astray by the Bose advertising. These speakers are marketed towards people who like to watch movies in front of their computer, something that, after spending all day in front of a computer, is the last thing I want to do. I've tried it and yes it's a great experience but if you never watch a video clip with these speakers it will still be the best investment you make for music and any other sound that comes out of them. The Bose experts will also tell you that these speakers should not be more than 24 inches apart because they are specifically engineered for you to sit right in front of them. When I heard that I also thought the sound quality would decrease if I stepped away, or perhaps it wouldn't fill a room the way I want. Not the case. Inches away or across the room, I cannot say enough about this virtual surround sound speaker.

So hopefully that gives you a little more insight into what these speakers can do for you, how they can be used, what I was looking for in particular and what the actual experience was. If you made it this far, your a trooper. I hope you found the review useful and if you wanted to contact me with questions we actually sell on the Amazon site. Just do a search for Epica journal and you can write in. Thanks! - Written over three hours near Los Angeles in the company of Bose Companion 5's.ced with the SounDock and so I spent 200 more dollars after I returned the Lansing for something that would be kept in my hallway which pointed into the bathroom. But it was more discreet, it had a revolving iPod dock that I could hide from view when not using it, a remote control that let me change my playlists (that most remotes do not do), a look that was much more attractive and streamline, and a sound that was just richer and fuller. And while it pains me immensely to know that I took the two-hundred heart pounding watts of Klipsch out of my bedroom, the amazing, clear, spacious and dynamic sound of the Bose Companion 3s out of my bedroom and now have replaced those with another SounDock, portable, it certainly does create magic in the bedroom. Aside from two lamps, it is the ONLY other wire in the room. It's small, and doubles as my alarm clock. Having dealt with many RMA's over the years, I'm amazed how unresponsive this vendor is.  I will never use any PNY product for home or work.

Instances.input: I have been using this drive for about 5 weeks now. I bought it for backups of my PC. After reading some of the reviews I was a little hesitant to get it, but it seemed overall to be the best drive available.  My initial backup was rather disappointing.  It took 24 hours to backup 29G/163K files.  I was starting to think about returning it. Then, the admin control panel for the drive indicated there was a driver update available.    After getting the driver update things have been much better.  That same backup now takes about an hour, using the included software (Genie Backup Manager Pro). I am not using file compression because I want to be able to use the standard explorer to get any needed files when the time comes. I am running a 100M Ethernet and have seen the backup use 90+% of the net capacity while transfering files. The PC is a new i7 processor, so it is quick.  There are lull periods during the backup; I assume while the software is determining what to backup next.    My only complaint is with the backup software. Comparing it with the software that came with my older backup drive; it is harder to find a backed-up file if I need to. I have not tried the restore features of Genie Backup Manager; so, this complaint may be addressed there.  My older backup drive's software organized the backup in latest, 2nd oldest, and so on directories so it was easy to find the first, second and 3rd oldest version of a specific file.  Genie Backup Pro just makes a copy, organized by the date of the backup. So, if I want something that I changed a while ago, I have to search all the backups until I find it.  Someday, I may try the restore capabilities of the software and see how they handle this.  For now, it is not a priority.

I bought three of these headsets for roughly $10 dollars each. One was for my girlfriend, one for my home PC and one for my work laptop. After four weeks, only one pair still works. The microphone on one stopped working. I'm thinking the wire connecting the mic to the earpiece got cut one of the times I had to push the earpiece back together. The earpieces came apart frequently.     The other one snapped in my computer bag and one earpiece was left dangling. That was kinda' my fault but I'm guessing more sturdily constructed earphones might've held up. If you'll follow my advice, you'll get a headset with a case.    If you're debating it, spend $30 dollars more and get a good wireless headset. You won't miss the dangling cord for one thing and you won't be tethered to your computer whenever you have to dial out from your PC. I got a pair from ASUS for $50 bucks and I'm thrilled so far. The set comes with a nice case too so I don't sweat putting them in my laptop bag.
USB 3.0 is a jump for the Dell Latitude that i am using. Unable to utilize this feature. Requires a different docking station. Would like to have had the dual option of USB 2.0 and 3.0.
DEFECTIVE
I had to return this item. It did not fit in my Kindle Fire. It was not what I expected at all from Amazon.

Works perfectly for my purpose. I needed this to set up dual monitors with my laptop and docking station at work.  The docking station only has one VGA port, so I used this adapter to plug the VGA cable from one of my monitors to the display port. It's worth mentioning that the brightness is slightly off on the monitor I used this adapter to connect.  Just a little bit more dim than the one connected to the VGA port in the dock, but it's not noticeable enough to be annoying or affect my work.

I've had several Asus computers before. I've always loved them. It seems the quality of materials for has gone down significantly since my last purchase a few years ago. The keyboard has poor response, and I often find myself going back to correct missing letters that I have apparently not hit hard enough. The keys also "bubble" up in the center of the top two rows, it's unsightly and they make an obnoxious noise when I have to it them.

Other than those issues, and maybe the fact that Windows 8 is a pain to figure out, I like this computer. It does what I need it to.

Acer had made a great laptop with a great price tag with what it brings to the table. Starting with the i5 processor at 2.6 Ghz is more than I could have asked for at the price point. Coupled with an outstanding, new laptop graphics card in the 730m can handle most/all games on medium to high settings at a decent fps(60). Games such as Battlefield 3 will not even be at 60 at the low/medium settings, but that is to be expected; this is not a gaming laptop. I know that this sounds like a advertisement for the product, but the laptop exceeded my expectations immensely, and you will find if you read on.

Along the the great CPU and GPU comes a whopping 8GB of RAM, which is more than the average consumer will need, and more than I need for gaming. A 750GB HDD can store all your music, videos, movies, and anything else you desire without running out of room. Speaking of not running out of room, this laptop packs a 17 inch screen! The brightness is well scaled and the colors are well saturated, albeit a touch washed out. Moving on from the specs, the computer itself does not work up a heat at all, even when gaming. Compared to my previous laptop, a 2011 Macbook Pro, this is the North Pole. The keyboard is better than a Macbook Pro, in my opinion. It gives you a lot more room to type, and includes an numbered keypad. The laptop is also very lightweight, which surprised me due to its large frame. The black finish and top cover are very stylish, with a simple \\"acer\\" brand on the top.

Now, on to the cons. The battery life definitely leaves something to be desired,it will barely last 2 hours unplugged. This isn't a problem for me however, as I keep mine plugged in 90% of the time. I imagine this wont be much of a con for other users either, as this laptop is not designed with portability in mind.
The 2nd problem that I have encountered is the laptop sometimes fails to charge when launching a game.This has happened once to me. It switches from chargingto not charging without me doing anything, and the brightness flickers due to the apparent unplugging and plugging in of the laptop. However, this can be solved with a simple restart, but I wanted to put this in my review.

No other laptop that I have owned has delivered these specs at under $1000, while performing this well with a 17inch screen. I would have given this 5 stars if the battery life had been improved, but some nitpicks can be expected with a sub-$800 laptop. This is a all around beast of a laptop that can be bought on a budget.
output: Amazing laptop, best I have ever owned.

There are a lot of good things about this unit- good price with good feature set.  I use this as a second monitor- it means that my \\"desktop\\" on Windows Vista is spread out over two monitors, giving me a lot of screen.  I do most of my computer work on the other monitor so that if I want to I can switch this one to HD TV via my cable tuner.      That all works more or less, but a big problem is that when my two monitors are coming out of screen saver mode, the other monitor comes out almost immediately and this T240HD takes up to a minute.  That's a really long time to wait.  If it was my primary monitor or only monitor on my computer that would be a huge problem.  I'm using the DVI connector and a digital connection to my video card.  I don't know if the problem also exists in VGA mode as I haven't bothered to try that.    The screen also though very nice doesn't have as much viewing angle as my other monitor.  Probably a good compromise to save on manufacturing cost- this unit is cheap for what it does.  Still, when I buy my next monitor some day, I won't buy one of these due to that big fat delay.
output: Nice enough TV, big delay as monitor

I bought the \\"Arkon IPM2CF-CM117 Extendable Windshield Car Mount for iPad 2\\" about 10 days ago to use the iPad's GPS function. Oddly, at that time there were a number of reviews that have since disappeared. They were largely quite positive.

I got this for an iPad 3 because the mount extension length for the newest iPad was unclear. The 0.8mm additional thickness of the iPad 3 may make the fit a little tighter, but it's not a problem.

I've used it in a 2004 Ford Ranger and a 2003 VW Jetta. I had to experiment a bit to get a good position in the Jetta's close quarters, but finally I placed it so the display is in front of the vents above the radio. When the AC is on, the display can be moved out to allow air movement. It is closer to the steering wheel, but not too close for comfort. When the AC is off, the display is snug against the vents and easy to see. It fit well in the Ranger with little experimentation.

Initially I had a problem with the display vibrating. Tightening 4 set screws on the extension resolved the issue.

The mount seems to be made with quality materials, suitable for the application. The suction cup is very good, and I've had to carefully insert a thin knife blade to release the vacuum. The instructions warn about breaking the glass.

Bottom line: it works well and I'd buy it again.
output: Works for the New iPad 3, too

Music from these little speakers sounds REALLY good. I got them in the blue color and my son loves them The sound that comes from the speakers in his laptop is pretty flat, so connecting these has made such a big difference. He listens to music and watches videos on his laptop all the time, so he was thrilled when I hooked these up so he could have better audio. Everything sounds so much clearer and music played from them sounds tons better.

They were really easy to set up. The cables come already connected to the speakers. So all you have to do is plug in the USB cable to the computer (powers the speakers), then plug the auxiliary cable into the earphone jack on the computer (when using with a laptop). Corded speakers like this are especially handy for young users like my son, because he doesn't need to go into the computer's control panel to set it up (which he would if they were cordless/Bluetooth). Computers automatically switch to playing the audio through the earphone jack when they sense something has been connected. So as soon as he plugs the cable in, his laptop automatically starts playing the audio through them. No need to change the computer's speaker settings in the control panel. With a desktop, they plug in on the port in the back designated for use with speakers.

These speakers sound even better than I had hoped for. And their small size and very simple set up makes them perfect for using with a laptop. There is a volume nob on the back of one of the speakers, so you can turn it one way or the other to adjust the volume. The cables have plenty of length to them, so they can be set up on a desk and spread apart quite a bit.They come in a bunch of fun colors too. The blue us a great looking shiny royal blue. My son loves!

Sample provided for review.
output: Perfect for my 13 year old to use with his laptop

Also, it came with just enough thermal paste to apply.  I personally wanted to use a little more, but i may have been a bit over zealous, and the amount that is included is just enough.    It runs Very quiet, and keeps my CPU running quite cool, enough to overclock (although, i have a performance cooling case, on top of this fan.) and the blue LED is pretty omnious.    my ONLY Gripe, would have to be the adjustable fan speed attachment. I originally installed it, only to remove it minutes later.  I thought it would be unique to have a little turn knob to control the fan speed, but it prevents my BIOS and any of my third party programs from effecting the fan speed, which isnt a serious issue, but its very anoyying that my BIOS freak out evey boot up, and i have to okay the fact that it couldnt communicate with the fan.  However, as soon as i removed this attachment, i had absolutley no problems.    All in all, im 100% pleased with my purchase, it was exactly what i needed. Its quiet, its well built, performs well, and looks nice.  If it gives me any problems in the foture, ill be sure to remember to come edit this review, otherwise, 5/5.

So I needed a replacement for my 5 year old Plantronics DSP 500 headset.  The first thing that caught my attention about the G35 set is the red light on the mic to let you know it is muted, and the 7.1 virtual sound, so I figured I would take a shot.    Pros:  - They sound good  - The volume roller is easy to use and is software based so you are actually adjusting Windows volume level.  - The mute button is easy to get to (and the already mentioned red light on the mic)  - The mic pics up sound very well  - The bass is a little stronger than DSP500's, but only slightly.    Cons:  - Logitech decided to use their braided cord that will FOREVER hold bends and will never just hang loose  - Ear sweat...  these things do not breathe (if you like ear sweat, put this in the pros column)  - The \\"pad\\" that rests on top of your head is not soft at all, and the 2 additional ones they provide are just bigger than the first  - Massive, you can't just slide these on, they take both hands to pry open   - Skull crushing, they basically rely on squeezing your head to fit properly  - Lack of audio controls, you get bass and treble, that is it  - They are more effective than ear plugs, you could be run over by a train and never know it (this may be a pro for some people)    The reason I kept my DSP500's for so long is because I could wear them for hours and hours and completely forget I was wearing them.  They also did not block any of the outside noise so I could easily talk to someone or listen for something while wearing them.  I can wear the G35's for about 2 hours before my ears feel gross, and the pressure starts to bother me.  I have to wonder if they are not a danger to little kids with soft skulls...  you might end up with a conehead kid if they wear these a lot.    I honestly can't tell you what other headset you should get, but for the price of these G35's I would recommend getting something else.  With the G35 you are paying for gimmick and look, not for quality sound hardware.      UPDATE:  After having this headset for a while there are a few more bad things unfortunately.  The material covering the ear pads will start to peel off after a while, mine are almost completely gone.  It starts with the material cracking and breaking off (looks like they used the wrong glue) and you will be left with chunks of black material on your neck and clothes.    I still use mine, but only because of the excellent sound and bass they produce, as well as the lit mute indicator and mute button.  Overall a $129 pair of headphones should not be flaking and coming apart in less than a year.

I got mine yesterday and played around with it. To put things in perspective. I had originally purchased (and still have) the Kindle 2 @ $249.
The K2 is strictly an e-reader. Nothing else. So, considering that. The Fire @ $199 is a steal, even with it's shortcomings.
I'm just hoping that there will be some major software updates and some Android mods, to make this a fully functional Android tablet.

Pros -

Small form factor
Price
Good web browser
Good video player
Ease of use (navigate through apps, store, books, etc)

Cons -

Power button on bottom
Volume - It should really have a dedicated volume rocker
Web browser - should be like an Android phone w/auto fit, so when I pinch zoom. It would automatically fit all the text on one page and adjust fonts (size) accordingly.
Home screen - I would rather have an Android or iPad look to it. With dedicated icons for each app and a background screen you can customize
Touchscreen - Not as smooth and sensitive as my iPad or even my Evo 4g Android. I'm hoping this could be tweaked with a software update.
Apps - There will be more, but at the moment it's pretty sparse. It should also have a dedicated Facebook and Twitter app. Not a link to the web version.
Email - Unless I missed it. There needs to be an dedicated email program.

Those are just a few things that struck out at me last night. Overall, this is a solid effort and is definitely a good buy for the holidays.
output: Not bad for a first try. I would give it 3.5 stars at the moment

I bought this about 2 weeks back and I love this product. I already converted nearly 20 of my VHS and miniDVs to DVD. There are 3 software applications given along with this... which I think is a bargain. I love the Arcsoft ShowBiz product. I was able to edit my video, set chapters, backgrounds on the DVD tilte page etc. I have not tried adding any audio yet. I like to keep the original talk/chatter on my home videos. It's kinda fun to hear those later.

As for the negatives and the reason I only gave 4 stars is that the direct transfer software does not seem to work correctly, at times. I set the capture time to 1.5 hours and it wrote only .5 hours of video to disk although I saw that the complete video was captured from tape. I don't know what went wrong and lost couple of disks because of this. Another reason I gave only 4 stars is that the backup software (not related to DVD conversion) does not seem to work well with 1.1 USB ports.

The installation instructions could have been better.

Another reviewer mentioned that they had problems with no video signal after a couple of conversions. Well, I had the same problem and tried changing the cables a bit and figured out that the USB cable was defective. Replaced with a new USB cable with gold plated edges and it worked fine.

Over all, I am pleased with product.

This is my fourth e-Reader. I've had a Barnes & Noble Nook, Kindle Fire, iPad 2 and the original Kindle. By far, this is the absolute best Kindle or e-Reader I've ever owned or used. The lighting is absolutely helpful in the best ways ever and not intrusive or irritable in any way. My apartment has a low lighting and it's perfect for it. I've also used it outside and had no issues seeing the screen and in bed with all the lights off. I've read about shadowing from the lighting but mine doesn't really have it. If it does, I haven't noticed it. While I liked playing games or looking at magazines on the iPad & Fire --- I never could enjoy reading books. I always got headaches from using them.  The Paperwhite is the best e-Reader for books and heavy readers. Obviously, the $119 price tag isn't good for someone who will read one or two books. The design is the best yet. It's small and compact and like holding an extremely thin paperback book. The touch screen is amazing and I love the sort of scratchy surface rather than the slick ones of the Fire & iPad, etc.  My favorite thing is the built in dictionary. You just press down on a word and it immediately shows you the definition. I haven't hit a word that wasn't available yet. As for the battery life; I've charged it one time and have read three entire 300+ page books on the device. Speaks for itself. Awesome. I can't rave it enough, it's changed my life! Haha. My only negative complaint is that new novels in the Kindle store are not much different than the price of a hardcover book and range from $9.99 - $14.99. Seems kind of steep for a digital experience. Either way, I'll never use another device but the Kindle Paperwhite. I hope Amazon leaves it as it is but just upgrades the amount of books you can keep on it. I don't really want the device to change much. It's close to perfect.
output: The absolute best e-Reader on the market. Hands down.
