I've been using the older WMM-3500 version of this product for quite a while. This one is a nice upgrade. It's just a hair larger though both models suit the size of my hand. This has more activity switches than its 3500 brother -- tilt switches on the wheel and an extra thumb-operated switch on the left side. All of these are rather inconvenient to use. The tilt switches (and now the wheel switch itself) requires a determined push and the thumb switch is located rather inconveniently, though I suppose that this was done to minimize the chance of inadvertent operation. The latest mouse software offers quite an array of button programming options, including a very useful macro function. This is a significant upgrade from the 3500. Microsoft's new post-Intellipoint driver software is a worthwhile upgrade. I like the R and L button click feel a lot, but especially like the high-resolution smooth-scroll wheel. That alone makes this a \\"must\\" upgrade from the 3500. If you're patient, you can find these occasionally at the same low promotional price as the 3500, which is a good time to grab a couple of them.

It has the usual stowable micro R/T. There's not much to say about this as it seems to work fine without any discernible temperature rise as some of the older ones had. I can't comment on range because the mouse and receiver are separated by only a few inches where I use them.

On the down side, the battery consumption of this is every bit as miserable as the 3500: -1 star. It will chew through an ordinary alkaline AA in two or three weeks. Having learned my lesson a long time ago, I use NiMH rechargeables and have a few charged cells handy everywhere one of these critters is in use. What has always puzzled me about this is that the older version with the typical flash-drive-sized receiver (WMM-3000 typically) would run for months on one rechargeable NiMH AA. Months. Without ever turning it off. So Microsoft... why did you screwthis up? The blue LED?

I still can't figure out the \\"pink\\" part of the color description. The one I got is a very attractive medium dark metallic red. IOW nothing that would threaten anyone's manhood if caught using it.

Bottom line: They're a great buy on sale. Just be sure to plan for the voracious battery appetite.

I have a pile of flaky USB hubs. It would make you weep. It makes me weep.

This thing is solid. It's huge, but who cares? The connectors aren't going to flake (half my defective hubs). The ports are solid.

And it's got a gigantic laptop power supply. This thing is half the size of the hub itself, and will supply 4 amps. Some of you might find the brick a negative, but for me the solid power is a godsend, because flaky hubs often flake when they try to supply too much power and choke.

I've got ten things plugged in right now, including two USB video cards, a USB audio card, myriad USB serial ports, two USB drives, some input devices, and a tablet in the high power port and it's working just fine. I'm ordering two more.

The on/off buttons for the groups of three three ports seems like a gimmick, but it doesn't hurt anything.

If you want to charge a bunch of tablets/phones at once I suggest you look at the Anker 25/40W devices ( http://www.amazon.com/Anker%C2%AE-Family-Sized-Desktop-Charger-Adapter/dp/B00DVH62J2 ) but for a standard hub this thing is the bomb.
output: This bad boy has a 4 amp power brick

Instances.input:
First off, DO NOT confuse the E FUN NextBook Premium 7se tablet with the \\"plain jane\\" NextBook Premium 7 tablet -- the Premium 7se has a capacitive touch screen (which means you just have to *touch* the screen . . . think iPhone, iPad, etc.), whereas the \\"basic\\" Premium 7 has a RESISTIVE touch screen (like most credit/debit card scanners in stores, where you have to PRESS to get the screen to respond to your input).

The Premium 7se comes with the Android Ice Cream Sandwich (ICS) 4.0 operating system (specifically, version 4.0.3 in my case) -- this falls in the same Android 4.x \\"generation\\" as the Android Jelly Bean 4.1 (and up) version used on the Nexus 7 tablets, so functionality and performance will be fairly similar, especially compared to the functionality and performance found on tablets running previous Android 3.x (\\"Honeycomb\\") or Android 2.x (\\"Gingerbread\\") versions.

The screen on the Premium 7se can be a bit laggy at times -- I think the processor is probably not quite as \\"beefy\\" as some other tablets out now, but it does fine and doesn't require a ton of patience, and I've not found it laggy to the point of being annoying (and I'm easily annoyed).

I've had the Premium 7se for well over a month now and I've not had any problems getting apps to work on it. The battery life seems to be fairly good -- unlike some of the older Android 2.x tablets that I've had, the Premium 7se with ICS 4.0 seems to do a good job of conserving battery life if you forget to shut it off and just let it go into standby mode on its own. I left mine on last night when I went to bed, and when I went to turn it on this morning it came on immediately as it came out of \\"sleep\\" mode (the boot-up is quick, but not as fast as \\"waking up\\") -- I expected the battery to be pretty well drained, but I was very surprised to find it still had about three \\"bars\\" left on the battery.

The wireless functionality seemed to be a big drain on most of my previous tablets as well, but even with the wireless on constantly, the battery doesn't seem to drain faster than when I've got the wireless disabled.

For me, this tablet does everything I need -- it's NOT an iPad, and it's not a Nexus 7 or a Kindle Fire, but the display is sharp, it runs all the apps I need it to run, it's great for casual web browsing, and honestly, it's the best Android device I've had to date.

One helpful tip -- the form factor (height and width, anyway) seems to be an almost exact match for the Kindle Fire. This is important, because that means that cases designed for the Kindle Fire WILL work well with the NextBook Premium 7se.

I purchased a ([[ASIN:B007V9O2FC YooMee Black Amazon Kindle Fire 7 Inch Android Tablet Leather Case Cover Folio with Multi-Angle Stand and Hand Strap (Black)(NOT Compatible with Fire HD)]]) and it's a PERFECT fit for the Premium 7se. This is the best tablet case I've found -- it's exactly what I was looking for, in fact, and it does a great job of protecting my Premium 7se.

If you want a solid Android tablet with the latest OS but don't have the money to spend on a Nexus 7 or a Kindle Fire, the E FUN NextBook Premium 7se is DEFINITELY worth looking at -- and I think it's the best value you can find right now in terms of the current crop of 7\\" Android tablets.

I bought the Wi-Fi only version with special offers as an upgrade to my original Kindle Keyboard. I was a little nervous about this decision, because my previous Kindle was 3G with no special offers, and I was worried that the special offers would be irritating. Fortunately, they're only on the lock screen and if I choose I can pay the $20 one time to have them go away forever.

I'm still not 100% convinced that the Wi-Fi was the right choice, since part of the point of a Kindle (for me) is the ability to get a new book the second I'm done with the one I'm reading. However, there is Wi-Fi almost everywhere. So far it hasn't come up.

The device itself is very nice, with a more crisp page than my Kindle Keyboard. The light feature is the sole reason I decided to upgrade, but it was well worth it. The only thing that I'm still having a hard time getting used to a month after purchase is the lack of back/forward buttons. The Kindle Keyboard was a little easier to use one-handed since it had a "page forward" and "page back" button along either edge. With the Paperwhite, if I'm holding the book in my right hand I cannot go backwards with one hand. If I am holding the book in my left hand (which is most common for me, since I'm right hand dominant and typically using that hand to eat, cook, etc. as I read) I have to stretch my left hand uncomfortably to change the page. (Please note, this may not be an issue for all users. I have carpal tunnel in my hands and have a more restricted range of motion as a result)

Overall this is an amazing device which I heartily recommend. My complaints are really just me being nitpicky.

So here is the deal with SSDs and my experience (I own several Crucial, Intel, and Samsung).

Intel - Best performance and reliability, but cost the most (I use this in my main desktop that I need the performance)

Samsung - Almost as good performance and reliability as Intel and usually cheaper (these are usually a better deal than intel)

Crucial - Good performance and so far good reliability (not as good as the other two, but usually way cheaper).

I use intel in my desktop, Samsung in most of my clients computers, and crucial in my laptop and server (needed ssd, but didn't need as fast as intel or samsung).

SSDs in my opinion should be used in all computers as they make a huge difference. If you need more storange just ass a normal hard drive or two and use those for storage. These SSD brands that I mentioned seem to be better quality then the HDDs I have and will probably last longer as well. I only use HDDs for storage now (such as nas or backup). I cannot deal with slow computers.

Having more than 13 years under my belt as a multi-certified IT consultant often engaging projects independently or as the technical lead for clients such as JPMorgan-Chase, Walt Disney's EPCOT Center, Orlando International Airport, Gateway, Hewlett-Packard, and more, I should have known better than to think this low-priced unit with such high-performance claims was too good to be true... and I would have been right.    The goal was to bridge a network where the EOC-5611 and it's predecessor, the now discontinued EOC-5610, were 240 feet apart. With direct unobstructed line-of-sight, mounted atop a 25' mast, and fitted with high-quality ethernet cable, the signal began to fade at 100 feet and was completely degraded by 150 feet, regardless of band or antenna type used. The unit likewise performed as poorly when used as an access point. A good signal could be achieved between 80-100 feet, but dropped so significantly that a connection could not be made past 150 feet.    In my tests, this unit failed to produce more than 10mW using the internal panel antenna and no more than 13mW using a 9dBi external omni-directional antenna for both the 802.11a and 802.11b/g bands - nowhere near the company's 600mW claim and more akin to consumer-grade indoor access points in the sub-$50 price range offered by LinkSys, NetGear, or Belkin.    Interestingly, phone conversations with the technical support personnel at EnGenius revealed that the unit, when fitted with the external omni antenna mentioned above, could expect to reach only a maximum of 400mW and that the internal antenna was only for the 802.11a band... that an external antenna was necessary if one wished to use the 802.11b/g band. They suggested that I spend hundreds more per unit for a parabolic, yagi, or patch directional antenna to achieve a strong signal for the 240' distance I required. Amazing... the advertising boasts that this unit is \\"high-power\\" commercial-grade client premises equipment, easily capable of 1-30kmtransmission range. Yet, in reality, I can throw a baseball a greater distance than this unit can transmit a wireless signal!    Based on the information presented here, at Amazon, and information and data sheets obtained at the EnGenius web site, I recommended this product to a client with a low-budget for the client/bridge solution. What should have been a quick and easy install resulted in many hours of on-site configuration and troubleshooting, and ultimately caused a strained client relationship. Although I salvaged the client, it cost me an additional $1300 to replace these units with a pair of D-Link DWL-2700AP's to do so. They work flawlessly and I have never looked back.    If I could give Zero stars for this product, I would. Unless you love headaches, frustration, and losing clients... run away, run far away from the EOC-5610/EOC-5611.

Instances.input:
The Blurex Rocket WiFi adapter and antenna is a little over 18 in. long and comes with an offset mounting bracket of painted metal plus screws and cable ties for installation. The permanently-attached cable with a USB 2.0 connector is about 16 ft. long. It can be used indoors or mounted outside.

Drivers for Windows, LInux, and Mac OS X are included on a mini disc. Installation was easy and took only a few minutes.

The antenna has a wide range and provides a definite signal boost to full strength in my own apartment and down the hallway. 802.11n data rate is up to 150 Mbps up & down.

I used this antenna to set up an open guest network as I have benefited from a neighbor's open guest network when having trouble with my own internet.

Blurex provided a Rocket for evaluation and review.
output: Easy to setup, instant WiFi signal boost

Instances.input: These are replacement disks for this jot flip. They are of good quality, but easily lost. the product is good. thanks

I loved this drive, used it all the time! I had almost daily use with it with my HP laptop and windows media center. It was slick as can be for about 5 months, then it crashed. I was on the phone with HP in Puerto Rico, LA, Canada, India (the rudest), and Argentina technical support. they kept bouncing me around making me mad. I kept repeating the serial number over and over to marginal English speaking people. Then out of desperation, I called sales and got woman who told me they only guarantee the drives or 21 days out of the box. She tried to sell me a new one. Buyer beware!

It was a very nice hdmi adapter until it suddenly stopped working.
It had clear picture quality, and it was very easy to use. (Quick Note for everyone with a mac, when you install a new device that can output sound you usually change which device outputs sound in the System Preferences, under Sound.)
Unfortunately, it stopped working a month or two after it arrived, my macbook will seem like it will output video but then it just stays on the built in display, I have tried multiple hdmi cords but none have worked so far, and I have tried it on multiple monitors as well.

I've only had the battery for a month, so I don't know what it's lasting power is. But the old battery, before it died, kept the machine going for about an hour, and the new one works for more like 2 - 2 1/2 hours, with my configuration. The minuses:  * it seems to have some difficulty getting to a 100% charge, hovering around 98% most of the time. At one point, it went from 98% to, after an hour of charging, 97%.   * There does not seem to be a way to get the battery to reveal its current state of health.   Still, for $35, keeping my XP computer alive so that I don't have to spend a couple of grand on software updates is not a bad deal.

The mouse is Okay I've had it for about 2 months

Pros: Looks nice, lots of different button combinations, easy to use button programming software, interchangeable parts, weights

Cons: the feel around your hand is very different and may take some time to get used to, this mouse cursor has spazzed out about a dozen times over the past month while gaming, where you cannot control the cursor's position which can be very annoying.

There is a reason why this mouse has so many negative reviews!
I would expect a 100$ mouse to be without cursor movement issues.

The mouse did not come with a nifty box for the weights and extra parts like you see in unboxing videos.
If you are going to buy this product I recommend you buy it from the Mad Catz sight and not off amazon.

I have very bad eyesight and had trouble seeing the print on the computer keys.
I ordered this product in the black with white letters and it is a little time
consuming and some have to be trimmed a little, but I just used a set of very
small sharp manicure scissors to trim some of the F-keys to fit. I used a
pair of tweezers to handle them carefully and make sure they were placed in
just the right spot. 100% improvement in seeing the keys and they look very
nice also. Beware of the cheap ones, as they are not made as well as these
and the printing will wear off. I was so pleased, I installed them on every

Additionally, it's American Made.

Okay, so I don't know if it's just me, or if there's something wrong with the particular router that I got, but I am so disappointed with this thing! I am not hardware savvy, but I can follow directions and I know how to set up and use a wireless router. This one was actually fairly easy to set up with very simplified and clear instructions, and I didn't have any trouble getting everything up and running. Or so I thought.

My old router had left dead spots on the other side of the house. This router has no trouble getting a signal to the whole house (2800 sq ft, two story) but it is SO MUCH SLOWER than my old router. Even when I'm on the computer that is in the same room as the router, which is the only time I can use the 5 GHZ signal, it seems sluggish and takes a long time to boot up just simple you tube videos. I never had a problem streaming netflix to multiple devices in the past, but now if one person is using it, the other person's device is greatly affected.

My husband has an app on his phone that tells you what the internet speed is and we were surprised to find it running at less than 1 MBPS; we had between 3 and 4 before. When we click the wifi off and go on cellular, it shoots back up to 4 mbps. Now, I guess it's possible that there's some magical setting that I need to tinker with, or change the IP address or whatever, but I really really hate having to jump through hoops to get things to work the way they are supposed to. I am homeschooling four kids and I don't have time to call support and walk through a list of troubleshooting tips... I think I will just plug in my old router and deal with the dead spot in the bathroom.

Jesus I must have got way to used to contemporary functionality. This feels like reading a book on an etch'a'sketch. In the age of instant response touch screen smart phones and tablets how can anyone deal with the response time on this device, it drove me insane immediately. Very disappointed. Refund please. I need to to test drive some better devices ASAP.

Over the years I have had very good experience with Lexar products but not this time.

My problem: This Lexar card would not format in the camera, nor would it format via my computer. In both cases I got messages that the card was bad and could not be accessed. I was worried first when I tried to read it via my card reader attached to my computer and the computer said it needed to be formatted that it was unreadable as it was. (I always check for bonus software installed on memory cards before I format them for use.) I didn't think much about it but then tried to format it in the camera but the camera couldn't format it. I went back to my computer to format it there and see if that might fix things but the computer said it couldn't format it and the card was not usable.

The price was astoundingly good for an 800X (120 Mbps) card. The SanDisk at 400X (60 Mbps) costs more than this one at 800X. Maybe that should have been a clue. Another clue that I chose to ignore was that I noticed reviews had consistently higher ratings on SanDisk over Lexar and some even mentioned that the Lexar didn't work but when a SanDisk was used the problem went away.

Thankfully, the Amazon return process is so easy. I have a SanDisk replacement on order. Sadly, it will be the 60 Mbps version but a slower-working card is better than one that doesn't work at all.
output: Did NOT Work in Nikon D800

Instances.input:
I've been running the Windows 10 tech preview, and the old illuminated gaming keyboard I had is totally unrecognized as a standard USB keyboard, which it worked fine as for Windows 7 through Windows 8.1. Since I work in an office where I keep the lights turned off (fluorescent lighting tied into another larger room my office is built off of) I like having the illuminated keyboard.

I had tried another earlier this week, and it was horrible. It felt bad, there was a really useless raised palmrest part in front that was NOT removable, and every time I hit the space bar with my thumb, the joint hit that raised part and after just a few sentences, started to feel annoyingly sore, so I returned it ASAP.

This one looks decent, but the keys are just a bit less responsive than I prefer as a fast touch typist. That's why I dinged a star. I do like the rheostat for volume, as opposed to just up/down keys, but I feel they missed a chance to have a push to click on it as well for an instant mute. But it works well for volume, and was one of the things that made me pick this keyboard.

I wish there were selectable colors, since the blue is a bit subdued, and like right now in my office, with some light coming through the open door from the tech area outside, some keys are more readily visible than others. Some of the letters and numbers look really striated, so there's lines and bits of them that don't light up well, so it's totally inconsistent.

I also see that the day the keyboard arrived, the price suddenly jumped up about 16 dollars. If it was still at the higher price, I'd say it's not worth it, but I got it for under twenty five, and for that price, the imperfections and mushy feel are expected and acceptable.

The feet raise the tilt angle slightly, and I like the fact that I can keep the palm rest off. I won't use the windows key lock feature, since on Windows 8 and Windows 10 I use that quite a bit since that's how I start my searches for files or programs, but I know some people who would love to have that option.

All told, for an inexpensive keyboard, it feels inexpensive, but it has at least a modicum of backlight (on/off options only though, no intensity) and for the cost I paid, it was worth it.how I start my searches for files or programs, but I know some people who would love to have that option.

All told, for an inexpensive keyboard, it feels inexpensive, but it has at least a modicum of backlight (on/off options only though, no intensity) and for the cost I paid, it was worth it.
output: If you get it when they don't raise the price, it's a decent enough keyboard

Instances.input: Here's the lowdown on this power supply. As a new builder you might think "Hmm for $80 which is a decent amount of money, this is probably a decent power supply, especially because it comes from Corsair, a reputable hardware company." I hate to say it but that is WRONG. Corsair makes fantastic cases, fans, cooling solutions, and RAM, but they do NOT make great power supply units. Even their top tier units are not fantastic, and this CX series is the lowest of the low tier. This power supply created huge amount of coil whine when used with two different 970 graphics cards. I returned this power supply and purchased a EVGA 850W G2 to replace it and surpise surprise i now hear ZERO noise. If you are planning on doing nothing but browsing this internet this power supply might work out for you, but beware it has a combination of Japanese and Taiwanese capacitors, instead of all Japanese which are far higher quality. Also note that this is a bronze rated power supply, and for only a little bit more money you can get a gold or platinum rated power supply that will be much more reliable. This PSU is a ticking time bomb waiting to take our your entire build. I highly recommend that you DO NOT buy this unit, and instead opt for a much much better quality PSU like the EVGA G2 series such as the 750W G2 or 850W G2.
output: Low quality capacitors - terrible coil whine - buy EVGA G2 Instead

YOU MUST BUY A LIGHT TO READ IN THE DARK!  -some of the cases don't fit    As you can see I came up with more pros than cons! The kindle 2 is a great gift and works really well! • It wakes and sleeps my iPad
• It was cheap
• Non slippery
• Protects from scratches and *small* bumps
• There's a big enough lip around the screen to help protect it
• Super lightweight and thin- I have VERY a small hands and I wanted a cover that would allow me to hold the mini in one hand. This case allows that!

Cons:
• The color- I got orange and it's not as happy and bright as I would like. But that's preference and I'm not opposed to ordering a differnt color
• The material seams to attract spots. (If I were to order another one because I wanted a differnt color, I would order a darker one.)

Overall:
It serves my needs beautifully. And if my only complaints are color and spots, I think it's great!

Side note:
I have four kids ages 10 and under, they use my iPad mini occasionally and the case is holding up so far. I don't expect it to hold up forever and I don't except it to save my iPad from a really drop. That's not way I bought this cover! That's what my otterbox is for. This cover is for protection against scratches and small bumps while the iPad is in my bag or left on the coffee table.

I'd like to start off saying that I've been a devoted forza enthusiast since the first was released. I enjoyed buying and tuning my car to my liking. Forza 5 excels in several ways and has miner setbacks that seem to cripple the game outweighing the fun factor. As sad as I am by this I will say the game is a blast to play! Starts you off like most racers and you build your way up by either buying more cars or upgrading your initial car. The graphical improvements are a huge leap forward from the previous forza games thus the background and foreground are immaculate. The new rumble triggers is a excellent idea that will allow you to hit a rumble strip on either side of the car and not only visually see the impact but feel it as well. The cars have a large improvement on physics; that when you turn in a car with under steer it will in fact feel like one and over steer it will truly feel as such. Every single car in the game has its only forza vista to were you can be informed every single thing about the car of your choosing. All of the tracks have had major overhauls to the graphics. I often find myself doing a solo race and just slowly drive admire ring the sear detail of the tracks. The AI improvement (driveatar) is one of the best improvements to a racing game in history of racing games. Having players around the world determine the driving path of ai in your race...Simply amazing.

All of the above might sound like a perfect game however it has some setbacks that should be addressed. First and foremost the number of tracks and cars have been cut in "half" or more than literal half its more like cut down to a 3rd. The overhaul to graphics and physics and forza vista is great but I found the vista type part of the game to be a complete waste on some cars. If I wanted to learn about a 83 beetle I would go buy one with a handful of cents. (figuratively speaking) I found after around 10hours of racing that the tracks already are becoming a repetitive annoyance. Some of my favorite tracks have been removed for unknown reasons to the community thus far. And after my experience with forza 5 the lack of in game funding makes racing not really worth doing career. If I put all settings off and expert difficulty racing exotic cars for a full season 10races of ranging laps from 3-4 and my payout for each race in 1st 8-10k seems less worth it to try and get gold on every race. Some of these cars will not be attained till most if not all seasons are completed. Lotus f1 is 6mill after each season I find myself at around 200-300k and it takes about 1 hour to complete a full season. At this point in my playing in I'm not sure if new seasons overlap the current completed ones. So far no new seasons have popped up leading me to believe that you are forced to reset the season after completing it. And forced to re-do the 10 tracks over and over again.

In summary forza 5 is a excellent game for launch of a new system. However I think in the next few months to come they will release updates to address issues players are having with the game so far. Expect to pay for the new tracks and new cars that are to come in time.
output: Detailed explenation of the current Forza 5

An hour later, after the battery cooled down a bit, fairly normal function seems to have returned. Don't know how long it will last, but it is recognized and charging at the moment. I should also add that the rubber feet on battery, which keep it from scratching the table beneath them, came off within the first 3 days of use. Clearly shoddy glue used. Ok, I don't do many reviews, but i feel this is something that might put Mac Users minds at ease. I didn't do a lot of research on this Alfa WiFi Adapter prior to buying this...so trying to install it was a hassle. The CD that this product came with was USELESS. So i had to go online to the ALFA Website to get the current Driver to install it onto my Mac. The site only offered 10.4, 10.5, and 10.6 versions...NO 10.7 (OSX Lion)!!! WHAT THE F***! Well DO NOT WORRY! I went ahead and downloaded 10.6 and everything worked out fine! I'll show you how to do that next....

First download version 10.6 driver for mac. Second, you are going to have to go on YouTube and click this link and watch the video...

[...]

Next, open up the \\"Terminal\\" in your Mac. You have to input this command into the Terminal \\"sudo systemsetup -setkernelbootarchitecture i386\\" (To set Lion in 32bits mode), reboot, install the' driver (For 10.6 on alpha website), reboot again, and tadaaaaa :D

If you follow every step in the video, you will have no issues! I only had one proble with this though, but nothing big. Everytime I unplugged my Adapter, I would have to input this command into the Terminal everytime I used it. \\"sudo kextutil -t -v [...]\\" it is the code to run the Realtek program.

Trust me this does work! It would be so much easier if Alfa just had an updated driver! Other than that, this product is great for long ranges! I would recommend getting a USB 2.0 Extension / Repeater cable Male to Female. Hope this helped out!
output: Does work on Mac OSX Lion!

This memory module did not work with my Dell Inspiron 3147. After a few hours the machine failed and it would no longer start up. When I reported this problem to the vendor, parts-quick, they pointed out that Dell's reference guide (PDF) says only 4GB is supported.

Intel's own documentation says that the Intel Pentium N3830 CPU supports up to 8GB, and several Dell Inspiron 3147 users have reported a successful upgrade to 8GB. I returned the memory to the vendor, and ordered an 8GB upgrade elsewhere.

I ordered the advertised Corsair brand memory, but received Crucial brand memory in place of it. The vendor did not ask me if the substitution was okay. I have had to repeatedly RMA Crucial memory sticks over the years, due to unexplained failures, blue screens, sudden reboots, Etc., so I was not happy with this unexpected substitution by the vendor. I would have canceled the order, if given the opportunity. While both brands have lifetime warranties to the original owner, this was used memory that I received, not new. I don't know if Crucial will honor their warranty if the memory fails. Either way I would have to pay the return shipping to send the substituted brand back. I have been ordering tech products for over 30 years and cannot remember a vendor ever pulling a stunt like this one did. This is clearly a case of bait with a high quality brand and then switch shipping an inferior brand. I would never order any products from Nemix again.

This cooler has certainly lowered temps on my VisonTek R9 290 Reference card. But it certainly wasnt easy to install.
The hardest part was installing the heatsink on the back, Maybe I misplaced the cooling pads but the heatsink didnt exactly fit the card, the claps used to hold it down bulged and I had to leave one off so I could fit it into the PCI express slot.

The fan is very quite, even at 1300 RPM (fastest setting)

Temps before with reference cooler: 94C and major throttling.

Temps after water cooler install: 57C max with cooler fan set to 100%

Temps using water cooler with recommended fan curve: 68C @ 50% max fan speed.

Oh and I have my card OC'd to 1050 core and 1400 memory. This is valid for all of the above results. Im sure the temps would be lower if I left it at stock clocks.

My case is a midtower and already could hardly fit the R9 290 so I knew any aftermarket fan cooler wouldnt fit, Thus I went with this option. It certainly does what it is designed to do and allows guaranteed OC'ing headroom.

R9 290 VisonTek reference from eBay: $220
Water cooler : $120

Total cost : $340 for better than GTX 780 performance and guaranteed cool temps.

I should have taken that it being on sale with no reviews what so ever was a bad sign, but said hey why not.  I'm not someone who cares too much about the sound quality, though that might change if I get a good quality headset, and the only other pairs of headsets I have owned were a Logitech h600 and some cheap $10-15 ones from Target, but I thought the sound quality was a noticeable set up from those.  Another positive was that it did reduce outside sound and it had good padding as compared to my previous ones.  My real issue was with the sound bleed.  I like to Skype with friends while gaming, and I don't like having the volume up very high, but they were able to hear everything about as well as I was.  Another problem was the mic gain.  Everyone in the call could hear even background sounds that weren't even that loud such as wind from outside and rain, both things that never caused issues with previous headsets.  Another thing was the size, it was fine for me, I have an average sized head, but I had to extend it to the furthest it could, so if you have a slightly larger than average head this will be too small.
output: Low quality headset for a high quality price.

Instances.input:
Few products provoke as much consternation as external hard drives, and since I've previously been a victim of Iomega products (remember the Jazz drives?), I'd sworn off the brand. But a special offer, and a stylistic match with the Mac Air, made this one hard to resist.

It's about the size of a wallet and comes with a claim that it can be dropped five feet without damage. I'm counting on the drive's not provoking me to test its claim.

So far I can attest that Helium is lighter than Air, that the device sets up immediately and intuitively with Time Machine, and that it has a well-positioned, small blue light that blinks for the amount of time required to back up your computer (about 5 minutes--not bad). Finally, it appears to draw more than sufficient power from the USB port. Power adapter unnecessary (though with the lone USB port of the Air, a wireless storage drive would rule).

I continue to be especially impressed by this drive. It eagerly appears on my desktop with startling regularity and speed, it appears to have no moving parts inside, it runs cool and silent, and thank goodness it's an overachieving mighty mite because there isn't even any provision for an AC connection. No Firewire 400 or 800, but the drive's power and efficiency make the Mac Air look all the better for their absence. Finally, it pretty much makes good on Apple's hype about Snow Leopard being an 80% stronger animal than Leopard. Let's face it: cooler is better.

6/30/11: I continue to get unfailing service from this drive, which came out before the 2nd (current) generation of Mac Air computers. It doesn't have \\"eGO\\" inscribed on the top of the device (just as the accompanying pictures are devoid of the label), it uses a thin and supple cable (as opposed to the thick transparent one of its successor) and, unlike its \\"eGo\\" successor, it operates efficiently with a single USB plug (the newer one employs 2 plugs). Finally, the back sticker states that the place of manufacture is Korea (the newer, current model lists China as the place of manufacture).re is Korea (the newer, current model lists China as the place of manufacture).

Instances.input: My husband is an IT tech he sets stuff like this up all the time and yet we cannot get these to work at all! Just like the reviewer CS it just will not connect to our XP system and fusses over the IP address. We have wireless, we've used it but for some reason this system just does not want to work. We will probably keep trying but for now this product is a bust for us.

This product works, ie. it connects two USB 3.0 cables into a header for a motherboard. That it does. Other than that, it is short. I was not able to hide it on the backside of my computer case. It is also very rigid. Trying to get it to bend even a small amount away from my mother board caused a great deal of flex on the motherboard header. I did not like that at all. It did not look good, and I was worried that it would damage my expensive motherboard. Instead I got rid of this and used this [[ASIN:B0058NN1A0 Biostar USB 3.0 Aluminum Front Panel CABLEUSB30 - Black]]. It is quite long, and once removed from the front panel cage, hides well in my case behind my motherboard. I would recommend the Biostar header to anyone who is looking at this Silverstone product. I would return it, but would pay almost what it is worth in return shipping. Lesson learned for me.

Wow, this thing SMELLS.  Really strong, and it reminds me of fish food or water.  After having this out of the package and airing out, it has not lessened at all.  As someone who is really sensitive to smells, it makes it hard to even hold this near me.  It makes me sick to my stomach. As to functionality, I bought this mostly for the handle.  It's pointless.  There's nothing that holds the lid to the rest of the case, so you have to hold it yourself.  So why even have the handle???  I like that the tablet is held in by a velcro tab, but I had originally though the velcro had something to do with holding the case open.  So that's disappointing but I guess at least the tablet isn't sliding out.  The part that goes around the screen is awkward for me personally.  All ports and buttons ARE accessible, even the sd slot area which often isn't, but it's not easy with the edge hanging over to push the power button.  I can't just push it, I have to feel around and then the case itself gets in the way of me being able to actually push it down easily at first.  This closes nice and flat though, and the magnet to auto sleep/wake works. Lastly, the case was dirty when I got it, dark smudges on the inside etc.  The whole thing looks like it was rubbing against something dark that stained it. Honestly overall, I'd rather use nothing than use this case, especially with the smell.  I've ordered another case, hoping that it will be better so I can return this one.

I bought the 2700 thinking that the only differences between it and the 2701 were memory and hard disk, but the 2700 only goes to 1024x768 resolution.  (The 2701 goes to 1400x1050.)  Nothing on the net (here or at Compaq.com) says anything about this.  Other than that, it's a nice but heavy laptop, as others have said.  Having a separate DVD and CD-R is a bit waistful, but doesn't annoy me too much.  The mouse pad is nice to use, the display is great, and the thing looks beautiful.  It doesn't have a serial port, which seems to be a trend in new laptops.  This was a problem with a GPS box I got at the same time.  I've had no problems with the machine so far.

I am totally satisfied.  It came in excellent condition, packaged well.  It doesn't seem to have the life span of the original, but I may be mistaken. (I notice the battery drains more quickly if I use Netflix for an hour or two.)  Seems I charge it every 1- 1/2 days or so, and I am not on it all day every day.  However, if it lasts as long as the original, I don't mind charging more often for such an excellent cost on this replacement!  Thank you for the excellent service.

Well this may have a good rep as a laptop hdd but as a component in a certain (cough..cough) Imation external USB 3.0 hdd it sucks. Just look up the Apollo M-100 ext hdd. Mine lasted about 9 months of light use before the heads stuck. Characterised by a solid blue read light and beeping coming from the enclosure. Had to do a non-clean room disassembly and move the heads with a pair of forceps. Worse than useless for external storage (as unreliable) but might be OK as a lappie or desktop drive as it might not get such a rough ride. Wouldn't recommend to a friend!
output: Might be ok in your laptop but don't survive well in an external enclosure

Instances.input: Highly recommend the Kindle Paperwhite with 3G!  Back light works well and is adjustable.  The 3G makes things so much easier and the touch screen with the keyboard is great. Big improvement over my last kindle.

Toshiba low-end laptops are pure garbage. Flimsy, cheap, unreliable, and built with the cheapest components available. Save your money and spend a bit more on something else not built by Toshiba. Best case scenario, you might get 6-12 months out of your laptop before things start to fail. Worse case scenario (as I've just experienced), your laptop will last a matter of weeks before the lights go out. And unfortunately for the buyer, Toshiba often refuses to meet their own warranty obligations. Considering how cheap the laptops are, they don't want to help you, or fix the laptop. They would lose money otherwise. So if you send it in for repairs, like they'll inevitably recommend, you'll find yourself being asked to pay elaborate sums of money because the 'scope of work' is not within the boundaries of the original warranty agreement. This of course is not true. Toshiba is simply trying to force the added costs of warranty repairs down the throats of uninformed customers. Their laptops are cheap, but they won't actually save you any money in the long run.

Save your money. Don't buy Toshiba. Consider any laptops made by Toshiba as being purely disposable, or built for third word countries with no consumer protection laws.
The smell of this case is disgusting!

I received this as an Xmas present. It was crap out of the box. App Store would not load, would lose internet connection within a minute. Researched online and found that it needed firmware update, but firmware update page would never load. This is a super buggy product that is chalked full of nothing but frustration. This may be cheap, however, that is no excuse to market such a faulty product. You have to be tech savvy to get this functional, but even if you managed to get it working, why bother? Any smart phone will out perform this beast of a machine, with far less technological hassle.

I would point out to anyone contemplating this purchase that the highest rated reviews for this item are either over a year old, or nearly a year old. It is already out of touch. You would be far better off to pony up a few extra bucks and go for the [[ASIN:B0051VVOB2 Kindle Fire, Full Color 7\\" Multi-touch Display, Wi-Fi]]. Additionally this product has nearly equal 1 star reviews to its 5 star reviews. You work the odds and note how many 5 star reviews start out with \\"I just received it and its great!\\" vs the 1 star reviews that have been dealing with this product's issues for some time.

Returning this item was a hassle, third party seller took forever, never emailed me back after several attempts to contact. Return was issued over 25 days later with no contact from seller letting me know status of return, despite emails.

Run, don't walk away from this product
Worked like a charm, just make sure you have the correct slot available before ordering it!

Ok, when I bought these I really didn't expect them to change my life. I mean heck, who can get excited about computer grommets? However when I discovered how cheaply these were made I was shocked. (Yes, shocked!)

Can the process to make a quality computer grommet be that much more advanced? The mold casting flash wasn't even trimmed off these! They measure a scosche under 2" BTW so they will wobble in your hole. Good thing they come in a four pack because the first one broke on installation. And by installation I mean setting the grommet in the hole!

Please, dear friends, I implore you! Spend the extra $1.25 on quality-made grommets so you don't have to spend your life in shame as I do. These grommets will be my scarlet letter for all time.
output: Daddy said avoid cheap wine and women but nothing about cheap grommets.

I put a 2.5\\" SATA drive into the caddy, and popped it into my Lenovo T400's optical bay. The drive instantly behaved as it had been there from birth. No muss, no fuss... excellent.

I subsequently tried the caddy with different drives in different machines - it worked like a champ, and I've decided to just get two more so that I don't have to keep taking this one in and out. Highly recommended.

I was hesitant to purchase this keyboard because it is wireless.  I work full shifts on my computer, often working overtime, so I cannot afford to have batteries die in the midst of a shift as was my experience with past wireless keyboards.  I sure hope this one lives up to its long battery life reputation because the comfort of this keyboard is amazing.  I have a lot of hand and arm pain so I have to be very careful about my keyboard selection.  This one has a great shape that does not overextend my fingers, which is a major issue with some ergonomic keyboards.  The keys have a slight texture, almost feeling like brushed leather, which is very comfortable.  The keys are very quiet, which is important to me (I cannot stand a loud keyboard because it is a distraction while transcribing).  I do have to get accustomed to the location of the "End" button, but I like the extended size of the "Delete" key.  I highly recommend this keyboard for someone with smaller hands who must avoid RSI, or needs to pamper themselves due to an RSI.
output: Should have purchased one long ago!

I bought this specifically to hook up a two Wii Classic Pro Controllers to my Nexus 7 (Android Tablet) to play multiplayer emulator games with my wife. When paired with a standard OTG USB adapter (converts the mini-USB port on Android devices into a full-size port), the emulators I used, which are gamepad-compatible, immediately recognized and allowed me to configure BOTH controllers as separate players!

I also tested my setup on a Moto X as well, and can confirm it works great on that too!

So yeah, this adapter is awesome.

I really love this netbook. I had an Asus eeepc for about 2 weeks before I bought this one, and returned it thinking I just wasn't cut out for the netbook experience. I'm glad I tried one more time! One of the most helpful features that sets this netbook apart from others, are the \\"chicklet\\" keys. They help you type so much more easily in the smaller space of netbooks. I also love the matte finish, because it doesn't show fingerprints and random dirt as easily as a lot of the shiny, plastic finishes that a lot of the other netbooks have. I installed the extra 1gb of ram myself, and I'm no techie. You just buy a 2gb pc2-5300 cls 200 sodimm card, and watch the youtube video on how to put it in. Easy. This little netbook is fast, holds all of the files, pics, and music from my old laptop, and has tons of memory to spare. It's easy to surf the web on, connects to wireless from anywhere, and... best of all... it fits in my purse to take to work, and lasts all day without having to bring a charger with me! Everyone said that I wouldn't be happy with a netbook, because they are too small, but the resolution on this one is higher than on most netbooks, and this screen is crisp, clear, and easy to read. I got a program that let me work around the windows starter version, because it doesn't let you set your own photos on the desktop, etc. Once I downloaded a little free program I got by searching google, I was instantly able to set whatever photos I wanted as a background without buying the full windows 7. I've got the adobe c5s master collection (dreamweaver, flash editor, photoshop, & more) and the whole microsoft office 2007 suite(word, publisher, access, excel, powerpoint, outlook, infopoint), Sibeleus, Picasa, and iTunes installed on it, and they run flawlessly with multiple windows open at once. I don't think there are many things this little netbook won't do. The only complaint I have is that the internal speakers are a little soft. I just have to get some external speakers for it.

DO NOT ORDER THIS PRODUCT.  it is a waste of your money

This is one of the best deals I was able to find on a 64GB SD card, as far as rating and price per byte.

The card has worked fine in my Lenovo Thinkpad Twist laptop and my Raspberry Pi single-board computer (using NOOBS). I've performed several partition and formatting operations in Windows 8 without problems. I'm quite happy with transfer speeds so far.

The only problem I've run into is trying to use the card to run RACHEL-Pi on my Raspberry Pi after writing the installation image to the card using Win32 Disk Imager. The Pi would not boot. However, I can't say that this was definitely any problem with the card.

I had been eyeballing this drive for a little while, then when the promotion price came up on it, I pounced. From the time I opened the box, I couldn't get the wireless feature of it to work on my KFHD or Galaxy S4. After going through the instructions and website and the videos, it still wouldn't work. Being late on a Friday night, I had to wait until Monday.

For several minutes, I tried to get a tech support phone number, then just went for the live chat function, with hesitations. It took less than 3 minutes to get a tech on chat. He actually helped me get the drive working wirelessly with BOTH devices in a reasonable amount of time. All it took was a firmware update.

I received this SSD drive as a Christmas gift , along with a caddy that the drive plugs into and replaces the DVD drive in my 2008 Macbook Pro. I purchased the SATA III version in anticipation of a future laptop upgrade,the 2008 Macbook I currently own only supports SATA II,but SATA III is backwards compatible so no problem there. I proceeded to remove my DVD drive and install the new SSD,my plan was to also keep my existing hard drive in the primary HDD slot.I then booted up the computer and attempted to partition the drive,so I can install a fresh copy of Lion on it and begin using it.The Mac OS X Disk Utility beachballed for around 3 minutes,which I thought was odd, and then displayed the list of drives,the SSD drive being one of them. The partitioning and formatting process took about 30 minutes,which I also thought was very odd. Once the formatting process completed I tried to copy a 3.8GB iso file onto the SSD to test it's functionality,the first 150MB copied and then it stopped copying and went once again to bechballing. I was unable to un-freeze the system without holding down the power button. I went to the manufacturer's website to see if there are any known issues with this drive in OS X,I was able to find a problem where the drive negotiates a link of 1.5Gbps rather than 3 ,along with a bootable iso image that applied a fix.Well I had just removed the DVD drive from the laptop,so I took the drive back out,put it in the main hard drive slot next to the battery,put the DVD drive back in and proceeded to apply the fix. Once the fix was applied , I took the DVD drive back out ,put my original hard drive back in,and proceeded to boot up OS X and see if the link speed issue had been resolved.Sure enough,the link was now showing 3Gbps. The SSD drive was still refusing to work properly though,I once again tried copying a file , no luck there,also a disk benchmarking utility I got from the app store,which just froze completely.I then thought I would see if maybemy Mac OS installation was somehow corrupted and booted up Windows 7 via Boot Camp. The SSD drive showed up in the list of drives,and after re-formatting as FAT32 I once again tried copying a  file onto it. This also resulted in a complete computer freeze , and had to hold down the power button to completely reset the system.All in all I probably had to hard reset my laptop around 30 times in my attempt to get this drive working.I have gone back to the manufacturer's suport forums to look for further solutions and posts about the freezing issue in Macbook Pros seemed to keep  popping up like mushrooms after a rain. After failing to get this drive working(and believe me I tried hard,I was very excited about having the SSD),the drive is going back to Amazon and will be replaced by a Samsung SSD,which will hopefully work out a lot better.If you are thinking of purchasing and installing this in your Macbook Pro,be prepared for frustration.Your Macbook may work fine,mine didn't(version 5,1),and I saw tens of other posts on their Mac and Linux support forums reporting the freezing issue.If you are still going to purchase this drive,the following advice may save you a lot of time and frustration:   - Go to the OCZ support forums and see if anyone with your model Macbook is reporting issues.   - Download and burn the iso containing the 1.5/3 Gbps fix for Macbook Pro users BEFORE you remove the DVD drive.You will need it afterwards as this seems to be a common issue with these drives.   - If you are going to have two hard drives in your laptop,install the other drive in the DVD slot,and not the SSD,chances are you will need to take it out and send it back,and you don't want to keep having to take your laptop apart.  - After moving your existing drive to the DVD slot,don't screw everything back together completely.Plug in the SSD and boot up to see if it's negotiating a 3 Gbps link.If not,remove the HDD caddy and plug your DVD drive back in so you can boot off the CD you burned and apply the manufacturer's fix.  - After putting the laptop back together, test your SSD drive to make sure you can copy a large file off of your existing drive.  - If all is working well for you,consider yourself lucky.

Instances.input:
Pros:
1) The dongle is kind of handy, it is a Bluetooth receiver so it will take many different bluetooth devices.
2) The range is good, it works in my living room at about 15 feet continuously.
3) Worked out of the box
4) Handy to have the volume on the keyboard, and the media buttons are kind of useful for my setup in the living room.
4) If the batteries die on the mouse you can just replace them and it starts working again, you don't need to have the Bluetooth manually \\"find\\" the mouse, but...

Cons:
1) The keyboard doesn't seem to do this, you have to occasionally have the bluetooth \\"find\\" it again by removing it from the bluetooth devices list and then finding it again. Kind of annoying.
2) The keyboard and mouse take some time to \\"wake up\\" after being left alone.
3) It's BIG. When did keyboards become huge behemoths with tons of useless buttons? Small bluetooth keyboards unfortunately seem to be hard to find though so I settled for this, (the logitech was more expensive at the time and seemed flimsy at the store) but if I could do it all over again I'd look a bit harder and find something smaller.
4) I had to disable the scroll wheel on the mouse because it went haywire. Web pages would suddenly constantly scroll up and down or the volume would suddenly go up and down wildly. I haven't re-activated it. Also the left mouse button became suddenly reassigned for no reason one time, I had to change it back to single click.

Battery life: I've had it now for about 4 months and I've changed the batteries on the keyboard around 3 times and the mouse around 4 or 5. There needs to be a way to turn off the mouse as is always on, this would save battery life.

I'd rate it a 3: If you need a setup for long distance it works, but the keyboard and mouse issues make it annoying and it might be too big for a home theater setup. It basically does what it is supposed to do but is nothing special.

Nice card.  Noticeably improves video performance and the price is right.  Pros:  HDMI, DMI and VGA ports, great phone tech support (24x7 free!).  Cons:  no documentation in the box and no dedicated audio out at all (not even an analog audio out).  Not much product-specific info on the website.      I wanted to use this card for video only, and continue using my existing audio setup.  But when I installed this the sound on my HP a1640n stopped working.  I tried every fix I could think of -- re-installing drivers, disabling them, etc.  I thought the geForce card' software had overwritten or corrupted my motherboard's audio drivers.  After reading many online posts I decided I had to re-install windows and start all over.  I spent a weekend backing up files and re-installing.  It still didn't work.  Eventually I went back to the EVGA site and found a tech support number (blame myself for not doing this *much* earlier).    EVGA has 24/7 free tech support!  After registering the card on the website (required) my call was answered immediately at 10 pm on Sunday night by a knowledgeable person who wasn't just reading a script.  (I think I talked to Doug?  Best tech support call I've had in years).  Problem solved in about 90 seconds (I had to re-boot, go into the BIOS, and set the on-board audio to \\"on\\" (options are off, auto and on).      Had I found the tech support number earlier I would have saved myself a lot of grief.      Bottom line, if you aren't reasonably comfortable mucking around with PC/Windows settings and/or prepared to take a risk, don't try to upgrade a PC with on-board graphics and audio (most mainline consumer PCs fall into this category).  If you are reasonably comfortable, go for it -- but call the company's tech support line if you have any problems.
output: Great value.  Outstanding tech support to call if you have installation problems

It hurt to pay so much, but I had the feeling that getting the Airport Extreme Base Station would save me time and headaches when trying to share broadband between a PC and Mac.
I was successful with this platform/OS/equipment combination:
Apple M8930LL/A Airport Extreme Base Station
Mac: OS 10.1.5, Apple Airport Card
PC: Win2000 Pro, NetGear MA101 Wireless USB Adapter
Plugged an ISP-provided DSL modem into the Base Station and configured the Base Station using the Mac. (Had no success with Apple's Airport Admin config software for the PC.)
Then plugged in the NetGear MA101 on the PC, installed the software from CD, and configured the settings to match the Mac security.
I got strong signal strength and throughput from both the NetGear MA101 and the Airport Card in a three story house.
40-bit WEP works fine. 128-bit is occasionally a little buggy on the PC, requiring me to temporarily reset both platforms to 40-bit.
Haven't tried setting up file sharing yet, but will attempt the USB printer connection on the Base Station. (Caution, check Apple.com/airport for list if approved USB printers that will work with the Base Station. Also, this USB printer feature supposedly requires the Mac to run OS 10.2.3+)
I wish the Airport Base Station manual had more scenario details and suggestions how to tailor your WAN configuration. I spent a lot of time searching the Apple BBS regarding questions I think should have been covered in the manual.
Overall, the Airport Extreme Base Station is a thing of beauty to look at, relatively easy to configure -- but I'm scared to death of someone knocking it to the floor.

This basic Kindle is very easy to read.  It seems to have a very long battery life and recharges easily from a USB port of my computer with the supplied cable.  It can also recharge from my cell phone charger.  Download of books from Amazon is very easy.  A feature I like very much is the ability to look up the definition of any word while reading by moving the cursor in front of the word and have a definition window instantly pop up with the dictionary entry for that word in the window.  Hit the back key to close the window again.  If your public library has kindle ebooks to loan, you can use the internet to browse the public library ebook catalog and if the book is not loaned out you can borrow the book with a download from Amazon.  You can do this 24 hours a day without ever leaving your house--and no worry about past due fines.  The book just expires and vanishes from your Kindle after 14 days.  You do need adequate light to read by just as with a paper book, as the KIndle is not self illuminating.  I read sitting, but I also read a lot in bed lying on my side and have no problem with the Kindle.  A very well thought out device and I like it more than I thought I would.

Instances.input:
The positive: the ipad air fits into the poly-carbonate shell perfectly. The magnet that secures the cover to the ipad is also strong, so the fit is very good (especially for a knock-off)

The negative: the materials for the smart cover are very lightweight. Mine came with several indentations & I'm confident that there will be many more as the case gets used. The BIGGEST negative is that the rubber on both sides of the case is VERY slick, your expensive new iPad Air could very easily slip out of your hand. As a minimalist case it doesn't offer a whole lot of protection, so a 'tacky' grip on the case is vital in my opinion. This was almost a deal-breaker for me.

Work-around: rubberized spray paint from a big-box for $5: http://www.amazon.com/Performix-11203-Multi-Purpose-Coating-Aerosol/dp/B0006SU3QW/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1394827333&sr=8-3&keywords=plasti+dip

After spraying a few even coats on both sides of the case (pay special attention to the corners, otherwise it will peel) the case is very easy to carry around with one hand. It does add a slight amount of gloss to the finish, but it still looks professional & clean.

2-stars removed because the original manufacturer should have done a better job in making the case easy to hold.
output: Excellent fit, so-so materials.  After $5 modification, it's great

Instances.input:
I bought the Dell U3011 monitor in November 2012. I upgraded from a older HP W2408 1080P monitor.
I am very interested in Exceptional video displays and have been using Sony XBR TVs ever since they came out and wanted the best display for my office so this is the one I got.
At first I used the Apple dual link DVI cable and occasionally when the computer woke up from sleep the monitor would be fuzzy. I would turn it off and on and it would be fine.
Then I decided to try the Display port to mini display port connection!!!
What a difference. the monitor never goes fuzzy when the laptop wakes up from sleep and man is it beautiful and bright just how I like my displays.
The Dell monitor comes with a Display port cable so I bought ehe Accell Display port to mini display port adapter here on Amazon and it works beautifully.(the one I got is the [[ASIN:B003TSDG06 Accell B112B-001B UltraAV Mini DisplayPort/DisplayPort(f) Adapter (Black)]] here on Amazon for less than $15. It works perfect!

I do not recommend the Apple dual link adapter for $99 for Apple computers but do highly recommend the Accell display port to mini display port adapter and this Dell U3011 monitor if you like big beautiful and bright.
I do web development and Photoshop and it works excellent.

Pros:
Bright
Easy to unpack and set up
beautiful colors
Big
adjustable height
tilt
All cables included

cons
a bit expensive but you get what you pay for.

I am typing this on my new Apple Mac Mini Server hooked up to the Dell U3011 monitor using the display port cable that came with the monitor and the display port to mini display port adapter I mentioned in the review above. It works perfectly.
output: Love it with my MacBook Pro and Mac Mini Server

Fits well in hand, worked immediately upon plugging in, I like the back button on the thumb.

Only issue is the small pads it sits on aren't exactly flat, so when the left click button is pressed, there is a slight rocking motion as the mouse tips forward and then back when released. Seems like a minor annoycance but I notice it every time.

Arrival time was superb, lovely colour and great case. Fits perfectly, easy to get on. Can't fault it. Really glad I ordered it and am super happy with my new aqua Macbook pro. :) Great! Couldn't be more pleased!

I bought this mouse for PC gaming, and I instantly fell in love with it. It's extremely precise, and I love the on the fly DPI switcher. That's a brilliant feature that I used very often.

The shape of the mouse is also something I'm fond of. I have very large hands, and it fit them nicely while not being overly large itself and I loved the way it felt when I gripped it. My fiancee has small hands and she did not like using it, so take that for what you will.

The downside to this product is that it's not very durable. My first one malfunctioned after a few months use and would basically experience enormous levels of input lag that would make any practical use impossible. I loved the mouse so much that I immediately bought a second one, thinking that it was just a one time defect or some such. Sadly, I was wrong, as the same thing happened to the second mouse a few months later, too. Same problem, same mouse.

I don't particularly abuse my electronics and for how good this mouse is it's fairly cheap, so I'm going to write that up to something they overlooked or cut costs on in the manufacturing process.

I really would love to be writing a glowing 5 star review of this mouse, because when it's brand new I like it more than any other mouse I've ever used. But, sadly, they just don't last and I can't recommend buying this if you're not okay with replacing it every few months.

I'd love to still be using this mouse today, but I'm not.
output: This is a wonderfully precise mouse, but it's not very durable

Instances.input: This review isn't going to be very helpful because I'm simply too pissed off to get into any details about what happened.  This computer lasted about a month and crashed 3 times.  I've been playing phone tag with Toshiba ever since.  I finally gave up and gave this the deep six.  Maybe it was just bad luck. Not sure, but this computer was crap.

First of all, as is customary of all Bose products, nowhere in the world can you find the power rating for this set of PC speakers. The specs on the single instructions sheet says the AC adapter is rated 22W maximum output, so my guess, as a layperson, is that the speakers output no more than 22W combined. My old Logitech speaker bar for laptops is rated at 20W, but this Bose set definitely sounds more powerful than the Logitech.

There is no lack of volume on these speakers. The instructions recommend you set your PC's volume to 75%; I set the volume on my Toshiba laptop to 50% since this particular model, A665, has a high-quality audio chip. Even when the Bose's volume knob is set to the middle, I get enough sound to fill both my dining room, where I keep the Toshiba, and the adjacent living room! Pretty impressive. Of course, these speakers are not small, and they actually feel heavy when I move them around.

What I don't quite like is these speakers output too much bass. It's interesting to note that the first thing you'll see upon opening the box is a small sheet advising you that Bose, founded by an Indian engineer named Bose, does not jack up bass or treble like \\"other speakers.\\" Well, my Logitech has a very neutral sound quality, which makes it suitable for all kinds of audio programs as well as tweaking if I so choose. The Bose, to my ears, has too much bass and forces me to tone down the bass via Windows settings, something I shouldn't have had to do. My husband and I tested the Bose over a large variety of music ranging from classical to heavy metal to Bollywood... Yes, I'm a fan of Bollywood films and music... :) We both agreed there was too much bass... This can readily cause a headache when you sit so close to the computer and hence these speakers! My solution is to put them further away from my PC, that option is limited cuz the speaker cords are not too long. And it definitely does not sound (no pun intended) like Bose putmuch thought into producing a neutral sound like my Logitech or a very compact Sony set, contrary to its marketing claims.

Conclusion: this is a good set of PC speakers with tons of volume. If you love bass or are half deaf due to years of listening to loud music, you'll love this set. If you want the best quality of sound, these are not what you're looking for.
output: Powerful sound, but a bit too much bass at default setting

I had just received a cherry Amazon Kindle Fire HDX on eBay for pennies and I waited for it to arrive to make sure I was satisfied with it and then I went to order a case.

You are presented with myriad options on here. I really didn't want a generic Belkin. On the other hand, I didn't want something clever like a case that looks like an old book. So after reading the reviews and swallowing hard, I plunked down $45 for the case, half of what I paid for a mint HDX (the person did a poor job listing it).

I was a little dubious as reviews seemed to be 50-50.

I am quite happy with it. The magnets held the HDX right in place and it is great in both horizontal and vertical modes. If I were to have a complaint, and it is picayune, is it doesn't stand well on the glass dining room table. But putting a paper towel under it fixes the problem. The front cover panel itself sticks well, also with magnets. At first you think it is flimsy, but it is quite strong. The origami is clever and once you "get it" (read the insert that says "read first"), you are fine. I am pretty careful with my HDX, though I fling it onto my bed. No problems. I am sure one of these days I will drop it and I am sure it will be fine.

You are in for $40 no matter what you do if you get an HDX. I think this product is either up your alley or not at all. No in between. Though I don't know if it is a production error or what, but the people who say the Kindle pops out baffle me. You have to have to strength of Samson to pull it out once it is in.

I like mine. Do I recommend it? Well, there aren't too many options out there. Of the choices, I like this best.

I’ll keep this short and to the point. I bought this Archer C5 to replace my Asus because the Asus had a few problems and was cutting me off of the Net. I went all over the net looking for reviews that were not written by the company that made it. After reading about a lot of routers and taking price into consideration, this looked like the best bang for the buck.

Once installed I went to several internet speed test sites to try it out. I have Cox as my ISP. I didn’t use the Cox Site for obvious reasons. I did make tests at cox in the past year and my upload was around 12Mbps. Download around 80Mbps. The download speed is not too shabby. Of course I am paying a Premium to get that speed.

Now for the Archer C5 tests. I went to three different sites and the results surprised me.
Upload averaged around 11Mbps. No surprise there. Download speeds averaged 115Mbps! Now that is fast! I feel I bought the best router I could in the $75.00 range.

The installation was difficult for me. I puttered around for a long time and stopped to read the installation instructions and got lost several times. The install sheet lead me to believe that I had to connect an Ethernet cord from the router to my laptop during install. There are a couple of ways to do the installation and one involved using a mini disk. I have noticed many posts that have a person doing the whole install in 15 minutes! It took me that long to open the box and lay everything out and do an initial read of the instructions. 15 minutes? Yah sure.

You won’t be sorry after buying this router.

This speaker works as advertised, and it definitely is louder and produces a better sound than, say, putting your phone into a cup. It is also easy to set up, so if you bring it to a friend's it wouldn't be a hassle to connect their phone before listening to something they want to share (although I definitely see it not happening). There are some drawbacks, however. As some other reviewers have pointed out, the bass isn't very good and it can sound a little tinny, but hey, only 20 bucks, right? It would also be nice if it came with some kind of carrying case, and the suction, while a nice function, won't stick to every kind of phone case, and it's quite likely you'll just pick up your phone to change songs anyway. The instructions, too, are pretty bizarre, almost like they were translated by Google, creating more initial confusion than necessary.

Nice to have, it would probably make a nice, easy gift, but not a must buy.
output: Good for what it is, not great

Instances.input: Great server for a great price.

The Good:

The privacy feature is AWESOME!! Works exactly as advertised and works well. The person even sitting next to me in public transportation cannot see what I am viewing.

The Bad:

The product didn't quite fit my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1\\". I had to cut 3/16\\" of an inch on two sides in order to fit properly and the camera hole to match. So, if you buy this for the same Samsung tablet, you might want to consider getting your razor blade and straight edge ready. Perhaps they will correct this since the tablet is a new model that is somewhat recently released (hopefully).

The instructions said to peel back a couple of inches of the backing and the start from one end, pushing out all of the bubbles along the way. The first try was NOT good. A part of the sheet that you peel off ended up sticking to the screen, although I was careful. Well, I couldn't have a 1/2\\" area with a bump in the middle of my screen, so I took it off and under the sink and ran some warm water over it and gently scraped it off. The second try wasn't good either. Lots of bubbles that seemed next to impossible to get completely out. The third try, I tried a different application process. After again thoroughly washing with dish soap and warm water, I kept the soapy water on the adhesive side. Gently, I positioned the screen on my tablet at the correct location. Then, going from the center outward, I used my credit card from my wallet (there was no squeegee card included) wrapped it in their soft cloth (included), and pushed the bubbles out. This worked SO much better. The bubbles came out much easier and the results were much, much better.

My advice to someone who purchases this product to NOT follow their directions as they say. Just peel off the backing (gently) and try the soapy water trick. If you don't succeed, you can remove it and try again. Make sure the tablet is COMPLETELY free from ANY link or dust of any kind.

I purchased this product mostly for the privacy feature. This part works great. 3M claims that it reduces fingerprints. My opinion is that it doesn't help reduce fingerprints much at all. Perhaps it makes it easier to wipe off, but they will still collect as before. I think a big part of that is the high gloss texture of the screen. As far as cutting the glare from the LCD, it works great. Much less eye strain.

As it stands now, my biggest complaint is that I had to cut it in order to fit my particular tablet. In the end, it all worked out, though.

Five dollars for an iPad SD card reader? Yeah right. That's what I thought when I first saw this product listed, at least. How could you possibly trust something that cheap to get the job done? But I was not willing to spend the money for the official Apple product so I took a chance. After all, what did I have to lose? Just five bucks that could probably have been refunded if it didn't work. But, surprisingly, it did. I was really quite surprised and quite pleased. I got the adapter just a day before I went backpacking in Europe and I didn't have much faith in it. Go figure, just a few weeks later I was sitting in a bunk in my hut in the Alps uploading and editing photographs with ease. This little device worked perfectly. Well, maybe not perfectly. Often times it says that it's not connected to the iPad when it actually is working just fine. And the construction itself is a little on the cheap side. I'm always afraid of breaking it. But I haven't so far and after a few months of use it's still trucking along. I know some people have given it a 1-star rating but if you approach with this item with the low expectations a five dollar piece of third-party equipment deserves you'll be surprised. It does the job - maybe not as pretty or smoothly as an official periphery device from Apple would - and you can't complain too much about that.
output: I Was Skeptical But You Certainly Cannot Beat the Price
