I'm an enthusiastic camper and backpacker who loves making campfires, and I also have a wood burning fireplace that I use a lot.
Lately I've been looking for a really good 'upgrade' axe or hatchet, both for camping and for splitting smaller logs up to 12-18" for the home fireplace.

After a lot of research, I settled on two FISKARS products, this X7 Hatchet and the 28-inch F25 axe. I'm totally pleased. They've exceeded al expectations, and I'm going to review each of them.
Other than size, their designs are identical, so everything I'm about to say applies to both the X7 Hatchet and the X25 Axe equally.

Long story short, these Fiskars' are really excellent. This is easily the best hatchet I've ever owned, including my Estwing all-steel hatchet and a number of very good vintage hickory-handle hatchets from Plumb and other USA makers.
Those are all great cutting tools, but this Fiskars is on a whole different level.
It's like comparing a modern Glock polymer .40 semiauto to a 1917 Colt .38 revolver. Both are great, but the newer design clearly outperforms.

The Fiskars has a completely hollow handle, which is a huge weight savings. That fiberglass handle is virtually indestructible; the Fiskars website shows a video of a big truck rolling over those handles without any damage.
So unlike wooden handles, this one won't break. It's totally immune to understrikes. It's amazing, and if I didn't own these I would have found it hard to believe.

And if you do somehow manage to break it, Fiskars has a lifetime warranty. If your Fiskars ever breaks, just email them a photo of the broken tool and they will ship you a replacement for free.

Fiskars' blade shape is like a splitting wedge, which is why it splits so well. The angle of the wedge on the hatchet is the same exact angle as on my 28" Fiskars axe.
By contrast, most other hatchets (and most axes) use a more knife-like shape which slices in, but does not wedge wood apart very well.
The Fiskars does both. It also arrives VERY sharp out of the box, unlike many other brands of hatchet/axe.

There are many homemade owner videos and reviews on youTube showing the Fiskars products slicing and splitting BIG logs, often with a single strike. It looks too good to be true, but these are not faked videos. I know because my Fiskars gives the same performance. I'd say 60-70% of the time I can split with one good strike. It's rare to take more than two strikes.
The design of the Fiskars is that ergonomic and the wedge shaped blade is that effective.

Fiskars uses a relatively soft steel, which means it is more prone to dent or roll on the edge. On the other hand, it's very unlikely to chip.
So plan on sharpening your Fiskars periodically, but that should only take a couple of minutes.
Fiskars makes a $10 sharpener specifically for their axes and hatchets. I don't own it yet but there are rave reviews on all the blade forums and websites.

About the sheath: The Fiskars do not come with traditional sheaths. (I wish they did). Instead they come with a lightweight plastic snap-in holder which protects the blade, but is not designed for belt carry.
There's a clever youTube video in which an owner shows his modifications of the factory Fiskars sheath.
Basically he cuts off the useless plastic loop at top and drilled 2 sets of 2 holes (4 total), then runs Paracord through the 2 sets of holes to make Paracord belt loops.
You could also just cut off that top loop and use the holder as is, either lashed to our pack or inside it.

Both the 28" X25 Axe and the 14" X7 hatchet are totally outstanding. There's also a F11 "splitting hatchet" and an F27 36" long "splitting axe" with even more effective wedge shaped blades. I don't own either of these, but the video reviews are impressive and I would recommend checking these out. I chose the X7 for backpacking and light weight, but if weight did not matter and I wanted a 'car camping' or base camp/cabin hatchet, I would have chosen the F11 instead.
I found my X25 axe for a giveaway price at a garage sale, but if I were going to buy it again at full retail I would spend the few extra dollars for the 36" F27, even though the X25 I found performs great and does a great job.
The 28" X25 works so well I'll probably never be able to justify buying the longer 36" X27.

Outstanding products. I totally recommend these, and the price on Amazon (around $25 for the X7 hatchet, around $45 for the X25 axe) is a steal for the quality you get. The X7 hatchet is also available at a lot of Wal-Marts in the camping department, and some WalMarts and all Home Depot's carry the X25 axe at around $45-50. These sometimes go on seasonal sales as well. So there's no need to overpay online.

I hope this is helpful as you comparison shop online. Happy trails and safe chopping, everybody.ut. I chose the X7 for backpacking and light weight, but if weight did not matter and I wanted a 'car camping' or base camp/cabin hatchet, I would have chosen the F11 instead.

I bought the Audigy 2 NX to hook into my laptop into my surround receiver. I'm especially pleased with the CMSS 3D surround "up-sample" feature. CMSS 3D beats SRS Circle Surround 2 upsampling (which only provides a mono signal to the surround speakers) easily, and is very competitive (although quite different!) with Dolby Pro Logic II upsampling.
However, I have several issues/problems.
1) The Audigy doesn't remember the mixer volume settings (eg Master and Wave) across a power up/down cycle of the Audigy hardware. I really hate having to go in and reset the volume every time I turn the system on.
2) I would like to apply CMSS 3D to my radio and other analog signals, but cannot because CMSS 3D does not get applied to "line in" signals, only to Wave signals.
3) There is no way to set the speaker distance to compensate for speakers that are at differing distances from the listening position. Competitor products like the M-Audio Sonica Theatre and stereo receivers have this capability.
4) There is no speaker size setting (eg small, medium, large) to ensure proper bass management. If the surround speakers are small, bass going to them should be routed to the front speakers or subwoofer (if present). Again, the M-Audio Sonica Theatre has this capability, as do stereo receivers.
5) It would be really useful to have VU meters for input and output (all channels) built into the driver. The M-Audio Sonica Theatre has very useful VU meters. Unfortunately the M-Audio also makes my system (XP) crash!
6) I find all the different "consoles" to be confusing and time-consuming to launch. They should combine the Surround Mixer, EAX, Graphic Equalizer, and Speaker consoles.
Fits fine unless there is a case about the iPad.  Well made, and well designed.  I would prefer a larger case allowing extra space for a case, but most iPad owners I know do not prefer cases.

The battery does not last as long as they say it does unless you keep it in sleep mode and barely use it but it still has an amazing battery life I cannot complain about it at all, turn the brightness down your eyes will adjust and you will save some battery and also kill your apps when not in use to help extend the battery.

The internet browser (Silk I think it is called) Is amazingly fast in speed, but you cannot watch allot of video content on websites which is a downfall. But definetly faster than most browsers out there.

Well I don't know anything else to say except for the price I do not think you can beat the Kindle Fire HD. It was actually a gift so even better for me! I would recomend this product I believe you will enjoy it very much. Some reason people think it is not bluetooth compatable which is false for mine anyway it does have bluetooth so you can use a wireless keyboard on it.

Oh and the antiglare is ok but if the sun comes through a window when watching a movie you will probably have to move if you want to enjoy the movie. Okay I think I am done now so the only downfall I really have is not with the device but with them not adding very much to the Prime movies hopefully it will get better.

I am no expert on reviews or testing devices I just thought I would recomend this after using it since Christmas being very impressed by it overall.
output: It is great for the price.

Instances.input: I bought this to hack out the Cam for another project, it is a nice little board Cam that is easy to get out of the case without damaging the Cam.  There are 6 bright white LED's mounted to the board with the Cam, they can be easily disabled as they have a separate  power lead ( gray ). There is a push button switch (N/O) for taking stills that can be snipped off as well.  Keep in mind that it is a 5 volt Cam and exceeding that will fry this Cam!  The little fold out ring on the base allows you to hang the Cam on the top of your monitor. Some reviewers seemed to wish that this unit had IR LED's thankfully that is not the case since this unit is to be pointed at your face. Recent research has shown that IR light directed into the eyes can lead to cataracts!   I found almost no time lag in the video, this effect may be due to limited memory or the way your software handles the images. I could not find a similar board Cam for less than $20.00 so this is a great bargain.

It comes up with the error \\"No USB smart card device found\\" but this cac reader is listed in device manager as \\"USB Smart Card Reader\\" and not \\"SCR3310.....\\" as others have mentioned (on another site). I guess none of this is really relavent to the actual device review,but I hope to shed some insight to some potential buyers on what to possibly experience if they purchase this for a MAC OSX 10.6 system. Why I love my Kindle:    - I don't have to turn the pages, so I can read with just one hand.  - Its feel and style still give that \\"book\\" experience.  - Since the buttons are on both sides, I can hold it with either hand.  - It weighs so little, my hands don't get tired from holding it.  - I can carry an entire library in my purse.   - If I get bored with one book, I press a few buttons and I'm reading another.  - I can read in the sun, unlike back-lit devices.   - My place is automatically saved, across several books.  - I save a lot of money since Kindle books are usually much cheaper than their print versions.  - My electronic books don't use paper, so I save trees.  - I can download books anywhere thanks to 3G, so no matter where I am, I'm never stuck without a book.  - I can search books. Instances.input:
Just a short review - there's one thing about this headset I want people to know.

If you search Corsair's forums, you'll encounter aging threads where people are complaining / have complained about their sound channels reversing.

I've used this headset for a solid year and I'm about sick of them. Going to attempt RMA and ask for newer revision and, if that won't fly, going to consider something from Plantronics, Astro or Sennheiser. In Skyrim, Counter Strike, Metro: Last Light and Battlefield 3, after a period ranging from fifteen minutes to several hours, the sound channels just suddenly reverse. Everything's fine... then boom, jacked. Sounds from the left are now in my right ear and vice-versa. Corsair has no idea what causes this (it's C-Media software or on-board USB soundcard, my guess), there is no fix (last C-Media update is several YEARS old), but hey, the warranty is good so I appreciate that from them.

This sucks, really, because Corsair is a respectable corp. with tons of goodwill from gamers and has other product lines which are somewhat strong. I really wanted to like these and do enjoy the larger speaker drivers (not to be confused with software), comfort and build quality. This issue, though, strikes many users, without warning, and it's not an issue with USB or Windows. Buyer beware.

I'll update here with a status on RMA.

In my original review I wrote that I was very disappointed with this product because the wake/sleep feature did not function. I also stated I read in other reviews that MKT Distribution was a family business that had an excellent customer service reputation and I would wait to see if I was contacted by them through Amazon.

Well, to my great surprise, the owner of the company, Rick Jen, telephoned me personally within about seven hours after I posted the review expressing my disappointment. In fact, he tried to reach me earlier, but I did not check the feedback box when I placed my order to permit this. So, he sent an email to everyone from the last thirty days with my posting name hoping he would obtain the purchase information. Once I responded, he then called me almost immediately. Rick strongly expressed his regret that I had a bad experience, but stated that because the case is hand stitched, the magnets were probably placed slightly out of position. Plus, he said this was only the second time a defect of this type occurred in the history of the product. Since we talked on a Friday evening, he then told me a new case would be shipped via overnight delivery the following Monday. After receiving it and examining all of the features, I now love it. The fit and appearance are great, it functions as advertised, so now I would highly recommend buying this case.

To say I was impressed with Rick and the manner in which the situation was rectified to my complete satisfaction is an understatement. He truly went the extra mile, and I only wish more businesses operated with such professionalism, courtesy, and integrity.
output: From a 1 Star Rating to a 5

Instances.input: The Gateway DX4850-27EU is a fast and aesthetic computer which i feel beats all of it's competitors remotely near it's price range. The Sandy bridge second generation Intel I5 quadcore processor is very impressive and i'm also running 16gb of ram so it's very fast. The 1.5TB hardrive is just overkill for me considering i already have a 3TB external drive, but it's a good overkill, it gives me more space than i know what to do with because the 1.5TB alone is massive. The hardrive speed isn't the quickest but it's no where near slow enough to even notice or complain about because it works great. There's enough PCI-E slots to allow upgrades to make up for anything this computer lacks. Although this thing is covered in usb 2.0's, there are no 3.0's, which would have been a problem but i picked up a PCI-E card to fix that. It could also have a Blu-Ray drive but it's really not a big deal and if you want one you can add it whenever. There is a tray on the top of the computer which is awesome if you have ipods, phones, or any other accessories plugged in on a regular basis as they just sit on top along with their usb ports. When this computer is turned on it really shines, no pun intended. The outline of the computer lights up with a bright aesthetic glow which surprised me because aside from powerful i didn't expect this computer to look half as good as it does. Don't worry though, the lights can be turned off via a button on top. The disc tray opens from a button on the right side of the computer so don't freak out and think the disc tray is broken, it's just too rad to comprehend, like the rest of this computer. The motherboard reads Acer for all of those who hate Gateways. Gateway is now Acer. So basically you get the awesome Gateway logo lighten up (which was always the best part of Gateway) with Acer power. If you want to do high graphic gaming, i would get a Video card, but you will be limited as the power supply for this computer isn't too large. Honestly though, the onboard HD graphics are awesome and can run any game i've played thus far on high graphics. Age of Empires 3 for example, runs great on high graphics! So unless you're some hardcore gaming maniac (if which case you shouldn't even be reading this because it's under 10 billion dollars and probably only a little worse than a what you're looking for anyway) you should be fine. There's also HDMI, and you can run HDMI and VGA to have dual-monitors, which is what i do. In conclusion, this computer is a very cheap way of bringing yourself into the next generation of computing. Great purchase.he onboard HD graphics are awesome and can run any game i've played thus far on high graphics. Age of Empires 3 for example, runs great on high graphics! So unless you're some hardcore gaming maniac (if which case you shouldn't even be reading this because it's under 10 billion dollars and probably only a little worse than a what you're looking for anyway) you should be fine. There's also HDMI, and you can run HDMI and VGA to have dual-monitors, which is what i do. In conclusion, this computer is a very cheap way of bringing yourself into the next generation of computing. Instances.input: I am a pc user of more than 25 years; my first purchase was an IBM XT.   I purchased a hp m8430 desktop system from Amazon several years ago for around $700.   I had recently decommissioned a Compaq laptop that I had been delighted with. It lasted six years. I had used other HP products and was a loyal customer, based on their performance.     The desktop was trouble from the start. I complained to customer service the day the warrantee ran out, and they would not honor it.     Soon thereafter, the machine became too slow to use despite Norton's then version of what is currently 360. HP customer service was extremely polite but totally incompetent. It was mostly Indian in India, but the problem wasn't language. They didn't know what they were doing. slowness was maddening. Their highest level tech told me to recover the main drive. I had backed up the drive using the HP utility, according to instructions. Although I am no geek, it appeared they had superimposed their logo on IBM's backup system. After recovery, the backup restoration did not work due to some problem with their software. With the help of an outside vendor recommended by HP, Omnitech, which charged me $200 for a year's service, I was able to get access to my files, although the directory structure and access had been damaged by the HP backup/restore system.     The slowness crept back after the year, during which Omnitech personnel had regular access to my commputer to keep it running at a reasonable speed. This invasion of privacy at a yearly cost 30% of the computer was not welcome, though necessary.     After the contract ran out, the slowness returned. I complained to HP and pushed it up the corporate ladder. Eventually, I reached the CHIEF of the pc division, who told me that since the unit was out of warrantee, he would do nothing to help me.     I resolved at that moment never, ever to purchase another HP product again. I am writing this review to notify potential victims of their customer service that if service is an important factor in your purchase, you ought to consider another company on that basis.

I had to disassemble the case just to force it in. Because it's so long, I'm unable to mount one of the fans to the top of my case.    Other than than, if you're looking for a power supply that will last a long time, this is it.

Instances.input: I have run this CPU for near onto three years.  I bought when it was the best i7 on the market.  As a gamer, I demand a lot out of my hardware, and this CPU has never failed to meet those demands.  I upgraded from a dual core 3.4ghz Intel, and although this runs at 3.2, loosing the front side bus was totally worth it.  My former CPU transferred data between cores at 800mhz, so no matter how fast I clocked it, there was latency built into the chip.  By building the host memory controller for the cores into the CPU, Intel was able to speed up performance significantly.  I went from a barley playable flight simulator x to one that ran smooth.  Although there are few programs that utilize four cores, having them available insures that computing will remain smooth for a while to come.  The CPU will shut down inactive cores, and boost the remaining cores internally by a percentage.  It will also ramp down the CPU if the needs are fewer than that available.  Having the Extreme version of this chip, means the core multiplier is unlocked, and the speed is really only held back by the available power, and cooling in the computer.  I have overclocked my machine to 4ghz stable.  I would recommend purchasing a third party cooler, and getting good thermal paste when purchasing this CPU as it runs hot.  I use the Chilltec thermal-electric cooler.  It combines a heat pipe, and pellitier solution that is better than most water systems, without introducing water into the case.  You will not be disappointed with this CPU.

I got this little gem going on my Debian system with ease by the following steps:    1) # apt-get install nvidia-detect  2) # nvidia-detect  This utility will come back with a recommendation to install the appropriate driver.  In this case it is the nvidia-glx package.  3) # apt-get install nvidia-glx  This will install the driver along with a  number of dependencies.  4) # mkdir /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d  5) # echo -e 'Section \"Device\"
	Identifier \"My GPU\"
	Driver \"nvidia\"
EndSection' > /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/20-nvidia.conf  6) # reboot  After rebooting run the NvIdia Settings utility to verify that everything is as it should be.  Under the section PowerMizer I set my system to Prefer Maximum Performance.

I have been using the UD-3900 universal docking station for about 2 weeks now and am extremely happy. I have test using the docking station with 4 different systems (2 desktops and 2 laptops all different brands/builds.) The only issue I encountered was that with my new ultrabook (HP Elitebook) that I cannot connect the laptop to the UD-3900 until after Windows 8 boots to the login screen. This was not case with desktops or with the Lenovo 410 laptop I tested with the docking station, so I believe it is just a quirk with the laptop (or even Windows 8) and not a problem with the UD-3900. I have the UD-3900 output (2 USB ports and the DVI port) connected to a USB-based KVM, and it works perfectly. The USB 3.0 ports on the front of the UD-3900 work great, too, as I have two external drives (a 1TB drive and a 2TB drive) connected. Windows 7 and Windows 8 both see my monitors, mouse, keyboard, and external hard drives as the actual devices, too; no "generic" drivers used by the OS. The UD-3900 is compact and looks sleek is sitting neatly on the corner of my desk. Using it takes up less space than my two old docking stations made for my laptop models. I compared a lot of features among several universal docking stations and opted to purchase the UD-3900 although it was not the cheapest vs. a couple others, but I can tell you it is worth every penny. The UD-3900 is easy to setup and use with any system that has a USB 3.0 port available to connect up to the UD-3900. It does not make any noise and does not appear to produce any heat. It is lightweight and doesn't take up a lot of real-estate on a desk. Please be sure to install the drivers (per the instructions) before attempting to connect a system to the UD-3900 or else it won't work.

Instances.input:
I'm a software developer with over 20 years experience. I've always been interested in electronics but every time I tried in the past to learn on my own, there has been nothing to keep me interested in the long haul. I bought a book on electronics (basically the same that would be used in a college course) but without any practical training, the theory got tedious. I bought a Radio Shack hundred in one electronics project kit but that took the fun of actually creating the circuits away from me. Not to mention there was no programming involved.

TLDR; pros: it's a great kit for getting started; one of the less expensive starter kits with a lot of value; up and running in minutes
cons: the book is too small for reading (I think there's a pdf on the disc but I don't have an optical drive; the company website doesn't exist; you'll lose a lot of sleep tinkering with circuits

I've heard good things about the Arduino as a great tool for learning electronics and finally decided to jump on the bandwagon when my daughters expressed interest in learning how to program. I want to make it fun for them and fun for me at the same time. I did research on Arduino vs Raspberry PI and came to the conclusion that while the Raspberry PI is a very interesting device, it's higher level than where I wanted to start. So I look through several offerings and land on the Sunfounder Super Starter Kit Uno (in retrospect I should have gotten the Mega but I didn't realize what the difference between the two are).

When the package came in the mail, I couldn't wait to get home and try it out. I also purchased [[ASIN:"1118549368" Exploring Arduino]] as a learning guide. After going through the first three chapters of the book and making the projects, I looked at the clock and realized it was 3AM.

From making the onboard LED blink to creating my first circuit to make an led on a breadboard blink, I came to the realization that electronics isn't the boogie man I've made it out to be in my mind. In fact as a programmer, I have a leg up. I'm used to working with components that when I send it input X, I get result y. Now instead of just being confined to the digital world, I can make software that controls physical objects.

And there are so many physical objects to control. You can buy a touch sensitive screen for 35 dollars and build your own digital universal remote. Or get a bluetooth module for 15 and communicate with your smart phone. The touch sensitive ring in the first iPod can be had for 2.50...the possibilities are truly limited by your imagination. And this is just a beginner's board. What comes next is up to you.he boogie man I've made it out to be in my mind. In fact as a programmer, I have a leg up. I'm used to working with components that when I send it input X, I get result y. Now instead of just being confined to the digital world, I can make software that controls physical objects.

And there are so many physical objects to control. You can buy a touch sensitive screen for 35 dollars and build your own digital universal remote. Or get a bluetooth module for 15 and communicate with your smart phone. The touch sensitive ring in the first iPod can be had for 2.50...the possibilities are truly limited by your imagination. And this is just a beginner's board. What comes next is up to you.
output: The Gateway to Your New Addiction.

Instances.input: This is a nice solid mount for a 2.5 inch drive.  But, if you have a quality case that uses rubber insulated mounts for the 3.5 inch drives, you won't be able to use your normal drive mount screws for this bracket.  In my case, the 3.5 inch drive are mounted by passing the screws through rubber grommets in the frame that holds the drives.  The threaded holes in this bracket are non-standard - not threaded the same as the mounting holes in the typical 3.5" drive.  So, you are forced to use the screws that come with this frame, but, they have very small heads and are too short for the grommets.  All this could have been avoided it they had just used the standard mounting screw size and threads.

In a nutshell: A cheap, competent wireless keyboard that excels in HTPC work. Some quibbles and questionable build quality hold it back.

Background: I have come across this keyboard multiple times. I initially bought the keyboard for the home HTPC, which played nicely with the computer it was hooked up to. After that, we decided to roll it out to the use for a startup company I am working for.

What it is: It's a tenkeyless (meaning, no number pads on right side of keyboard) keyboard, with touchpad on the right side of the keyboard, all the function keys are small, and some additional keys on the top left corner. On the very top left is the secondary left mouse button; it comes in surprisingly handy. The keys are slightly smaller than your regular keyboard--think Eee PC (netbook) keyboards.

Pros: Logitech hit the sweet spot for the no-frills HTPC keyboard. Using the touchpad while holding it with your hand is as natural as you can make it; you move your cursor with the right thumb, while left clicking with your left thumb over the secondary left click button. It's light. Keeping multiple keyboards of the same kind in relative proximity is no problem, as well; they don't seem to interfere each other's signals. They keystroke is adequate, although it's no mechanical keyboard. Think budget laptop keyboard. On/off toggle is present and relatively easy to find. The keyboard regularly hits $29.99 or less; great value for money.

Cons: Right shift key has shrunk (which is no problem on its own) and was placed on the right side of the up key. That makes it very hard to type naturally. Shrunk keyboard takes some getting used to for typing quickly. The lightness of the keyboard actually gets in the way for typing from the lap. There's no backlight--but you shouldn't expect it with a budget HTPC keyboard. Lack of right mouse button on the upper left corner of the keyboard is a missed chance; it would have been infinitely more convenient with it. Build quality is questionable; it flexes very easily.

In conclusion: It's no home run, but it's probably the best HTPC keyboard I have used so far. Just don't try to do heavy typing work on it.
output: Great HTPC keyboard; some quibbles for general purpose.

Instances.input:
I've always been a desktop type person. I few months back I tried an Asus 15.6 laptop with an Intel Celeron 1007u, 4 GB memory, and 320 GB HD. I returned that device and didn't think of getting another laptop. I then saw this and was interested on purchasing it for it's low price($299.99 at Best Buy). Some of my comments will be comparing it to that Asus.

Here are some of my comments:
- The build quality is pretty decent. When I first got it, the lid would occasionally creak as I opened it. It seems to have gone away now. The keyboard area is also very sturdy. This area doesn't bend as you type as you might find on other cheap laptops. The lid seems to be a huge dust magnet though for some reason.

- The screen is ok. It could be better. The viewing angles are ok, much better than the Asus'. In a room with a window on the ceiling, the screen was very hard to see even on maximum brightness. I could only see the screen if I went to a darker part of the room.

- Processor = It's meant for battery life(it's supposed to be a tablet processor). It could handle most things without a problem. Videos were not playable while on AMD's Power Save Mode(which makes it run at about .6 GHz per core). With the base clock of about 1 GHz, videos loaded ok, but were sometimes jumpy. I could play games such as World of Wacraft and Simcity on lower settings and low fps. WOW had FPS of about 15-30 with 1366x768 resolution and just a few settings above the lowest. This processor features Turbo Dock mode. Turbo Dock is meant to activate when you put a tablet onto its dock. Since this is a laptop, it only activates when plugged in unless I'm doing something wrong. Turbo dock makes the max clock at 1.4 GHz and the power save clock at maybe .7 GHz(can't remember the exact number). This makes video playback a lot smoother.

- Memory = Good enough for basic things. The system only uses about 1.8 GB in most cases.

- Fan = This thing is pretty loud. It's dead silent usually when the processor is clocked lower, but when watching video on basic clock speeds, it'll get a little loud.

- Hard Drive = Mine came with a Western Digital Blue drive. It's not the fastest out there, but it gets the job done. I must say though, this drive is incredibly quite. I can barely hear it and it's only a small sound when under full loud. The fan usually drowns out the hard drive sound.

- Graphics = See processor.

- Keyboard = Going from a full size desktop keyboard to a keyboard of a 11.6 laptop is rough. I think the keys were pretty comfortable though and are decent enough.

- Trackpad = Here is where it goes bad. The trackpad randomly becomes possessed. It will once and awhile refuse to tap click anything unless you tap it rapidly. It will also go all over the place as you try to move around. This is supposedly common across all forms of this laptop and there's a large thread about it(I think on the Dell forums). There doesn't seem to be a fix yet. It can be fine for hours and then one minute later go crazy. However, it's a smooth surface to rest your fingers on.

- Touchscreen = Very responsive and doesn't commonly miss any touches. I usually end up using it whenever the trackpad decides to not work right.

- Speakers = I don't know much about how loud laptops get, but this gets pretty loud in my opinion. It can get a little distorted near higher volumes. Music sounds good, but watching any videos with just regular talking sound a little odd off the laptop's speakers. They sound a little echo-y.

- Battery = The battery + the processor equals long battery life. Depending on the settings and what I'm doing I can get about 6-12 hours off a charge. The 3 cell 50 WHr battery is pretty big compared to what you usually find on 11.6 budget laptops. Charges up pretty quickly.

Update:
- I forgot to talk about the webcam. I haven't used it much at all, but it's \\"ok\\" and it's as expected on a budget laptop.
- I also forgot to mention how this laptop comes with a low amount of bloatware. It only contains dell specific software from what I saw.

Feel free to comment on anything I may have missed or any questions you may have that I might be able to answer.

Instances.input:
The glass screen is not easy to scuff or scratch, but protecting it preserves the pristine condition & the resale value. Belkin F8M164eb is durable, masks fingerprints, diffuses ambient light, reduces glare, but also clarity, especially of the crispiest screens, due to the matte finish and the increasing accumulation of the invisible fingerprints. It is easy to remove without a residue left.

First, read the instruction and clean the surface. Tape the protector's edge (the clear backing down) to the surface edge with an alignment strip or a substitute. Flip the protector over the attached edge, lift the protector's backing starting from that edge, and roll the exposed sticky protector's back over the surface slowly covering it with the aid of the edge of the cardboard packaging or a short ruler. Applying light pressure initially allows easy peeling back for corrections, as the adhesive is sensitive to pressure.
output: Durable, masks fingerprints, diffuses ambient light, reduces glare, but also clarity

Instances.input: I have not used this exact Linksys router,  but I have been through four Linksys routers in the past 2.5 years. Currently, I am using an EA3500 which was installed on Jan 28, 2014.  It worked well for about three months and then it started having the same problem as the prior three routers.  It starts dropping you and at first, you reboot your PC and it works again (for a while).  Start a spreadsheet of the date, time, what YOU did to correct it, whether you called Linksys, Name or ID of whom you spoke to at Linksys - add a column for what THEY had you do to resolve it.  Once you realize you are doing this on a every other or daily basis you call Linksys.  First they tell you it must be your ISP - Internet Services Provider (Cox, Verizon, AT&T, etc.), so you hang up and call your cable or other provider and if they don't tell you - ask them how many days your internet has been connected in a row.  You call Linksys back and they tell you that you need to have a computer directly connected to it with a RJ-45 or Ethernet cord. (so much for owning a laptop to use wirelessly).  You connect your PC to the router so now you should be able to get onto the internet.  They immediately tell you that your software must need an update.  They get you signed into their Smart WiFi site and they run an update for the software even if you don't need it.  You will Never see them run the  "is my software up to date"  button because then they might have to look further and do more than an update.  After they run the software they always changed the channels your router is using and tell you that will fix it.  And it does, for about a week. When it starts again, you think about having to bring your PC to where your router is located and sitting there while they try to correct the problem. So - you Google the problem - and you discover that Windows 8 has a new piece of software that resets your router adapter for you which corrects the problem.  You start using this nifty tool andyou think, this isn't so bad, at least I have a network connection.  After a while you realize the problem is persisting and your little fix isn't working all the time.  That is when you start going to the router and unplugging it and plugging it back in again.  Add every little thing you do to your spreadsheet.  For some reason resetting your router and at times your modem seems to work well and you think, its fixed - I solved it.  You get into a project and you are spending a lot of time on your computer and it starts again.  Now it happens when you use your computer for more than checking your email and calendar. You call Linksys and they update the software and change the channel a few more times.  Then out of frustration you go to the library to do work or anywhere they have a free network.  The seasons have changed and getting out isn't so bad.. then one day - you say I've had it and you call Linksys and tell them you can't stand the problems with this router.  The are very polite and tell you that you have only called 7 times in the entire year so it doesn't qualify as a recurrent problem and oh by the way  - your warranty expired.  But they are happy to sell you a new router, a better one - SAY _ NO Thank you and Run to the nearest real store to buy a different brand.  I wish I had... j
Fits my mini ipad with Logitech keyboard perfectly. Just what I wanted plus side pocket for stylus and a screen wipe

This is my third livescribe pen. I have thought with each iteration that the company has improved their product. This one has some features I really like, but it also currently needs a product running iOs7 to get the full benefit from the app. In other words you need a iPhone 4S or higher, iPad 3rd generation or higher, iPad mini 1st Gen or higher or an iPod touch 5th gen or higher. Android support is supposed to arrive this year but no ETA is announced-- which is an annoyance to me since I switched from my iPhone 4S to an Android phone a few weeks ago. So I'll be back to using my Livescribe Sky or Echo

until the Android app makes its appearance.

The pen pairs with your iThing running the app via bluetooth. The audio recording is done through the microphone on your iThing. This is a really big con for me right now, although when I had my iPhone I did find that the recorded audio was superior to the audio recorded on my Sky and Echo. I like the style better. It looks more like a real pen than the prior versions. It's round all the way to the top with a pocket clip to make it more secure to store in a pocket. The top of the pen (opposite the pen point) acts as a stylus. The worse problem I had was getting the removeable stylus tip off in order to charge the pen with the microUSB cable charger cable. The instruction booklet was pretty much no help and I ended up going to the support part of the company web site and searching for information. The cap is on good and tight, which is a plus. The pen point has a rubberized covering that I like better than the hard plastic one on my other two Smart pens. At least I haven't lost it yet.

The pen turns on with a twist of the ring in the middle of the pen which also extends the pen point. Twist the other way and the pen point retracts and the pen turns off. This is the feature I like the best.

This kit comes with everything needed to get started including a rather nice black leather portfolio and a notebook with the special paper you need. It's important to remember that these gadgets are great for specific purposes, but the accessories and supplies are not cheap. I tend to buy Livescribe branded refills, paper and parts. The paper I think can be printed with a sufficiently high grade printer, but I've never thought it worth my time. Also, if you have notebooks that were designed to work with one of the earlier pens you will find that you can use them with the Livescribe 3 as well.

One word of caution. This is a recording device and depending on where you are when you are recording, there are laws about privacy or even wiretapping. Check the laws of your state and remember that if a telephone is involved then you may fall under federal requirements. It's best to get everyone's permission although federal law in the US only requires that one party consents. If you are recording in certain states then all of the parties must consent.

So I really like this version of the Smart Pen and I am looking forward to the Android app.black leather portfolio and a notebook with the special paper you need. One word of caution. This is a recording device and depending on where you are when you are recording, there are laws about privacy or even wiretapping. Check the laws of your state and remember that if a telephone is involved then you may fall under federal requirements. It's best to get everyone's permission although federal law in the US only requires that one party consents. If you are recording in certain states then all of the parties must consent.

So I really like this version of the Smart Pen and I am looking forward to the Android app.
output: Best Smartpen Yet, but You Need an iThing Running iOs7 to Run the App Needed to Use It. Android App Promised for the Future.

WOW!        After reading all the reviews I really cannot believe how bad these are, so so bad. I will start with the two worst features, which in my opinion also happen to be the most important. The sound, my god, these sound bad. Shrill and harsh through the entire reproduced frequency, and as unlikely as it seems, the sound is the most restricted, dull and lifeless out of all the headphones I have listened to, ever. Unlikely to have a small and restricted soundstage? well, with the large 50mm drivers the corsairs are touted as having, I expected a bit more, but got quite a bit less. I dont know how its possible, but these even sound worse than the turtle beach x11's and thats no small feat. At least the turtle beach headphones sound loud, reasonably clear, and open. I could understand how the headphone neophyte might believe the turtle beaches to sound good, there is no doubt with the corsair, these just dont sound good.        These are the heaviest headphones I have ever strapped on my head, even heavier than the already heavy x11's. And, finally these are head clamps, the corsairs relentlessly squeeze your head until blood vessels swell and pop in your eyes. There's really no need to go on with the additional features. I'm really doubting the integrity of the reviews, i see some of the reviews are for the corsair usb headphones, but the manufacturer claims they both have the same drivers. I watched all the videos posted by corsair before I made the purchase, and I bought into what was being said. I feel like a fool, spending 80.00 on something this bad, these headphones aren't just bad for the price, these are bad for any price. This was such an egregious purchase, it made me rethink everything. I spent a high end price for something that was quickly thrown together in china by the lowest contract bidder. I realize its next to impossible to avoid Chinese manufactured products, but these corsair headphones seem to embody absolutely everything that is wrong, andcould go wrong with that process. Its as if these headphones slapped me in the face and said \\"got you\\", then while I was still stunned, it told me your whats wrong with america, you created this economy, you did this.

I do not think I am the first or the last to mention the issue with the scroll wheel, but I feel it is extremely important to state it. The scroll wheel has a tenancy to break. The reason for this is due to the hexagonal catch that locks the scroll wheel into the receiver is made of a cheap rigid plastic that breaks instead of bends when put under enough pressure. The only reason why I still recommend this mouse despite this issue is because the problem is easily fixed. Luckily the wheel can be easily replaced with most mouse wheels, so if you have an old or broken optical mouse just break it open and swap out the wheels.

If you want to replace the mouse wheel or fix any part of the mouse here is what you do.

1) First remove Mazer sticker and the 4 plastic padding underneath the mouse. The screws are hidden beneath them.

2) Remove the screws and place them in a container (they are small and easily lost)

3) Carefully remove the top of the mouse, there are unfastened parts that can easily fall out and be lost

4) Carefully remove the top circuit board from the bottom one, there is a jack (or two, don't remember) connecting the two together. Make sure you remove it without yanking out the port.

5) Remove the broken mouse wheel and replace it with the new one by sliding in the hexagonal piece into the catch, this may require some maneuvering to slide it into place, just make sure you do not bend or break the port.

6) after everything is done, put it all back together remembering the unfastened pieces if they managed to fall out.

If people need further help with fixing this mouse, I may make a video.
output: Great except for the scroll wheel.

I have been a happy Kindle user since the Kindle 2, but after using the Touch for a few years, it was time for an upgrade. I read through the reviews, not sure whether to upgrade to the Voyage or the Paperwhite. My husband has the newest Paperwhite. He's very satisfied with it, and I knew it would be a big upgrade. So the question I needed to settle was whether or not the difference between the Paperwhite and the Voyage would be worth it for me.

I read through multiple reviews and decided on the Voyage. I couldn't be happier with my choice! If you're thinking about this, don't hesitate.

Here's what I like and some of my observations regarding common criticisms:
________
Display
With its 300 dpi resolution, the Kindle Voyage's text display is crisp and clear. Compared side-by-side with the Paperwhite, I can see the difference. Reading on the Kindle Voyage a pleasure, as there are no blurred edges in the text display.

The screen of the Kindle Voyage is smooth and silky in contrast with the screen of the Paperwhite and Touch, both of which feel slightly pebbled. This textured surface was less pleasing to the touch than the new smooth Voyage surface.
________
Screen lighting
I see no evidence of the "two-toned screen" display that other users have cited. Again, compared side-by-side with the Paperwhite, I am pleased with the even tone and "whiteness" of the screen display. I especially like the Auto Brightness function of the Voyage, which is an improvement over the Paperwhite. With the Paperwhite, I notice that my husband keeps his lighting fairly constant and it always appears too bright to me. With the Auto Brightness function turned on, my Kindle Voyage adjusts to the ambient lighting, maintaining a relatively constant screen tone that is neither too bright nor too dim. It is worth noting that you have to turn the Auto Brightness option on under the lighting display, as the default option is manual control.
________
Flush bezel
Amazon continues to refine the design of the Kindle, and the Voyage has undergone some welcome physical changes. In addition to being the lightest and thinnest Kindle to date, the bezel, or frame around the reading screen, is perfectly flush with the reading surface. I am a fan of a clean screen, and with this new design, there are no corners for dust inevitably to settle in to.
________
PagePress
Hallelujah! I'm thrilled to have touch sensors on the frame that allow me to turn pages with the press of a thumb. I tend to read one-handed with the Kindle held lightly along the edges. With the Touch, I adjusted to read with the Kindle balanced in two hands so that one thumb was free to swipe the surface display and turn the page. Now with the Voyage, I can read with the Kindle in one hand and press gently to turn the page forward or back. The surface is still there, but I find myself turning pages with the touch sensors almost exclusively. Both the pressure needed to to turn a page using PagePress and the haptic response (vibration feedback) that the user gets to acknowledge the page turn can be adjusted under Settings. The default setting for both is Medium. I adjusted both my pressure and feedback settings to Low. The feedback setting can be turned off with PagePress still enabled.
________
GoodReads integration
The Amazon site, GoodReads, is integrated with the newest Kindles. My hope is that this will make it easier for me to get good book recommendations! This is a feature of the Paperwhite as well.
________
PageFlip
Again, this is a feature of the Paperwhite, but it wasn't part of my reading experience with the Touch. When reading a book, you can swipe up from the bottom of the page and scan forward and back in the text without losing your place. I appreciate this, as I tend to rescan the text to check a detail . With older Kindle models, I had to skip back or forward and count page turns or recall a significant text string and use the search feature if I had not previously marked a passage. Overall, this feature makes it easier to interact with a text.
________
Speed
Last, but not least, I should note the processing speed difference between the Voyage and the Touch. Using my old Touch, book download speeds were fine, but if I wanted to navigate the Kindle store, I could feel myself growing old and impatient as I waited for a page refresh. When I wanted a new book, I always avoided the Kindle WiFi and went to my laptop, turning the WiFi on on my Kindle only when I was ready to download a new book. The difference in speed between my old Touch and my husband's new Paperwhite was one of the factors that made me commit to an upgrade. With the Voyage (and with the Paperwhite), using WiFi and navigating the Kindle store is no longer painful.ard and count page turns or recall a significant text string and use the search feature if I had not previously marked a passage. Overall, this feature makes it easier to interact with a text.
________
Speed
Last, but not least, I should note the processing speed difference between the Voyage and the Touch. Using my old Touch, book download speeds were fine, but if I wanted to navigate the Kindle store, I could feel myself growing old and impatient as I waited for a page refresh. When I wanted a new book, I always avoided the Kindle WiFi and went to my laptop, turning the WiFi on on my Kindle only when I was ready to download a new book. The difference in speed between my old Touch and my husband's new Paperwhite was one of the factors that made me commit to an upgrade. With the Voyage (and with the Paperwhite), using WiFi and navigating the Kindle store is no longer painful.

Instances.input:
Ordered this PSU in March of 2015 and for 5 months it worked as expected. In August 2015 I began to find that my tower had shut off (lost power) overnight. I suspected the PSU, but plugged the tower into a different UPS just to clear the possibility of an external issue first. The tower continued to shut off at random times. Eventually it got to the point that the tower would shut off within minutes of being turned on.

The fan wasn't coming on with startup, but that isn't unusual for this PSU since it employs an "on demand" fan, however the PSU felt cool to the touch after each failure so I doubted that it was overheating. Rail voltages were within tolerances so it wasn't being shut down by a watchdog circuit, unless the watchdog was faulty.

I swapped out the PSU with an old BFG 500 watt that I had on the shelves and the tower once again ran stable, not shutting down even after several days. With the culprit almost certainly being the RM650, I called Corsair Tech Support. My wait time wasn't overly long and the tech walked me through the steps that I had already completed before he reached the same conclusion I had, namely that the PSU was faulty. He recommended that I use the Corsair Web site to RMA the unit, which I did. I just shipped the PSU, so I'll update as the process moves along.

I was going to 3 star the PSU for now, since it did fail on me in a very short time, but I don't like paying for shipping a heavy PSU back to the manufacturer when it failed through no fault of my own. It's like paying an extra $21 for a working RM650. So I subtracted a star for making me pay to ship the bad unit.

The AmazonBasics Mouse Pad is, as the name suggests, a basic mouse pad sold via Amazon. This mouse pad is enough to get the job done, but if you're looks for a mouse pad with a great surface, ergonomic design or comfortable padding, this is NOT it. For a few bucks you get a 9-inch by 8-inch mouse pad that has a bottom made of thin foam rubber and an even thinner surface made of polyester similar to a cheap T-shirt.

In my opinion there are two problems with this mouse pad:

1) It's too small.
2) It's made of cheap materials.

I've honestly received free mouse pads that are better made than this one, and the 9x8 dimensions don't give you much room to maneuver a mouse if you're got a high-resolution display and a low-res mouse. I frequently had to pick up my mouse and reposition it on the pad or slide my mouse completely off the pad while testing this pad.

Considering that I've used free mouse pads that were given away at banks or at the time I purchased a PC that were better than this mouse pad I'm a little amazed that Amazon is selling this mouse pad for as much as they are.

Again, if you just need a very basic mouse pad then this does indeed get the job done ... it's just there are a lot of other mouse pads out there for around the same price that do the job even better than this.
output: A very, VERY basic mouse pad.

I got the computer and that was fine. I wanted it for video editing and HD editing since I am an avid youtuber. I wanted something that would get the job done. As soon as I got it, I threw in the best low profile card I could possibly find and the only thing I could really find that would fit was a Sapphire Radeon HD 5450 1GB graphics card which barely fit. The thing ran for a good long while. I hate no real problems with it. It did what I needed it to do. It was as fast as I would ever need it to be. It converted and processed videos like a beast and I could also run minecraft without any dip in frame rate or quality. It did what I needed it to do for a little over a year. Then it blue screened upon start up every single time. The hardware failed and I could not get it up and running again. The computer was done and left me in a tough spot. I had to run out and buy a new computer which I should have done in the first place. The computer is what it is.. It's as fast as a whip and has beastly processing power, but it died on me. Take it as you will. It's cheap and got the job done for awhile. Would I get it again? Probably not, but for 100 bucks, it lasted a good year so I say meh. If you really need a cheap computer, you can take a shot in the dark and throw 100 on this. Just don't expect to throw a really nice graphics card in it because it has no space inside for that. You'll be lucky if most low profile cards fit. It was nice while it lasted...

Instances.input:
I'm using it for an Epson R300, which is an older inkjet printer and is *NOT* on the official "supported list". It prints just fine and is solid (I find network printers prefer static IPs, so I assigned a static one for this unit, as well), though the ink level reporting feature does not work. This is okay with me, since the GPSU21 did not claim to support my printer so the fact that it's working at all I count as a plus.

As for Windows 8.1, yes, it definitely works with 8.1 (64 bit) - that what I'm using, as well as another machine running Windows 7. I pre-emptively downloaded the very latest drivers from IOGear rather than installing the ones which came on the CD. I don't know if that was strictly necessary, but it seemed like my best chance for getting good results.

I have an unusual LAN addressing scheme (not 192.168.1.x) but no problems getting set up. The IOGear widget used DHCP at first. The driver software had no problem finding it and reconfiguring it to use a static address was a snap. Overall, very easy to use and it appears, after a week or so of infrequent use, to be a solid product.

My specific configuration has this unit connected via ethernet to a wifi bridge which also serves a laser printer, also with a static IP. Both are getting along fine. The laser printer prefers a static IP, too -- making that change for it some weeks ago solved a lot of problems. It seems the wifi bridge and the printer's DHCP features did not completely get along.
output: Works fine under Win8.1(64), Win7 - easy to install; Use FIXED IP for best results.

Instances.input: As soon as I received this item I was extremely excited and I was completely satisfied when I used it. This device is perfect for anybody that loves to write, whether it's for random stories, writing a book or an essay paper for school or college, this baby does it all. However for first time users it will take a while to get used to like say an hour at least but once you get the hang of it, it'll be like playing the game Portal a second time. The AlphaSmart 3000 can only store up to eight files max and has a spell check button, once done though, open up a word document or anything that supports stuff similar to it and hit the send button. What's cool about this is that once you do you get to see the words get played out as if you are holding down one of the keys to spam one single letter. I am a storyteller at heart, I write random stories that involves drama, action, etc, but unfortunately thanks to a thing called the internet I was always distracted by responding to group chats. Now I'm able to write freely from writing one sentence a day to nearly a page per hour. Trust me when you love to write like I am, I would highly recommend this product, even better it's as cheap as forty to fifty bucks so it's well worth buying. I give this item a 10 out of 10, it's easy and simple to use and doesn't come with internet which means no distractions.
Does not last more than an hour. Not pleased at all. Must be a refurbished battery but I would expect it to last longer than that.

This tablet was purchased for 4 reasons; skype(incompatible), movies(they will not download), games(it can't even support the preinstalled games, and has an app store that will not download to the device, even when you can get to the app store), and an ereader, which is somewhat decent, however it claims you can reach four bookstores, I can only reach aldiko, which cannot find any preteen books.  He is an advanced reader and asked if I could find stephen king, funny, out of the hundreds written, aldiko can only find two, and both are the \\"lesser read\\" ones.  If you are only looking to watch youtube, then this is the tablet for you, it is the only fully functional app on there.  Also, you cannot download apps either, Applib, which is NOT Android market, does not work, even though it is preinstalled on the tablet.  It plays youtube like a champ, though!  I feel that I was mislead by all it claims to do, especially having Android market.  I am retrning this tablet(my sons christmas present).  I am reading from others that you can download amazon android market by googling it, which, i also read, is unsupported by google.  However, I have read that it is possible to go through extensive research and add to it, after hours of research and work, but I wanted a tablet that a ten year old can operate without the need of a hacker or 4 hours of research and fustration on my part, I would rather pay the difference for a better tablet.

Instances.input: I found the Life-Phorm to be very practical. I've used it mainly for holding and elevating my Bose Soundlink Mini Bluetooth speaker. Normally, the direction of the speaker is well below ear level when situated flat on a table but with the Life-Phorm I can direct the sound toward my head. I've attached the Life-Phorm with the speaker to a lattice in my back yard which enabled me to position the speaker at ear level when sitting on a lawn chair.  I've also used it to read my Kindle at a tilted and elevated, \\"eye friendly\\" level while I'm sitting at a desk or table. It would be perfect if they had a ratcheting device instead of a screw for locking a device into the Life-Phorm. The bottom line is, I like the multi-use Life-Phorm; its innovative, versatile and easy to manipulate. It's also a good buy at a little over $18.

Instances.input: I bought this Kindle as a present for my wife for Christmas last (2011).As the Kindle stands, she finds it wery usefull but she says it could do with some sort of light.You still need a light on to read in dim light or in bed.The real problem with the Kindle however is Amazon`s strategy of only selling books in US dollars,this despite we are living in the Rep.of Ireland.  This would not be a real problem if you were given the choice of paying in either Euro,Dollar or GBP.We are paying significantly more for books than people are in the UK.I would love to know hoe Amazon calculate their conversion rates.This was NOT pointed out at the time of purchase,and I would urge people to look carefully before buying a kindle,then if you decide to go ahead and get one of them I would further urge you to look in Tesco or PC world because they can sell the Amazon product cheaper than Amazon.!!!  I will be very interested if this review is posted on the Amazon site.They requested a review,so now let us see how much they value my opinion.  John Byrne.

Instances.input: I waited several months after making this purchase to write the review, because I wanted to make sure I still loved it after using it awhile.  The picture is crystal clear and I have no dead pixels. I would highly recommend this monitor if picture quality is a top consideration.  The only negative thing about this monitor is the built-in speakers are horrible, but I already had external speakers so I just kept them hooked up (I didn't mind this so it didn't affect my review.) If you absolutely need built-in speakers then either look for a different monitor or accept the fact that you'll have sub-par sound.

Telikin Support team,
Thank you very much for helping me get my mother set up on the Telekin. I can’t tell you how it’s improved her quality of life with being able to Skype with me and my sister, her grandchildren and being able to see and speak with her great-grandchildren. It really only took me 2 half days to get her set up and comfortable with getting emails and using Skype. I tried to introduce her to the games and she was on overload so I didn’t pursue. Within a week, she told me how she got into Solitaire and how it helps her pass the time when she is waiting for someone – She did that all on her own. We all send her pictures from our phones as well as video’s. She loves walking by the Telekin and seeing that she has emails especially when they contain pictures of the great grandchildren. Previous to this we had to call her to tell her we sent her pictures, she had to go down to a computer room and access them. The computers were set up for security reasons – not to be able to see video’s. She was missing so much.

We set the Telekin up in her bedroom on her desk. Now I call her and ask her if she wants to Skype and the answer is always YES! I get to see her and can access how she’s doing much better by seeing her on Skype. Sounds kind of funny, but I think she also likes to see my smiling face as well as my wife's too!

Thanks again for all of your help and for developing such a great product!

Should you ever need a testimonial or wish to use any of the above, feel free. It was the best investment we could have made in our mother. We’re heading back up there in later this August so round 2 of training is forthcoming.

Thanks again for helping me with this. I can’t say enough about it.
output: My Mother is So Happy with her Telikin

Instances.input: I bought a Renice K3VLAR 1.8" PATA ZIF SSD 128GB (Renice Z2), and while it worked well, I was getting data corruption over time. As soon as I saw that I could use well known manufacturer's SSD (for example, Crucial) in a Sony VAIO TXN, I purchased the Micro SATA Cables mSATA SSD to 40pin ZIF adapter. Eureka! It works. The primary difference here is that when you install it in the Sony VAIO TXN27N, you have to install it FACE DOWN (port down). The original Toshiba MK1011GAH is installed port side up. I thought the device was incompatible initially because nothing happened when I initially detected. After flipping it around, all's well. Another note, the device is VERY small (about a 1/3 smaller than the 1.8" HDD). It's slightly larger than the mSATA drive, so you'll need to figure out a way to keep it from moving around too much and detaching itself, so I used a thermal pad strip to "glue" it in place.

The mouse works fine. Keyboard has emotional issues.

Press the left shift button, and you get a >

For geeks like me for whom computers and technology put bread on the table (I'm an UNIX Systems Engineer) this was a no biggie ... remapping the keys is done in a matter of seconds.

so no 5 stars. Sorry
output: it works well, but only after I made adjustments

This device is wonderful. I originally got it as a replacement for my Macbook, which always seemed just a little from the moment I took it out of the box (yes, fanboys, I know I should've gotten the crazy expensive Macbook Pro). I was expecting a laptop like I have a work, decent speed but nothing amazing. Boy was I blown away--this puppy can cook. I have never had performance issues, even when playing intensive games like MMOs.

I also found myself using it much like a tablet, which was rather unexpected. Windows 8 is actually a brilliant software when you use it on this device (I've never used it on a desktop with mouse, so I can't comment on that). It's touch-intuitive and the movements just *make sense* rather than being based around someone thinking they need to throw in touch because it's the newest cool thing.

The touch responsiveness is great, and I really, really, REALLY like the stylus to take notes and draw using Illustrator (well, my free version of it: Inkscape). I feel like I'm writing on paper, but paper that can magically re-write my handwriting as typed text (note: you will need a paid version of OneNote for that feature).

I haven't had any battery life issues or sleeps of death that I've seen other people talk about. I guess I'm lucky. When I play my games, it does need to be plugged in, but otherwise I can get upwards of 8 hours of use out of it.

Overall, I would heartily recommend this device for anyone looking to get rid of a laptop and maybe downsize. It's just amazing.
output: I love everything about it and will not go back

Instances.input: This thing is HUGE, not just big. When I got it saw the reviews people posted and just kinda went \\"pfft\\" ok so it's a little big. I see why they said that now. However, when I began to scroll through said prime books (thankfully without my son present) I found many many books with pornographic covers/content.  While I have no problem with this being available to adults, I was concerned that it is just a click away for a young child to stumble upon.  They are listed with all other books that are free to prime members.  Perhaps a separate section or some parental lockouts might be helpful?  I am now unable to allow my independent nine year old to search for his own books.  I know some parents are planning to buy these specifically for children, and they should be aware that this inappropriate content is easily accessible.  Very disappointing.

Instances.input: Nice unit, works great.  USB is all you need.  Quick backup and decent software at an affordable price.

After eagerly anticipating the Kindle experience, I was sorely disappointed at not being able to download a single e-book. The WiFi did not work at my home, so I had to drive about 2 miles to one of the highest points in the area where I was able to get three bars of reception. After spending about 20 minutes shopping at the Kindle store, I was unable to download the selection because there was not enough power left in the battery. This, after starting out with the battery fully charged. Okay, I thought, I'll just use the USB cable and download e-books from my computer. After hooking up my Kindle to the computer I received a message to the effect that if I wanted to use my Kindle or continue charging, to disconnect it from my computer! No other options offered. Actually, I would have preferred to just use the USB cable and shop from my computer. However, I could not find anywhere in the user manual that says how to do this. There has been too much hype about the WiFi capability without consideration for people who live in areas of low signal strength. If there was information available in the user manual regarding downloading with the USB cable, it certainly was not where it could easily be found. All I could find was information on how to use a wi-fi option. Also, lots of luck trying to get tech support. I would probably order another Kindle if someone would just make it plain to me how to download e-books without having to use the wi-fi option.

Rob Danis

Follow up review; 1/4/13

I'd forgotten about this review, and wish I had remembered it sooner. I stand chagrined, as I now love my kindle, and seldom buy paper books anymore. Granted, the instructions could have been clearer, but I finally realized that you simply control input from the computer when the Kindle is attached, and treat it like any other remote drive. Download, drag and drop. Duh! My humble apologies to Amazon. I have since got a wireless router formy home network, so now buying books is really effortless.

This product gets 0 stars.  If you insert it all the way into the USB port it is not recognized.  You have to withdraw it ever so slightly from the USB port to get the device to be recognized, and at that it is highly inconsistent.  Even when the blue light flashes on device recognition by the MAC is hit or miss.  I remember reading another review describing just this problem.  This product is cheap for a reason.  Avoid.
output: Cheap product does not work as advertised.

Instances.input: Products of excellent quality, I am very satisfied! Buy More.

No trouble at all with getting up and running. Does everything I expected without any installation hassles on my Lenovo X230 laptop running Windows 8. Haven't tried it on anything else yet. It was able to handle my backup of a 128 GB file with full 3.0 speed. Very nice. May get another.

Was tooling around at the BOSE store and stumbled across these small speakers. Surprisingly they sounded better than the 2.1 setup so thought I would purchase and take home for further experimentation.

Quite simply, they are very strong speakers for their size and believe them to be exceptional value regardless of the brand name. In terms of sound they have very crisp highs, very deep and punchy bass, and the mid-range is not lost. I've never felt the need to adjust them, they seem quite well balanced. If anything, they are a little heavy on the bass but noticeably so, which for their design is an impressive feat on itself.

The control wheel gives you a nice analog feel with a good amount of control, but you might find yourself accidentally muting the volume when reaching for it, which is the only thing I find annoying.

They sound very clear at low volume and you only notice artifacts on max volume when you want to fill the entire floor of your home with sound and rock out. Amazing.
output: Deceptively good, not really a BOSE fan

Years ago, I bought a Logitech thumb trackball of some unknown model name when I bought my very first computer. I remember that I was really enjoying using it until a friend stopped by to visit after school, and chided me for not having a regular mouse. I realize, today, that that friend of mine was an idiot.
I have several wireless mice I use with my netbook for school, and they were helpful when I would take the computer to a coffee shop or to school to do some work. But I leave the house less for these purposes, and instead work on a tiny non-computer desk with approximately zero space to maneuver a mouse. I then recalled the trackball of yore and sought one out.

There are several on the market now, and Logitech and Kensington seem to be the main players (which is a shame - trackballs really are great). I initially tried the [[ASIN:B0043T7FXE Logitech M570 Wireless Trackball]]. It had its good points: laser tracking, unifying receiver, quite comfortable for right-handed people. I found, however, that when compared to the Marble, I much preferred the trackball to actually be in the center so that it can be controlled with my index and middle fingers. By comparison, the thumb-control style felt much less precise and efficient. And this may have had more to do with my thumb itself than with the device. Another plus for the Marble is that the actual ball itself is of a larger diameter than the smallish M570. Personally, I think it allows for more economy of motion and a surer 'grip' if you will while navigating.

The Marble is also quite comfortable to use - my hand just lounges across the top of it, and I can click and move effortlessly (well, almost effortlessly, but I'll get to that part soon). And when I first realized the Marble used optical tracking, it sounded like I was taking a step back in time. No worries - for general usage, it is extremely precise and I've read that some people enjoy playing FPS games with this model. My needs are less strenuous than that, though, so I cannot attest to the Marble's efficacy there. And, since it stays at home, the USB cord is just fine by me - I save on batteries. The entire device is very stable on the old, polished wooden desk I 'appropriated' for my work space; it does not slide around or wobble back and forth. It is quite steady.

I suppose it is the nature of things to not be all perfect, and the Marble is not and thus I took off a star. If you have read this far (thank you!), then perhaps you have enough interest in this trackball to already know it is ambidextrous. This is both a blessing and a curse. Many 'thumb' models require you to be right-handed, which is too bad. However, this model can be easily placed on either side of your work space and accomadate whichever hand you navigate with. If you look at the pictures at the top of the product page, you see the red marble in the top center, two large, gray paddle-shaped buttons (typically mapped as right or left click)on either side and on top of those, there are two small darker gray buttons (these default to forward and back).

Now bear with me here: as a right-handed guy, my left thumb uses the left large paddle button as left click, and can move up to hit the little button to activate the Universal Scroll (the Logitech Software allows you to customize the buttons as you desire, and I never use a forward-back button, but I am a scroll junkie). My index finger primarily uses the trackball, while the middle one helps it out as needed. Now, here is where I docked a star, although I noticed this going in: my ring finger can tap the upper edge of the right paddle button easily, but to access the tiny upper right button (the one that defaults to forward), I'm required to lift my entire hand off the device hit the button and resettle. I know, I know: cry me a river you say. But it does hinder the otherwise fluid usage of the device. I like the concept of a trackball anybody can use, but not when all controls are not easily reached. I simply don't have that button assigned to do anything, and frankly, I get along great. But I wanted you to be aware of that.

A few more things: if this is the first review you have read on this device and you plan on reading more be forewarned: Many reviewers feel the Marble is missing something (here's a hint: it begins with a 'scroll' and ends with a 'wheel'). Kidding aside, its a valid point - scroll wheels are ubiquitous and many computer games and programs are designed to assume you have one. As I said, I am a scroll wheel junkie. I love that thing! But, when I have the auto scroll function mapped, I click the button once, and scroll with the trackball. Its an extra step, but it took me a day or two to start doing it automatically. I literally don't think about it anymore. So for me, no sweat - I'm very pleased.

Another thing to note is that as of this writing, I have had to uninstall the newest SetPoint software (version 6 something or other) and install an older version, 4.80. The reason for this is that the newest version of SetPoint didn't register the Universal Scroll feature in Office 2007 (I use Word and PowerPoint a ton for school, so I wanted to see if I could fix that issue). I had to call Logitech's service reps who were very pleasant and helpful, and I was told that the software designers know of this issue with the current SetPoint, and are working to resolve it in a future update. Meanwhile, version 4.80 essentially does all of the same stuff that the new version does, so I don't feel cheated there.

Finally I should reiterate something first time trackball adopters may be thinking about: yes, it will take some getting used to using a trackball (thumb or finger style) over a traditional mouse. The first few days you will shakily move the trackball and your cursor will shoot across the screen. You may try to click on a small space on a website and will end up having to make multiple attempts. This is normal, and dissipates quickly. I'm writing this review after owning the Marble for about a week or so and feel quite proficient with it. Prior to a week ago, I used a mouse for ~ 15 years, give or take. And I don't regret the switch. If you are buying a trackball for the first time I urge you: Keep the receipt (if it doesn't float your boat, send it back), use the software to customize the cursor speeds and button layout (you can make the cursor slower to allow you time to adjust to the new device), and have a little bit of patience. Within a few days, you'll more than likely be using it without a second thought.

I hope this was helpful to some of you!y can use, but not when all controls are not easily reached. I simply don't have that button assigned to do anything, and frankly, I get along great. But I wanted you to be aware of that.

I hope this was helpful to some of you!
