After installing then original card in my Galaxy S3, the card would unmount and mount again and again through out the day. This created horrible battery life. Then within a week all the data on the card became corrupted. I formatted it in FAT32 hoping this would solve the problem only to have the same thing happen again. Then I tried once more with exFat, only to get the same data corruption. I contacted Sandisk and they replaced the card.

Card #2 did the same thing within two weeks. I decided I might use the card in my SLR since it was a no go in my phone. However, it was slower than the three other class 10 cards I owned and the two other class 6 cards I own. I tested them with both a Windows program, a Mac program, and in the SLR itself. My slowest class 6 card from Transcend would take 18 pictures in burst mode before slowing down. Sandisk's \\"Ultra\\" card would only take 14.

This problem is well known, just look at the reviews here or Google the card. So when I talked to Sandisk, I asked that they replace the card with of equal value from one of their different line of cards. I talked with a representative at length and she escalated the next level of support to see if this alternative was possible. I was assured that the same representative would contact me shortly by phone so I would not have to go through the whole process of explaining things again from the beginning. Seven hours later I got a call from a different representative who knew nothing of the problem, requiring me to explain everything from the beginning. He said all Sandisk could do was send another of the same card. He assured me that the problem with the card had been fixed and that Sandisk's products were reliable. Funny, the representative told me the exact same thing a month ago when they shipped me card #2. I have 9 other SD cards (two of the micro SDXC variety) and none of them have had any problems. Yet, the two Sandisk cards of this variety have both failed. Please, please buy a different card so you can avoid my experience!

I purchased this graphics card in April of 2011 in order to upgrade my existing decent HP PC that I had. I purchased this card, upgraded my power supply, and was up and running.

The card is large, so hopefully you have a mid or large sized case ready for this guy since you don't want heat to be too much of an issue.

I can run most games at medium to high settings and they all look great and run smooth.

It's almost time for me to build an entirely new PC and I'm considering just keeping this card since it is so decent.

Edit: February 2014 - still have the card in my PC and it works really well. Able to run games at decent settings even after nearly 3 years.
Easy to put together and now I feel confident in having a nice case on my Tab 4. It's fallen from my couch already,but everything seems to work fine!

There are a lot of screen protectors out there. The main reason that I chose this one was its blue light UV filter, as I know that that precise light wave (around 450-470 nM) is damaging for the eyes.
I'm also glad that I haven't received a flimsy screen protector. This one is robust, yet touching my screen is just as responsive as it was before I put iLLumiShield on it.
I had a little trouble, though, to separate the protecting layer from iLLumiShield itself. The small tag which was supposed to help removing that layer was of very little help. I had to separate the layer from the Screen protector using my nail, but then applying the Shield on the screen went well.
But don't let this last comment turning you away from this screen protector. The 5 stars I gave is a clear recommendation for buying it.

If you use your Macbook for music, or even watch films, you might use a home speaker system in lieu of the marginal on-board speakers. That can be a little cumbersome even at home unless you have multiple speakers / stereos, or only one room!   The Twelve South Bassjump is a wired speaker, but other than that being a drawback for some, it is as portable as possible. The company provides a really nice form fitting fabric bag with a handy netting pocket inside for stowing the cord. The cord itself is a white (in the apple style), USB-mini USB so if length were ever a problem there are multiple alternative lengths for sale almost everywhere. I didn't measure the cord exactly, but it's around 2 feet long (60cm).   I have used this speaker CONSTANTLY (!) for three weeks. The difference in sound from stock is tremendous and transformational. Nothing will make the volume any higher, but if you can make the sound this full and balanced it is so much more easy to live with.   Crossover and volume are customized via proprietary (downloaded) software. sound can be changed a bit just by moving the satellite speaker around to suit.    Performance was really my number one concern (would it even work?) when I plunked down the cash for this, but the style and quality and care that went into design extended even into the packaging, I felt like I bought a product from people who cared. I felt better about spending the money.     This is my first review ever, and I thought it worthwhile to spread the word to other music lovers. I take the Bassjump everywhere and it has been a compromise that surpasses expectation, I am actually grateful that someone saw fit to make this.
output: adding much needed balance with a minimum of extraneous add on

When unfolded, the keyboard is comfortable to type on with good key response. I also like that it has the standard layout I'm used to.en while maintaining a standard keyboard layout (roughly an 11" laptop). It was easy to pair to my Windows 8 Surface, I didn't even need to read the instructions. Just opened it up and it automatically came on, I saw the bluetooth symbol on the "c" key so I pressed Fn+C and it was detected and installed by my Surface, couldn't get much easier than that.
I am taking one star away (if I could only take half a star I would) because I wish they had made a way to lock it in the open position so you could use it on surfaces that may not be completely flat, a minor issue guess, but still a issue. That said, it will still be keyboard of choice for my 2 tablets.
output: This keyboard will be taking it's place in my backpack

Instances.input:
Amazon launched the new generation of Kindles at the end of September 2013. I spent time perusing these latest greatest Kindles. They were supposed to be pretty much the same as the Fire HD, but with better graphics, battery and sound. A few other perks like really great support and cameras front and back. Gadget junkie that I am, I resisted until December, but my Fire was slowing down. Probably from all the stuff I was doing on it. Mind you, it never stopped working but it didn't work quite as well as it had. When Amazon dropped the price by $50 before Christmas, I bought the HDX. It came with 6-month financing at 0% interest. Nice.

The Amazon Kindle Fire HDX has a new, improved interface for email and the calendar is better too. I know the audio and video were technically better, but they didn't seem different to me; the audio and video on the Fire HD are super and from super to more super? Nothing to notice. I loved my Kindle Fire HD and figured I would love the new one even more. And so I did. For a day. Maybe two. The battery drained in a phenomenally short time. At one point, I was on the phone with Kindle support complaining about the battery -- and it was dropping at about 1% every two or three minutes. In about 40 minutes, it dropped more than 50%. I plugged it in before it went flat. It also drained while it was not in use -- sleeping -- at approximately 5% per hour. Reading -- not audio or video -- drained it at 15% per hour. As the battery hit less than 20%, it became unresponsive. Customer support suggested I let it drain all the way and recharge it. Which I did.

Same story. It seems you can't turn off any of the apps once you turn them on except by forcing a stop. Which slows (but doesn't stop) the draining while the device sleeps, but not when you are using it. Then it just chews through the battery at warp speed.

Back at customer service, she said I should send it back and try a different one, there must be something wrong with the unit. I wasn't so sure about it. I had a funny itchy feeling in my brain that the problem was NOT my unit, but a design issue. I'd been reading reviews. Too many people were complaining of battery problems. I had noticed the reviews before I bought but refused to believe Amazon would knowingly market a product not suitable for its intended purpose. If a portable device -- a 7″ tablet -- doesn't have a good battery life, it's useless.

The Fire HD didn't have weeks of battery life, as does a plain Kindle, but it had a solid 12 hours. Twelve hours of actual use. On the Fire HDX, you'd be lucky to get 4 hours. Nonetheless, after being assured if the replacement was unsatisfactory, I could return it, I agreed. A couple of days later, the new HDX arrived.

The second HDX was worse than the first. After little more than a week, I called Amazon and said \\"That's it, I'm done.\\" In the meantime, in a fit of totally unwarranted optimism, I had given my Fire HD to my daughter-in-law and I couldn't bring myself to ask for it back. I wouldn't have gotten it anyhow because she REALLY likes it. So there I was without a Kindle. I could use my husband's temporarily, but not long-term because he reads too.

I bought the Paperwhite -- the model with WiFi, not 3G. It arrived yesterday. I set it up late in the afternoon. It went live as soon as I plugged it in. It immediately - at blinding speed -- connected, displaying all my books and documents sorted into the categories I'd created on my original Kindle. The Paperwhite reminded me why I fell in love with Kindles. It's a great reader. It has a few little bells (no whistles). It's light, small, easy-to-use. It has some similar design elements as the Fire HD -- a touch screen, virtual keyboard and its own light -- but retains many things I loved about the older Kindles, mainly that it is a wonderful device on which to read a book.

Paperwhite is a dedicated reader, not a tablet. Flat, non-reflective surface -- very easy on the eyes. Adjustable fonts and lighting that won't wake your spouse or make you go blind. It weighs almost nothing, even with a cover. You can get inexpensive covers for it. Mine (from Fintie) cost $10. There were cheaper ones, but I liked this design and I've owned Fintie covers and knew the quality is good. I settled in to read last night and for the first time in a long time, could focus on the book. The Fire HD was a great little tablet, but it was forever teasing me away from reading to play a game, hear a tune, or watch a movie -- things I can easily do on my laptop.

Perhaps this is what I should have gotten in the first place. Regardless, I cannot recommend the new Kindle Fire HDX. The battery is inadequate to the tablet. I'm really sorry to have to say this. Unless you plan to use it plugged in, charge it after every use ... nope. Doesn't live up to its PR or its predecessor.

Sorry, Amazon. The HDX isn't ready for prime time.lat, non-reflective surface -- very easy on the eyes. Adjustable fonts and lighting that won't wake your spouse or make you go blind. It weighs almost nothing, even with a cover. You can get inexpensive covers for it. Mine (from Fintie) cost $10. There were cheaper ones, but I liked this design and I've owned Fintie covers and knew the quality is good. I settled in to read last night and for the first time in a long time, could focus on the book. The Fire HD was a great little tablet, but it was forever teasing me away from reading to play a game, hear a tune, or watch a movie -- things I can easily do on my laptop.

Perhaps this is what I should have gotten in the first place. Regardless, I cannot recommend the new Kindle Fire HDX. The battery is inadequate to the tablet. I'm really sorry to have to say this. Unless you plan to use it plugged in, charge it after every use ... nope. Doesn't live up to its PR or its predecessor.

Sorry, Amazon. The HDX isn't ready for prime time.
output: RETURNED IT FINALLY. SAD BUT TRUE

I'm of two minds about this power supply. Professional reviews complement the power delivery characteristics, and if mine lived in a server closet, I'd probably rate it five stars. I'm pulling back two because both my TX650 V1 (2010) and TX650 V2 (2013) exhibit coil whine under some loads. Coil whine occurs when copper coils resonate at an audible frequency. The resonance is natural, though ordinarily dampened or designed to occur above 20 KHz. It's harmless except to your sanity. My V1 was fine for two years, but eventually began to squeal at idle. The replacement V2 squeals during network transfers. UPDATE: As does the TX550M. I wish I could blame the system; a Cooler Master Silent Pro 600M and Seasonic G 450 work just fine.

SUPPORT:

Support is solid at Corsair, but I had some initial trouble taking advantage of the 5-year warranty. Contact methods include an online RMA form, a phone number, and, if you can find it, a hidden email feedback form. Turnaround times for a conventional RMA are measured in weeks. Corsair will do advance RMAs (wherein they send you a replacement first with a credit card hold and you then send yours back), but this is not possible to arrange with their online form.

Calling them leads to a phone tree. When I first called, the phone tree ran in circles, eventually to a full voicemail box. Using the email feedback form netted an email telling me to use the same phone tree. I was later informed by email that this was a result of their 'Holiday' schedule where the entire office leaves for a week. This information appears nowhere; you're just meant to infer it when no one picks up.

It took three phone calls to set up an advance RMA. Disconnections occurred even during in-office transfers. Hold times were two to fifteen minutes at 1PM on a weekday. The process aside, support ultimately upgraded me to a superior unit and provided return shipping labels, so I'm only out time. They definitely stand behind their product.

PERFORMANCE:

When my V1 was new, it was effectively silent and, at a Bronze rating, moderately efficient. Gold-rated units are 5-6% more efficient, which can result in significant yearly savings ($10-$25) if your load is near rated capacity around the clock. It continues to function even while emitting nasty noises, so I can't knock the reliability.

Most power supplies have two general characteristics: they're most efficient at half-load, and half-load is when their fans start to ramp up. If you want a silent PSU, your maximum load should be no more than 60% of rated capacity. A Core i7 quad using integrated video will idle around 40W and draw up to 150W at full load. A mid-range ($200) graphics card will add 15W to the idle and 90W to the max load. A high-zoot or dual-chip graphics card ($400+) can double or triple both numbers. Overlocking can bump the load total by 25%.

Because efficiency trails off rapidly below 20% load, and most systems spend most of their time at idle, it's best not to buy capacity well in excess of your needs. Naturally, this conflicts with the silence objective, so it's a bit of a trade-off with Bronze-rated units. Gold units preserve more efficiency at low loads. Some PSUs aren't capable of silence at any load. Seasonic (the designer and builder of the TX series) is better on that front; they use quiet fans and a fan power profile that keeps the fan idling, or entirely off in some cases, at low loads.

The TX650 is designed for a system with a quad chip and dual-mid-range graphics cards. Here's how the numbers play out relative to, say, a Seasonic S12-380, also a Bronze unit:

0.2 * 650 = 130W
0.5 * 650 = 325W

0.2 * 380 = 76W
0.5 * 380 = 190W

Typical integrated video PC:
idle: 40W
max: 150W

Same PC with a mid-range graphics card:
idle: 55W
max: 240W

In all cases, the first PC will be better with the lower-capacity power supply. It'll run more efficiently and it'll still be silent. The other system will put you to the choice: do you care more about fan noise at full load or efficiency at idle?

Here's the load ballpark for each component:

Quad CPU: 10W idle, 100W sustained
Motherboard: 15W-50W
Hard disk: 15W spinup, 2W idle, 7W sustained
SSD: 1W idle, 5W sustained
Optical: 1W idle, 10W sustained
Video card: 15W-25W idle, 70W-250W sustained
RAID card: 25W
NIC/sound/peripheral card: 10W
120mm fan: 3W

FEATURES:

This particular 650W TX is not a modular power supply. Modularity means that some or all cables are attached separately so you can pick and choose what you need. The more wattage and the more concerned you are with a clean build, the more important this feature is.

With the semi-modular TX550M, modularity was no great help. Any system liable to require that wattage will use most or all of the available cables. The TX650 is something else; it has four cables devoted to molex and SATA plugs and two more to PCIe. The TX850 has an additional two PCIe. Unless your system has a dozen hard drives, at least a few will end up behind the motherboard tray.

Lack of modularity can make for a bargain. The TX650 goes for as little as $50 after rebates. For a Bronze supply of this wattage with this warranty, that's very compelling.

The cable sleeving for the three TX and HX copies I received could be improved. The sheath was loose (looking and feeling like a shedding snakeskin) on some cables and gluing wasn't completely hidden.

COIL WHINE:

If your unit whines, you have two options: RMA it or change the system power profile. Disabling EIST and the C1/C3/C6 halt states in the BIOS significantly reduced my coil whine. Idle power use went up 10-15W. Running Prime95 in the background eliminated the whine entirely. With my Core i7 quad, a single Prime95 thread at 11% CPU usage added 40W of idle power use, more than enough to kick the PSU above the power profile that caused noise. For reasons of performance and efficiency (40W of extra power in a 24/7 machine costs about $50 a year), I consider Prime95 a stop-gap solution until a replacement PSU arrives.

IN SUM:

In a stacked system, this TX650 would be a wonderful PSU. Power delivery is exemplary and you won't have the odd acoustics for which I've docked two stars. Systems without powerful graphics cards will do better with lesser-rated models.er with the lower-capacity power supply. It'll run more efficiently and it'll still be silent. The other system will put you to the choice: do you care more about fan noise at full load or efficiency at idle?

Motherboard: 15W-50W
Hard disk: 15W spinup, 2W idle, 7W sustained
SSD: 1W idle, 5W sustained

The TX650 is something else; it has four cables devoted to molex and SATA plugs and two more to PCIe. The TX850 has an additional two PCIe. Unless your system has a dozen hard drives, at least a few will end up behind the motherboard tray.

Lack of modularity can make for a bargain. The TX650 goes for as little as $50 after rebates. For a Bronze supply of this wattage with this warranty, that's very compelling.

This thing is just awesome. This little guy is LOUD. I do agree the bass is not crazy but the sound is so clear it makes up for it. Instances.input: Works great! Pretty thin for a leather cover (much thinner than others I have seen). Make sure you follow the videos for how to get the fit right and to use the stand (not the most secure stand, but it works fine). It's not hard to follow the videos, but is well worth the time.

Instances.input: Super solid keyboard. My wife really likes it to help her type things with google drive.
The price is right and the protection is great. My 4 year old son loves it. Great handle and stand.

This router came with Belkin firmware that is four years old. I knew I wanted Tomato firmware, but I wasn't sure which mod I wanted. I tried Shibby and Toastman; Toastman seemed to work best. Earlier reviews recommended flashing to Tomato from the CFE. That didn't work for me no matter how many times I tried. I had to flash the firmware through the Belkin firmware web GUI in the upgrade section. What I finally decided on was flashing first to the newest version of Tomato Toastman mini for this router:
tomato-F7D3302-1.28.0505.2MIPSR2Toastman-RT-N-Mini.bin.
After that I flashed:
tomato-K26USB-1.28.0505.2MIPSR2Toastman-RT-N-VPN.trx.
Tomato Toastman doesn't have DHCP running by default, so an IP address must be assigned manually.
(The newest version of Tomato Toastman, the one I used, is from May 2014. )
After quite a bit of testing, I'm very happy with this router running this 3rd party firmware.
output: A wonderful router to run Tomato Toastman for under $30

Instances.input: Got two of these drives for holding data. The first has been a workhorse for my HTPC for over a year now.
Just received my cover for my Kindle Fire.  I love it.  It fits great.  Love the color.  Very pleased with this product.

So if you want a good performing, easy to use home NAS this is the ticket. Just plug it in start using. No, the interface is not high tech but funtional and easy to use. I have 6 pc, 1 xbox, 2 wii, 2 network printers and 5 smart devices/tablets. The performance of HD Live on the pc wired or wireless is fantastic.... I have 1.4 TBs of data and i move data from PC to WD live amazingly fast for NAS. This is my second NAS(older design) and this is years apart. The iphone/android applets are simple, they could be writed to operate faster on the mobile devices, but it works.... I often have 4 i devices streaming with no hickups... mostly audio/music but movies too. The nice thing about these devices is that your data (Music/Movies)or photos are not only available while on your home wifi network but securely over the internet. The applet authenticates your authorized smart devices and allows access to your data. Very cool and works great over 3G and Wifi. As I say good device.... you might want to upgrate your wifi router :-).

ps.. i do not work for WD or any other related company... just like the product a lot..

Sufficient to protect from scratches

This is by far the best bang for the buck so get out there and get one. No these speakers are not huge and the sub-woofer fits under my desk and you don't see that either, they are so cute! You can make adjustments to the bass quality and just zone out from there. I have set my music up in my bedroom (loft) and enjoyed the sound from down stairs. It is heaven. I am so glad to be away from those tinny sounding little puter speakers and have some real sounds to listen to when I get home.

Thank you!!!

The Netgear ReadyNAS 104 is small, quiet and easy to set up. For what I needed, I thought I would be limited to huge back-up servers that costs thousands of dollars. This device is an absolute blessing as I was able to set it up within minutes and get my files backed up with no problems. For the value, it's hard to beat the ReadyNAS products. This device in particular is great for those looking to have a seamless backup server that is reliable and secure. I was able to set this device up in my basement near my router and do not plan on ever needing to touch it because it seems to be well-built.

I would recommend this product to those looking for a low-cost personal or small business back up solution. As a disclaimer, I received this product for free with my participation in the Friends and Family program.
output: Good value solution for those seeking a personal and/or small business back-up solution!!

(1) The caddy fits into the bay fine but does not have any screw tab to secure it into the bay. So the only thing holding it in is the connection between the caddy and the motherboard. Nothing has happened so far but it is something you need to watch for.

(2) Make sure your hard drive is good to go before installing. Once the caddy is in without violently shaking the laptop it can be difficult to remove. The caddy is a little loose so the lip can get stuck on the screen side.
output: Does not secure well to the Asus N53S (or probably any other laptop)

the little rubber things come off if you dont take care of it. but its a great price and it works with any touch screen for phones and ipads. i love it.
This item was better than expected.  It was plenty long enough unlike the power cord that came standard.  I was always plugging that into an extension cord, not this one.
output: great item for a great tablet

Instances.input:
I looked everywhere for a front USB hub. I hate the idea of having to reach around the back of the computer to use the other USB ports and the two front USB ports are always in use. I also hate having to depend on my external USB hub because my hub has problems reading some devices such as the ones that have to be connected directly to the computer itself. So adding four more ports in the front is a welcome addition. All I used to find were USB hubs for the back of the computer. When I did find front USB hubs, they were almost always sold out, overpriced or the wrong color. I was glad to find one on this site for such a reasonable price.

The Cables To Go 4-PORT USB 2.0 Front-bay Hub is a great product. It was surprisingly easy to install. Once installed, it was up and running in no time. It works just as if it had come with the computer all along. My tower is black and silver so the port's black color fits in nicely. It's truly plug 'n' play. The data speed is fast. I've plugged in everything, cameras, my ipod, blackberry, portable printer, portable hard drive, etc. No problems at all. Even devices my external USB hub has problems reading, this port does. Good deal.
fits for the most part. However, beware that this item does not ship with adhesive. You will have to provide your own when replacing the original bezel.
output: Good fit but no adhesive backing

Instances.input: Nice product. Quick delivery
Stable

Package:
Usual clear plastic & resealable which comes in handy for storage of other drives.
Compatibility:
Used this in external eSATA HD dock. It supports the new serial ATA3 6 gig interface for added speed for those with the most up to date computer as of the day of this review. Mine isn't as fast, so using SATA2 3 gig hardware.
Operation:
The HD powered up fine, I formatted from Win Vista 64 setup as one large partition & so far in the past two weeks it's been running well & consistent even with a lage amount of files. It runs also very quietly, which is surprising considering it's immense speed & capacity. The drive is in reasonable temperature range with use.
Speed:
So far this is working well, the speed is great. I can write a 4.15 gig file in under 40 SECONDS.
Conclusion:
I recommend this drive, the performance is great, with fast speed, great reliability & quiet operation.

Will definitely update this review if there are any issues.
output: Seagate Barracuda 2TB: can hold it all, one of fastest & quiet too!

Instances.input: I absolutely love my Kindle. It's small and comfortable to hold and it has a white screen so I can read it in daylight.

The price was too good to pass up. If the new Blackberry OS10 comes through, you'll have a great tablet. Hopefully will access Android, Netflix etc. This is an investment gamble but you can't lose. It always make a great media player.

I love the grabbit, it makes the experience of using the iPad 2 much more enjoyable and it is easier to handle than with other cases or \\"naked\\".
I particularly like the comfortable leather strap that allows my left hand to hold the pad while I use my right hand to surf or use email even write in Pages. New Trent has not disappointed me with any products thus far and I'm always excited to have New Trent when I use my iOS devices!
This card has been in my computer for over half a year, and has worked fine.

I teach computing/Internet to seniors and this is the perfect computer for them. They do not have to worry about updates or malware/virus protection. I have found they can pick up most of what they need to know in 2 weeks time without any prior computer knowledge. I have my own Chromebook and with their permission I can sign in to their accounts on mine and assist them remotely. That is very handy because we are only in the same location in the winter in South Texas. Most seniors want Facebook, email, Google search and Kindle for PC. Once they have that down pat they are happy. Chromebook is the perfect tool for them and me.
Another point I want to make is that the apps include most anything you would want to do on any computer. I have yet to find anything I cannot do.

After trying another brand of "smart case" and it torn apart I knew that buying the smart cover from Apple was the solution. Works like a charm. The only "issue" I have is that it seems to be a little bit bigger than my iPad 2, so the rotate screen button sometimes is not that very accessible. Except for that, I recommend buying this smart cover.
output: ... and it torn apart I knew that buying the smart cover from Apple was the solution

Instances.input: I'm a warranty addict. And its paid off with Squaretrade! Don't risk losing ANY money. 6 stars or more if possible.

I bought this as a replacement for a corded mouse.  I paid 5X the corded price to get rid of the cord, which was always getting in the way.  I was also interested in the long battery life.    First, the mouse is very picky about what surface it is on.  I finally found a mouse pad that it would track but the mouse to screen scaling is almost 1:1.  As a result, moving the cursor across the screen takes about 5 sweeps of the wrist. Now my wrist hurts. Eventually, I was able to fix the problem by cleaning the LED with a swab and alcohol. I assume that the special low power LED is sensitive to dirt or dust.     I don't recommend this mouse to anyone unless you try it in the store.  Lotsa luck with that, since you have to destroy the packaging to remove it.    Save your money and buy a cheaper and more robust product.
Like all the reviews stated, this is a very fast SSD product.  Easy installation.  And I do not have compatibility issue with my i5 Window7.  For 3 weeks now, it is still working smoothly.

The best bag for the price I've found that was sturdy enough for everyday use that could carry every thing I need, that also has metal sturdy metal  zippers that doesn't look like I'm carrying a mail bag. Vary pleased with my purchase and I would buy again.

The charging port messed up in my kindle fire, so Amazon sent me another one. I love Amazon, they are truly a great company and they are there for their customers. I love my Kindle Fire and I love Amazon!

The warranty stinks. I had an issue with the jack going in to the drive & I contacted them about it & they told me I had to pay for shipping both ways & if I didn't send it back in a timely manner, they were going to charge me a nonrefundable $85. The unit is well constructed on the outside & a very nice & slim. I plug mine in to a 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub which is connected to the back of my computer & this allows me to have it on the side between my PC & desk & I can make a quick removal to take it anywhere. After using it for a long time, it began to make odd noises & occasionally took what felt like forever for the PC to make a connection.  1 year ago, out of the warranty & this crashed & took all of my back up information. What do I have to do? Keep a copy at home, a copy at work & trust this to transport it from one end to another.
output: I cannot recommend this product - TRASH

I chose this one cause it was the cheapest I found with Amazon Prime. All of these things are the same to me. Didn't even know it was a 3 pack so it's good that you get 3 tries.Only needed one. Looks fine. Wasn't too hard to apply. Had zero bubbles, dust, and lint. Just did what I always did with my other screen devices.
- wipe down screen with microfiber cleaning cloth (included)
- use scotch tape and dab the screen little by little to remove any dust or lint
- wipe down one last time
- do not unpeel the film yet
- quickly place the unpeeled side of the screen protector on top of the device before any dust or lint gets on
- center it perfectly as best as you can
- use a couple small pieces (or 1 long piece) of scotch tape and tape down the top of the screen protector onto the top of the device
- with the top of the screen protector taped down somewhat,unpeel the film, from the back side of the screen protector, all the way
- use the hard plastic squeegee (included) to push out any bubbles
- remove the scotch tape. you probably have to clean the residue maybe using a damp towel
output: Works fine. Applied it pretty easily. Zero bubbles, dust, and lint.

Instances.input: This was a great purchase. The amount of storage for the price was great. I would recommend any of my friends to have one around for emergencies.

After around a year of moderate use, LEDs began failing.  Now, after 16 months, with 3 of 8 LEDs out the light is of marginal utility.  Kensington Tech Support says LEDs can't be replaced, and I need to replace entire unit.  I'm replacing it with an identical unit because my credit card provides additional year to unit's original one-year warranty.  Otherwise I would not buy same light again.[[ASIN:B00022VBAE Kensington 33120 FlyLight USB 2.0 Notebook Light (PC/Mac)]]

It's a bit wider than I expected (dimensions are 15.75" W x 10.5" H), which is a bit awkward for my 15" Lenovo laptop, but is probably perfect for the Macbook it's intended for (which is an inch wider than mine). I'm considering ripping the side seams out and redoing it to be an inch shorter, which shouldn't be hard with a sewing machine, though would necessitate losing the leather corners.

The pocket (which was ultimately why I chose this one over another similar sleeve) is also bigger than expected (13.5" W x 7 7/8" H), which in this case is definitely a plus. I thought it would comfortably hold my 7" tablet and a few other things, but it can easily hold an 8.5" x 11" notebook or two.

The felt is nice and thick, about 1/8", definitely enough to protect from dings or scratches, though I wouldn't drop it or hit it with a hammer. I still plan to keep the sleeve in my briefcase when going anywhere, but if you're only travelling a short distance (say, from dorms to class) and don't need to carry much more than your laptop, a notebook, and some pens you could probably get by just carrying this sleeve. The magnet clasp is strong enough that I can hold it upside down without my laptop
output: Perfect for Macbook, might be big for other 15" laptops

This is actually my third Kindle. My first was a second generation Kindle with the integral keyboard, and it was excellent--right up until the day I dropped it. It still works, but now it has an annoying and distracting gray bar across the top 1/2 inch or so. So I bought this model, the Kindle Touch with \\"special offers\\", aka advertisements. I bought the one with 4GB of internal memory because I am retired, and have downloaded close to 10,000 books altogether.

Anyway, this Kindle just froze up on me one day, for no reason at all. It wouldn't reboot, it wouldn't do anything. I called customer service, because it was much less than a year old at that time. They just asked me to describe what it was doing, and asked if it had, to my knowledge, been dropped or had liquid spilled on it, which it hadn't. Then, MUCH to my surprise, they told me they'd issue a replacement order for a new unit! A few days later a new Kindle showed up, with instructions for how to return the bad unit with the enclosed prepaid label.

I was concerned about having to reload the 5,505 books I had already put onto the previous machine, but to my further surprise Amazon had placed all of them in my Archive, to be accessed whenever I wanted one (or more) of them! I also found out at a later date that they also had saved my entire book collection on My Cloud, offering yet another way to access my books. They made it easy as possible for me to retrieve my books.

I love my Kindle(s), but the incredible Customer Service is beyond placing a value on. I am still amazed at how readily they accepted my explanation, without any suggestion that they didn't believe me, or that I was somehow conning them. Incredible company! I HIGHLY recommend the Kindle, regardless of which model you prefer. With the kind of support Amazon gives, you can't go wrong.
output: I Never Leave Home Without It!

Bought a 100-pack of these at a local electrical supply store. Worst RJ45 jacks I've ever used. The package states for stranded wire. All the Cat5e UTP cable I've ever used has been solid -- not stranded -- wire.  Do not attempt to use this wire with solid cable. Period.  I've gone through about a dozen of these so far and still haven't made a working patch cable. Fifteen years of experience in networking, and I've never had this much trouble with cabling. Not even on my first day on the job...  These may be great for stranded cable. I don't know as I've ever seen stranded Cat5/Cat5e/Cat6 cable.  Good luck if you buy these.

Instances.input:
I've owned the Apple Wirless Pro Keyboard for almost a year. I am on the original set of Apple-supplied batteries. I truly don't think about this product, which is a compliment. I just grab it, turn it on, and do what I need to do on my Mac (which is connected to a 37\\" LCD TV in my living room). I have never had a dropout, delay or problem of any sort. To me it is just like having a normal keyboard. Suggestions to Apple? Give us a \\"power on\\" button to power up the computer and a dedicated CD eject key. Otherwise, this is a perfect keyboard, especially for those who have Macs connected to their media center.

UPDATE:

After the first year I was less and less impressed with this keyboard. Like many reviews I've read about it the keys started to get stiff and they had to be pushed at a precise angle or they wouldn't even move. It got to the point where I literally threw the thing in the garbage. Like most Apple products, design comes first, making a buck (big bucks) comes second, quality comes third and customer service doesn't even exist. It is simply no wonder that Apple, after all these years, can't sell more than 2 - 3 % of the computer market despite their grossly misleading \\"PC vs Mac\\" commercials. Mac products continue to be shoddily built and shamefully overpriced. If this site would let me I would drop my rating to less than 1 star.

In a nutshell:

PROS - Price, fit and shipping are all great. Retractable feet on bottom are a nice bonus feature.
CONS - This case is GLOSSY and SLICK. Slippery in the hand. A fingerprint magnet. And the build quality feels a bit cheap.

The ordering experience was great. The case was shipped quickly. It was packaged nicely. Communication was good. My single biggest issue with this order is that the picture on Amazon makes this case look more MATTE vs GLOSSY. I don't believe this was done intentionally but it is a significant issue for me. It lacks the "grippy", tactile feel of most protective cases which I believe increases the chances of your computer sliding out of your hands.

Bottom line - Decent but not great. If you plan on being on the move with your Asus laptop, you might want to invest in a more substantial case. For toting around the house, this could be a decent option.
output: Slick but not in a good way...

I received this tablet yesterday. Already have a Xoom wifi tablet which has served me well for almost a year now. I traveled internationally only with the Xoom last year to Japan, Singapore, and India. This worked out very well for me and meant that my bag dedicated to laptop and electronics was suddenly much lighter. I plan on using the Galaxy Tab 2 for every day use like editing documents, writing email, viewing websites, watching movies on netflix.

I found the tablet to be very responsive and installed all the applications I wanted but this is where I take one star away and only give 4. If you have an investment in some HD tablet applications like quickoffice HD the market, play store, whatever will claim the device is not compatible. You can install the \\"phone\\" version with no problems. I believe that this is because of the display size primarily but if someone knows more, please let me know here.

Getting ICS by default is nice and means you can get the thing up and running as you want and not sit through updates at first. This makes a very nice difference on these tablets especially. I believe that this form factor is the future for tablets. The Google Nexus tablet will probably come in at this size and we'll see new tablets I believe through this year stress-testing this size.

Finally, the tablet has a very nice feel in the hands and the screen is quite nice and fresh. Installing wallpaper does not result in the usual \\"cropping\\" requirements.

I was never tempted in the final analysis to buy the Kindle Fire or this tablet. I view the Kindle Fire as a \\"Amazon Experience\\" device only. If all you want is that content, by all means get one. I want one that is expandable, has the market/play store on it, can do more tasks and be a light-weight companion when I do travel. I think traveling with this little slate will be quite enjoyable. If you journey forth for pleasure, try doing it with no laptop and using a tablet. Along with the games, wifi connectivity, bluetooth, etc; I'm sold.

Instances.input: The Acase back cover for the iPad 2 is indeed the perfect partner to the SmartCover!  Although it's rigid, unlike the usual silicone \\"skins\\" that I prefer to protect my electronics, it provides similar cushioning to my iPad--plus, the rigidity allows for a truly perfect fit, so it doesn't slip over the rear camera lens or prevent my closing the SmartCover.  I've been able to use FaceTime, including the rear camera, without having to make any adjustments or remove the cover.  And while I can't fully enjoy the sleek matte silver finish of my iPad's back side, it's going to stay that way instead of getting nicked or gouged when I throw it in my backpack.  Best of all, since I'm somewhat of a klutz, I've dropped it several times--but between the Acase and the Smart Cover, no damage was done.  The one inconvenience is that if you use a dock for adding external speakers, you'll probably have to remove both covers.  Maybe there's some kind of adapter that would somehow solve this issue, or some way of using the dock with covers on that I couldn't figure out...but at any rate, it's not a huge issue, as the cover does remove fairly easily.  Note:  the picture on Amazon does show the Acase cover on the back of an iPad but also shows the SmartCover in position as a stand.  If you don't already have a SmartCover, you won't have  that triangular-shaped thing shown in the picture!
With AmazonBasics cables. They seem to be solid enough and the price is fair. Use this as an extension for a USB Plantronics speakerphone and quality is unaffected by the extension.

No problems with this LCD monitor at all. It's my first LCD flat panel, so I haven't got much to compare it with, but I must say, I am pleased. Excellent contrast, bright screen, works well with both my 2 year old G4 PowerMac (in OS 9 and OS X) and my 3 year old Windows 98 PC. I had no problems getting it set up or working with either system.
Of course, it is a transition from a traditional CRT monitor-there is a set "native resolution" that the monitor looks best in (1280 x 1024). Of course you can use other resolutions, but they are not quite as nice. Since I was planning on setting it at 1280 x 1024, this is a non-issue for me. (All LCD monitors have a set "native resolution".) And, color calibration is ... "different" than it is with a CRT. Also, the colors get a little skewed when I look at the screen from an angle. (In this monitor's case, there is a pretty good viewing range, so I have no complaints.) I hasten to add, these are issues with all flat panels, so it comes with the territory! All-in-all, minor issues for me.
I am very pleased with this monitor, and hope to get another just like it soon.

The Kingston 4gb SDHC memory card, like all other Kingston products, is an exceptional piece of equipment.  I use it with my Canon SD1000 and I get nothing but blazing fast write times and no headaches.  Make sure your device supports SDHC because if not, it will not work.  This is a key reason why people are left \\"unsatisfied\\" by what they get, not because of the product, but because they did not do their homework.    Buyers, you should really take note that, most reviews on any site about not only Kingston, but other great brands, is heavily altered by idiot customers leaving comments to attack the site that sold them the items.  So don't quickly judge an product based on how many stars it has, because honestly, you cannot take that into consideration unless you have read every review posted.
output: Don't be swayed by idiot customers..

Instances.input: I have had this router for several months.  Generally speaking it is just OK.  Way overpriced for what you get.  Please note that you cannot combine the two speeds as their advertising would have you believe.  They are separate.  I also purchased a Netgear Dual band wireless USB for my Panasonic TV. Neither the TV or the router will recognize it.  I went to the website for assistance and I couldn't even enter the serial number for support.  Netgear refused to recognize the serial number of their own device, and I was unable to contact support. I will be returning the device to Amazon. Sadly its too late to return the router.  I'm really sorry I went with Netgear.  For networking, you should carefully consider which company you want to be tied to.  Wireless networking, especially with Netgear is a real pain in the a**.  Bye the way, you can buy support from Netgear for some outrageous amount.  I think it should always be free, otherwise it is an incentive for companies to sell defective or inferior products, and for them to make lots money on support subscriptions--seems to be the way things work these days, particularly for companies such as Netgear.
output: Not a great as some would have you believe...

I read the reviews and thought I would take a chance on this product, not a good decision.

This tablet never started up and never registered as a device in ADB nor FASTBOOT, Therefore it is safe to asume that the nand came broken/improperly flashed. A tablet manufacturer has one job when a tablet comes off the assembly, and that is to make sure that the tablet works before its packaged and sold. The corsair Link software did not detect the pump and fans initially on Windows 8.1 and the fans were running on max speed, after several hours of researches, I found a workaround on some forums, modified the registry and got it working, I run both fans now on quiet profile which is roughly 900-1000 RPM and its still loud, while other fans in my rig run at 1600 RPM without any considerable noise.
I have ordered a twin pack of Corsair SP120 PWM High performance edition to replace the stock fans, hopefully the noise will be reduced.

Instances.input: This PSU is completely modular to include the 24 pin connector, SATA, Molex, CPU, and PCI-E connectors. All of the cables are sleeved nicely and included is a nylon storage case for unused cables.The unit is quiet, produces Gold Rated power and is well made. If you are planning on a  2 CPU 2 GPU set up and have a large case there may be a couple of things you want to order with this product. With two GPU's and a motherboard that is going to require multiple PCI-E connections for GPU power, you will run out of outlets on the power supply. I am running an EVGA SR2 motherboard with 2 GPU's in SLI. The SR2 requires 3 PCI-E connections to power the SLI configuration and in this configuration you will end up one outlet short. If this is the case order two 8 pin to 2xPCI-E 8 pin Y cables and you will be in good shape length and connection wise. If you have a large case you may want to order extensions for the CPU connections. OCZ could make their cables 2 inches longer and it would solve the length issue. I have seen some negative comments about OCZ power supplies but as far as I am concerned there is no issue and I would purchase this product again.

Did you ever buy something and get more than you expected? Well this is one of those times. First, it performs as advertised, and works well. But then, that's what we pay for and that's what we should get. What I didn't expect is it shuts off when it isn't being used therefore the batteries should last forever - well, not forever but for a long time. When it wakes up a green LED comes on letting you know it's awake and the batteries have  enough power to support your work. The instructions tell you when the battery (one AA cell) is nearing the end of its life, a red LED will come on. I haven't used it enough for that to happen but I'm sure it will. If that doesn't work as advertised, I will be on with a follow up. The instructions also give you an option to d/l software to take advantage of Windows Eight and move the screen back and fourth in addition to the more conventional up and down. I haven't tried that little feature but when I do, I'm sure it will perform as advertised. Finally, and this is a small item, - I'm talking about the antenna. It's a tiny little thing. It only protrudes from the USB port a 1/4 inch (6mm). You don't even know it's there. The only down side, the mouse is a little on the small side, perfect for the small or average sized hand but some ham handed person may find it too small for them.

So far so good. I let you know how good when I see how long the battery lasts!
Though I asked if there was a charger with it and was told yes-but it was not the type of charger I thought I was asking for. It was USB charger, not outlet charger. Had to buy that seperate. Absolutely no paperwork with it, no instructions. Everything had to be done online. All questions, etc.
Fine for the tech-savy. A little annoying for the not-so-tech-savy!

Wanted to backup a 3tb drive from my 3 year old Rosewill RX-DU300 dock to another 3tb drive, so I needed a second docking station. I figures 3tb hdd have been out for years now, and I don't see why any docking station should not be able to recognize them.

Reading the reviews I figured I would buy this product, after already buying and trying out the \\"Plugable USB 3.0/2.0 SATA Hard Drive Docking Station (ASMedia Chipset; UASP and 3TB+ Support)\\" that did not work.
When I got it I plugged it to my computer and it did not recognize 3tb hdd drives I placed in it (Toshiba, and Seagate). Item was promptly returned to Amazon for a refund.

Finally I just spent the extra 5 dollars (Was trying to get them on sale) and purchased my second \\"Rosewill 2.5-Inch and 3.5-Inch USB 3.0 Hard Drive Docking RX-DU300\\" would you believe i? It just plugged in and worked right out of the box, as it should because that is what it stated it did in the first place.

Only thing I must point out that it is a slick looking docking station, but the wires in the back would not allow me to put it against the wall with power button faced out to me, had to be placed at a slant. could easily be designed to allow wires to go under and plug in so that I can have it against wall, but that would require someone who knows what they are doing and this is a fail on their part.

Hope this helps someone from returns, wasting time, and trips to the UPS store.

----------------- Update

Just got an email form Plugable to let me know that the 3tb read/write might only function with the chipset of the Docking station I am currently using \\"\\"Rosewill\\". Since I can't confirm this and not sure nor have heard of chipsets read/writing to drives in a different manner.

No 1: I am alarmed by this information and hope that I don't lose any data. Need to do some deep research on the subject.
No 2: I have to give a neutral 3 star update for \\"Plugable\\" and \\"Sabrent\\" plus 1 extra star to \\"Plugable\\" for great customer service.
output: Cant read 3tb drives. update to 3 stars.

I wrote a scathing review about a month ago regarding this product. To be fair and honest I am making an update to my review as slowly with use I have grown to like the tablet and its versitility. I am using this machine more and more and my iPad less and less.

The main problems I had with this machine was poor WiFi performance and great difficulty every time I wanted to connect a Bluetooth mouse. The first problem was solved by installing a Diamond WiFi booster. The Bluetooth problem was solved by throwing away this type of mouse and buying a USB wireless mouse.

With these problems resolved its a great little powerful and versatile machine. Acer should take note and in newer models improve WiFi performance and Bluetooth connectability and then they would have a fantastic product to sell.

Below is my original review:-

In less than a month I am on my third machine. The first came with no sound so was returned. The second machine I managed to break the glass screen on the first day and once again returned the product. The third machine seemed OK until I left the USA to return home only to discover that the WiFi is complete crap. Move more than a few feet from the router and it feels like your connected via an ancient telephone modem. I installed new drivers for the WiFi which improved perfomance a little bit was still crap.

Only buy this machine if your going to use it sat beside your router. Forget about being able to use the machine in your bedroom or sitting room unless thats where you have your router.

I am now outside the USA and trying to see how I can return this piece of s***, get my money back and return to using my faithfull old iPad.

I cannot understand how Amazon sells such lousey products. They should withdraw this product from sale.

BE WARNED AND DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT!!!!!!!.

This is a great motherboard !!! For those that didn't like it either didn't know what they were doing or needed to RMA it, because they screwed it up.  It has been very reliable.  My own personal computer, I have been using for over 10 years and it still works great. I personally use Gigabyte motherboards exclusively for all my builds along with AMD CPU's. (for years and years) Why ? because they are the best. They know what they are doing and the quality is not hype. (as proven in court cases). So much is "under the hood" so to speak. I love their reliability.  Of course, as many of these posts show their ignorance, anyone can screw up a fine piece of equipment, before they even assemble it. (static electricity, etc)  A person who drives a truck will not appreciate a Ferrari when he tries to use it like a truck.  Some education  and experience applies. I personally have never had to RMA a single motherboard, nor an AMD CPU. Believe the posts that speak of the quality they notice right out of the box.  There is some configuration that needs to be done in many cases. Learn from someone who knows what they are doing rather than some student who experiments and "hopefully", learns from their screw ups, how not to do it. Operating systems can also show stupidity. 7 is absolutely better than 8. Newer can be worse than tried and proven. I personally use Linux almost exclusively. Only users know how sweet it can be with the proper distro. and hardware. Don't always believe the numbers, they can be misleading if not downright deceptive.
output: Fantastic board !!! (Best on the planet?) One of the best that Gigabyte has ever produced. A diamond in the rough.

Background. I have small hands and Logitech mice always work much better than Microsoft mice for me.

Pros:
1. Excellent tracking -- much much better than standard optical, especially on tough surfaces.
2. Higher dpi -- must compensate by slowing mouse down in software.
3. Price -- reasonable at under $20.

Cons:
A. Mouse is generally too high -- considerably higher than the other Logitech mice I have.
B. Ergonomic hump is bad -- other Logitech mice have a hump in the middle of the mouse, but this one has it on the front-edge -- clearly a bad design feature. This forces my wrist into a higher position.
C. Not as comfortable for long use -- but with a mouse pad, works out better.

This device runs on a Linux system that is tailored specifically for it.  All told, I am very happy with this device, so much so that I bought a second one within a month.
Arrived quicker than expected and as described, couldn't ask for more. Also have been using it for about a month and it seems brand new and holds a charge very well.

We are very happy with this case. Hold the IPAD in place by velcro. Nice padding on the inside. It protects the IPAD very well. Shipping was very quick coming from the UK. Price was great! I would buy another.

Instances.input:
This review is of the Heat Orange Edition. Some aspects may or may not apply to other versions.

I like the shape, weight, and feel of the mouse. I have average-sized hands and it fits perfectly; I use the "palm" grip. I am right-handed so I use the two top main buttons with my index and middle fingers and the side buttons on the left with my thumb. The buttons are easy to click and have a great feel to them. I originally wanted to also use the buttons on the right side but they are not easily accessible without moving my entire hand, so I hardly use them. I also use the top DPI button but I rarely use it to change the DPI, I use it for other things (More on that below in the software section).The mouse wheel rolls just fine, not too loose nor too stiff. However, to click the mouse wheel button requires more force than I would prefer. It seems to be getting easier over time though so maybe it requires a break-in period. The braided wire on the mouse seems like a good idea in terms of durability; however, the texture of the braid gets caught on the shelf my mouse and keyboard rest on and interrupts my movements. It's minor but still pretty annoying.

I love the SteelSeries Engine software that pairs with the mouse. You can set various profiles according to the different games you play. So for instance, in Battlefield 4 I have the top button change the DPI from say 1800 to 2800 for sniping (and there is a light to let you know which mode you are in). But in DOTA 2 I have the button programmed as a macro which simulates pressing "2" "W" "B" on the keyboard, which selects the courier, sends it to the secret shop, and adds a speed boost. It's nice to be able to turn three relatively awkward key presses into one. In the default profile, I have the left side mouse buttons set to forward and back for web browsing, the right side buttons to page up and page down, which is faster than scrolling with the mouse wheel. In addition to programming buttons, you can also adjust the brightness of the LEDs on the mouse and turn them off completely if you desire. I personally really love the "breathing" effect. This is my first "gaming" mouse and it is by far the best looking mouse I've ever had.

My biggest complaint about this mouse is that the smooth, shiny surface accumulates grime very quickly. I wash my hands regularly and don't consider myself a dirty or sloppy person by any stretch of the imagination so I honestly don't know how it gets this small, kind of sticky stuff on it. I don't use lotion or anything like that either. At any rate, I wonder if other models of this mouse have a different texture and are less likely to get buildup. I seriously have to wipe it at least once a day, which only takes a second, but it's rather annoying. Otherwise, it would easily get 5 stars, especially if it continues to work well for at least a few years.
output: Excellent hardware and software but a minor cleaning issue

Instances.input:
I am a complete newbie to applying any kind of screen protector. Seriously.. this is the first I've ever done. I will say you SHOULD NOT try using the dust removal tape by sliding it along the screen. It will leave residue, though it easily comes off when you use the tape by pressing and lifting (as I should have done to begin with. I was being lazy. Sue me.)

The first application was my learning experience. I tried aligning it with just the awake button at the bottom when I should have aligned with the bottom edge of the ipad. The first go-around, I was left with lots of dust and bubbles from constantly trying to lift and realign. The second protector went on perfectly when aligned with the bottom edge. I am SO happy with this product. I can't yet comment on the protective nature, but I'll update if anything happens to my screen in the future. Definitely happy with my purchase thus far!

this cover is nice and sturdy works well all holes line up correctly cant beat the price as compared to other stores for sure! would recommend this item Ive had it for 3 months with continuous use so its a thumbs up for me very fast delivery as well!
For my granddaughter, and she loves it. She loves to read!

I have used this for 2 days now - the first day I ended up borrowing a friend's Microsoft wireless mouse (which worked flawlessly) because my 2 hour old Kensington was falling apart (there are 3 magnets inside holding the case together, 2 of mine came off the first day). I glued the 2 magnets back on that night, and the second day was better, but after using it for about 15 minutes, it would start flaking out and I would be unable to select anything on the screen. I ended up borrowing a friends Logitech wireless, which also worked flawlessly. Now I liked the idea of this one - mainly the slim profile so I could slip it in my pocket, but the construction is cheap and the performance is unreliable. Both the Microsoft and Logitech mice were clearly of higher quality construction. I don't know which one I'm going to buy but this one is destined for the trash bin. I forgot to mention that the wheel rubs against the plastic, so when I use the wheel, I have to hold it slightly to the left just so it will rotate, again - cheap construction.

I bought this little bluetooth and added it to my Dell D620 laptop.  That was fairly easy.  The difficult part was finding the correct driver for my laptop.  I finally found one that worked on the Toshiba website.  I downloaded a zip file called BT-stack-toshiba, within the zip is a file called v80012T_20110809_x32.  This is the only driver I could find that would work with my Dell D620 Windows 7 Ultimate 32 bit version. A few other drivers would install and my mouse might work for a few seconds but this is the only driver that actually worked. I did get an error installing this driver but then it loaded ok afterward.
output: Works well if you have the correct driver

As long as you know exactly what you are getting with the Hauppauge HD PVR, you won't be disappointed with the performance of this little black box. It is designed for PC Windows users only, although Mac owners can use it with some add-ons.

First, you'll need to understand and accept what this PVR does not do: without any memory or hard drive inside, it does not store video itself, making the PVR label somewhat misleading, and it does not burn video to DVD. To use it, you must hook it up to a PC or Mac (more on the Mac later) for both recording and playback. And it relies entirely on software running on your computer to record, edit, program, and burn Blu-ray format DVDs. The box itself has no controls other than a power button. It has component, composite, and S-video connections (no HDMI) for video, and optical and stereo audio inputs.

So what does it do? It takes the HD signals streaming into it and compresses them in a format that preserves the HD quality in a savable AVCHD file; you can record/save manually or on a schedule. These signals can come from a set top box, camcorder or other video source that can connect with the above inputs. The included ArcSoft Media software for Windows allows you to record on either the computer hard drive or an external one. Once the files are saved, you may use your computer's DVD-R drive to burn a Blu-Ray-compatible DVD or HD-DVD, edit, play back on your computer or television, convert to iPod-, Xbox-, or PS3-friendly format (MOV, MP4, M2TS, or WMV), or share playback within the same wireless network. The included IR blaster can change the channels on your set top box to the one you've programmed to record. Note: the blaster works with the included software and therefore only on Windows.

Chances are, you're going to have to do some thinking before you decide how to set up the PVR. The conversion box is 7.5\\" w by 6.5\\" d by 2/5 \\" h, so it doesn't take up much space itself. However, you will need a computer next to the HD source. For those who don't have their computer in the same room as the set top box, this may mean buying a computer specifically for video, and naturally, that increases the price of the set-up. However, if you don't plan on recording every day, you can hook up/unhook a laptop very easily - just pull out the USB cable and your connection, if any, to the television. Hauppauge includes the basic component cables (HD source to PVR) and USB cable (PVR to your computer), but, if you want to play the video back on your TV, you will need to buy the necessary cables/connections for that. As of June 2009, the bundled PC software includes a program that allows your PC DVD drive to play the PVR Blu-Ray-format recordings. Depending on your set-up, you may want to add a USB hub, an external hard drive, and/or Apple TV.

Unfortunately for Mac users, Hauppauge does not support OS X, which means you'll have an additional software expense. Two software packages currently work with the Mac and the Hauppauge. The cheaper and less elegant solution is a program called HDPVR Capture, developed and sold privately by a Hauppauge engineer. The fuller featured, more versatile option is Elgato's EyeTV , but unfortunately, you can't use several of the features because it doesn't communicate with the IR Blaster to change channels. Both programs are available only online, although EyeTV 3 comes bundled with Elgato hardware products. If you can find a workaround for the blaster issue, the EyeTV 3 will be nothing short of awesome. It converts the PVR files to a wide variety of formats used by iLife programs. Hauppauge really needs to work more closely with Elgato to satisfy the rapidly growing Mac population. If you are a serious videophile and Mac user, you'll probably also want a product like [[ASIN:B001OLZOW8 Roxio Toast 10 Titanium Pro]].

The minimum systems requirements for the PVR are: Intel Core Duo processor, 512 MBRAM (1 GB recommended), graphics card with at least 256 MB memory, and a sound card. Windows users need either the XP Service Pack or Vista 32. I'm using a three year old Intel Core Duo MacBook without any difficulty. I bypass the MacBook's hard drive to save all my recordings on a portable external hard drive, the [[ASIN:B001C5AJLM Iomega eGo 320 GB USB 2.0/FireWire 400 Portable External Hard Drive 34403 (Ruby Red)]].

Consumers expecting a DVR with onboard memory and playback may be frustrated with the Hauppauge since it requires a computer, but for those who want to capture HD content and do something with it, you've found your equipment.

With special thanks to fellow reviewer Frank Miller.

-- Debbie Lee Wesselmannd with at least 256 MB memory, and a sound card. Windows users need either the XP Service Pack or Vista 32. I'm using a three year old Intel Core Duo MacBook without any difficulty. I bypass the MacBook's hard drive to save all my recordings on a portable external hard drive, the [[ASIN:B001C5AJLM Iomega eGo 320 GB USB 2.0/FireWire 400 Portable External Hard Drive 34403 (Ruby Red)]]. Consumers expecting a DVR with onboard memory and playback may be frustrated with the Hauppauge since it requires a computer, but for those who want to capture HD content and do something with it, you've found your equipment. With special thanks to fellow reviewer Frank Miller. -- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
output: A Powerful Device for PCs and, with add-ons, for Macs

Instances.input: Had visible scratches the second day. My previous one (different brand) lasted 2 years without a scratch.
