Update 6/30/2015: This laptop is still ticking away. I now have the power options set to sleep on lid close, and I don't use the touchscreen much in day to day use so those issues have pretty much disappeared for me -- I do not know if they are legitimately fixed at this time but since the power setting change the trackpad has not caused any issue at all.  This laptop is typically on my desk beside my main computer, for using Facebook chat or reading messages boards while I use the main one for playing games or videos.  I also take it with me whenever I need a machine away from the house, and don't bother bringing the charger -- it beats any tablet I've used in speed and also battery life depending on what exactly you're doing.  I really can't complain too much about this computer.  It does feel a bit sluggish at times but I still believe that's more to do with the hard drive than anything else, because once it gets going on a CPU intensive task it's quite impressive "for a 1.9ghz machine".  I have also managed to play Euro Truck Simulator 2 much more smoothly than I had anticipated, although it can't run at maximum settings.  I frequently take it from the desk to the bed and run on battery power for continuing Facebook / message board use and I've been impressed with battery life.  One thing that irks me is that with large (inefficiently encoded) 1080p h264 video files it seems to stutter, and I'm not sure why because the CPU / iGPU should be more than capable of handling that plus some.  It's 100% been my 1080p video game recordings from my main computer using NVIDIA ShadowPlay that cause this problem so it may just be the way it's encoded.  If I recode them in Handbrake with my custom settings (which are pretty hefty) they work just fine.  I'm reluctantly adding the fourth star here just because this laptop, even with its faults, is the best $500 I've spent and I wish I had gotten one sooner.  And just once again, the sound that comes from this thing is amazing.  Every time I turn up the volume on a video or song I'm still surprised at how crisp and vibrant it sounds.  To be fair, one other thing I have to note is that occasionally it will say "unrecognized charger" or something along those lines, and will continue to run but not charge (or discharge) the battery.  This seems to only happen during CPU / GPU intensive use and unplugging + replugging the charger fixes it every time.  Not sure what to say about that one.  ------------------------------------------------------------------  Update 4/19/15:  Overall the replacement has been doing well.  It runs everything I expected it to so far and the performance is about where I expected it to be.  It's pretty smooth and the battery life is good.  I'm leaving my stars where they sit for now and I'll go into that in a minute but some things I've noticed:  Battery -- If I'm browsing the web or doing something non intensive, the computer claims the battery will last anywhere from 7 hours to over 10 hours depending on what you're doing.  But if you're using the CPU at 100% or a combination of CPU/GPU, that number will drop to about 2.5 hours.  According to my history so far of actual usage (powercfg /batteryreport)... the low end of my projected battery time is 3.5 hours, high end is 7.5 hours, for an average of about 5.5 hours.  I almost always use it for a mixture of web, lightweight games, and videos while on battery.  I find this quite acceptable and similar to what I expected for this CPU.  I haven't timed how long it takes to charge the battery but it seems faster than most laptops I've used.  Apps -- Sometimes Metro apps take an abnormally long time to load, and I'm not sure why.  It's usually Facebook or a file manager that does it.  My Venue 8 Pro doesn't do this, and this CPU is more than capable of running any app, so I don't know what to say on that other than "weird".  Once loaded there aren't any problems.  Sensors --  Gyro is smooth and responsive, I have been playing Asphalt 8 some using tilt steering.  The light sensor seems to be well adjusted for screen brightness (not too bright, not too dark) although I do wish the minimum brightness of the computer in general was a little lower for very low light use.  I understand most screens don't go extremely dim, but it seems like it should be an option.  Sound -- I really didn't expect to have anything to say about sound, but the speakers are surprisingly crisp and loud for their size. Don't expect theater quality sound or a hidden subwoofer, but it'll probably make you do a double take the first time you crank something up.  Speed -- I really don't have any complaints in that area. I know it's not a gaming computer by any stretch but I have been able to run Civ V, Sims 4, and Flatout: Ultimate Carnage without a hitch after a few tweaks. I haven't tried much else besides older games so far (DosBox, Tiberian Sun, Empire Earth II, etc). I should note that to get the best experience you'll want to run any newer games while plugged in, to enable active cooling and eliminate any CPU / GPU throttling unless you want to change those settings manually, which will decrease battery life.  One thing I noticed is restarts and starts from shutdown are slow despite Windows 8's quick start feature. I'm willing to bet it's mainly the HDD's fault and upgrading to SSD will probably make a world of difference. I almost always use sleep or hibernate so it's ready quickly and isn't a big deal to me.  Input -- In general the touch input (screen and touchpad) takes a little getting used to but is acceptable, if a little less responsive than you might expect.  Sometimes though for whatever reason, it gets weird (this is why my stars are staying the same).  It's not often enough for me to return it but it's often enough to be irritating.  For the touchscreen I notice it starts to degrade or stop responding in certain areas of the screen (random areas) before eventually becoming unusable or not responding at all.  This seems somewhat random.  The touchpad sometimes will disable everything except the "button" area of the pad.  This seems to be a little more likely to happen if I close the lid while the computer is on (power setting: do nothing when lid closes) and open it back up again later.  I suspect that both of these issues are driver related because I can't seem to "cause" them by any movement of the computer or lid, except sometimes fully closing the lid.  I hope it will be fixed soon.  For some reason, 99% of the time, either or both of these problems can be fixed by putting the computer to sleep and waking it up again although I have had to do a full shutdown or restart a time or two.  Conclusion:  This computer is so close to the mark of what I was looking for in this purchase that I almost feel bad about giving it only 3 stars.  But a problem like not accepting input, is something I can't say I've ever seen before and that really brought me down out of the clouds.  The price is nice (compared to similar products), it looks and feels good, but to get an edge it must deliver on its promises consistently.  ------------------------------------------------------------------  Update 4/7/15:  I ended up getting a replacement of the same model because it was easier and I hoped I would get a good one.  So far so good.  This one does not have the keyboard warping I described before, and the hard drive seems quieter.  I am installing apps and updates now... Will be cautiously upping the stars a bit until I figure out how this goes, but I'm still a little upset about getting a bad one.  Things happen though and I'll update again later about this one.  ------------------------------------------------------------------  Update 4/4/15:  Well I guess I spoke too soon.  I really wanted to like this laptop but it looks like I couldn't avoid a defective one after all.  Within 24 hours of having it, it's developed a problem in the screenwhere it seems to invert some colors.  This is not a Windows or driver issue as it happens from the time it's turned on, in BIOS, and in diagnostics.  It's also retaining ghosts of any image left up for any period of time (minutes) that don't go away until hours later.  I will be sending this back as soon as possible and deciding whether I want to chance it with another one or go for the 1.7ghz version again.  If I get another of this model I will update again...  ------------------------------------------------------------------  Original (too early) review:  I had originally bought the older 1.7ghz i3 model of this laptop due to the 4/5 bad reviews on this one (and a hefty discount on the other for buying a lightly used one), but when things didn't work out with that (shipping drama, long story) I decided to take a chance and grab this one against my better judgement.  I figured if I could avoid one of the defective ones I should be able to count on the touchscreen / trackpad problems being fixed and any other minor bugs being worked out to some extent.  I've only had it a few hours but so far I'm glad I did it.  One confession I have to make is that I'm a bit of a Dell fanboy, but I think with good reason.  I have had a lot of computers over the years, and I work on them for friends and family.  As far as laptops go I get more HPs thrown at me with hardware problems, and more Dells with software problems -- usually the problem is between the keyboard and the chair.  I have had several Dells myself, I even have a working Latitude XPi P133ST from 1997 purely for nostalgia, and overall they've been good to me and relatively trouble free.  With that out of the way...  Overall this is a very solid laptop.  It looks and feels nice although a bit heavy for a tablet, but that wasn't the main reason I bought it.  The case doesn't have a lot of flex, and it doesn't seem to creak and pop if you pick it up by a corner while open, which I'm prone to do.  The hinges are pretty snug and it doesn't wobble around excessively.  There will always be a slight wobble with any laptop and this is apparent when using the touchscreen in laptop or stand mode, but not annoyingly so.  The keyboard area is a little spongey (which is pretty common these days) and this one in particular seems to have a very slight upward curve in the middle, neither of which affect performance (and not really noticeable if you aren't looking for it) but that's just me being picky.  The older model I had for two days was also spongey but did not have the curve, so that isn't related.  Probably a minor manufacturing defect that I can overlook.  At first I was put off by the buttonless trackpad but it seems to do pretty well, and I do like that it can click anywhere on the pad.  The fan is on the rear of the computer which is kind of odd but I see why they did it; if it was on the side like usual then it'd be kind of awkward to hold in tablet mode.  I wanted this because it was a reasonably powerful small form factor machine and had a touchscreen, which I personally think Win8 is worthless without.  This is meant to replace both a Dell Inspiron N5050 (2nd gen i3 @ 2.3ghz) and an HP Mini 1104 (dual core Atom -- which had a failing wireless card when I got it second hand, if anyone's counting HP hardware problems).  It theoretically is the best of both worlds -- comparable power to the N5050, with the form and battery life of the Mini.  Don't quote me on this but by my calculations and a little research, a Haswell U-series i3 @ 1.9ghz should give a Sandy Bridge M-series i3 @ 2.3ghz a good run for it's money while using around half the power.  On these things, it seems to deliver.  The hard drive is definitely the bottleneck in this computer and I'll probably be replacing it with an SSD in the future.  Once it's booted up and ready to go, it handles "normal" tasks with ease and is quite smooth.  With the integrated HD4400 I think it should play a fair amount of moderngames, if only on low settings, but it may have to be plugged in for that since the passive cooling setting and other tweaks for battery operation will degrade the performance.  As for the battery... I can't say for certain yet but I think I am going to be pleased.  Out of the box it had ~95% charge and I've been messing around for about 5 hours, some of that time was plugged up (#1 to make sure it recognized the charger and would charge, and #2 for bios update) and it still says it has 22% charge.  Most of that time was spent installing software, copying files, and extracting archives.  If you're playing games or doing anything CPU / disk intensive your battery life will be cut in half probably, but with some light web browsing and such I could see it easily lasting 7-8 hours from a full charge if not more.  I'd imagine a few tweaks in the power settings for the GPU performance, video optimization, and max CPU state could stretch the battery a bit.  In conclusion, so far I have had no issues out of this little guy other than my being picky about the keyboard.  It's done everything I've asked of it and then some.  The trackpad has been a little odd on occasion, mostly being not quite as sensitive to taps as I expect.  Or it could be that I'm just not used to it yet.  So far I'm very happy with it and I will update if anything changes.  The only thing I'm not thrilled about is that literally hours after I bought this, Amazon reduced the price by $60.  Assuming the computer is in good working order (time will tell how many are defective I guess), I don't think you can go wrong at this price range.  Similar models from other manufacturers seem to go for more money and still have less battery life, so the decision to go Dell once again was pretty easy for me.  Sorry if this was long winded, but I hope it helps someone.

Instances.input:
FINALLY!!! My ASUS G73J Republic of Gamers computer FITS INSIDE THE COMPUTER COMPARTMENT of this bag!

I've been looking all over for a bag that will fit my mondo computer. This bag does the trick.

I'm giving it only 4 stars, because it's a very basic bag. I don't much like the layout . . . here's why:
Notice the two clips on the front . . . those clips attach the top of a front flap. You could put your coat in there & snap the clips on above it . . . but I hardly ever use that type of functionality. The pockets aren't as well organized for holding all my various computer gear as my old bag ([[ASIN:B000WQCYDI Swiss Gear Ibex 17-Inch Notebook Backpack]]) which was awesome EXCEPT the old bag didn't handle my oversized computer well. (Actual computer dimensions: 17\\" x 13\\" x 2.5\\")

I don't like it when things can fall out of a bag . . . and the storage inside that \\"clipped flap\\" (2 big mesh pockets) would be great for holding stuff, but don't have a zipper to secure the contents.

SO . . . bottom line:
Five stars for fitting my ASUS G73J
Minus 1 star for mediocre bag layout & being such a \\"basic\\" bag.

I'll use it for a while . . . and if I get to really like that flap, I'll upgrade back to 5 stars . . . but . . . for now . . . I would highly recommend this bag as a basic transport for your ASUS G73J.

((EDIT)) . . . minus another star for lack of padding & the bag doesn't stand up on it's own. I replaced the bag with this [[ASIN:B00507NAYQ Targus Drifter II Backpack Designed for 17-Inch Laptop TSB239US (Black/Gray)]] . . . a MUCH better bag! The [[ASIN:B00376ANBK ASUS G73JH-X3 Laptop Computer]] does NOT fit in the computer slot, but it DOES fit in the same compartment, is well padded as such, and even fits in that compartment WITH my backup computer (HP G60-535DX).
output: Basic Bag: fits ASUS Republic of Gamers G73J

Just got my keyboard cover and I have to say, I love it! The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars are the following to factors:

Instances.input: During Amazon's Prime Day I saw this laptop for sale in two colors one being blue and the other being a violet pink. I wanted the blue, but it was sold out immediately so I had to settle for the violet pink. It's very light, small than basic laptops, and is a very fast laptop to my surprise. If you don't like the touch sensor mouse that it has you can connect a mouse view usb or wirelessly to accommodate your preferences. I don't use apps as much on it, so a lot of space is just taken up from pictures on my phone while my music and videos are all separately put on an external hard drive. Unlike the later models this one isn't touch screen so your using a mouse all the time, but I'm okay with that. I still haven't gotten the recent update for Windows 10, but again I'm okay with that. Maybe it'll update somewhere down the line, but it's whatever. It's pretty convenient that it came with the Microsoft Office Suite for a year, but the supposed $25 gift card from Microsoft is invalid due to link being a dead end. Other than those few tidbits I'm satisfied with this purchase and use this laptop with no issues at all.

This router's speed and range is also not as good as the Asus RT-N56U. I ended up going with Netgear WNDR4500 as it seems to have the best range and average speeds.

Much better than anticipated. None of the reviews I read mentioned that there were magnets on the front flap that activated the device like Apple's Smart Cover. Very nice touch!  There's a strong chemical smell to the product, but otherwise I can't think of another negative. It's well padded, is very sturdy and seems like it could shelter the device from a decent fall. The mechanism that allows the case to fold into a stand is firm, and the stand itself is sturdy once you situate the iPad directly into the grooves on the cover. It does add thickness to the device, but that's to be expected with a padded leather folio case.  edit: The initial case I received from the seller became slightly loose/defective after several months of use. I sent a message to the seller and promptly received a new case within 2 business days that's *improved* over the previous design. Very impressed.  AYL tweaked the design a bit to make the notches in the cover more angular instead of rounded. This benefit allows the device to now use all the notches for the stand, as opposed to only the first few. Very pleased with both the case and the seller's service.
Fits my Kindle Fire perfectly. Very sturdy. Even four-year-olds can manipulate this case. It was exactly what I was looking for.

This case is a perfect fit to a 11.6" Acer Aspire One 756.  The case is hard, so it protects the netbook from all the other things I have in my bag.  I've been using this case for 2 months, and the material is quality and looks like it will last.  I especially love the vibrant teal color!  Unfortunately, dirt shows easily on this bright color. It is also a bit heavier than a typical neoprene laptop sleeve, but I think the better protection makes up for this.  I would recommend this case to anyone with a netbook!
output: Great case for a small laptop

Have you ever had a dream where you are on a beach surrounded by beautiful women enjoying paradise, then your mother shows up and someone drives your car into the ocean? It's kinda like that. For a few hours I was surfing the internet, streaming music with Pandora, watching videos on YouTube, movies on the Xfinity TV player app, comedy on HBO GO and shows on Netflix. It didn't make a sound, perfect for the bedroom, used nearly no power, economical and ecological, created no heat compared to consoles, great for summer in small rooms.

Then it was all taken away from me the next morning when cheap construction combined with bad firmware left me without all those features I was so excited about. Being tech savvy, I flashed a new ROM from the website that worked once. Then it was a hardbrick \\"almost unheard of in the Android world\\"; I really miss the features...

If you are looking into getting one of these I would recommend waiting for a Dell Project Ophelia, or if you are savvy sideloading apps on the Ouya. Both coming in July and late June respectively.

But if you wanna take a gamble, go ahead and get one, if you get a winner that keeps running, it's pretty awesome... goodluck.

I purchased this three times.

Review for the one I purchased on 9-23-14: Just a few days old, so it is still working.

Review for the one I purchased on 6-23-14:

Worked perfectly for 3 months until 9-30-14. The connection where the power cord connects to the USB piece developed a problem. I have to position this part of the cord manually so that it will keep working. Otherwise, the fan stops working. I believe, in a few days, the cord (and so the fan) will be completely useless. The manufacturer has to make better quality power cords (thicker; not just a tiny, slim cord). It is nice that the fan itself is slim (as the name implies), but the power cord shouldn't be that slim; it has to be thicker. I searched their website; I couldn't find power cords as accessories. With a replacement power cord, the fan would be fully functional again... until the same thing happens. Where do I find a replacement power cord (preferably better quality)?

Also I attached sticky rubber pads to the bottom of my notebook, so it doesn't slide anymore when the tabs in the back of the fan are extended (see my first review below).

Review for the one I purchased on 6-6-12:

Pros: Very efficient and nice design. Large fan, silent, slim and light.
Cons: If you use it in a flat position, it is OK. However, if you use it in an inclined position (by flipping the tabs in the back), your notebook will slide, as it has no rubber pads (What is the purpose of adding tabs to the fan, if it has no rubber pads to prevent the notebook from sliding, I wonder). After 2 hours of initial use, it started to produce a strong, burning-plastic odor. I had to return it the next day.
output: Five stars for a short time, then becomes two stars

Instances.input: This is an excellent cable. It charges my Samsung Galaxy Tab S at the full rate of the charger. I especially like the dimples in the angle connecter, which provide a little better grip than some other angle-micro-usb cables. The only thing that stops me from giving it five stars is the micro-usb end is a little tight in my Samsung Galaxy Tab S. Maybe it will loosen up a little over time, but as it is now, compared to the OEM Samsung cable, this cable requires about twice as much pressure to plug in.  3/8/2015 UPDATE: After hearing repeated complaints about the tablet taking a long time to charge, I finally got around to checking the charge rate using a "USB Charger Doctor" type device. Turns out that this cable maxes out at less than 1/2 amp, no matter which charger I use. The OEM cable charges the Samsung Galaxy Tab S at about 1.75 amps, with the OEM charger, or any of the Orico multi-port chargers I tried.  Since I specifically asked the seller about this before I bought it (and was told it 'supported' a 2 amps charge rate when used with the OEM charger) I have reduced the rating to one star.  I now know that in order to charge at the full rate, either the cable or the charger must have the data lines connected together. This cable does not.
output: micro-usb end is a little tight, maximum charge rate is 1/2 amp

I ordered two of these fans to replace the 200mm fans in a Cooler Master Storm Enforcer Case. What I quickly found was the universal mounts that come on the BitFenix make it not fit in the Cooler Master case. Others have said the same regarding this product and other Cooler Master cases. Thankfully I have a full tool shop and was able to take the fans to my jigsaw and cut off the extra plastic that was blocking their installation. That being said, that is NOT the reason I gave the product a 2 star rating.

The reason for the 2 star rating is due to the self tapping screws that come with the fan. They are ABSOLUTE RUBBISH. The screw is supposed to seat itself into the plastic mounting hole of the fan for installation. This requires quite a bit of torque on the screw. I am by no means a muscle head, but without fail, each head on the screws supplied got stripped while simply trying to turn them in by hand before they were even flush with the case. This happened with no less than 3 different screw drivers, just to make sure my tool wasn't the issue. I then had to take needle nose pliers to back each screw out. Fortunately the screws that came with the Cooler Master fans were still around. I twisted them in with no issue and now have the fans mounted.

Having gone through all of that, I would say avoid these fans and stick with Cooler Master. Though the Cooler Master fans may not move as much air (reportedly), they are superior in quality.
output: Will not fit a Cooler Master Storm Enforcer case without heavy modding.  Screws provided are garbage.  Avoid.

This screen is NOT compatible with the Asus G72GX-RBBX05, as the listing says. The connector for this screen is on the opposite side of the cable in the laptop, meaning you have to get an adapter of some sorts or wire it yourself somehow, neither of which the seller states in their listing. It might be a great screen, but it doesn't work with the laptop it's advertised for.

Also, seller expects me to pay for shipping both ways, despite their false advertising.

EDIT: I actually got an adapter cable to move the connector to the right side of the screen, and it still did not work. I then ordered a screen from a different seller, which was also advertised to work with the G72, and also had a resolution of 1920 x 1080, and it worked. So basically this seller is falsely advertising compatibility and their customer service did not provide a full refund (including shipping) when I made them aware of it. Amazon, however, DID provide a full refund.
output: Does not work with the G72GX-RBBX05

Instances.input:
I attempted to use this for work with an HP Elitebook laptop running windows 8 and I am very unhappy. I'm chucking these in the trash as I waited a bit too long to return them. There are a few issues:

Once paired, the blue tooth connection would often fail to reconnect. The device would need to be removed using the windows blue tooth control panel and then paired again. It made me late for several calls.

The blue tooth audio connection was very poor and "popped and cracked." It was difficult for me to participate in conversations and music was un-listenable.

After a few weeks, the small boom microphone would not stay in place. It freely swung around and could not be manually positioned.

These headphones have generally good reviews so I'm surprised with my experience. Perhaps the manufacturer has released a new poorly conceived model recently.

At this point I only get a 94% full charge notice, and it runs down in less than 2 hours. As well my screen flashes while the battery is charging, plugged in. I assume this might be the power plan settings, but I can't get it to stop this issue. It's a flash that happens every few seconds. So, I am not totally happy with this battery as it isn't lasting as long as I wanted it to, like my old one that lasted 4 hours. I have followed his instructions on how to charge it up for the first times. I am going through those instructions again. If the seller is reading here and can give me some suggestions, I would welcome them as to how to get more life from my battery, or how to stop that flash screen while it is charging. Email me if you need to ask more questions. That's about all I can tell you guys at this point. It works, but not to my expecations...unless there is something else I need to do to make it work better. I'm waiting to see if seller responds before I send it back.

Excellent, sturdy, well manufactured cable. This cable is very useful to connect an external USB hard drive to the computer. One of the best features is its The extra long length (6' long)- that alone renders this as an immensely helpful tool.

A word of caution: check your USB port and verify that you do not need the mini, rectangular one, for this cable is longer and a bit thinner. It is NOT for the micro-USB port. Be certain that this is the end connector that you need.

Bottom Line: Belkin cables have always been reliable and this one is no exception.

The SH67H3 was purchased as a replacement for my Shuttle SD37P2 V2, which died recently. Installed are an [[ASIN:B005L9E7J0 Intel Core i3-2130 2x 3.40GHz 3.4 2 LGA 1155 Processor (BX80623I32130)]] , 4 x [[ASIN:B002K23V1Q Kingston ValueRAM 4GB 1333MHz DDR3 Non-ECC CL9 DIMM Desktop Memory]] (KVR1333D3N9/4G), and 3 x  [[ASIN:B0042SGDVG Samsung Spinpoint F4EG 2 TB SATA2 5400rpm 32 MB Hard Drive HD204UI/Z4]]. I also have an Intel PRO 1000 PCI Express NIC installed.  The SH67H3 is well made and on par with the quality of the SD37P2 V2. It is extremely quiet when running. I like the brushed metal and uncluttered look of the front of the PC. Other pluses are the recessed front power button (which prevents accidental pushes), along with adjustable brightness of the blue power LED.  Note that the Mini PCI connector on the motherboard is *NOT* mSATA compatible, and is intended for Wi-Fi adapters, etc., not SSDs. In order to install a 3.5\\" hard drive into the 5.25\\" bay I used a [[ASIN:B0001UZQWG StarTech.com 3.5-Inch Universal Hard Drive Mounting Bracket Adapter for 5.25-Inch Bay BRACKET]]. There is space enough behind the 5.25\\" bay for a 2.5\\" SATA SSD, so I may add a SATA 6Gbits/s SSD at some point in future.   Unlike the SD37P2 V2, the SH67H3 does not have space for three 3.5\\" hard drives plus a 5.25\\" optical drive. In order to install Linux I also ordered an external  [[ASIN:B005FUKLHM Sony Optiarc USB 2.0 Slim Portable DVD Writer, DRX-S90U]], which sits on top of the PC case. The drive needs two USB connectors and would only work for booting the Linux install CD when plugged into two USB 2.0 ports, and would not work on USB 3.0 ports. (The front of the PC has two USB 3.0 ports and a USB 2.0/eSATA combo port, so the drive has to be plugged into the back).  Check the Shuttle Website for BIOS updates. My SH67H3 needed flashing - no big deal.  I'm running Debian 6.0 on the SH67H3 and it makes an excellent Linux server box. Highly recommended.
output: Replacement for my Shuttle SD37P2 V2 - an excellent Linux server box.

I got this monitor for Christmas. I am pretty picky about my eyes because as an Application Developer, I spend 10+ hours infront of a computer screen. After exchaning this monitor for one that yielded the same results, I upgraded to the professional line VP191b (more on this in a bit).

If there is one thing I have learned about Viewsonic through the years, it is that there is a significant difference in each of its lines of monitors. This is to be expected for the most part, but you would think that the price point would be complementary to the product line. Not always the case. For example, when it comes to flat panels, the product lines offered consist of:

X Series - Consumer line
P Series - Professional line
G Series - Graphic line

This is not a comprehnsive list of all their product lines, but is what you will find in your average retail outlet.

The VX910 (notice the X in the model name) is a decent monitor. For $500 though, it is subpar, even for being a Consumer line product. The colors are good, but the quality of the display is substandard. Red hues in the upper left corners, noticeable pixelation during refresh and an overall grainy appearance make this monitor pretty average for the money.

Night and day difference between X series and P series!

The VP191b (Pro line) is a superb monitor. Beatutiful, crisp colors, smooth display. No pixelation. All for $550- thats just $50 more than the X series! Now, I understand that when this monitor first hit the market it was signifcantly more expensive, but today, I would strongly recommed it over any X series, the VX910 included.
output: Too Expensive for a Consumer Level Display

Instances.input: My husband was rejecting the use of his new iPad because he wanted a real keyboard, so I bought this case for him. I already had a similar case, or so I thought. When it came and I easily snapped his iPad into the top clamshell and charged up the keyboard, the differences between the one I had (but seldom used) and this one were clear. While mine was bulky and did not always support the iPad in an upright position, this one is slim and has solid support for the iPad to sit in not only horizontal upright, but also vertical. The arm attaching the two sides of the case slides out to accommodate your desired angle, and - get this - it pivots to allow you to turn your iPad into a vertical position if you prefer! My husband loves it, but, unfortunately, so did I. I convinced him I needed to take it on a business trip with me because it is slimmer and lighter weight than mine, plus the protection it provides is much better with the solid, though lightweight material in the clamshell than the padded vinyl cover I have. I took it in carry-on luggage through airport security and was able to easily use it on the plane and throughout my 8-day trip. The keyboard held its charge throughout my trip, and I loved the ease and security of this product. I own one other New Trent iPad case with this same clamshell material, thought it does not have a keyboard. I loved the protection of that one, although there were design issues I did not like and I seldom use that case. This Airbender 1.0 is maybe the best keyboard case I’ve ever seen. I had to give it back to my husband when I returned from the trip, but it won’t be long before there will be a second one in my house. Now if only they would make them in a choice of colors so we will be able to tell them apart!
output: Bought for husband - now I want it! 5 stars!

This is a great case for the ipad air.  I have several griffin cases and also the main competition the Otterbox defender series.  I love both the cases, they are both durable and well made.  I have dropped my ipad several times and nothing has happened not even a scratch.  I have done the same on the otterbox and it has scratched the corners of my devices.  The reason is that the Griffin Survivor case has better cushioning in the inside case, while the otterbox is all hard plastic on the inside case.  So, when you drop the otterbox the hard plastic corners push up against your device causing indentations and scratches while the Griffin does not.  In addition, when looking at the screen in the Griffin you get a clear view on the Otterbox you get a clear view with an oily film.  Not sure why this happens, but it tends to happen on most otterbox cases with the covering.  The stand on the Otterbox case is better in my opinion and it does come with a cover to protect the screen, while the Griffin does not.  They both weigh about the same.  It will make your ipad air heavier, so keep that in mind.  It is a sleeker looking case, the Griffin but to keep it protected from drops and bangs, you get the added layers of weight.  I would highly recommend this case for those with kids or people that tend to be rough, or afraid of dropping it.  It's worth the added weight to me, for that security.

Instances.input: Coming from an Antec 900 (still in use), can't help but compare:  Antec 900 Pros: Somewhat better build quality. HDDs and drive bay covers screw in. Cooling is better out-of-box, with the helicopter fan on top, and fan switches to control speed. See-through panel. Looks sleeker, IMO.  Carbide 400R Pros: Cable management and ergonomics. No contest here. With all of my drives and Corsair TX750 transferred from the Antec, it was MUCH easier to tuck cables out of the way behind the motherboard panel, thanks to lots of rubberized holes around the motherboard mounting, the rear-facing orientation of the hard drive bays (the HDD trays fit the drives very snuggly), and the extruded side panel. Makes for plenty of room in the case for GPUs. Looks stodgier by comparison, but I don't really care.   Couple gripes: the HDD trays -- if you try to install an SSD, the retainer clip for HDDs gets in the way. Also, what's with the current fad of putting USB ports right above optical drive bays? Sure it makes for easy access, but dangling cables can block ejecting trays.   Really nice case overall. Would buy it again for a new build.     Edit: You can remove the pins in the HDD trays for mounting an SSD by removing the entire pin bar.

I purchased this Zippy BT500 keyboard as a warehouse deal, seller PCMicro. It arrived quickly, couldn't be distinguished from new (despite being classed as \\"used\\"). Very happy with the vendor.
The keyboard is more than I could hope for! The picture shown on this vendor listing is the earlier version of the keyboard, without OS-specific \\"hot keys\\", but the item shipped was the current version with iOS (ipad) hotkeys. I have an android 4.0-- nearly every hotkey I've tried so far works just fine, and I have a feeling that those that don't quite completely function as expected are due to Android, or device-specific problems.
This keyboard is tiny-- about 8.75\\" overall width, and only about 8 1/8\\" actual key width. I'm a man with average width hands (glove size large or xl), but probably thinner than average finger diameter, and I'm a touch typist. A few minutes use gets me aclimated to the tight spacing. A chubby friend at work (same width palm as mine, but fatter fingers) had problems with the key width. Since I'm pairing it with a 4\\" smartphone, living with the small size of the keyboard is an easy choice to gain portability. Key action is a traditional keyboard scissors action with good feel and a reasonably deep throw. The keyboard has a slight tilt when placed on a desktop which I find natural, but there are also kickstand feet underneath the rear if you desire a steeper tilt.
There are a few details worth making note of: This is one of only 2-3 keyboards of this size that I could find that has nearly every key in the standard keyboard position-- I would have said \\"every\\", but someone pointed out today that the tildy and backslash keys are misplaced. Still a great advantage over the common mini-keyboard practice of relocating the question mark & apostrophe keys, and/or missing right shift, tab, backspace, etc.
If you have occasion to do number-crunching on your tablet, this is also the only 8\\" keyboard I could find that has imbedded number keys (calculator layout) that can be switched into play-- losing, of course, the corresponding letters while in use.
I've tested the keyboard with the stock browser, Kingsoft Office, InkNote, Gmail, and AOL mail-- it works flawlessly with all.
The keyboard is somewhat thicker than some of the other mini keyboards, at least partially because it uses AAA batteries instead of a rechargeable pack. (just over 3/4\\" thick). As a trade-off, the keyboard does not seem to go into hibernate mode to save battery, although there is sometimes a slight delay in getting back up and running if you've let it sit for a while-- but no need to press pairing or reset buttons again.
Pairing was simple with good directions included. This keyboard can be paired with multiple devices, saved into settings of the keyboard, and selected from the keyboard as to which device you want to pair with. (I only have a single bluetooth device, so I haven't tested this function, but other reviewers say it works well.) So far, it remembers the pairing flawlessly, and connects about 15 seconds after I turn it on.
The directions do not go into detail about the special function keys, however. The Search key calls up the search entry box in my web browser, and acts as a \\"find\\" function in my office app. Repeated clicks of the Search key will place a cursor in position, and then place begging/end cursors around the search term. (I haven't figured a way to enlarge/shrink the highlighted area, or to activate cut/paste/etc directly from the keyboard.) The home key takes me to the main Android home key, and I can pull up in-app settings directly from the keyboard, and select/enter with the arrow and return keys. The arrow keys work well to navigate and select apps from the home page, and to navigate around a text document and menus. Escape functions as a \\"back\\" key with my Android. Some popup/dropdown menus still require using the screen, but any menu \\"sidebar\\" seems to navigate fine from the keyboard.
I haven't tried the media keys as of yet. I can lock the screen from the keyboard, and I can call up the \\"locked screen\\" from the keyboard if it's gone into hibernate-- so far, haven't figured a way to actually unlock the screen without swiping the screen itself.
There are a few nit-picky flaws I'll mention. The key labeling seems to be decals, and may wear off over time. The decal has a shiny surface, so the labeling can be hard to read if the area lighting is at the right angle to cause a glare on the decal. I wish the overall design was somewhat thinner, but so far it's certainly a compromise I'm willing to accept given the many excellent qualities of the keyboard. I wish it came with a cover, so that I could feel better about tossing it into my knapsack. (A feature missed by all but a few \\"portable\\" keyboard manufacturers.) Obviously I haven't had it long enough to comment on long-term quality, but it seems to be quite solid despite being 100% plastic. The keyboard doesn't have as many hotkeys as some I've seen-- if I find it's missing something that I really need, I'll try External Keyboard Helper from that other App Store (costs a few dollars, but allows re-mapping keys for special functions.)
Overall, I would definitely purchase this again based on my initial use. At full price, it's not cheap. But, it's also a great little keyboard without most of the flaws I've read about in other keyboard.

I read the reviews for this drive (positive and negative) and decided to give it a chance. I have a newer PC and didn't think the \\"PC not recognizing the drive\\" complaints would apply to me. Usually, my PC is very responsive and a fly could land on the USB port and my PC would recognize it...not with this drive.

I tried this on several drives on my laptop and two other laptops I own and it wouldn't recognize it on any of them. I would plug it in, you could hear the drive spinning (LOUD) and my PC didn't notice it at all.

I did a little more research and this drive apparently requires 800mAmps of power to start up but can run on 400 mAmps afterwards. A normal USB provides 500mAmps, so you can see therein lies the problem. So, a work around is to get a Y Adapter or a powered USB hub and the drive from that but if I wanted a bunch of complicated cables or a wired HUB I would have purchased a desk top hard drive not a portable hard drive.

This was just way too much work for me and I think it's completely ridiculous that I should have to go purchase some additional equipment to make something work that should work just out of the box.

Thankfully, amazon has a great return policy has paid for return shipping.

Thanks Amazon for making this right...even when Seagate couldn't make their product right!!!!!
output: Save your frustration and PASS on this portable hard drive.

While covered, it protects well from minor dirt, splashes, bumps, and scrapes.  It also adds very minimal size or bulk. Instances.input:
I noticed several folks that had a bad experience with CF card compatiblity, especially in terms of expected vs actual performance. You should check out the digital storage review section on dpreview.com, where they test the raw read/write speed (using a firewire card interface), the speed in high-end digital SLR type cameras, and representative point-and-shoot digicams.
It turns out that some high-speed CF cards are a poor match for digicams, and will actually perform worse than ones that are appropriately speed-matched to the device. For instance, I've had very good performance with Lexar 12x 128 MB CF cards with my Nikon Coolpix 4500. It comes packed with an 8x Lexar 'starter' card, and test results on dpreview.com with the Coolpix 995, which is very similar bear this out. Faster cards for that camera would be a waste of money, and might not even perform as well.
On the other hand, I've ordered Simpletech 512 MB cards to go with my new Canon EOS Digital Rebel SLR, because if you go to Canon's site and look at their recommended storage media, they sell Simpletech cards. There is a definite reason for this. If you check out dpreview.com, you will see that Simpletech, among others, scored very well when married to such 'pro-sumer' or pro digital SLR's. The Lexar and Sandisk CFs (two very well-known brands) fared poorly, by comparison.
So, if your camera came with a 'starter' card, find out the speed and manufacturer of that card, and buy some more just like it, or maybe a bit faster and more than likely more storage. If your camera didn't include a card, check out the camera maker's web site to see what they sell, or pester them to tell you what they tested the camera with.
Unless you have a camera that shoots RAW photos (if you don't know what that means, you don't have one, and probably don't care), then you should always shoot in JPEG Fine at the highest (or possibly 3:2) resolution. Digital storage is cheap, and life's too short to shoot in 640x480, and wish you hadn't, the one time you want to make an 8x10 enlargement. Once you figure out the average size of JPEG file produced for typical shots, then get a couple of like-manufactured CF cards sized for about two rolls of film (about 64 shots). For the 4 MP Nikon Coolpix 4500, that comes to about a 128 MB card (a far cry from the 16 MB 'starter' card they include). With one card in the camera, and a spare card in your pocket, you are set for a day's worth of shooting (unless you are a button-happy picture-shootin' maniac -- in that case, get a battery-operated USB drive with media slots, like the Xs-Drive-II to store your shots on, instead of buying a ton of CF cards).
I'm now back for another 512 MB card. I've had no problems or complaints with the first one in my Digital Rebel. I'm currently using it with a Lexar USB 2.0 Multi-Card Reader, RW018 Rev. B on an ASUS P4B533-E motherboard-based system (has six USB 2.0 ports, and two firewire). Works like a charm, after I found out that you don't need to load the Win2K drivers supplied with the reader, if you have a recent service pack on the system. Otherwise, the two sets of drivers clobber each other.
output: Please check out compatibility before buying ANY CF card

I have bought many gaming laptops in my past, some I still own, others I no longer own.
This one so far has impressed me immensely!

To give you an idea of what I currently own and have owned:

Own:
Lenovo Y510P
i7-4700MQ 2.4GHZ
16GB Ram
Crucial M500 960GB SSD
2x Nvidia GT755M 2GB GDDR5 in SLI
15.6" 1080p Display

Owned: (Given to girlfriend)
Sager NP8275
i7-4700MQ 2.4GHZ
16GB Ram
Crucial M500 480GB mSATA SSD
500GB 5,400 RPM HDD
Radeon HD 8970M 4GB GDDR5
17.3" 1080p Display

Owned:
Alienware 17
i7-4700MQ 2.4GHZ
16GB Ram
2x500GB 7,200RPM HDDS
Nvidia GTX 770M 3GB GDDR5
17.3" 1080p Display

Owned: GPU Died out of warranty many problems with this laptop
Samsung Series 7 Gamer
I7-3610QM 2.3GHZ
16GB Ram
120GB SSD
750GB 7,200RPM HDD
Nvidia GTX 675M 2GB

I have used the Everki Beacon Bag with all these laptops as well. I love new technology and if I have the cash I buy it. This laptop was bought though with the pure intent of complete and utter future-proofing myself as well as finally getting the most powerful mobile gpu out upon release for once. (I usually am behind on the technology.) I really am hoping for about a 5 year lifespan at minimum on it, I know I'll have to lower details over time, but for now I am enjoying full "Ultra" or "High" details (depends on max settings for a given game.)

Games I currently play are: Minecraft (I run a server as well, not on my laptop but is hosted elsewhere), Saints Row 3 and 4, Sims 2 and 3, Farming Simulator Titanium Edition, Starbound, Terraria, Bioshock (all), Borderlands 1 and 2, Diablo 3+ expansion, Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars+ expansion, Supreme Commander 1 and 2, Dungeon Defenders plus many others. This laptop plays all that maxed out and at 1080p no problems! Now I know I haven't listed many heavy hitter games, but i can say that this will play anything out now at 1080p on "High" and I may be conservative on that.

Build Quality:
The Alienware has the winner on this for build quality, with it's reinforced alloy frame, but this laptop isn't very far behind on quality. This laptop is a cross between the Alienware and the Sager. The Sager had a better build quality than the Samsung I felt.
This doesn't mean this laptop is cheap feeling, far from it. It's got just about as good a feel as the Alienware did but not quite there. The keyboard does feel much better than the Sager, but the Samsung's keyboard was a winner in that spot. The screen on this laptop doesn't wobble as much as the Sager did or the Samsung did. It's a tie between the Alienware and this one. Also, this laptop probably has more of an Alienware look than the Sager or Samsung one did with the multi-color keyboard and extra lighting.

Features: This is a hard one to compare, but personally this laptop wins out.
6x USB 3.0 ports, 2x Mini Display ports as many audio connections to support 7.1 surround should you want it. This laptop also has a blu-ray BURNER! which was more than what the Alienware had with it's default DVD-Burner. This laptop also has a direct button for switching between the dedicated GTX980M and Integrated GPU. This requires a reboot but the Alienware can do this as well with a Function key. But there is pretty much a shortcut button for this.

Performance: This is unfair as each laptop was pretty much an upgrade over the previous one. So obviously this MSI laptop outbeats the past ones.

Price: MSI wins, for $2300 you get a beast of a laptop. Alienware (as of this writing) doesn't have the 980M gpu and will probably charge far more for the same setup.

Cooling: The cpu seems to sit at about the same temperatures as previous cpus, but the gpu maxes out at about 72C when being pushed to it max during benchmarks which obviously push it to it's max. (Chances are I won't max this gpu out for a little while.) This laptop has an excellent cooling system. It does get a little loud when the fan ramp up to max, but I took a like at the physical fans and they are the largest fans I've seen in a laptop. Max speed I hear a faint whine, but chances are your gonna be gaming and not notice it, and honestly if anyone else complains they should just shush up themselves. (I wouldn't suggest gaming in a library, while it may not be super loud that's just disrespectful, but ultimately any ambient noises will probably drown this laptop. Also I must note that the fan noise is only noticeable at max speed which you may not reach, I only reached it by hitting the "Turbo Fan" button. Even when benchmarking I didn't notice the fans much if any.

Storage:
This comes with a single 128GB m.2 SSD and a 2.5" 1TB 7,200RPM HDD. This laptop only supports ONE 2.5" drive, unless you replace the optical drive with a Hard drive caddy. BUT! It has a total of 4 m.2 slots. with current m.2 SSD's you could put 4x 512GB SSD's in plus the 2.5" HDD! SSD's are coming down in price pretty good, I remember when a 64GB might have cost $300+ now it's nothing. A 512GB SSD now cost about $280 now! a few years ago that would have been probably $1000 or more!
I do plan on adding in an SSD very soon. I also must state that MSI DOES include all the screws needed to add in more m.2 SSD's.

Audio system: The Dynaudio system on this MSI blows me away! The Sager plain sucked, I will admit it, The Alienware sounded really good as well as the Samsung, but the MSI's blows them away in my opinion. Now I'm not a audiophile and far from it, but I enjoy listening to my music as much as the next person and also like to share music or videos with others and this sound system can fill a medium room pretty decently. There is plenty of range and it is far from sounding tiny!

Overall, I am VERY pleased so far with this laptop and plan on upgrading it's 128GB SSD with a 512GB SSD. I will keep the original SSD as a Driver/ Dump drive until I can afford a second, third and fourth 512GB SSD. But otherwise it is one BEAST of a laptop without being HUGE! It is even outdoing my desktop somewhat and that has a GTX 770 SC gpu in it. (I read it could rival a 780 which may be overkill for my personal needs, but I got the money so why not?

Incidentally I have to get rid of my desktop due to downsizing on my living arrangements which is why I was forced to another laptop, so I just decided to go all in this time around. Short of if I could upgrade on my own I figured I would just do that on my own for a tad cheaper.

I will update this review if anything changes or after 6 months of ownership with plans on updating my review every 6 months until I can't edit/ update it anymore or get rid of the laptop.

All in all if you got the cash, I suggest this laptop if you are looking for something to game on the go, i really don't think it will let you down!marks which obviously push it to it's max. (Chances are I won't max this gpu out for a little while.) This laptop has an excellent cooling system. It does get a little loud when the fan ramp up to max, but I took a like at the physical fans and they are the largest fans I've seen in a laptop. Also I must note that the fan noise is only noticeable at max speed which you may not reach, I only reached it by hitting the "Turbo Fan" button. I do plan on adding in an SSD very soon. I also must state that MSI DOES include all the screws needed to add in more m.2 SSD's.

Audio system: The Dynaudio system on this MSI blows me away! Now I'm not a audiophile and far from it, but I enjoy listening to my music as much as the next person and also like to share music or videos with others and this sound system can fill a medium room pretty decently. For what it is, it works fine.  It feels slightly cheap and flimsy, the screw holes are not well-drilled or aligned properly, and the stand doesn't have a perfectly flat bottom and so has a tendency to rattle a bit, but the drive itself works.  Transfer rates are fine, the external power means that the draw on the USB port isn't an issue, cables are fine and of adequate length.  For a sub-$20 USB drive, that's pretty much all you can expect.    If, after you buy it, it claims to have connected fine but the drive doesn't appear anywhere, you probably need to assign a drive letter by hand.  In Windows, go to the control panel, select \\"Computer Management\\", find \\"Storage\\", and look under \\"Disk management\\" to see if your drive appears there.  Right click and select \\"Change drive letter and paths\\" and give it a unique letter; if it's a new hard drive you might need to format it as well, which you can do from the same spot.

Belkin makes good products. This case/cover is another example of the thought and care they put into the things they make. The exterior of the cover is a durable leather-like material while the interior is very soft and luxurious. It feels like brushed suede but is actually a man-made made material.The iPad (both the new version and the 2nd generation) is held securely in place in all four corners by fairly large L-shaped pieces of the cover material sewn to narrow elastic straps. These overlap the corners by nearly three-quarters of an inch but don't interfere with the screen. There is a wide elastic strap on the cover that can be slipped over the closed case similar to a Moleskin notebook. This keeps the whole thing tidy when it is put in a bag or briefcase. The cover is made so that it can fold backward out of the way completely when the iPad is in use. Nicely made, nice looking, too.

Instances.input: Would be nice to see WITH the a/c adaptor.

The concept of the product is great. All computers in my network now have access to the important files when the others are turned off. Consumes only a small amount of power (I've heard 17 Watts, which seems about right) and is very quiet, unless the fan is on. I did not find this information on any reviews or on the Maxtor online help, but enabling the media server (which is off be default) will kick the fan on indefinitely until you disable the media server again. Despite being a small fan (35-40mm), I can hear it from across the room (12 ft). So I was disappointed that I couldn't just keep the media server on forever, effectively ruining the synergy it has with my D-Link DSM-520 media player. Also, my media player can't find the videos/pictures/audio I put in the NAS unless their in the pre-allocated \\"My music\\", \\"My photos\\" and \\"My video\\" folders, which are re-created if you delete them and then enable the media server. I used the 2 rear USB ports as a print server and to attach another external hard drive. Some people have said that the print server is slow. I've only printed out small jobs and it does seem to lag sometimes. Note that since the printer is no longer attached to a dedicated computer, the printer software (ink reserve checks, diagnosis tests) are not available. Any USB hard drive/flash drive you stick onto the NAS needs to be FAT32 (according to Maxtor), otherwise you might have limited read/write access. The speed is the expected speed of a 100Mbit connection. It would have been better if they included gigabit connectivity for future-proofing.

Summary: Good 10/100 Mbit NAS with print server, but issues w/media server which seems to trigger noisy fan, even if no CPU load. This negates the advantage Maxtor had on media server-less NASes for me. No gigabit connectivity. Overall, if using for basic backup and network storage, this is good and quiet. If trying to utilize everything Maxtor equipped, you'll find some quirks.

I am a developer, and yet new to the smartphone/tablet phenomenon. The reason? Price.  Now there is finally a device where the value justifies the price! Over the last two days I have downloaded 40 or so apps and can do just about everything I use my computer for (except work!). I can track everything I do (calorie counter, exercise, car maintenance, emails, IMs, yes even fruit ninja!). Access my office email at home while I am eating breakfast. Listen to npr, listen to my music. I can read my books anywhere, at any time. I can even read them at night with the lights out!  I am very, very, very happy with this purchase. I love the alarm clock extreme. Suddenly I can get up in the morning because there is an alarm smart enough to make me get up. Then I turn on the local radio app and tune to npr. I carry around the kindle with me (in my pocket!!!) while I go through my morning routine.   My wife is happy because now we have a truly portable radio/music player. The speakers are just the right loudness and quality.   I can read the news in the morning while I am waking up. Like the title says, changed my life.  My one complaint is that the touch screen is a little hit or miss. It's like it sometimes just doesn't notice that you touched it. I find that it works well, you just have to be patient and touch *slowly.*  This doesn't bother me. As a developer I am used to working with things that aren't quite perfect, but that is how I would describe the touchscreen. Very nice. Beautiful, actually. But the touch is not quite there.  I am glad to deal with that slight annoyance to have a tablet that does everything I want (and more than I ever expected!) for $199. Way to go Amazon!

This is one of the most popular generic styles coming out of China, but with an advertised capacity of 512GB, it is also one of the most common fakes.

You risk losing some or all of your valuable data if you buy this drive.

Beware fake capacity flash drives. This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are really low capacity 4GB or 8GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by a few clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.

Such drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties, but will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data once their true capacity is exceeded. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back.

Only a few manufacturers such as Kingston, Corsair, and (only recently) PNY make legitimate 512GB drives and those cost several hundred dollars (as of Q3 2015). The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars. The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips.

The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting generic and novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips. They also do not have the ability to make a 512GB drive using a single chip design as is contained in this drive. The technology is not there yet.

Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below. For example, if the 64GB drive is only $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is only $10 more than the 64GB. Real memory is not that cheap.

If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.

You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.

Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.. If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties. You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 35GB with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt. Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.
output: This is not the drive you are looking for.  Move along... PLEASE READ CAREFULLY

Instances.input: This speaker is perfect for me. I live in an apartment where I'm limited on space. I was looking for a speaker with good sound but didn't take up a lot of space and this one did the job. I can also move it to the bathroom and have music while I shower or even take it on the go with me to the park. It's great!

Only regret: The keyboard layout is bad. There is no way to turn the mouse pad off if you are using an external mouse so you will end up hitting the mouse with your palm often. The keyboard layout has the laptop-function key on the left where all standard keyboards have the control key. This means if you are a coder, etc, and are used to hitting left control-V, etc, you will find yourself messed up hitting the function key instead. The F1-F12 keys are not highlighted in white, they are in dark red making you have to physically look at the keys to see them. So for anyone who is very particular about your keyboard layout - look carefully at this first. Other than that, great laptop, easy to get rid of the pre-loaded software or simply wipe it and re-install.
output: Laptop works exactly as specified. It's a great laptop. Beware of the keyboard.

This is a perfectly adequate entry level video card for standard, routine computing needs. Supports 1900x1200 resolution with a very satisfactory image. Easy installation into a PCIe slot with no extra power cords to attach as would be required by the higher end, more powerful cards.

The main objection I have to this card is the consistent intrusive whiny noise generated by the small fan on the card. Unlike many cards which are noisy at startup but slow once Windows is fully booted, and at relative idle except on demand, this fan runs at full-out speed all the time. I admit that I am sensitive to noise in computers, but for me this characteristic was a deal-killer, even with the desktop tower placed in a kneewell. I wound up exchanging it for an Asus fanless Radeon 5450 card with otherwise similar specifications and performance except that it was dead quiet, as would be expected. Even running it for hours, again with routine computer tasks, I felt no significant heat on the conductive heat sink, so that occasional reviews complaining that it overheats I deem to be totally unjustified and were probably either mean-spirited or related to unwarranted overtaxing with overclocking or extreme gaming, neither of which are within the purview or designed function of such an entry level card.

BOTTOM LINE: For those of you who don't care all that much about noise, or who are used to substantially noisier computers, I think you will find this card a bargain. For those of you with sensitive ears, go for the 5450, as described above, for approximately the same price.

Instances.input:
Hello, lets start off by saying that i have never really used gaming mice so i really wanted to see what the fuss was about. At first i bought a Cyborg rat-5 and that worked great for about 6 months but the ergonomics were starting to cramp my hand. I decided lets go see whats rated well. Almost everyone said that the razer deathadder was the best gaming mouse there is. I went out and bought one. I used it for 2 days and it was the best mouse i had ever used. The cord was a bit in the way so i thought lets buy this mamba since its the exact same thing except wireless...I was wrong.
When my mamba arrived i first marveled at the legendary boxing which probably cost 20$ out of the 100$ price of the mouse. Once i had unboxed the mouse i felt and it and was almost exactly the same feeling as the deathadder except the coating was smooth as the deathadder had a bit of grip. After 1 week of use i was absolutely impressed but thats when things started to go wrong. First my mouse would have this little \\"jiggle\\" which after many hours i found out is because that mamba tracks very high so when i moved my mouse i would lift it unconciously maybe half a millimeter off the pad which would cause this little jiggle.
I thought i could deal with that as it was a really good mouse.
Then my mouse would randomly keep running out of battery. Then i found out that some genious at razer designed the mouse so that you have to turn it off every time you want to charge it on the dock otherwise it will drain the battery.
After dealing with that i came to yet another problem. The mouse kept turning off randomly and i could not figure out why. The battery was at 100%
This lead to my final problem which led me to my decision to try to exchange it..
My mouse will hold absolutely no charge on its battery. IT WILL NOT TURN ON IN WIRELESS MODE.
I have to use the wired mode because the battery will just not hold a charge. So i will wait for this replacement and maybe continue the review after i receive that. If the replacement also has problems. I will repurchase the deathadder as that had no problems whatsoever

***********************************
Fixed***************************
After receiving another mouse ive kept it for a week and it showes no issues of which i had with the other mouse... yet so im moving it back up to 5 stars. :Dcontinue the review after i receive that. If the replacement also has problems. I will repurchase the deathadder as that had no problems whatsoever

***********************************
Fixed***************************
After receiving another mouse ive kept it for a week and it showes no issues of which i had with the other mouse... yet so im moving it back up to 5 stars. :D

After the iPad 2 was released and the price of the original went down, I decided to pick one up being an avid fan of Apple products.  I thought I might use this device occasionally to read an iBook or watch a video.  I was wrong.  I use it ALL THE TIME.  I've been using Apple laptops ever since I got out of college because I like bringing my computer around wherever I go or watching TV while I surf the web.  After buying an iPad, I'm looking into replacing my laptop with a Mac Mini and making my iPad my primary computing device.  If you think about it, what do MOST of us use our computer for MOST of the time?  Surfing the web, checking email, organizing pictures, listening to music and watching videos.  The iPad can do all these things.  Even those who use their computer for more \\"serious\\" activities (word processing, music recording/editing, keynote presentations) will find that iPad can do all those things as well, though you may have to actually purchase an app to do some of those things.  In addition, this thing is GREAT for travel.  Bring this on a plane and you can watch a video or read a book.    True, the iPad will not REPLACE your laptop/desktop for most people, but you will find that you end up using your iPad instead of your computer for most things.  You will still need your regular computer for the large hard drive and flash videos (at least until Apple fixes that in an iOS), but you may even find that you prefer your iPad for things like email, Facebook, and the web.  Without using an iPad 2, I can't really make many comparisons to the two models.  I haven't really wished my iPad had a video camera because I can't imagine holding this thing up to take videos, and I have my computer and iPhone for Facetime.  I can see how a lighter weight might be nice, but I haven't really found this device to be all that heavy.  Bottom line, don't think of the iPad as an extra little toy that Apple came up with just to make a few more bucks.  If you use a computer atall or if you do a lot of traveling, you'll find that this device will become your new best friend.
output: Yes, it is an amazing product

Instances.input: This is like any other screen protector not quite easy to install. I wasted a sheet before I was happy with the amount of bubbles. The reason I leave so few stars is the glare. For a device labeled anti-glare I can't use it if the light is shining directly on it. I practically washes out the entire screen. Once tilted the glare goes away slightly, but unless the light is behind the device don't try doing anything you need to see color for.

I like the look and feel of this product and unlike some customer and editorial reviews, I actually prefer the arrangement of the side buttons.  The macro button is far removed as it should be and the vertical arrangement of the two programmables are just right for me.  Very easy to select and much bettor than the usual horizontal configuration.    It has good to excellent battery life and I like the combo 'mouse feet' storage, charger and cord storage module.  It's not only utilitarian but....cool.    With my large hands I would actually like more height built in to the body of the mouse but it is large as mice go and has good length.    The wheel is not entirely to my liking.  I would prefer it further to the front and with a smooth movement as opposed the the 'ratcheted' feel it has now.    The button dedicated to opening the games folder in Win 7 really should be programmable.    Microsoft is too often an easy and inviting target but all in all, this effort is a very nice product.
output: Sidewinder X8.  A Good Effort From Microsoft

Instances.input: I chose this cable modem for my parents when they moved to suburban area of DC and they have Cox cable for Internet. No connection drop or any other problems since day one. Just needed to let install by Cox installation guy (not an option... had to pay installation fees regardless). They sometimes turned off at nights when no one at home use Internet. They put it on the middle floor of 3-story town house. Wireless connection from 3FL is great... 5 full bars everywhere whereas 1FL (no basement in the house, just GF) can be 3 bars sometimes. That office room is blocked by the stairway and one BR from where the modem is located one floor up. With external wireless adapter hooked up to USB extension cable (I taped that adapter on top of a bookcase) and got full 5 bars. I don't see any reason to get a new modem as long as thy have Cox, only cable service in the area.
output: Still working great after 2+ years of daily use

Instances.input: The Kindle Fire has been an extreme disappointment. Others have noted its many flaws, and all of these flaws are real and significant. But it's the browser that exhibits perhaps the most frustrating set of flaws. Just to site one such problem- the 'back' button is completely disfunctional. More often than not several touches on the button are required to get the browser to actually respond. Here we're not talking about the user missing his mark when trying to touch the button. A highlight around the button acknowledges one's touch each time, but nevertheless the browser does nothing in response. I've tossed the Kindle Fire aside now and am back to using my Android phone for browsing when needed.   Don't buy a Kindle Fire unless at some point in the future Amazon updates the software and you begin to see reviews indicating that it works well. Presently it is a paper weight.
output: Not at all ready for prime time

Had I written this review, say a half-year ago, I would have undoubtedly given the Macbook 5 stars. I took it with me to college after my previous laptop - an Acer Aspire - failed me horribly. My Aspire had an issue with overheating, which only presented itself after my warranty expired. The cost of repairing it was not worth it when compared to getting a new laptop that was smaller, lighter, more powerful, and more capable of multi-tasking (more RAM).

I come from a family that has been using Macs for over a decade, although I myself preferred Windows computers...up until Windows Vista came out. We had many Macs around the house growing up since my parents use Macs in their office, and I was never really impressed with the Apple Operating System, so I had doubts about the Macbook. But since the Macbook is loaded with 2GB RAM and an Intel processor, you can run BOTH Mac AND Windows operating systems with ease. I therefore figured worse comes to worst, I'll use my Macbook as a laptop to run Windows XP with. I used it very heavily in college and it served me very well. It's light weight allowed me to easily carry it from class to class, its included photo and video editing software gave me hours of productivity, and perhaps best of all, it was reliable! I really loved my Macbook and would like to give it 5 stars...but...

My sister, who was in graduate school, also got a Macbook at the same time I got mine. Her laptop fared well, up until the end of last year. For some reason, the laptop started getting buggy...it'd freeze, it would overheat, it became a major nuisance. We've reformatted several times, hoping that would solve the problems, but to no avail. I HIGHLY recommend getting the AppleCare protection plan. We regrettably didn't, and really don't feel like forking over the money to repair the Macbook since she doesn't use it much anymore anyway. But our attempt to save money by not getting the protection plan will end up costing us more money now, should we choose to repair the laptop! The experience with our second, identical Macbook, is why I have to give 3 stars instead of 5 for an otherwise strong performance product, that can run both Windows and Mac, that comes bundled with a lot of great software, and that looks really cool (especially on a college campus where almost everyone has Macs!)

A last note...I have more recently purchased the sleeker Macbook, and would like to emphasize that while its construction is nicer, and it doesn't look as cheap as this plastic one, I still think this is a good deal. If you're looking to \\"wow\\" people and can splurge, get the newer model, but if you are looking for a powerful laptop and don't care too much about having the latest build, this one is just fine. I still use my plastic one even though I have the newer (cooler-looking!) one.choose to repair the laptop! I still use my plastic one even though I have the newer (cooler-looking!) one.
output: Have two: one is great, one is dying!
