I use the TK820 for my HTPC. I'll skip the wall of text and dive into what you care about instead:

>> Keyboard

The Good
+ The keys have a great click feeling that make typing very easy and comfortable.
+ The keys are well spread out.
+ SetPoint allows you to disable the Windows and Caps Lock keys.
+ The F1 - F12 keys are defaulted to perform their media functions (e.g., pressing F9 mutes instead of performing "F9"). You need to press Fn+F# in order to send the desired F# key. That said, I believe SetPoint allows you to swap this functionality (e.g., you need to press Fn+F9 to mute instead).
+ Dedicated on/off switch (not a button so you can't accidentally turn it off).

The Bad
- No Home, End, PgUp, and PgDn keys.
- No numeric keypad if you want one.
- No "flippers" to incline the keyboard if you're into that.

Overall score: 9/10

>> The Touchpad

The Good
+ Larger than most touchpads.
+ Surface is slightly rough providing a nice tactile experience.
+ Supports a wide array of multi-touch gestures. It supports up to 4 finger recognition (swipes, presses).
+ SetPoint software is fairly customizable (e.g., you can change the scroll direction when 2-finger scrolling).
+ Very sensitive. You don't need to press hard in order for the touchpad to detect your finger.

The Bad
- Poor click/movement detection. This does not mean the touchpad is not sensitive. Rather, the software driver has a hard time distinguishing when you want to click and when you want to move the pointer. Sometimes you'll click when you want to move the pointer, and sometimes you'll move when you want to click. This happens often and is a large annoyance.
- The touchpad has 2 DEAD ZONES. If you look at the touchpad and draw a vertical line about 0.66" (I don't have a ruler handy) from the left and right sides (like this: [ | | ]) of the touchpad, those are the dead zones. When you're moving the pointer and your finger crosses either of these lines, the pointer will momentarily stop. If I had known about this beforehand, I probably wouldn't have bought this keyboard. These dead zones might be related to software-enabled scroll regions but I didn't see anything in the SetPoint settings. I am also on the latest version of the SetPoint software as of the date of this review.
- Mechanical click actuation is stiff. I'm usually a mechanical clicker but I think I'm going to rely on tap clicking with this touchpad because it's just too stiff.

For reference, I have used a number of touchpads, and this one ranks near the bottom. If you think you're going to have an Apple experience with this touchpad, you're gonna have a bad time.

Overall score: 3/10

>> Recommendation

Get this if you're a mostly keyboard user but want the option of a touchpad. You may want to look at the cheaper Logitech K400. I haven't used it, but the price difference is large enough to warrant a look.

I have the original TruGlide stylus, and it works great for my iPad. I bought this one because I wanted a longer and heavier stylus. This one is a bit longer if you keep the cap on, but it tends to be a bit on the heavy side. The microfiber tip is still very smooth. Although this Turtle Beach headset is made primarily for gaming, it has other great uses as well, especially if you have a PC (more on Macs later.) It has a removable mike, over-the-ear headphones, a padded headpiece, and both USB and audio jack cables, the last for mobile devices. And the sound quality is quite nice, with excellent stereo differentiation. These headphones are great for gaming, watching films, creating podcasts, and, to a lesser degree, just listening to music.

My only complaint about these headphones is that Turtle Beach says that they are Mac-compatible, yet the Dolby surround sound feature is not available to Mac users. In fact, the company says that there are different listening modes for music and home theater, even though I seem to have no such options on the Mac. Since most gamers use PCs, that usually isn't a problem; however, if you want to use these for watching DVDs, you cannot get the same degree of immersive experience. (Note: I don't know if this is an inherent Mac issue or an oversight on the part of the manufacturer.) That said, the headset still reproduces great sound for DVD watching even on a Mac, and the mike works well for creating podcasts and talking on the phone. I found the headset somewhat lacking, although still competent, for music listening. If you have a PC, the first thing you should do when you open the box is to go to the Turtle Beach site and download the drivers for PCs.

Bass is well produced on the Recon 320, although I expected more of it, especially given that bass is a critical sound component of gaming. Voices are clear. Even without surround sound, stereo effects are crisp and immersive. Both the audio cable and the USB cable have in-line controls for volume, and the audio cable enables phone answering. As expected, the audio cable is relatively short at about 4'. The USB cable is longer since this is what users will need for gaming, about 7'.

I found the Recon 320 to be comfortable enough to wear for hours because of the generous padding. The earpieces are sound-porous, however, so you will hear ambient noise, and other people will hear what you do. Depending on your gaming/listening environment, this could be either a deal-breaker or a non-issue. I also like that the mike boom is flexible so that I can position it exactly where I like. Of course, the fact that the mike piece is removable is another great feature, especially for people who want to move from one use to another with ease.

-- Debbie Lee Wesselmannugh to wear for hours because of the generous padding. The earpieces are sound-porous, however, so you will hear ambient noise, and other people will hear what you do. Depending on your gaming/listening environment, this could be either a deal-breaker or a non-issue. I also like that the mike boom is flexible so that I can position it exactly where I like. Instances.input: When my Roku 1000HD died, I decided to replace it with the Apple TV.  There seems to have been no thought to features in the photo category by the designers.  There is no setting to allow you to display a full frame.  The result is that if your camera has a typical 4:3 aspect ratio, you will lose a significant part of the picture.  The box arbitrarily pans across part but not all of the photo to compensate.  There is no zoom as on my old Roku either so you can't get to just a part of the photo.  Some of the TV features are nice to have but as other reviews noted, the HDTV standard requires full 5.1 sound.  Let's hope there are some software fixes to this box soon!    (Revision:  The goofy zoom and pan is actually the default \\"Ken Burns Effect\\" and can be turned off.  That does get you the full picture on Landscape photos but not on Portrait.  No \\"help\\" and no documentation comes with the box though - so easy to overlook this!  Very user unfriendly!  Also, it has no \\"OFF\\" Switch  quite the little energy pig.)
output: It's a dog for displaying your photos!

LOVE the Paperwhite...if you're an avid reader, you will appreciate this reader!

It moves very smoothly and, a huge plus, is super quite even on tiled surfaces. The way it is made it doesn't bump into your legs while you carry it by the double strap handle. I can't think of anything that could be added to this bag to make it any more functional or attractive.  I am in love! I am planning to order another one of these just in case they ever stop making them.  The price is more than a steal when compared to other bags of MUCH less quality! If you need a rolling bag, buy this one!

Instances.input:
I recently purchased a MacBook Pro 15.4 inch model, and of course, I wanted to protect my new baby. There are literally hundreds of bags to choose from, but the reviews on this bag at the Apple Store website were inspiring, as was the design, and the testimonals on the Brenthaven site itself.

Now the bag itself *IS* a nice bag. It's certainly sturdy, there's no questioning that, and I feel extremely confident that my MacBook will survive in there unscathed.

The problem is, the bag is big, and yet it doesn't hold very much, at least by my standards.

The \\"CORE\\" protection system inside takes up a lot of room, and of course, the MacBook itself, while thin, is big, because of the beautiful widescreen display on it. The bag itself weights about three pounds, the MacBook another five and a half, plus then the charger, so you're talking about nine pounds right off the bat to be carrying all the time.

The bag I had before this, a Jansports green \\"messenger brief\\" which I could sling over my shoulder, or carry like a briefcase, just like this, was, and still is a great bag. It held a lot of things, and I would pack it thusly. I can't do that with this Brenthaven bag.

If I have my MacBook in this bag, I can fit, say, two half liter bottles of water, the MacBook charger, my cell phone charger, and two 120-page spiral notebooks for class. And it's an uncomfortable fit then, and the bag is very bulky then. I can't fit my copy of The Times in there either anymore, with said items.

With my Jansport bag, I would usually carry around notebooks for school, two bottles of water, The Times, random food items for the day to save money (can of soup, pouch of microwave rice, things in a Pyrex glass container so they wouldn't get crushed), along with other odd ends. I can't do this anymore.

So, again, while the Brenthaven bag is nice, don't expect to carry much in it other than the MacBook itself, and a notebook or two, espcially if you use the mesh holdings inside to store things like bottles of water.

The back of the bag has a pouch to store stuff in, but don't expect to put much in it because to close it (via velcro), it can't be bulging out much. Also, items in this pouch, if not flat, will beat against your leg if slung across your shoulder.

There's also a front zipper pouch which doesn't hold much, and is annoying to use.

I'm probably going to return this, and purchase the \\"Brenthaven Metro,\\" which is really just to hold the MacBook itself only, and nothing else. Then I'll just have to carry around two bags each day, probably just carrying the MacBook around like a suitcase.d a notebook or two, espcially if you use the mesh holdings inside to store things like bottles of water.

The back of the bag has a pouch to store stuff in, but don't expect to put much in it because to close it (via velcro), it can't be bulging out much. Also, items in this pouch, if not flat, will beat against your leg if slung across your shoulder.

There's also a front zipper pouch which doesn't hold much, and is annoying to use.

I'm probably going to return this, and purchase the \\"Brenthaven Metro,\\" which is really just to hold the MacBook itself only, and nothing else. Then I'll just have to carry around two bags each day, probably just carrying the MacBook around like a suitcase.
output: Sturdy bag, but large and doesn't hold much...

Bought 2 of these from another reliable vendor.
The first cooler failed after about 3 months, it was RMA'd back to Corsair. Prior to sending it back it was examined, there apeared to be corrosion around the copper waterblock (which is not really a water block, more on this in a minute). The second cooler failed in exactly the same way. Again more corrosion. This time, thouroghly fed up with Corsairs terrible support I dismantled the entire cooler. I found extensive corrosion to the back of the copper "water block" I pulled appart the stupidly designed pump to find more corrosion to the internal surface of the impeller around the spindle. The was the cause of the rattle that is the sound of failure, the only way to repair this cooler is by replacing the pump unit as the spindle is damaged by the corroding impeller too. The cause of failure.... cheap coolant that was acidic. Certainly was not coolant that was designed for this kind of use. The seal around the "water blocks" copper contact surface is very bad too, this allowed for a small quantity of coolant to make its way out and air to make its way in, further compounding the failure.
The way the thermal sensor makes contact with the copper is very poor, leading to inaccurate thermal readings and control.
The "water block" is laughable, its a thin 2mm peice of copper plate, on its back is a rubber material obviously desinged to flow control the coolant. This rubber covers most of the copper and so prevents thermal transfer heat from the copper to the coolant. The corrosion mentioned earlier obviously corrodes the exposed area of copper and so furhter reduces the performance of the system.

Its a pooly designed, badly made peice of garbage. The designers of which have/had no clue on materials science or even rudimentary chemistry to understand how their materials would be affected by the coolant they choose. I can't speak for their newer models, but needless to say I have completly lost faith in Corsair products. Had a few cases and had problems ranging from catches breaking, fan control knob failing and even broken front usb port cables. Memory I have had a few and the heat spreaders became loose on all of them, one shorted out. Dont get me started on their SSD's Thats for another review.

Their replies to all of these complaints:
"You can return the item, once its received and the fault is validated we will send you a replacement free of charge."
I said:
"So I have to have my system out of action for 2 weeks becuase of your terrible product"
Their reply:
"You can avail of our swift replacement option, you provide us your credit card details and we send a replacement, your card will not be charged if we receive the product back"
Thats all well and good I suppose, but every time I tried to arrange to have my product replaced in this was I was told "That Item is not in stock"
output: Worst cooler on the planet even worse support from Corsair

Instances.input: This is my second replacement battery from this company and you can't beat the performance for the price; you could purchase approximately 4 of these for every 1 Apple brand battery. The battery fit is acceptable; if the slight alignment mismatch is an issue for you, then purchase an Apple unit. My daughter purchased an Apple unit, and the alignment is not any better than this unit, so price/performance is the only comparison at hand and this unit wins, no question! Don't forget to re-set the PCM when you swap the battery (remove the old battery with the laptop off; press & hold the power button for 5 - 10 seconds, and proceed with installing the new battery). Additionally, charge the battery only when the battery power level is low. Lastly, calibrate your laptop battery at least once a month by using the computer with the battery low until it goes to sleep and won't wake; let it sit and run down until it shuts off; then charge the battery completely in one sitting. I get about 3 hours per battery charge and any battery that I have lasts at least 3 years.

This Viivant USB LED Lamp definitely took me by surprise! There isn't a on/off switch to this lamp but that's not a big problem for me since if I want the light to turn off all I have to do is unplug it from my laptop. I really love this lamp and would definitely recommend the Viivant USB LED Lamp!!

I purchased this item for my Kindle after viewing several brands and styles of covers, both online and in stores. I settled on this one because the price was so low for a leather cover and the product description appeared to be satisfactory for my needs.

I'm impressed with what I received. Great pebbled leather cover with soft interior to protect my Kindle. The convenient elastic closer fits in a groove on the cover, and has enough tension to keep the cover closed. When opened, the elastic strap fits along site the kindle or can be moved to the back, which also serves as a way to hold the cover back like a book or magazine folded on itself.

I was concerned about the \\"ears\\" used to hold the kindle, compared to other models that either used a full face cover which seemed to restrict use, or the Amazon version which clips into the side lock ports. After using the Kindle with the cover, the \\"ears\\" don't interfere at all and actually protect the corners from dents and dings.

I am very satisfied with this product, and have just purchased 3 more for use with my children's Kindles.

Cheers!
output: Excellent Quality and value for Kindle Users

I was an early adopter of Kindle 1.  Unfortunately, last week it went into \\"sleep\\" mode and never woke up.  Ok, I've had the device for three years now... so maybe it's asking too much for an piece of electronic equipment to function without flaw for this long.  However, I'm a relatively light user and always store my Kindle in its case after reading.  The device wasn't dropped, hit, etc.  I usually read it in bed before going to sleep.  One night it was fine, the next morning I tried to wake the device up and the screen went black (with white lines across).  I've tried resets, taking out the battery, etc. but nothing helped.  RIP Kindle.  I phoned Amazon to ask if they had any suggestions.  Unfortunately, their warranty has long since expired and they had no explanation for what was going on (software?, hardware?).  Despite this they told me that it was a critical failure and offered to sell me a refurbished Kindle 1 with a limited warranty for $100.  For me the fixed cost is too high.  I told them I would think about it.  I could justify a one time fixed cost in return for the potential lower variable cost of e-books (+ the ease of use of the device), but the cost/benefit analysis changes now that I know the device won't last more than 3 years.

Just purchased this last week to replace the mediocre built in speakers that came with my monitor. So far, i am pleased. Installing the speakers was very simple. Just plug it in to the wall and connect the audio cable to the one where the previous speakers where connected. Installation time: less than 1 minute.

As far as sound is concerned these speakers get the job done. They get fairly loud and are more than enough for the average consumer. Are they movie theater quality? No. But i was not expecting them to be. Not at this price. It is enough for YouTube videos and the occasional music.

One of the speakers has a port to plug in headphones and a volume control toggle. Both come in handy when you want to quickly silence the speakers.

The only little thing that i did not like is that they are a little bit bigger than i expected. Is it a big deal? No. But it did catch me off guard. It certainly not enough to detract me from purchasing the speakers again. Overall, if you are looking for decent loud speakers at an affordable price i would recommend these ones.

Update: I've received my Kindle and have been enjoying it, and the things that I was concerned about, like the buttons being in the way, when I first handled one really aren't that big a deal.    Here's some of the things that really grow on you as a Kindle owner. Being able to get a book almost instantly is killer, and separates the Kindle from other ereaders. Getting that first chapter free is also very nice. Being able to download public-domain ebooks in Mobipocket format is also very cool.    And, I understand why DRM .MOBI doesn't work on the Kindle... it's a design decision that, upon reflection, I agree with, because it makes a lot of things possible with the Kindle and with Amazon, that will be of great benefit and utility to Kindle owners, that just can't be done using the DRM .MOBI format.    In short, if you're in the market for an ereader, you really ought to get a Kindle!    ---    I had the chance to play with a Kindle ([[ASIN:B000FI73MA Kindle: Amazon's New Wireless Reading Device]]), thanks to a friend who was a beta tester, and decided to order one. It's on the way.    I don't want to give yet another blow-by-blow description of the device; enough people have already done that. Instead, I want to talk a little about why people should strongly consider buying the device AND I want to give a little advice to Amazon that will make the product even more appealing.    First, anyone who thinks that a PDA or mobile phone with an LCD screen is \\"just as good\\" as a Kindle has never used a device with eInk technology. The Kindle's screen is very un-computer-like, and very much like reading paper. If you haven't seen one in person, you really can't comprehend how much easier on the eyes an eInk display is. It's effectively the difference between reading a laptop and reading a book... yes, it's that good.    The Kindle is going to revolutionize the book industry, much as the iPod revolutionized the music industry. Yes, it has some birthing pains. Yes, the page forward and page backward and back keys, on the sides of the Kindle, make holding the device as one would normally hold a book a bit ackward. The device is best when it is rested on your lap, or another surface, while you read it. But, the unique thing about the Kindle is that it is completely self-contained. No need for a computer.    You, the reader, can be anywhere that Sprint's EVDO network will reach (all populated areas in the US), and you can get any book available from Amazon. No other ereader can do this today. Yes, I know the iRex iLiad has WiFi, but WiFi doesn't work everywhere. I'd like to see Amazon add WiFi to the Kindle so it would work on home and corporate networks and at places with public WiFi access, but this can wait until v2.     The biggest flaw I see with the Kindle is that it doesn't currently support DRM-enabled Mobipocket files. Mobipocket is owned by Amazon, and the Kindle will read unprotected Mobipocket files, so there is no technical reason for this limitation. Of course, there is a business reason: other publishers can't put protected media on the Kindle using the widely-used Mobipocket format.     I understand that Amazon wants to be the sole source for content, just as Apple wants to be the sole source for DRM music on the iPod (that's why Apple sued Real Networks after the Rhapsody music service figured out how to be iPod-compatible). But, this is a little different. Amazon promoted the Mobipocket format as an open standard.    The way around this is for Amazon to offer either DRM Mobipocket support on the device, or to offer a conversion service for Kindle owners for Mobipocket DRM to Kindle DRM, just as they have converters for other formats. Let new Kindle owners have 90 days of free conversions so they can bring over all of their currently-owned Mobipocket ebooks, and then charge them thereafter. This would be the best of all worlds. Current eBook owners who are prospective Kindle owners don't have to worry about re-buying theircurrent eBooks. Other prospective Kindle owners don't have to worry about only being able to buy eBooks from Amazon. Other publishers, who followed Amazon's Mobipocket guidelines, aren't frozen out from providing Kindle owners with content. And, Amazon gets to make a little money for every book that goes on the Kindle, whether or not it came from the Amazon Kindle bookstore, while also protecting itself from unfair trade practices lawsuits. Everyone wins.    I'd also like to see Amazon offer an SDK for the device, and a good web browser. The Kindle is truly a transformational device, and I'd be willing to bet that websites will start being reformatted so that they display optimally on it.     In summary, like the original Palm Pilot, the Kindle is a transformational device. Unlike the Palm Pilot, it is much better at data retrieval and display, and I fully expect that soon it will be used in ways that Amazon hasn't yet imagined. If you're a prospective customer who's really into books and reading, buy one. If you're Amazon, add online conversion of DRM Mobipocket ebooks to .AZW, quickly!
output: The Kindle is going to revolutionize the book industry

I've had this bag since July 2011, and I'm surprised the negative reviews pertaining to durability. I don't know if there was one bad production run, or conversely, one good production run, and I just got lucky, but after a year of daily use, my bag looks exactly as it did when I bought it. I don't even have any scuffing along the sides like my previous bag. All the stitching and zippers have held up nicely.

I think that the positives have been well covered by now in other reviews, but I'll add that my 17\\" Macbook Pro fits perfectly, with a little extra room all around. My ER earbud case fits in the appointed headphone pouch, so that was a bonus, though I don't use the little pass-through port. As mentioned, there is plenty of storage, and I have a ton of documents and my organizer in the largest pocket, plus a ton of cable, adapters, other accessories, and office supplies in the remaining pockets. That's another point in favor of its durability, as it is packed solid -bulging in some areas- and I still haven't busted a zipper or seam. I haven't had any problems with the TSA in using the ScanSmart feature, probably in 20-30 trips through a checkpoint.

On to the negatives...

1. Padding on the bottom of the laptop pocket. There is none. Well, there is the thinnest strip of foam built into the bottom of the bag, but it might as well not be there. As others have mentioned, I have heard the crunch when setting my bag down too hard on more than one occasion. I should add some additional padding to the bottom myself, but there is no reason why I should have to. The lack of padding should have been glaringly obvious in the design stage.

2. Lack of organization in the pockets. I'm sure this is a personal preference issue, but my two smaller pockets look just like the ubiquitous 'junk drawer.' Everything is just thrown in there with no organization, because there is none, save for the few office supply slots in the medium pocket. My previous bag had dividers or internal pockets in every external pocket.

On the whole, this is a great bag for the money. You could spend double and not get as good of a bag as this one.

An Excellent pair of speakers. Ive had them up and running for 24 hours now, (not continuously) and the sound is really good. The highs are rich and not too treble-y. Mids are fat and colorful, and the Lows are the best part. These things rock a low frequency really nice. I Dj a lot in San Francisco and I also do lots of outdoor stuff like parties and some street fair stuff, so clear and really loud are my priorities. This has been an excellent investment. I own 6 behringer B250d's. Great speakers that i have used for years and for the price, they have more than paid for themselves. These, however are a super sweet upgrade. I played a variety of quality bitrate music through an ipod, traktor, pandora and a also used a microphone through a mixer , just to investigate the frequency range. One song that i felt really that worked through the spectrum of sound ranges is this one
https://soundcloud.com/bobby-c-sound-tv/whatd-i-say-bobby-c-sound-tv
The ZlX-15p's really bumped it nice. I think for the money, these provide a great range and lots of output for all kinds of situations.
The one thing that might be an issue down the line is the digital DSP board on the back, as analog usually hold up much longer, but we'll cross that bridge when we get to it.
The Speakers are also lightweight and really easy to move, but they dont have stacking brackets, so you cant stack them up in a tower.
Stands and Covers are nice quality. Nothing amazing, but it's nice that the set came with them.
Final word, BUY THESE SPEAKERS. They sound great and dont cost too much. (my wife is still not happy with me buying them though, Lol)

Been using for a month now.  Everyone at the office chuckles, but then looks into one.  No more back trouble from slouching all day in my chair.  Set mine up with a 27" monitor, and even fit my Bose speakers on the shelve below my monitor.  You have to get one.

The bottom line is that I would not recommend the Lenovo Z565 to anyone, for any use or at any price.    I did not purchase mine through Amazon, but from a computer retailer with a good reputation - under duress.  My previous Lenovo Think-Pad crashed during finals, and I HAD to have something that got me through - on a limited budget - ASAP.  I would have been miles ahead if I had dug deeper into my savings and purchased a quality machine.  This one is NOT.    The specifics:    Pros  - The aluminum hand rest is aesthetically pleasing  - The LCD display seems as bright and sharp as other mid-range laptops, but it does not compare to my prior high-end TFT display.  - I find battery life acceptable:  2.25 - 2.75 hours  - It is reasonably lightweight  - The \\"feel\\" of the keys when typing is good - but the layout of the keyboard is a deal-breaker.    Cons  - It is SLOW    - I am not able to stream video (as in YouTube or MP4 files) without it locking up and giving me the pinwheels of death.  Since a \\"cinema experience\\" is what Lenovo is marketing for this machine - this is a deal-breaker.    - Speaker quality is extremely poor.  At maximum volume it is impossible to hear audio with even a small fan running in the background.  It is difficult to make out words with NO background noise.  Even tweaked through the control panel, the range and quality of sound is poor.    - There is a random, sudden problem that happens sometimes when resting ones hands on the aluminum hand rest adjacent to the touchpad:  It blanks out the screen without warning and sometimes repositions the cursor on the screen - inserting it in the middle of a prior sentence.  Perhaps this is a faulty machine?    - The keypad layout is HORRIBLE!  I noticed prior to purchase that the layout of the keyboard was off-set to the left of the machine to accommodate the 10-key numeric keypad at the right hand side.  I thought that like a new cell phone text pad - I would get used to it.  NOT.  No matter how much Itype on this, my hands can not adjust to the odd location of the cursor arrow buttons, or the off-set layout.  While the keys do have a nice \\"touch\\" to them, this layout results in excessive typos for me, along with ergonomic strain from shifting to match the odd layout.  I have had numerous laptops and type on multiple computers with different keyboard layouts at work (in excess of 60 wpm), and have never experienced anything like this.  I do not use the numeric keypad and this was not a factor in my buying decision, but I did not expect it to cause problems with useability.    - The touchpad is extremely poor!  Yes, as other reviewers have noted, it is somewhat grainy.  That has not caused any issues for me.      ...But - it is almost impossible to browse the internet using this machine because the touchpad randomly opens links and popups as I am scrolling down pages.  That happens at a very high volume meaning I am constantly closing windows I have no interest in.  As I am moving the mouse within a webpage such as the Denver Post site, it randomly opens ads they have embedded in the page.  I am NOT clicking to open these - the computer is mis-reading my hand moving over the touchpad.    ...It also sometimes will not scroll at all.  There is a designated scroll location at the right hand side of the touchpad.  Sometimes there is no problem, then other times it will not function to scroll down the page until I manually move the cursor to the page scroll cursor at the right hand outside edge of a webpage.  This is also random, but frequent.    ...When typing emails in Gmail, or using an Excel spreadsheet or Word document - the cursor randomly and suddenly repositions itself at another location within the page.  This is incredibly frustrating as I sometimes do not notice until I have typed a ways down the page.  This happens when my hands rest a moment on the touchpad, and when I am just typing normally!    ...It also has some issues when using Excel from MS Office 2010.  It RANDOMLY will not display cell contents when \\"wrap text to fit\\" has been selected, particularly when I have set this for the whole spreadsheet.  I am able to open the same Excel file on a machine at work and view the cell contents.  The contents are there, but not visible except in the cell reference line at the top of the page.  This makes updating spreadsheets extremely painstaking.    I have had many laptops including HP and a Lenovo ThinkPad and use community computers and laptops at work and school and have never had an overall negative experience.  While each machine may have its quirks, none rendered them as useless as this Lenovo Z565 has been for me.    Ultimately, the bad audio and video capabilities combined with the virtually useless touchpad and keyboard make this Lenovo Z565 a bad buy.  Yes, I got a good price, but I learned a lesson.  I have had it less than a year and will be purchasing its replacement in the near future.
output: Lenovo has Disappointed with the Z565

Well, I purchased this gaming rig/laptop about two months ago and I'm really pleased with it. The amount of features it has is without parallel unless you talking about another gaming rig from say like, Alienware. The toshiba x500-110 comes with the intel i7 core chip 720 at 1.60ghz which tranlates into 3.2 ghz to 3.8ghz maxium cpu speed, a bluray player/burner coupled with an 18.4 inch screen that brings a crisp 1080p for watching hi-def movies or gaming, 8gb ddr (european model which I have#, two 500 gb hard drives #1 terrabyte# wow!, windows 7 premium, a ton of toshiba software which are really great, security features like face recognition and fingerprint #however haven't got the face recog. to work yet#, harmon kardon speakers are superb, and many more features. Now my review is that while the toshiba qosmio x500 is loaded with all anyone could want in a laptop it's HEAVY AS HELL! I couldn't find a carrying bag in any stores, but found one made by toshiba here on amazon. That's the only con I have for anyone thinking about buying one. It looks really sleek and the design is beautuful and can pass as a non-gaming laptop unlike an Alienware rig which is clearly for gamers. I play pc games and can safely say this can play anything except Crysis warhead I think because of the windows 7, but Crysis warhead as everybody who games knows pushes everything in regards to graphics and cpu usage to the limits. I've played COD waw, Half-life #brilliantly#, Bioshock, Left4dead 2 #amazing), Unreal 3, Dirt 2 and PES2010 all in 1080p and with ease. It comes with the nvidia 250 m chip which does well enough and I'm so happy with that because you can't upgrade laptops, so I should be ok for the next 3-4 years. This laptop is considered a desktop replacement so if you want the reliabilty of a desktop without the bulk of a desktop then this is it. I comfortable place it on my lap and use this laptob better than any other laptop I've had previously. It also has an Eco mode that saves and monitors energy usage which is pretty cool. Well this concludes my first review ever. I hope it helped.

[[VIDEOID:37522051]]The SlingMedia Slinglink is economical way to extend the range of your router. Unfortunately, SlingMedia devices (Such as [[ASIN:B000VXD2S8 Sling Media SlingCatcher SC100-100 Universal Media Player for TV]] or [[ASIN:B000VXKD8K Sling Media Slingbox SOLO (SB260-100)]] ) must be plugged directly into an internet source. The SlingLink allow you to use your home's electrical wiring as a means to extend your router.

A couple of things

1 - You must plug the SlingLink directly into your wall socket. It will not work with a power strip or surge protector.
2 - Reaches speeds in excess of 1MPS
3 - Set-up is very, very easy
4- Only 1 port - so you can only plug one device into the unit.
5- Homes with older electrical wiring may have some issues

Final Verdict

I use the the SlingLink for use with my [[ASIN:B000VXD2S8 Sling Media SlingCatcher SC100-100 Universal Media Player for TV]] and I must say that it works perfectly. I have not come across a single issue (and if I do I will update this review).

5 Stars
output: A Video Review on the SlingLink

Instances.input: This is a high quality metal case to protect your BeagleBone Black.  All cutouts are aligned accurately with the board, for example the microSD slot has very little clearance but the card can be inserted without touching the enclosure.  This is not a sealed case, but provides small slits through which to view the various onboard status LED indicators.  Knockouts are provided for a DB9 connector (9 pin serial / VGA) and a round pushbutton / indicator; the DB9 could be used for connection to internal IO pins (which provides a more finished look than an opening for a ribbon cable would).  Drawings are available on the manufacturer's web site.  Recommended for the "finished project" rather than active experimentation.

I eventually made it work :)  The problem was about 1) the documentation, and 2) the device version difference.  The documentation is a disaster. Besides, there are at least two versions of the Iteaduino: v.1.0 and v.1.1 (I don't know anything about others). They are different, and so they require different jumper settings.  This device works fine, provided that you use the correct settings.  Here is what I discovered.    1) First of all, to load a sketch you MUST NOT use \\"Arduino UNO\\" setting from the Tools > Board menu in the Arduino IDE. The board looks like UNO, but is can't be programmed like UNO! Choose \\"Arduino Duemilanove w/ ATmega328\\" instead.    2) Look at the version of your device on the back side. It must be 1.0 or 1.1. You should use different jumper settings to program the device depending on the version of it.    3) The device has three working modes:  a) PC connected to ATmega328 via USB - a \\"normal\\" Arduino mode. You load sketches and use a Serial port over USB in this mode.  b) PC connected to HC-05 chip via USB - you change HC-05 Bluetooth chip settings using \\"AT\\" commands.  c) PC connected to ATmega328 via Bluetooth - that's why you bought this board. You can't load sketches, but you can use a serial connection over Bluetooth to make an external Bluetooth device (PC, cell phone etc.) to communicate with your Iteaduino sketch program.    4) In mode a) you should use the following jumper/switch settings:    jumpers: remove all jumpers;  switch: any position, but it is more safe to set it to DAT.    And when you upload a sketch, don't forget: it is a \\"Arduino Duemilanove w/ ATmega328\\", not \\"Arduino UNO\\".    5) To succeed in mode b), you must first UPLOAD A SKETCH which doesn't use a \\"Serial.begin()\\". You may use the simplest \\"Blink\\" sketch example from Arduino IDE. Of course, you must use mode a) described above to do it. Every time you want to change HC-05 settings you must first switch to mode a) and replace your current sketch with \\"Blink\\". (Youcan avoid sketch reloading if you have an option to make your sketch somehow to skip the Serial initialization.) I believe that this requirement is an Iteaduino BT design issue.    In mode b) you should use the following jumper/switch settings (set them when the power is OFF!):    jumpers: v.1.0: position \\"B\\". v.1.1: position \\"A\\".  switch: position CMD.    Connect a USB cable, open a serial terminal, set speed to 38400 and configure your device using AT commands. Every command should be terminated with CR and LF in this order (you may just use \\"Both NL & CR\\" option in Arduino IDE terminal window.)    A description of of the AT command set can be found here:  http://www.linotux.ch/arduino/HC-0305_serial_module_AT_commamd_set_201104_revised.pdf    IMPORTANT: To successfully work in mode c) you sketch must initialize Serial to the same baud rate your HC-05 device uses!  The HC-05 baud rate can be set using AT+UART command. I am not sure what value it is reset to by AT+ORGL. The HC-05 command spec I referred above says that it is 38400, but the same spec says that the default value of the baud rate is 9600. In my case, as I received the device, the initial baud rate was 9600.  Note that changing the baud rate settings affects only the rate in mode c) but doesn't affect the rate in this configuration mode b): the last is still 38400 (provided that you switch modes and set jumpers when the power is OFF.) See more details by the link to the spec above.    6) In mode c) you should use the following jumper/switch settings (set them when the power is OFF!):    jumpers: v.1.0: position \\"A\\". v.1.1: position \\"B\\".  switch: position DAT.    This is it. Hopefully I didn't forget something important. Good luck :)
output: It is difficult to make it work, but it works.

Instances.input: I love my Kindle.  I purchased an iPad several years ago thinking I would use it as a reader.  But it was too heavy to hold comfortably, and, of course, too expensive to just toss in a bag and go, especially to the beach or outdoors.  Also, trying to read in the sunlight was a problem.  So I never really got into reading books electronically.  I decided last year to give it a second shot and decided I wanted just an e-reader, so it would be light and easily portable.  I was glad I waited, because the Paperwhite had just been released, and I loved the idea of a built in light for reading in the dark (which I do a lot), but which I could still use for reading in regular light and outdoors, especially at the beach.  I have now read several books on it, and I love that I can take it with me wherever I go, and I have my entire library available to me.  I have pretty much stopped buying hard copies.  I chose the ad version because it saved me some money, and it honestly hasn't been a bother to me.  I'm so used to ignoring ads on my iPhone apps, anyway, that it seems natural to just ignore it and swipe to open your novel.  There are no internal ads to interfere with your reading, and, sometimes, there are some good recommendations at cheap prices.
Still learning  how to use it! So far, so good!!

Instances.input: I bought this for my bungalow.  The bungalow has aluminum siding and foiled back insulation, so it is hard for me to get a signal outside, and did not want to switch WIFI inside and outside.  This led me to look for an access point solution.  These are affordable and do the job well.  It looks good on the hallway ceiling, and not cluttered with cords due to being powered by POE.  With only the access point in the hallway, I can get WIFI in my garage, and after adding the garage can get really good signal on the property.  It was easy the configure using the Unified software, and the access controller does not need to be running continuously.  Just needs to be up to configure.  I highly recommend this product as an easy N solution for small business, or large area, or non-signal friendly area.  (If Amazon did not tell you there is a newer version of this for AC ~$250)

I am also able to watch cable TV in the 2nd bedroom too with the IOGEAR receiver.  The quality of the video and audio is GREAT.  I am 100% satisfied with the IOGEAR wireless digital kit.  The distance between the transmitter and receiver is about 30 feet with one wall (drywall and wood studs) in between.  I highly recommend this product.

Instances.input: On window 7 the installation couldn't have been easier.  Installed the software from the disk in less than 5 minutes, clicked on the windows internet access icon, put in the the network password, and connected immediately.  This unit replaced a Linksys WUSB600n receiver  which was plagued by disconnections. I've used this one for two days with zero interruptions and, it appears to carry more bandwidth than the Linksys device gave me.
Great purchase for upgrading my old graphics card and my new motherboard needed it to function or it would not work
Installation/cloning process had one stumbling block that was solved by a selection that had no explanation as to it's meaning, however, so far the SSD I purchased is working fine.

While the price is nice, the product is rather useless. I've had this for about 6 months or so and I don't use it at all.

First, it's not well sized. After fitting the device into it, the playbook sort of slips down and you can't use it properly unless you push it back into place. Really annoying.

The stand feature is hard to use as well. Inserting it into the slot is really annoyingly difficult and I often find myself struggling with it after I move it. After it's setup and I leave it where it stands, it stays put. As soon as I try to move it, however, it comes undone and now I'm fiddling with it again.

There is no hole for the charge port, so I have to undo the strap at the bottom of the device to charge it. At this position, I have to keep it flat and half way out in order for me to charge it. Considering that I have to recharge my playbook about every week, this became really annoying.

Nice try, but this thing is pretty much useless. I stopped using mine and now it's going into the garbage. I guess I should have paid more for a better device.
Protects the device. I like the plastic shell. It has tecture like some phone covers that prevent sliding. Also has a elastic strap that holds it closed. The stand is also a nice feature.

I purchased this wireless router because the one I had was 10 years old and my laptop could never get a strong connection.  Needless to say, this new router was quite the improvement.  I have never had a problem connecting, or staying connecting, with my laptop several rooms away.    All I really needed was an occasional wireless transmitter.  Even with all the security features, I know that no wireless transmitter can be 100% secure.  Plus we are not convinced that sending a wireless signal through the house is completely safe health-wise, especially when this router has to sit on a shelf at head level in the room where I spend most of my time.  I prefer doing most of my computer work on a desktop computer anyway, and only rarely need to connect with my laptop in another room.  So I just wanted a wireless transmitter on the rare occasions when I use my laptop.  I could not find a wireless router that has the option to turn off the transmitter, or at least one that listed that capability.  So my network is made up of two routers.  I have a wired router for a couple of our home desktop computers.  I then plug this wireless router into the wired router only when I want to use the wireless connection for my laptop.  Otherwise the wireless router is unplugged.    This works great for my purposes.  It took quite awhile to set up, though it connected easily the first time.  For some reason, the software that came with it, Linksys Adviser, for managing your computer network was very slow to install.  Plus, after the software was installed, over the next couple of weeks it kept notifying me that I needed to get the updates for the software, even after I downloaded and installed the latest updates.  I couldn't find any way to get it to stop telling me that I needed updates.  So finally I uninstalled the Linksys Adviser software.  The router continues to work just fine without that software!  Plus, I really don't need it for managing my network anyway, as it is really my wired router, not this wireless router, that controls my network.    So I thought the router itself is great!  But I found the software to be lousy and unneeded.
output: Great wireless router, didn't care for the software

Instances.input: I always liked WD Hard drives. I decided to go with external drive with USB 3. Well let me tell you - first one worked good until I actually started doing backup (which means once I actually copied 1st file onto the HD). Took 30 min to copy 200 MB. I called WD tech support to find out that \\"these hard drives have connection issues\\" - that I was told my the rep. So they sent me another one that died/started making scratchy noises after about 3% of 500 MB backup. It just got stock making scratchy noises. I had that one replaced again to find out that the 3rd one - Died after 10 days. I just gave up and threw it to garbage. West to get a Seagate freeagent. So far so good. BTW - WD tech support is outsourced and they hardly speak english and Im not even talking about spelling. They made so many mistakes and I had to correct them 3 times to find out that they completely butchered my name and address on the box. Unbelievable. Worst than Dell india support. Never again!!!
output: Worst Hard drive I have ever had after replacing it 3 times with same unit

Instances.input: This is my first USB 3.0 purchase, so I didn't know what size to expect. The flash drive is bulkier than other 2.0s I have, but the speed and available space make this buy completely worth the price!

So, I had spent several days looking up cheap Xbox360 HDDs. I had purchased an Xbox360 Slim 4GB, and realized I wanted to download DLCs, games, music, movies ect. I went onto Amazon and looked up the expansion drive HDD from Microsoft and flipped out. I wasnt going to pay another 150 dollars on a hardrive. Thats costs more than just buying a 250 GB Xbox itself! So I looked around at all these cheap HDDs and saw this one had the best reviews. I was scared that I was getting some cheap xbox harddrive that would give me the 'red ring of death' or just stop working altogether. So I figured hey, this one has the best reviews, ill give it a shot. I have had this for a year now, and I havent had a single problem! It says 120 GB, but its actually 106 GB. Still plenty of Gigs. I have like 20 games and tons of DLC content installed and it still has room on it! The xbox even reads it as an official Microsoft HDD. I havent had any problems and enjoy it. Im glad I made the gamble to buy it.

Instances.input:
I'm an IT guy. I got his for my home PC. After using it for a while I was responsible for my employer buying many of them.
Combine this with a an AMD A10 5800K and I don't think you can find better bang for your buck.

NVIDIA has put together an amazing board here. With hardware that is many times more powerful than the RasberryPi and other small/low power SoC mini PC's, this has the performance and expand-ability to handle a wide variety of uses. I hope though strong sales the price will be able to come down (due to manufacturing efficiency and the accessories market will pick up.

Uses for these boards range from a 2nd desktop, network router (with a 2nd Ethernet port coming off the pcie slot and maybe a USB wifi adapter), or a file server, and perhaps the largest potential: an extremely efficient HTPC to play media on your TV.

The existing arm boards are too slow for many functions and too expensive for what they offer. Now we just need this to come down in price a little bit and include a case & power brick and they will be flying off the shelf.

But be aware, this board currently only supports Ubuntu OS (no support for Windows on ARM or Android) although again if this becomes popular we may see other options open up.
output: NVIDIA has put together an amazing board here

This is my second Razer mouse, first was the ProClick, the middle scrolling button stopped working after some time and I finally decided to replace it. The Orochi comes with wired and wireless (bluetooth) which is great. Love the idea of being able to use it with a wire if I run out of battery. The software isn't the best for customization of the buttons and the mouse can be a little to small (I do have large hands). Buttons on the right side of the mouse can be accidentally clicked when using the mouse. It is a step up from the ProClick but I feel it is still lacking. The cable for wired mode has started to come apart without much use. The cable isn't plastic coated instead it is some sort of nylon or something (not sure) and strands of it started to loosen up within the first two days, really disappointed that this is happening with a mouse that is expensive. The scroll isn't the best either. The rubber on the scroll can be easily moved during normal usage that will lead to the scrolling not smooth, this could have been easily avoided if the rubber around the scrolling was glued together or something instead of just wrapped around. The look of it is good overall, but needs work, considering whether to return this or not, it does not seem like a mouse the is durable for the high price it is but I do like being able to use wire or bluetooth. I expected better quality for this mouse but am disappointed.
output: Overall okay, but has problems that you shouldn't overlook

I've had this monitor for a little while now and I have to say it's by far the best LCD diplay I've ever laid eyes on (having looked at a few) The colors, sharpness, brightness and contrast are all very good indeed. It does have a stuck pixel, but in normal useage it's less noticeable than the support wires of any Trinitron CRT. Backlight evenness is also very good and the build quality looks excellent. It's also very stylish. The glass panel on the front seems to help visually and adjusting it for color and contrast is fairly easy allowing for very good display gamma settings.
It's a real treat using this in it's digital mode at native resolution. Sharp, precise and very easy on the eyes. When calibrated and given a suitable display profile It's at least as good as any high end CRT I've looked at and better than most, it was important for me to get the best image quality I could find. The X-174 is very impressive and I have ordered a second one after trying a cheaper LCD... it's really not worth the eyeball pain.
I think the only downside is the maximum resolution, 1280 x 1024 can seem small when used to 21\\" monitors running 1600 x 1200. That isn't a fault in the monitor though, 1600 panels are rare and not necessarily as good as this. I am very happy with this monitor and though it's expensive, it's worth it.

And I think that is a major plus. I've looked at quite a few external chargers, but few match the size of my phone like this one does. Why is that important? Because I know that if my phone will fit--in an evening bag, small purse, coat pocket, etc.--then this charger should tuck in nicely, nestled right up against the phone.

Having looked at quite a few other chargers, I can say that most work basically the same. Your main decision you need to make is just how much mAh you need for your particular situation. This one, at 4000mAh will fully charge your phone one time. If you need power for standing 24 hours in line waiting for concert tickets or a Black Friday event, you need a much bigger power bank (say 10,000 to 15,000mAh). If you are going camping out in the wilderness, you need an even bigger power bank (maybe 15,000 to 20,000mAh). If you are the designated power-holder for the entire family on vacation you need a few big banks to keep up with demand. At the opposite end, you can find tiny, simple chargers that will give you a burst of emergency power to call home for help. Those can be the size of a thick business card that fits in your wallet.

So, if 4000mAh is the power size you've decided on, you can't go wrong with this charger: It works well and efficiently. It is also sharp-looking with its brushed aluminum finish. The aluminum finish is on the top-side; the bottom is a hard, but rubbery-feel plastic. Why the four-star, and not a five-star, rating? While the design is decent, it is not outstanding. There are some chargers available here on Amazon that will wow you! This is not one of them. But if design is not important to you, this is a perfectly fine model.

Another plus is that the amount of charge remaining is showed quite clearly in five LED light combinations. Most other chargers only give you four stages. With this charger, the LED lights start with a solid red light when it is under 25% charged, the progress through flashing red, flashing red and green, flashing green, then solid green when there is a 96-100% charge.

The silky black draw-string pouch is nicely made and will hold the charger, the mini or micro USB cables, and your phone, too (if it's in a minimalist case).

*I received a sample product from Arctic.the progress through flashing red, flashing red and green, flashing green, then solid green when there is a 96-100% charge.

Instances.input: Ive been using them for gaming for a couple months now.  The sound is decent.  The whole 5.1 thing is interesting though.  I feel some people are going to think its really neat and others are just going to feel like its an advanced version of stereo.  You have to just test it yourself.  There are supposed to be 5 or more individual speakers in the headphones and the surround sound is not simulated.  The bass levels are not too shabby in my opinion but I dont have any headphones to compare it to because these are my first 5.1 set.  It does not out perform a real sub though but what do you expect?  Where these things kind of disappoint is some of the construction.  The controller piece is alright but it sucks to just let hang on your head so you have to either lay it on your lap, clip it, or deal with it.  There is a light on it too that can be quite bright and annoying so if its near your head its a huge distraction unless I am missing a way to turn it off. I see no switch or option in the software.  I have a buddy that bought them as well and he had to put electrical tape over it just to be able to stand it.  If you try to clip the controller the clip is flimsy and cheap and can break easily.  I have not tested the microphone part of it yet other than levels.  I just use these for 5.1 single player gaming and they seem to do well for that.  The last issue is the driver for the headphones.  It has a program that only starts when it is plugged in which is nice but that software looks like its straight out of windows 95 for some reason.  You'll see what I mean if you use it.  Its just plain ugly.  It lets you get the job done though by adjusting levels of each speaker and changing your environment settings but the way it looks like something from the movie \\"Hacker\\" makes it seem a little shady.  It has some environment settings that are actually pretty funny like making the sound seem under water.  A complete waste of time?  Yup.  Will you ever use them?  No, no you wont.  Oh well.  Anywho go ahead and buy them if you are cheap like me and just want a pair of decent 5.1 headphones.
output: Seems good for the price so far but has flaws

I discovered a software problem with the Acer Fn+F2 key software toggle (Wireless toggle), and contacted Acer Technical Support about it. Unfortunately, the response I received about the bug from Technical Support (Praveen, Rajeesh, and Sreekanth) was \\"...the wireless toggle button is working.\\", and \\"...resolve the issue please contact \\"Pay for support\\" who will be able to provide you with the best options available and help you further.\\", and \\"For support concerning this issue, we have a dedicated team called \\"Pay for support\\" who will be able to provide you with the best options available and help you further.\\"    My computer is still under warrantee, so I don't know why I would have to pay for support for a problem with the Acer software. Fortunately, the bug I found is not the end of the world (there is a work-around), but you would think that Acer would want to get information about the bug and maybe update their code to fix the problem.    Hopefully I won't find a major bug with their software.    Other than this bug the computer does seem to work OK - actually the computer works much better than Technical Support.

Instances.input: it works great i have it for a while with noproblems or regrets there is no need for me to buy another one so that makes it a very recommendable product

Great product. I was a little hesitant to purchase my first wireless router after watching the cable guy install the one I rented from them and reading all the technical stuff that the guys who deal with wireless networks had written in the reviews, but all I wanted was to have a wireless internet connection to my computer so I don't have to run cables around the house. This was a good deal for the money and had good ratings, so I decided to try my luck.

Installation was easy. I just followed the steps on the install CD and in less than 10 minutes had a fully functional wireless internet connection. Its a little faster than the previous wireless router that the cable company had given me and the connection is always great.

My only complaint is that if my computer is off for more than 5 or 6 hours, the connection turns itself off (probably actually a good feature), and I have to manually turn it back on, but even that is just a matter of 2 clicks so it's not a big deal - an extra 5 seconds out of my day.

It's a secure network with a password so no one else can log into the network but me, and the wireless management software that comes with it remembers all that, so there's no retyping passwords every time I want to log on.

All in all, a very satisfying purchase for me and I'd recommend it to anyone. Don't let the technical guys scare you with their reviews, this is easy to use and install. :o)
output: Linksyss by Cisco WRT54G2 Wireless-G Broadband Router Review

Several reviewers commented about the lack of an internal CD/DVD or s wireless keyboard & mouse on a $300 PC.  Is this a realistic expectation?  I found the PC to be a good value. Th unit is essentially the equivalent of an Acer Revo R3610 (Acer owns E-Machines & Gateway). For $100  or $150 more, you get a inexpensive wireless keyboard & mouse.  What you do get is the HDMI port, which allows you to stream Netflix, Hulu, etc as well as local media files to your HDTV.  The software can be downloaded (Boxee or similar).  The PC can be mounted behind the HDTV.  As a Home Theater PC, it is an exceptional value.  Get your own wireless Keyboard & mouse (MS, Logitech, etc).  You will be happier with the quality & lifespan.  Similarly, a USB DVD is not an expensive item.  I plan to put one  of these PC's behind each of my HD TV's.

BTW, if your home button does work on android device, try to follow my step.
1. Root your android device.
2. Root Explorer </system/usr/keylayout/generic.kl>.
3. Chang the file's permissions to writable.
4. Open the file with text editor.
5. Modify the line "Key 102 MOVE_HOME" to "Key 102 HOME"
6. Save your file and reboot your device.
7. All done.
output: If your home button does't work.

I do some gaming but I mainly wanted these headphones to conduct private video conferences and VOIP calls without using the speakers on my laptop or desktop. So others around me cannot snoop.  I like them.  They are comfortable and light weight compared to many other headsets I have used over the years.  I also like the in-line volume and mute mic features.  That said, these headphones even when set on max volume (and with the computer set on max volume) are not as loud as I expected.  They are not amplified.  All persons I have gamed or conferenced with said they could hear me fine, and I heard them fine.  But if you need a headset with higher or amplified volume levels or are hard of hearing you may want to consider some other product.  I also liked the fold flat earcups as it allows me to carry these in my luggage better when I am on the road. I give 4 stars.  Had the price been lower than $80 (say $50 or $60) and the volume a bit louder I would have given 5 stars.  No problems so far with breakage, and I will update if that becomes a problem, but I would note for the curious these are mostly plastic with a metal headband.  Earcups and padding is foam rubber.
output: Pretty Good Headphones - Price is high however

Upon receipt, this battery lasted almost 1.5 hours - a far cry from the 4-6 hours my original battery provided, but long enough to last through a single college class.    Now it's been three months, and this battery does not even last 20 minutes.  It's worse than the battery I was replacing in the first place.  I can't believe I wasted $90 on this.  Maybe I got a bad (or ancient) battery, but I think it's a little too late to return it (my fault for not complaining immediately).  There is no manufacturing date on the battery, so I don't know if I got one that's been sitting on a shelf, rotting, for the last five years.      I was looking for the cheapest replacement battery available when I found and bought this.  Don't make the same mistake!  I'm going to shell out the extra money for a new battery straight from Dell once my tax return hits.    For those that care, the paint color/finish was pretty close to the laptop's color - it's not as deep or sparkly, but the finish is smoother - the paint on the battery has less orange peel than the paint on the laptop.  But come on, do you leave your laptop upside down on your desk?  The fit/finish is not the reason you're looking for a new battery (I hope).

Instances.input: I spent about a week speaker shopping after the kid down the hall in my dorm played music 24/7. To answer the other comment/reviewer, a PSP is the Sony Playstation Portable. They were released here in the USA in March 2005. It was released in Japan late 2004. Not sure about the rest of the world. The PSP uses memory stick duo media for a variety of purposes, most noteably video, music, and game data.

As far as the product, Sandisk products have been great and I've never seen any compatibility issues with Sandisk versus Sony media, so go for the best price. However, if you have a digital camera that supports high speed transfers, you might want to get the Red Sony High Speed since it supports that high speed transfers. To my knowledge, only Sony, not Sandisk, makes the high speed transfer version. However, from what I understand for PSP usage, you do not need the high speed; although, you can use the high speed in a PSP from what I've read. It could make transfers using a card reader quicker even if not the actual accesses with the PSP.

Anker comes through again with a new Ultra-Slim case and Bluetooth Keyboard for the iPad Air. They were nice enough to supply me with a sample for test and evaluation, but no worries, I promise that my review is fair and honest (this is not my first product review rodeo!).

I've given it a thorough going-over and found much to like. First, this is the lightest Bluetooth keyboard I've ever seen. The keyboard weighs just a few ounces; it's so light in fact that it seems almost like a toy. Yet the advertised battery life is 100 hours working and 100 days standby. While I didn't try to test either figure (I do have a life, you know), other Anker keyboards I've tested live up to the advertised specs.

Secondly, the keyboard attaches to the magnetized cover. Position it to allow the iPad space to adjust to the desired viewing angle, or remove it entirely. Use in on your iPad or your cell phone; I tested it successfully on my Galaxy S3, Kindle Fire HDX, and Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1, all list it as the "Anker Keyboard case for iPad 5" and operates perfectly.

Next, the iPad itself fits snugly into a polycarbonate case attached to the Folio. I really love this feature; I've highlighted it in reviews of other Anker iPad cases. The case holds the iPad securely - a must considering the cost of the iPad; hold the case at any angle and the iPad remains in place.

The Bluetooth connection is easy to set up and remains connected even when the iPad goes to sleep, just hit any key to get things started again. A simple on/off switch and Connect button are present and the keyboard recharges via a micro-USB cable (provided).

Now, I'm not a talented typist, but I found the keyboard a little small; a necessary compromise given the size of the iPad Air. You are not going to type War and Peace, at least not without getting used to the small keyboard size. There are, however, a full set of function keys including sound, brightness, and media controls; throw in a lock function, a home key and a few others. The keys have good travel and are responsive to the touch. In fact, I typed the whole review using the keyboard and the Pages application on my iPad Air.

A note of caution; with the keyboard in place the iPad does not turn off when you close the case - the keyboard blocks the magnetized case which turns the iPad off. Remove the keyboard and close the cover and the iPad powers down. A magnetized flap closes to secure the cover and folds back when open to stay out of the way.

All this at a great price! Grab one of these and make your iPad more functional.rightness, and media controls; throw in a lock function, a home key and a few others. The keys have good travel and are responsive to the touch. In fact, I typed the whole review using the keyboard and the Pages application on my iPad Air.

All that being said, there is no guarantee that this sound card will give you a more pleasant listening experience. I bought the Antec USB-Powered Notebook Cooler on the basis of the reviews available at the time. And it probably was the best available then. But at best it could keep my laptop from getting hot, not cool it down if it already was. And the fans tended to get dirty and vibrate, creating a racket. I'd have to apologize for using it in quiet settings—so much so that I sometimes just used it as a stand to create room for air to circulate beneath my 15-inch MacBook Pro on its own. For information about a cooling pad that is quiet, unobtrusive, and will not only keep your laptop from heating up but also cool a hot laptop down while you continue to use it, see my review of Logitech's Cooling Pad N200. Now that's a 5-star product!
output: Clunky, louder than I thought it would be, and not as effective as I needed it to be.

He just complained last week that his has snapped off and got stuck inside his ipad. Then today I picked up mine and pulled it out, it hadn't snapped off, but the metal plug part had come loose from the base and when I touched it after removing it, the end fell off. This was not user error. Neither of us had done anything to cause it. And neither of us has had this happen to any other iPad charger before.

Sadly 99% of review users leave their reviews very soon after receiving the product, which is really only helpful if there are no reviews at all to go by. But, obviously, those reviews will not gauge how well a product holds up over time. If I had reviewed this immediately upon receiving, or any sooner than last week, I would have given it 5 stars like so many others here have.
output: Did not hold up after 6 months

Instances.input: I bought this cover because of the excellent reviews from other purchasers...along with some research on Bear Motion.  The combination provided enough confidence in the quality and suitability of the product to make the purchase.  One reviewer noted that the cover fit \\"to the mm\\", i.e. exactly as it should.  In fact, it does.  So, great fit, high quality leather and workmanship, excellent packaging, immediate follow-up by Bear Motion (to ensure that I was completely satisfied), and several months of very satisfactory daily use are why I give it 5 stars.  (Previously, I bought an expensive vinyl cover for an Ipad 3.  The fit was fine and the swivel and notches for upright use were just right.  But the vinyl has worn unacceptably and proven very disappointing.  I'm looking at a Bear Motion leather cover for it, at the moment. My wife will be pleased.  Of course, being a rather fanatical pro-football fan, she repeatedly asks if she can try my Bear Motion cover on her Ipad 3.  I don't think the cover will fit her Ipad, but I'm not taking a chance that she could force it in.  When it's time, I'll buy her a Bear Motion cover that is guaranteed to fit her Ipad.)    Update:  I have really enjoyed this cover that I paid $49.99 for.  Have enjoyed many compliments on its styling and perceived quality...kudos to Bear Motion Cases.  However, for several months, the \\"strings\\" / laces on the case have become increasingly loose and risk pulling out of the cover with almost any degree of snagging.  If/when that happens, the appearance of the case will degrade rapidly. So, this feels like a significant flaw unless it can be remedied easily.  I have searched for a way to contact Bear Motion about this to no avail.  And I can't find their earlier communication. So, I hope someone from Bear Motion follows this site and can tell me if there is a \\"fix\\" for this problem.  I see that their current Ipad cases don't have the \\"football\\" design, so no more problems with the \\"strings\\" coming unraveled.  That was a good decision.  Wish it had been available when I ordered mine.    2nd Update: I sent an email to ProBiz (as they invite us to do), but no response.  I bought this long enough ago that I know it's beyond any warranty.  But given the ProBiz general model of seeking / responding to feedback / complaints, I expected at least a reply to my concerns.  I expect the time will come when I simply cut the laces off and live with the holes. If I had paid the current price for the case, I might be more tolerant of the product degrading.  But when a company touts the quality of the product and promises a response to concerns, well, I expect both.  Didn't get either.
output: Update:  1st impression: Excellent.  Lingering impression: Disappointing

The easiest security for your home documents and to prevent someone from stealing your identity, is to purchase a paper shredder. There are many people who spend time looking through people's garbage to find personal information. Once you've had your identity stolen, it's really hard to fix all that.

There are two types of popular paper shredders, strip cut and confetti cut paper shredders. This shredder is a confetti cut, also known as cross-cut, and is the most popular type of paper shredder, because they offer a higher level of security. A standard letter size paper is cut into 300-400 small pieces. This makes it difficult to retrieve sensitive information.

Most have sensors, so they start shredding when you put a piece of paper in and turn off when it's shredded. If you have kids or pets in the house, it's always best to unplug your shredder when you're not using it.

This Aleratec DVD/CD shredder is one of the best I have tried. The shredder came well packaged. Placed in an attractive blue box, the shredder blade portion was well packaged and easy to remove from the package itself. The shredder box and the DVD/CD receptacle were separate and easy to remove. A very informative User Manual was enclosed, along with the Aleratec Registration form and envelope. A shredder lubricant sheet was enclosed, you feed this sheet directly into the shredder. Easy set up, plug the shredder into an outlet. Place the side switch to Auto position, a green LED light comes on and then start shredding. I had 4 advertising pieces of mail in an unopened envelope. Each piece was probably equivalent to four pieces of paper. Went in like a breeze. I don't find the noise at all loud. I do not have any CD's or DVD's to shred at this time.

I found this an extremely easy shredder to put together, the users manual was helpful and concise, and most importantly the shredder works very well. Excellent paper shredder, I will use it often. A sample was provided for review.

This is my second Apple computer... I also have a 6.5 year old Apple Powerbook notebook computer that still runs OK after all those years... I recently purchased the Imac, a 32 GB IPOD Touch (to upgrade from a 4 year old Nano 2 GB), and an Airport Express Wireless router... I like all my new Apple purchases A LOT!!... the Imac is amazingly fast compared to what I was used to (the old Powerbook G4 1.25 Ghz)... the display is awesome and its huge size allows me to have multiple apps running and displayed without overlapping/hidden windows... I upgraded the RAM to 12 Gig (from Crucial Memory), and bought the magic trackpad (which I am only starting to get used to, and REALLY LIKE IT/haven't been using the magic mouse hardly at all)... I have only just recently finished migrating all my stuff from the Powerbook, and added some graphic/photoEditing/movieAuthoring applications that will show the power of the I5 CPU and 12 Gigs of RAM -- so can't really give a complete evaluation at this point in thyme... the setup was superEZ (typical for Apple products), and I could have used the Apple migration with a firewire to migrate my old account from the Powerbook --> but since the Powerbook was PowerPC based and the Imac is Intel based, didn't want to do that and possibly run into problems with program executable image incompatibilities... Migrating Iphoto and Itunes libraries was a little tricky but there are plenty of tips online on the Internet to assist when I got into a bind... So, in summary, this new Apple desktop computer ROCKS the BIG_HOUSE to the MAX in so many ways and I haven't even begun to test the computN_waters... I am such an Apple fan, and that is after using Windows PCs for several years at home (and still use them at work)... I am an IT person (been in the business for about 29 years), software support/etc... I would totally prefer an all-Apple compute environment, but for now, at work that isn't the case, and it is nice to see Windows continue to evolve (have a Windows 7 PC at work, and I like that OS OK as well, but not half as much as I like Mac OS/X)...

This bag is wonderful.  It fits my Dell Insprion like a glove, but let me tell you why I call it a bag for my bag. I often have to make a meeting where a coffee shop helps me kill time between stops. I have a large over the shoulder laptop bag which holds the kitchen sink and perhaps even the dish rack too. There is a pocket for the laptop, but I throw so much stuff in all the various pockets when I am in a hurry, I risk placing something that will shift position and end up in the laptop pocket.  The Dell has a beautiful glass-like outer shell and I don't want it scratched by my iPod, cordless mouse, pens, and all the other junk I toss in the bag.    This bag in a bag allows me to easily slip the laptop into it and then place the entire bag in the pocket in my big bag. It never shifts and it is incredibly protective. The bag is a 'perfect' fit for a 15.4\\" laptop.  The only extras that will fit in the bag is a few USB memory sticks, or a mouse pad, but NOT the power cord or anything else too thick or too large.  If you're looking for a perfect bag, this is it.    Oh, often, when I go to a meeting, the only thing I need is the laptop.  It is so convenient to simply pull this bag out of my big bag and then see my client. When I enter with my laptop in this sleeve, it is impressive, thin, and ultra convenient.    That's my two-cent worth.
