This is an excellent product and it is easy to see why it is one of the best selling gaming keyboards on the market today.

The keyboard is fast and responsive when keys are pressed, which is probably the most important "feature". Out of all the keyboards I have ever owned or used, this one is probably the fastest and most responsive that I have ever come across. Its sturdy construction and heavy weight keep it from moving around when weight is applied. The construction also provides a good amount of shock absorption, which helps avoid fatigue and soreness that you might find from prolonged usage of thinner keyboards. And the distinct clicking sounds of the keys provide a distinct audio cue that lets you know a key was pressed.

The green back lights are a visual delight and they of course compliment any mouse (I.E. The Razer Death Adder) or PC tower (I.E. A black case with green LEDs) that has a similar color scheme. You can adjust the intensity of the lights using the Synapse software or the function keys on the keyboard, which is a nice feature. The function keys also provide you with audio and media control as well as some other keyboard specific commands. These aforementioned function keys are not absolute necessities, but they are convenient and something you would come to expect from a high end keyboard.

The Synapse software for the keyboard provides you with a decent array of options to configure the keyboard. Its layout and overall visual aesthetic looks a little unpolished when compared to the look and feel of some of the programs you may find for Logitech or other big name peripheral manufactures driver software. This isn't the biggest problem with Synapse however; you will find many complaints across the internet about Synapse wanting you to go online (although there is an option inside of it to go offline). While I question the practice of Synapse' cloud approach myself, it isn't the biggest detriment to the BlackWidow.

The only true complaint about the BlackWidow that I have is its seemingly unnecessary audio hook ups on the side. While in practice these are good ideas, the placement of the hook-ups on the right side of the keyboard cause a space problem, especially since my mouse is right next to the right side of the keyboard. And of course, in order for the USB port on the right side of the keyboard to function, you will need to sacrifice an extra USB port. So the keyboard itself is hurt somewhat by the fact that it requires 2 USB ports (instead of the traditional 1) to fully function.BlackWidow.

This is a generic 'Type A to Micro B' USB cable and, as far as I can tell, everything is right, including the price. It is USB 2.0 certified, meaning that it supports data transfer rates of up to 480Mbps and, if your device accepts a Micro-B plug, this is the cable to get. Maybe the 2-meter length (6+ ft.) is a little bit too much but it does not bother me a lot and there may come a time when a cable this long may come in handy.

I am awarding this item 5 stars for price, quality and for not making any special 'claims' as a pretext to charge an inflated price. It's note the absolute cheapest but, being an Amazon brand returning it if it's not what you needed or while under warranty should be as painless as these types of transactions go - I am speaking out of personal experience here.

And, YES, it DOES work with the latest Kindle and YES, you can use with with a Blackberry Bold and most smart phones and Bluetooth headsets.

______________________________________________

Notes:

Anyone in the market for a USB cable should be very careful because there are at least 6 kinds of USB connectors. If you are buying a cable that connects 'something' to your computer or laptop, the computer end of the cable will always be a USB-A or 'Type A' connector. At the other end, you may have a USB-B/Type B - a nearly square shaped connector used mostly to deliver power to a device but this is rare. Most likely, you will have a Mini-B or a Micro-B. The difference between the 2 is that the Micro-B is half as thick while the width is the same - Mini-B is 3x7mm while Micro-B is 1.5x7mm.

If your device (phone, PDA, camera) is a 'new' one and it's using USB, chances are that they will need a Micro-B connector because the industry seems to be adopting the 'Micro' form factor as its standard. If the above sounds simple, you should keep in mind that some devices require Mini-AB or Micro-AB connectors, also known as USB OTG (OnTheGo) devices.

My advice: before ordering any cable, make sure that you clearly understand what type of cable you need. If in doubt, do some more research or call the maker's tech support.le, make sure that you clearly understand what type of cable you need. If in doubt, do some more research or call the maker's tech support.
output: Standard USB but the Amazon brand is a big plus

I've had this mouse for a little over a year now. I didn't want to spend money on a cheaper wireless mouse because most of the cheaper ones around my local stores were too small. I wanted something that would be comfortable to grip in my hand. I saw this mouse for $29.99 and decided to spend a couple of extra bucks to purchase it.  Now, when I first bought the mouse, I had Windows Vista. I had no problem hooking this mouse up on my laptop. I simply plugged in the usb receiver and could instantly use the device without a problem. When I upgraded to Windows 7, I still had no issues using the mouse.  Someone in another review mentioned the side buttons are easy to hit by mistake. This happens to me a lot. While gripping the mouse, my thumb will sometimes hit one of the side buttons, essentially a back button. It frustrates me when I'm on a page reading something and by accident, hit the side mouse back button. Despite this drawback, I really like having the side buttons on the mouse. It makes it very convenient to go back on one or several web pages without constantly hitting the back button on my web browser all of the time.  When it comes to the cursor when using this mouse, it follows my hand movement almost precisely. The mouse is durable enough to remain still so the cursor isn't constantly shaking as I found with several other wireless mice. I've seen some wireless mice being so sensitive, even the slightest bump from my hand will send the cursor flying all over the screen. Fortunately, this doesn't do that.  I also like the rubber grips on the side. Apart from obviously making the mouse easier to hold, it rests more comfortably in my hand.  And the one other drawback I find with this aside from hitting the side buttons easily by mistake is the usb receiver itself. I've seen newer mice have a shorter length for the usb receiver. As you can see from the picture of this mouse amazon provides, the usb receiver sticks right out when plugged in. I've came close so many times knocking this out of the usb port on my computer and damaging both the port and the receiver. Luckily, this hasn't happened yet. I only wished the receiver was a LOT shorter.    Would I recommend this product? Of course! Just be careful not to hit that usb receiver when it's plugged in, though.

I am overly please with this trackball mouse and don't know how I lived without it before. If you are only gonna use it for general mouse use, this trackball is probably gonna be overkill for you and there are many other cheaper and more practical choices for you. But if you do graphic design, video/photo/music editing, or any other task that has numerous multi key combo commands that you use repetitiously, then this mouse is a must have. It is rather large and seemingly bulky when you first use it, but you soon realize it is for maintaing a fair amount of comfort during long and/or repetitive tasks. The beauty though lies in the program that comes with it allowing full adjustability of all aspects of it. You and adjust speed, sensitivity, and acceleration of the track ball and scroll ring around it. You can program each of the four buttons to tackle six commands, either from a preset, or fully custom key command string or combo. Each button does one command and the top 2 together and bottom 2 together for a total of six. You can also set your choice of "hot keys" on the keyboard to engage effects such as slow(or fine) scrolling and vertical/horizontal scrolling. It has increased my workflow efficiency exponentially. Complex 3 key "Command+Alt+Character" type commands that I use most for a task, become single button clicks saving time and aggravation due to my limited memory ability of commands when swapping from one app to another. My only wish for this mouse is that they would add the ability in the programming software to save different profiles for your most used configurations. But I don't mind to much programming the buttons myself for now and I still give this product a 5 star and recommend it to others who have similar needs of their trackball.

I love my Kindle. It's a five star item that I've bought at least half a dozen times for myself and friends. I can't say enough good things about it.

The Kindle Fire? Well, we're still having our fling. The ultimate fate of it is yet to be determined. I want it to be the very sexy iPad. It seems like it could be. However, I'm not sure it's even the girl next door. Compared to the iPad, the Fire is a little temperamental -- the touch recognition isn't quite as polished, and sometimes it does things you don't want or didn't expect. It's not quite as versatile due to the Amazon store's limited selection of applications. It doesn't have all the bells and whistles and doesn't quite do as much. Plus, I'm not really the target audience, as I want to fall in love with my girlfriend's iPad but I can't figure out where it fits in my life.

Really, that's my primary complaint with the Fire -- where does it fit in my life? I have a laptop for heavy computing and I have an iPhone for not-so-heavy computing. Anything I can't do with the iPhone I really need to haul out the laptop to get done. However, at the price I figured I could take a chance. $200 goes down a lot easier than $600. What I've found is that I may not be in love with it, but I don't want to return it either. It's kind of nice to have a lightweight computing platform I can throw in a (largish) pocket. It does a lot of things really well, and it's a fantastic media consumption device. Watching Netflix streaming and Amazon Prime streaming videos has been a joy. Plus, I found that many apps do exist in other stores, and it's not overly difficult to \\"sideload\\" those applications onto the device. A little bit of hacking, and this has become a pretty useful and cheap electronic device.

I'm not in love, so I can't give it five stars. But I am in a surprised state of severe like and I think it might blossom into a beautiful friendship.
output: It's not an iPad, but for the price, it doesn't have to be.

2) If you just want JBOD or are a manly man Running RAID 0 (Mac OS Disk Manager), or RAID 1 and want to save money vs. ThunderBay
3) the handle might be a plus, but you still have to carry the big honking PS.
4) I got 650 MB/s, RAID 0 with 4 HGST NAS drives
5) I got 465/430 MB/s read/write with SoftRaid RAID 5
6) you can always try some freeware RAID (at your own risk)
7) Low Cost if the negatives don't matter.
output: External Power Supply, No RAID software.

I am typing this review in my bed, on the very product I'm reviewing.  If you're looking or a netbook - look no further.  This is the best one you can get.    First a little note about different versions out there.  You basically want to get one of the three listed below, as they are identical hardware-wise, and differ only in enclosure color/finish:  Samsung N150-JP05 - Black Matte (the one I got)  Samsung N150-JP06 - Blue Matte  Samsung N150-JP07 - Glossy Black    They all come with the new version of the atom chip - N455, which differs from previous N450 processor by supporting DDR3 memory.  The netbook comes with 1GB of DDR3 memory installed already and you can upgrade up to 2GB (just keep in mind there is only one memory slot, so you need to buy 2GB).    I was looking for a way to read pdf books in bed (a lot of software/engineering books are written in that format).  I was hoping I could use my Kindle for that, but sadly, while great for fiction, Kindle was a big let-down when it came to pdf reading.  Not only do you have to jump through hoops to convert pdfs to mobi format, but the end result often misses pictures/graphs/tables and is not searchable.  This is where I got an idea to use a netbook, and it surpassed my expectations.    I was initially planning on buying an Asus, from Eee series, but luckily enough, a coworker already went that route, and was thoroughly disappointed.  Asus machine was loud, was getting very hot, and had a reflective screen.  My coworker promptly returned it, and bought the Samsung instead.  After I got a chance to look at it at work, I immediately ordered mine.  This notebook is quiet, doesn't run hot, and most importantly is perfect for reading due to matte screen.  You don't get that annoying shiny reflection (I don't understand why manufacturers insist on making glossy displays - they are unusable).    The notebook comes with Windows 7 Starter, and 1 Gb of RAM.  It runs fast enough when it comes to typical daily tasks, like browsing the web, reading PDFs and checking email.  I am actually planning to install Visual Studio on it, and see if it can handle it.  Will update the review when I do.    It is capable of playing Netflix if you have the streaming plan.  I did see it drop a couple of frames every now and then, but it's not a big deal.  I'm sure I can improve the performance by removing all useless processes running in the background.    This series is very popular - and stores constantly run out of stock.  Amazon used to sell these for 299, but now it's over 300.  Do a little search online, and you can easily find a deal for 280 or less.  J&R Electronics just had these on sale the other day.    If you have any specific questions, ask in comments - I'll be sure to respond.    UPDATE 05/01/2011:  I just ordered 2GB RAM for the netbook - to save you time searching for the proper type here's the link to the compatible one:  [[ASIN:B001KB6Z2U Crucial CT25664BC1067 2GB 204-PIN PC3-8500 SODIMM DDR3 Memory Module]]  Visual Studio 2010 express runs fine on the netbook.    I did notice a bit of stutter playing Netflix.  It would mostly happen when the netbook was unplugged.  After going through settings I realized when the netbook is unplugged it tries to save battery life by throttling cpu and display performance.  You can adjust those settings inside Power Management options.  If you see a performance problem, that disappears when you plug the laptop in - chances are you can fix it there.

I have been searching for the perfect stylus and notes app since I purchased the very first iPad. The thing that you need to consider if you are looking for the same is that you really need to find the proper synergy between BOTH stylus and App. Especially when you are considering these active stylii that pair with the app, you need the app to support the sdk provided by the stylii manufacturer.

Last year I settled on this Jot Script and the Goodnotes app. I primarily value a pairing that allows me to use it like a journal, and this pair works brilliantly. Initially the offset and lag of the Script did not allow for writing full screen with any precision, but over time both the SDK and the app have developed and now it works passably for full-screen note-taking, especially with the latest iOS update which supports the best palm rejection I have yet seen. Using the zoom box for writing is my preferred mode (even when I have a precise stylus - I actually think this is an improvement of pen and paper) and the Script works great for this. I have found that the currently best solution is to either pair the stylus with Goodnotes and use the Goodnotes Palm Rejection (which makes for more precision at the tip) or to just not pair the stylus at all (which I find has good enough precision and a bit less lag).

This is still not a perfect device, but overall it is the best of the many options I have tried. I have had excellent luck using Sanyo Eneloop rechargeable batteries which is far cheaper than the provided lithium option, and still lasts for many weeks of daily use.
output: Among the best of the currently available options

(REVISED review, originally 5, now 4 stars)  I've been using the Lenovo on the go almost daily for 3 years, connected to a 15" MacBook Pro. I work with Adobe design programs, so I dump all but a few of the panels onto the Lenovo (see pic), leaving a large, uncluttered design space on the laptop (I configure custom 'workspaces' inside Adobe).  (NOTE: if using a Mac, you need to download the Lenovo driver from displaylink.com.)  For the most part I've been loving it, it's been a godsend. Text and images are crisp. The anti-glare screen is a big plus. I would not use it as a main graphics screen, however. At maximum brightness the screen is noticeably dimmer than the maximum brightness of the MacBook Pro's screen, not a big drawback for my purposes, but it makes for dull colors, and there is a yellowish tint, impossible to correct. There are no color settings. When I bought it I paid a total of $165, not sure I would pay the $300 it's listed for now.  People commented on having trouble with the cover, I don't know why. If you grab one corner and pull up, it's easily removed. The newer ones slide on.  THE REASON FOR DROPPING ONE STAR After 2 years, the monitor suddenly wouldn't power on. I contacted Lenovo directly. GREAT customer service. I was told it actually had a 3-year warranty—almost unheard of, RIGHT? They promptly replaced it (although with a factory refurbished one). BUT THEN, the same thing happened to the 2nd one after less than a year. I contacted Lenovo again, and again they replaced it, to their credit, although this time it was more difficult, since it turned out that the serial number of the refurbished one wasn't in their system. After 2 HOURS on the phone and my having to send them a pic of the serial number, it got straightened out.  Don't know if I'm correct, but I've concluded that THE PROBLEM LIES WITH THE USB CORD'S BEING LOOSE where it connects to the monitor. My guess is it eventually tore wires inside the Lenovo. So, I decided to affix the cord semi-permanently but securely with a glob of silicone (I didn't want to use anything more liquidy that might seep into the connection). It's not pretty (see pic), but I don't care. Hopefully the monitor will now last for years.
output: Great portable 2nd monitor; BUT beware of loose USB cord connection

As expected.

The wired and 2.4 Gig wireless connection worked. The 5G radio was DOA, dead on arrival.
Spent 2 hours on a call with the help desk trying to get 5G wireless working. They had me repeat the same things I already tried before the call (like reset to default, reload firmware, power-off/on). They finally told me to send it back.
Return was easy but I'll try another brand.

First - the refurb seems to be pretty good. It works just fine, and no noticeable scratches or dings. A+ on that.
Now to the company, etc - I received it quickly with everything I needed to fire it up immediately. A+ there too.
To the product - It's a little small for the eyes of an old(er) man, but I can zoom quickly, so I can live with it. The same thing that makes it a little rough on the eyes makes it a dream to carry/lift. It's sitting next to my 15.6" Acer. It feels like it weighs less than half that. Pretty sweet. The battery has never been an issue for me either. The instant startup is awesome, I must say. They say it takes 7 seconds. It's never taken more than 4. Compare that to my Acer at 30 seconds plus, and then I have to wait for it to find the wifi - I find myself picking up the chromebook more and more. Storage can be interesting. Photos still go on my "real" computer as that has the space. I'm not paying extra for cloud storage, so that's what I'll have to do for now. Also, I'm not a big gamer anymore so I'll be okay without the latest edition of "Knights of the Old Republiic". The audio is about what you'd expect. Meh. Bluetooth works like a charm though. Finally, the keyboard layout is a little... compressed. Again, you get used to it.
And finally the software - It's my first time using Chrome OS and was pretty intuitive and speedy, especially if you're used to other OS's AND have a google account. I've had no problems at all with speed on Netflix, youtube, etc, and it works great with my Chromecast. One weird thing is that even setting the mouse at full speed, it moves slower than on my Windows computer. You get used to it, but I could see it bugging someone who was playing a speed-click game. Google works just fine for docs, spreadsheets, etc. So it would be good for schoolwork too.

I'm sure I've forgotten a few things, but you get the idea.
Is it perfect for me? It's pretty darn good, but not quite. A 14" would be great, both for screen size and keyboard spacing. But the bigger ones jump like mad in price, so, no thanks, not yet. Am I glad I bought it? Definitely. Would I recommend it to others? Definitely so, but only after they read this and a few other reviews to be sure its limitations won't be too much of a pain, or at least don't outweigh the benefits. It's not for everyone, but it would be plenty for many. It's a great backup (almost first) computer. It would make a great schoolwork computer for kids and even college students. And it's the perfect little travel computer as well.
output: Not quite perfect, but pretty stinkin' good

Instances.input: I bought this last month and have used it in my camera and my ASUS EEE PC. It works much faster than my 1 GB SD card and I am very happy with it.

Seems like a good deal. Had a little trouble getting this working at the beginning, which admittedly may have been due to my lack of familiarity with the Raspberry Pi. HDMI out to a TV doesn't work with the boot SD card provided, which lead me to use the RCA video out connection, or an HDMI to DVI adapter (which I had laying around, not included in package), which seemed to work fine. The power supply included with the package is garbage, and doesn't actually provide enough power to boot the Pi (It will give you an error message until you switch to a decent adapter or plug it into another PC for USB power.)

The clear case looks nice, but is a little too tight. I felt like I was going to break the tiny Pi trying to pry the case open enough to slot it in properly.

The little breakout board could be better replaced by the T-Cobbler from adafruit which has the pins set up in such a way that their labels don't get covered by the wide grey cable. Better for prototyping and learning IMHO.

Hopefully this info helps the seller improve, or gives others proper warning of what they are in for.
output: Decent package, but beware the power supply.

Instances.input: This laptop is a great laptop to get.  I picked this up several years ago when it had just come out and the thing works like a charm.  In my opinion this laptop blows my newer Inspiron 1318 out of the water.    First off the computer is super light, you can stick it in your bag and take it wherever you want while not giving yourself major back pains.  Secondly the performance on this machine is awesome and it is very powerful.  I am able to run newer games such as Doom 3, Quake 4 and Resident Evil 4 on here without any problems or lockups.  Conversely my newer Inspiron 1318 which is supposed to be upgraded and more modern wont play ANY of these games.  This laptop is super fast, it is great for general use, school work, buisness and gaming.  Not only do I use it for gaming, I use it for research and projects for my graduate classes as well as for running my buisness.      I only have 2 minor complaints about this computer.  The first is that the glossy screen does not work so well outside and the outdoor glare is a killer, but that is easily avoided by replacing the screen for a matte version.  Secondly the wireless card is not exactly the fastest at long range, but this can be easily avoided by getting a wireless expander or an addition pcie wireless card such as the one I use by NetGear.  This is a great windows XP computer, soon I am going to try to upgrade it to Windows 7, and if that works correctly than it is a wrap, i'll get a second one!!    Just a warning, dont drop the computer too many times, since it is smaller, the screen is quite a bit more deliciate than most laptop screens, although the laptop is built like a tank, and god knows mine has taken a beating, the screen is a little delicate.  I dropped mine a cracked the LCD screen, but replacement parts for it are easy to find and the screen is super easy to install.  Secondly, you dont want to drop it too much becuase this model was one of the ones with the exploding batteries.  While mine did no such thing, there were stories of it happening but Dell has since replaced the batteries and offered all owners new batteries, so this should not be an issue, it is just a quick heads up.  (the battery only exploded if it was dropped and it fell on the battery).      This had to be the best laptop I ever bought.  I got this when it was very expensive, and to see it on here for cheap is like a dream come true.  I have had mine going on almost 10 years now, and it is still kicking and has not stopped working!  When mine finally does decide to die, I am going to pick up another used one from here, that is how much I love this laptop.  Forget the new stuff, this one is great and a real workhorse! I got this device because we have a glut of old 3.5" floppy diskettes and modern computers don't come equipped with the drives to read them anymore. So as a device for backup and transfer it seems to get the job done. Sadly a lot of the old disks were unreadable or had partly corrupted files, but I recall that back in the day a lot of the disks were pretty flimsy, especially if you bought them cheap. As such, sometimes it takes awhile to read them, but generally speaking, this no-frills device does what it claims to, which is allow you to read old disks on a modern system through USB, so you can copy them to a longer-lasting medium (or even transfer them to a brand new disk if you wanted to use them on an old legacy computer).
output: Let's you read 3.5" floppies on a modern computer, great for backup purposes

Instances.input:
It will take you DAYS to fill this drive. LITERALLY! Because it's so big? No. It's just that slow.

Blackmagic Disc Speed test clocks the write speed at about 4MB/s. Read speed is better at 22MB/s. By comparison my hard drive writes at 170MB/s and reads at 200MB/s. Apples to oranges yes, but at 4MB/s you should be able to fill it in a couple hours, in reality it took 7 hours to copy 8GB.

It's small and SanDisk stuff is usually pretty reliable, so if you like small and you aren't in a hurry, go for it.

If you can deal with a normal sized thumb drive you are better off going with the SanDisk Extreme where you should see 22-27MB/s. If you are lucky enough to be in a USB 3.0/money-no-object situation you might try something like the Lexar JumpDrive Triton. It has write speeds around 106MB/s and reads around 169MB/s
output: Great to look at. Not so great to use.

I've tried all sorts of styli for my iPad ... not for navigating around but for writing and drawing. The Nataal was inexpensive, just bought because I needed something quickly for writing. I didn't know what to expect, but certainly nothing I could draw with. It's not as heavy or solid as the Wacom Bamboo, but that's not necessarily a bad thing ... and it doesn't feel cheap or fragile at all. It's a decent length, so easy for me to hold onto. The tip narrows just enough that by the time it's touching the screen I can see what I'm doing around it (not like using a big fat crayon); and it's long enough that I can hold the stylus at a natural angle for writing without worrying about the metal bits of the stylus touching the screen. Drag on the screen is a bit more than, say, the Kuel or AluPen -- nothing excessive, though. The tip is very sensitive, moreso than the Bamboo or my trusty old BoxWave stylus (which I lost), so I don't have to press too hard to register a click or stroke. It's an excellent writing tool, and a completely acceptable drawing tool. The audio jack plug for hanging the stylus on the iPad is quite handy.

I bought this cooler so that it would fit in my NZXT M59 case. I checked the dimensions before I bought, so I knew it would fit. There was about an inch left before the cooler would make contact with the side panel of the case. Before I was using the stock cooler and ran Prime 95 on my i7 930 with no overclocking and all stock BIOS settings. At 100% load, Prime 95 gave me 93 degrees C (using Realtemp). Yikes! I stopped the program so that it won't fry my i7 930. After installing the Hyper N520 and running Prime 95, the temperature was at around 70 degrees C with no overclocking. Then overclocked to 3.5 GHz with a max CPU core temperature around 76 degrees C. I'm quite surprised. An overall 20 degrees drop in temperature. Cool is good.    The fans are quite quiet even running at 100%. I had it set for manual to run at 100% no matter what.     One drawback is that you would need to take the motherboard out and install it on the outside. It is quite possible to install it without the motherboard taken out. You would need a clamp or an extra pair of hands to hold the cooler in place while another person turns the nuts on the backside of the motherboard. I do agree the instructions are horrible. But if you know what you are doing then you probably won't need it. The diagram for the direction of the air flow is wrong on the illustration. You would need to look at the fans to figure out the directions.     A good cooler for a decent price. There are probably better coolers out there but are larger and more expensive. If value is what you want, then this cooler would work for you.     As a side note, I used Arctic Silver 5 instead of the included thermal paste.
Got the item a few days after order, quick delivery. Product complies with the description of ads and works well. I am happy with the service.

The Aukey 4-Port USB 3.0 Aluminum Desktop Hub is an attractive design which positions the 4 ports on a slant where it's easier to insert the plugs for your devices. The ports are positioned so that even wider drives will not encroach on the space of the other devices plugged into the hub.

The Aluminum hub comes with a 3 ft. USB 3.0 cable with standard type A sized plugs at each end. The plugs have the blue interior that designate them as USB 3.0. The cable can be plugged into a USB 2.0 port but will only function at the USB 2.0 speed. When connected to a USB 3.0 port, the M3H4 hub provides data speeds up to 5 Gbps.

The M3H4 measures 3.75"L x 2.75"W x 1.25"H. The front edge slants downward to sit on the desktop. This makes it really easy to insert the plug or flash drive in the correct position. A small blue LED light indicates power and activity functions. The 3 ft. USB 3.0 cable connects to the left end of the hub and is long enough to reach around to the back of your desktop computer to attach to a USB 3.0 port.
This hub is compatible with any Windows (XP, Vista, 7,8) PC, Mac, or Linux Desktop or Laptop computer with the latest software updates installed and it's backwards compatibility with USB 2.0 / 1.1. The hub supports hot swapping and plug & play with no additional drivers needed.
It also Incorporates a built-in surge protector to safeguard your USB devices. This key hub is an exceptional product at a great price.
Performance is fast and consistent even with a mobile hard drive attached.
output: Aukey M3H4 4-Port USB 3.0 Aluminum Desktop Hub

This is a great product. I gave it 4 stars because the squeegie is not the best. It is really rough and will scratch the shield. I used a nail buffer to smooth it off and it still left small scratches in the protector. I was concerned about using a wet protector, but it worked out really well. I got a small hair in it and was able to lift it up, spray the hair, remove it, and get it back down. It did have small bubbles and lines (from where I lifted it), but they were completely gone in the 24 hours that it sat. Use caution around the speakers and try not to get too much moisture in them. I got some in them, but they are fine. Since they cover the majority of the sides, you might want to put some painters tape on them before applying the protector so you can squeegie the fluid over the tape. Remove the tape immediately after application though so any moisture can dry.

You need to do the wet application to get everything exact. Once you have gone wet, you will never go back. Do you make one for the Samsung Galaxy S3?

The late 2010 Mac Pro (5,1) is a fantastic computer with one of the worst Bluetooth antennae ever created. Unless your magic mouse is 6" away from the box, good luck to you.

But add one of these puppies to the closer USB port on the back of your cinema display (or anywhere else), and suddenly the mouse tracks like a champ! I wouldn't be surprised if I end up getting longer battery life out of the mouse either since it probably has to broadcast with less power now (if that's even possible -- I don't know enough about Bluetooth).

Summary: cheap, NO DRIVERS TO INSTALL, works immediately, easy.

Note: there is a newer version of this product: GBU521. I have heard it doesn't play so well with Macs, so I got this older GBU421. No complaints. If you're just trying to fix the problem of poor Bluetooth reception for your mouse, don't risk the newer one. Just get the GBU421 and be happy.

Instances.input:
Whatever eReader you decide on, consider there are two minimum qualifications: a large catalog and eInk. The first is obvious. Why buy an eReader without easy access to any book that you can pick up at a large book retailer? The second must not be discounted. If you purchase an eReader with a backlight, your eyes will tire after a chapter or two and I fear will have hazardous effects for heavy readers.

The reason I give the Kindle 5 stars is that it is one of two eReaders (including eReader software) that meets this criterion. Naysayers will rightly so complain about wiz-bang design issues in the Kindle. But, unless a device meets these two qualifications, it is not an eReader.

This speaker system is not more than a good, not excellent, speaker system for a desktop computer.  Its small woofer is easy to hide behind your computer screen and the left-right units are compact and good looking.  The sound is best at low to mid volume with a low base setting, and that sound is acceptable in quality in virtually all ranges.  Music sounds fine.  But do not expect any \\"home theater\\" qualities out of them.  Do not expect the sound to fill a room.  I still get better quality with a good set of headphones.  Nevertheless, at the truly bargain price, I'd buy this system again for this limited, specific need.  They do the job.  I especially like the separate on-off control switch that I can access easily behind my monitor screen.

Do not buy,  bought this for my in-laws in Florida.  Installed worked fine for 2 months. Stopped working. Returned, second one stopped working after 3 months.  All lights on but would not talk to modem.  Obviously the quality of Netgear's  Chinese factory is lacking.  I'll stick to Linksys from now on.

I have had this case for close to a month at the time of this writing.  I have gone on SEVERAL flights and a cruise to the Western Caribbean, and Central America.  I LOVE this case.  It's ability to become two separate cases has made this all too convenient.  I travel with two gripped Canon bodies, at least 5 lenses (One being a 70-200L), flashes and light modifiers, batteries and chargers, filters, manuals, my laptop and it's charger, along with various other accompaniments.  I even, remove the internal camera compartment, and place my shooter's vest in flat, and easily replace the compartment.  This case is tough and very well built.  It makes organizing your equipment extremely easy.  What I really appreciate is that even though I've carried all I described, I still have room for more.    As you may be able to guess, with all I have to carry, this can get to be quite heavy.  The rolling wheels make this a dream.  I simply extend the handle and zip right along through airports with no problems.  Removing the computer compartment and re-attaching it is fairly easy.  Meaning, it's not exactly a one handed job, but it's not difficult and time consuming.  It makes storing the pieces very easy. Instances.input:
I had a Sony eReader for 5 years until I sat on it recently and managed to ruin the display. I read a lot of reviews and everyone more or less seemed to agree that Kindle PaperWhite is the best eReader out there (for its money), and since I spend A LOT of time reading daily, I decided to buy one to replace my old device. Well, I own one for only 3 days, but I'm currently regretting my choice and this is why:

Kindle PW is indeed the best (probably) eReader out there in those three cases:
-You are a new reader or own only a few ebooks already
-You already own a ton of books bought from Amazon
-or you're simply not a fanatic reader (=spending more than an hour daily to read)

In my case where after 5 years of owning a Sony eReader I've managed to collect over 800 ebooks -obviously not from Amazon's site since it doesn't support the ePUB fromat that this reader featured- the Kindle is more or less a bad choice for me. My main problems are:
-I used Calibre to organize my books in collections because with 800+ books, you have to keep them separated by themes/groups else you can't find anything. Unfortunately, the Collections from Calibre do not apply in the Kindle; I have to manually make new Collections on my Kindle and -also manually- add the books in them from the kindle. For so many books, this is simply not practical nor is the choice of emailing 800+ books to my device so they get added to the cloud and then to my device. Not to mention I'm not a fan of cloud saving options; as a software programmer, I'm a bit sceptical that this is a perfectly good way for someone to keep tabs on you and I'd hate that.
-The kindle keeps your reading location ONLY for the last book read. In my case where I usually read more than 2-3 books at a given time, the kindle only keeps the location of the last book opened. I guess this wouldn't be a problem if I had the WiFi turned on all the time and the books were synchronized by WhisperSync. Unfortunately, I live in Greece and as strange as it may sound to some people, WiFi is NOT always available here so this is not an option for me. Weirdly enough, the Sony eReader which was 5 years old, managed to do that without the need for a WiFi.
-Also, because I read more than one book at a time, I have a problem with the "Recent" sorting. When I add new books to my reader, only the last book I opened stays on the home screen as recent; the other couple of books I was also reading along, get pushed behind the last added books and I have to search for them again. Well, Sony solved this 'problem' simply by having two different sorting options: Last Added and Last Read which worked -again- much better than the kindle.
-Ok, I'm used to the Sony after 5 years, but I can't help noticing that there is just no option of adjusting the weight of the fonts on the kindle, as opposed to the Sony (and the Kobo as far as I know). This can be annoying, since the new "Bookerly" font, while otherwise great, needs a bit more weight for my taste, but since I can't change that, I'm stuck with Caecilia.
-The PDFs display badly as opposed to the Sony. I can only zoom in but cannot increase/decrease the font size which for documents (=text, not drawings) just doesn't work.

When you have opened a book, the screen is very good, the lighting works perfectly and the touch response is excellent; no complaints about the reading experience so far. But, if you like me have an extensive collection of ebooks bought outside Amazon, I would not recommend this eReader. In fact, I'm already saving money to buy myself a Kobo.as it may sound to some people, WiFi is NOT always available here so this is not an option for me. Weirdly enough, the Sony eReader which was 5 years old, managed to do that without the need for a WiFi. -Also, because I read more than one book at a time, I have a problem with the "Recent" sorting. When I add new books to my reader, only the last book I opened stays on the home screen as recent; the other couple of books I was also reading along, get pushed behind the last added books and I have to search for them again. Well, Sony solved this 'problem' simply by having two different sorting options: Last Added and Last Read which worked -again- much better than the kindle. -Ok, I'm used to the Sony after 5 years, but I can't help noticing that there is just no option of adjusting the weight of the fonts on the kindle, as opposed to the Sony (and the Kobo as far as I know). This can be annoying, since the new "Bookerly" font, while otherwise great, needs a bit more weight for my taste, but since I can't change that, I'm stuck with Caecilia. -The PDFs display badly as opposed to the Sony. I can only zoom in but cannot increase/decrease the font size which for documents (=text, not drawings) just doesn't work. When you have opened a book, the screen is very good, the lighting works perfectly and the touch response is excellent; no complaints about the reading experience so far. But, if you like me have an extensive collection of ebooks bought outside Amazon, I would not recommend this eReader. In fact, I'm already saving money to buy myself a Kobo.
output: A very good eReader IF you don't already own way too many ePUB books and do have WiFi available everywhere

I use this in my living room on a computer that is connected to my big screen TV. It suites my needs well. It's a compact version of a full-sized keyboard. I like it because my six year old is able to use it without difficulty and is also learning the standard layout of a QWERTY keyboard without even knowing it. The touchpad is very sensitive to tapping. However I'm getting used to it, and so is my kid. We're both able to easily surf the Internet sitting approximately 8 feet from the computer without any issues. There's no numeric keypad and all of the reviews commenting the lack of a right shift key are noted. Everybody in my family is right handed and none of us use the right shift key, so it's not a problem for us. I wonder if the location of this key is more problematic for left-handed people. You can tell just by looking at the picture of the product that It is designed for a right-handed person. Anyhow, I have no regrets with this purchase. It's large enough that it doesn't get lost like all of the other 5 remotes that I have for my TV's. It feels solid yet light. I would not hesitate to recommend this to a friend that is looking for a wireless keyboard solution for their living room TV.

Instances.input: I had originally used the Thrustmaster Ferrari GT Experience 3-1 wheel for games like Need for Speed (various titles under this) and then iRacing.com.  After purchasing iRacing.com's product, I found that such a wheel was not up to the standards of the simulated race experience.  So, I saved up and purchased the Logitech G27 Racing Wheel.  Let me tell you this, the difference is AMAZING!  There are tons of great things I can say about this, but I will spare you that for now and get straight to what you will want to know - the cons.      Logitech does not con you with this product, but there are a few pitfalls.  Straight away, you will have to 4 chords to manage.  They could have put it all into 2, but they gave us 4.  But once you work out a system, or get one of those nice wire management foam/plastic shells you're good.  The other pitfall is that you might want to work out your arms and shoulders some before getting this!  It only can put out a max of 3NM of torque, but trust me those 3NM of torque will tire you out quick if you're not used to such harsh reality.  In real life driving wheels can be subject up to and beyond 10NM of torque!  (that's more than enough to break fingers and possibly arms, if not injure you!), but you're safe with this product from any injury as long as you keep ergonomics in mind.  Also, at first, with such torque at the wheel you will want to make sure to take frequent breaks.  You won't believe how fast this wheel (when set to realistic specs of 102% overall effect in the window's control interface, and the default of 16FFB in iRacing.com's settings if you're getting it for that) can tire you out!    *****BUT*****      Here's the great things about this product from logitech!      This wheel is the closest you're going to get to the real thing for under 300 bucks!  Amazon provides a great discount here.      Once this is set up, you can set it and forget it (for a while, EVERY wheel needs recalibration here and there, even the best).    It's the most solid build you'll find.  It's even quieter with helical cut gears!      You get 3!  YES 3! Pedals.  Clutch!, break and throttle.  Does it get better than this in simulated racing?  I mean it's pedals are covered in REAL STEEL!  The wheel's frame seems to be steel too!  The pedals' base even comes with 3 ways to keep it from moving, hard mounting (screwing into place on say something like a Playseat, can I advertise for them enough?), rubber feet for hardwood floors, and even spikes at the back than can be pulled down to keep it from moving AT ALL on carpet!  (And such great design there!  It won't move, nor damage your carpet/rug!)  Can I say enough about these pedals?  I think not!        It's accessability is rated 4 just for the amount of chords and the time you'll have to take to set it up in windows and in your various games/sims (which shouldn't take THAT long ;) ).      It's comfort is second to none!  It's genuine leather they wrapped it in!  (though, it has a lot of torque, you get used to it once it's set to you're preference and you give it time)      Speed of this wheel is incredible... it can't be turned faster than real life would allow, unless you turn down/off the forced feedback (FFB).  With FFB turned off, it's like driving a Cadillac, or so I've heard.       You can't get much more real, nor can you get much of a better feel than this... real steering wheels are bigger, but you don't need it really.      It's immersion is second only to the real thing.      Ergonomics... GREAT!, IF AND ONLY IF you keep in mind where you are supposed to keep your hands and take frequent breaks!  Otherwise you could injure yourself.  This is professional level simulation here.  But if you keep correct positions and breaks in mind, this wheel will not injure you.  It's like anything else out there.      Cable management could have been better, but they do give you some stuff to help out with the 4 chords they give you.  4 groves to places them inso they don't get pinched and before that a place to wrap excess cable around.      Overall, this is the best product you can get for your money (unless that elusive G29 ever comes out, ROFLMAO).  There are more expensive products out there, but you will pay much more for them!  You can spend hundreds of thousands of dollars for a real simulator, tens of thousands on the lesser equivalent that doesn't move but will give you feedback in the pants in the form of knocks and vibrations and good sound/visuals, 500 USD or more for over-the-top reproductions of this wheel, or you can get the original!  The logitech G27 Racing Wheel for the pc is THE BEST  wheel you will ever get, without paying too much.  Some would say 250 USD is too much, but trust me.  You get everything you pay for, and THEN SOME!      **Oh, and one last thing, make sure if you're doing your sim racing on a desk (as opposed to the Playseat also available on Amazon), that the desk isn't a cheapie!  This thing will have your desk and everything on it bouncing (and possibly breaking), including that expensive HD monitor you payed a lot more for ;).  (But don't worry too much here, I haven't bolted anything down and have yet to have anything break or fall) Otherwise I'd recommend bolting down everything that's loose, or at the very least duct-taping it all down!  I'm being serious here, that wheel has a ton of force in it.  When Logitech call it \\"force feedback\\"  they mean it has FORCE!  3NM of torque, that is a TON of force for a gaming/siming race wheel!**
output: The best you can get for under 300!  There are however, some pitfalls.

Instances.input:
I'm pleased with the video output of this device. From standard cable TV input, it gives a MUCH better picture than my mid-priced 13 inch TV that is next to the computer.

Mechanically / electronically, it is pretty decent for the price. The only quibble I have in that respect is that you have to run a seperate audio line to your sound card, rather than everything going through USB (maybe this improves data flow, but it is a minor irritation for me.)

The software and drivers is where this really disappoints. Installed on two different systems, it gave lots of trouble on both:

On the laptop (Sony Vaio GRV550 2.4Ghz, 512 RAM, XP Home SP1) the drivers gave me \\"Blue Screen Of Death\\" on an otherwise absolutely stable system several times before I finally managed to get it to work. Once installed and sort of debugged, video worked fine, but audio would cut out completely after 10 to 30 seconds, no matter how you had it set. I had to to close the program and reopen to get another few seconds of sound. (I solved this problem by buying an external Soundblaster USB sound processor, which the KWORLD tuner liked a lot more than my internal Yamaha soundcard.)

I still get a \\"cannot create shell notification\\" error when Windows first starts (I think this is probably from the PVR Plus application) but after clicking \\"OK\\" everything seems to work as it should.

The newest driver downloaded from the manufacturer's site was even more buggy on the laptop than the one that came with the device. I must have gotten 7 \\"BSODs\\" before I gave up and went back to the older drivers.

On the desktop (Homebuilt, AMD 3200 running @ 2.1 Ghz on a Chaintech 7NIL1 MOBO, 1 Gig RAM, XP home SP2, completely fresh OS and program install with all the latest direct-X, encoder and Media Player 10 downloads and patches) the newer driver installed OK, and the problem with the sound cutting out from the laptop install was not encountered.

On BOTH systems, recording through the included interface (TVR) in either MPEG-1 and MPEG-2 brought several different DLL related errors when you tried to stop recording. (Have to hit Ctl-Alt-Del several times to end the program to get out. (However, that doesn't mess up your recording, so I suppose one could live with it.) MPEG-4 (with Divx codec) and AVI recording work without those DLL errors upon closing, (although AVI gives you HUGE files) I didn't try recording at the DVD, VCD or SVCD settings, so can't say if they work or not.

On BOTH systems, using the included recording interface, there was a distinct audio lag on anything recorded in any of the MPEG formats(1,2 or 4) , and the longer the recording, the farther the audio got behind, Record a 90 minute movie, and by the end, the audio track would be three minutes behind.

However, I lucked out and discovered that the free Windows Movie Maker works perfectly with the KWORLD USB2.0 Video Capture on both of my computers. No audio lag, no crashes when you stop recording, and the .wmv format gives you sharper video and much smaller file sizes than Mpeg 1 or 2. If you need MPEG format, record them through Windows Movie Maker and convert them through Win-Avi or one of the other converters. I've even recorded some broadcast TV to WMV, converted to MPEG1, and run that through Kinoma Producer to play it on a Palm.

The DVD / VCD recording program in the NERO Suite also works well with the KWORLD tuner if you have a lot of empty hard drive space to fill.

Several other people on another site have given the software and drivers a high rating, and video quality a lower rating, so my experiences in installing on two different systems with similar results and difficulties may be the exception.

(Hint: disable Spybot S&D before attempting to install, if you have it on your system. It won't make it easy, but it will help a lot).

I will start with the pros. First, I love the feel of this case. The coloring is a little more greenish than in the image (which I had read from other reviews as well, and it's true) but that doesn't bother me at all. Still a nice looking cover. Second, it's fairly easy to put on and take off. I also like the fact that the Apple logo shines through the case when the computer is on, and not visible when the computer is off or in sleep mode.

Now for the cons. As the case fits on easily, it seems the plastic wasn't cut right in certain places so it looks a little "off". I also don't like the fact that it doesn't cover the outside back part of bottom half of the computer. So the two edges in the back are exposed when the screen is closed. So I got this because of all the great rating I was reading. Here is my take on it.

Yes it does get rid of some glare, but not all. How it affects your reading depends on your other settings. I like black background with white lettering. For this setting it doesn't do much to improve my reading experience in sunlight. It's a little more effective if you have white/beige background and black lettering though.

There is something about the matte finish that is appealing to me, it just feels nice. Some screen covers reduce the sensitivity of your touch but this one doesn't seem to which is a big plus. You don't get fingerprints on it but you still get smudges unfortunately.

One big big big flaw in it that makes me want to try another one is that it gets permanent marking really easily. By that I mean like if something hits the screen, it'll create a visible \\"dent\\" on the screen. With my old screen cover I would throw my Kindle without the protective case in my bag and take it out just fine. With this one it can bump up against a textbook and create these really irritating permanent smudges.

Instances.input: I've used the original Yubikey previously on other sites and can attest to its durability. I've had my old Yubikey on my key ring for over 2 years and no issues. I expect this new one to have the same durability. As for the functionality, the Fido U2F Key works flawlessly. I always had an issue with 2 factor authentication when I used someone elses computer. I needed the Google authenticator, or cell phone to get my google codes - now all I do is plug in the Security key. I did have an issue registering it with Google, but that was my fault. It does state you need Chrome version 38. I was using my Asus Chromebox which only has version 36 so every time I tried and register my key, it would time out. I then used my desktop computer which is running Chrome version 38 and everything went perfectly. You do have the option to use the Google Authenticator , codes or cell phone if your device does not have a thumb drive or you don't have your Security Key with you . - One real safeguard is that if you happened to land on a fake Google site through Phishing, the security key will NOI allow your codes to be transmitted -it knows if you are trying to log into a fake site. I'm really looking forward to other sites allowing its use - excellent product

I've had an Acer laptop for a couple of years now and the built in system recovery feature has saved me tons on repairs.  I just partitioned my hard drive into two halves (C & D drives) and keep all my stuff saved on the D drive.  Whenever it gets slow or the browser starts crashing: I suspect a trojan virus after years in tech support. So I just run the built in recovery program and it sets the whole system back to brand new automatically.  All of my own files are still there safe and sound on the D drive.       You can find instructions on how to set up a partition on Google.  It's like 3 steps.  Running the recovery is also easy.  I've done the same thing for a friend who has an Acer desktop.      Acer computers are really just clean and solid: with a lot less trial-programs to plug up the system.  I simply remove the included antivirus program and anything else I don't plan to buy using a program called Revo Uninstaller, and then I install a free Antivirus program called Avast: I find it to be much more reliable and faster than the famous programs.      In my opinion, Acers are far easier to repair than Dells or Gateways.    P.S. Don't bother getting the extended protection scam from the \\"Geeks.\\"
output: Best for the Money Hands Down!

Instances.input: Not much more to say what the first reviewer hasnt already mentioned.  I used a Macbook Pro until now (which had - after < 2 years of use - enough bugs for 3 laptops - fan out of control, cd/dvd drive broken, etc.), and I dont regret switching to the W520 (I own a W520 for a month now). I am doing a lot of Matlab image processing on my laptop, and the performance as well as screen resolution / quality is great (upon purchase, Lenovo lets you choose between 3 different screens with different maximum resolutions - i chose the highest resolution - 1920 X 1080; also they let you choose between 2 different gpus). One unique thing to mention is that you have full control over which graphics processor (integrated vs. Nvidia gpu) your laptop uses when, and for which application separately - i think this is kind of new and unique.  The only thing that bothered me initially was Lenovo's trackpad, which doesnt come close to the comfort of my Macbook pad. Normal cursor control is ok, but e.g. two-finger scrolling is almost impossible. After my initial disappointment,  I got really hooked to using the red lenovo track point. It takes one to two days to get used to it, but once you have the hang of it, it's much more convenient for cursor control, scrolling (instead of 2 - finger scrolling, one uses the middle button above the trackpad), etc. than the track pad. So - no complaints there. And if you want to do e.g. technical drawing, you may want to use a mouse in any case...  One thing more that took me a bit of patience to figure out was the fact that - by default - the operating system shuts down and 'unmounts' the physical cd drive when not in use. This is a good feature as it helps saving energy. However, it interferes with the installation and usage of virtual drives (e.g. Daemon tools). Anyway, I figured out that you can easily disable this CD drive - auto-shutdown option. So - if you have the money - stop looking. This is your machine.

I've been looking for a similar product like this for a while. As anyone who owns Mac laptops knows, they can get pretty hot. I've always worried about frying the processor and was excited to see this cooling pad. It comes in a clean, sleek white box that is easy to open. The cooling pad has a USB cord to attach to your laptop and works essentially as a plug and play. It's incredibly easy to use and foolproof. There are instructions but it's very obvious. There are some requirements as far as OS but I don't really see why.

The cooling pad does expand and supposedly it's meant to fit every type/size of macbook. I own a 17 inch Macbook Pro and my laptop was MUCH bigger than this cooling pad. The macbook extended over the sides of the cooling pad in every direction and there was no real stability keeping the macbook on the cooling pad. There are 2 rubber stoppers that are meant to keep the laptop attached (I think) but my laptop slide over these constantly. So it was difficult to accurately use the cooling fan since the laptop wouldn't sit on top unless it was on the table or on my lap.

The fans are rather weak and didn't actually give any great air flow/cooling to the laptop when the cooling fans were sitting on the table (for stability) or on my lap. The laptop didn't seem to cool much when the pad was plugged in and on. I did notice that when using the cooling pad that the battery life of the laptop dropped substantially so it was only really viable to use if/when the laptop is plugged into a charger.

Additionally the entire unit is very lightweight and feels flimsy. I'd be worried about easy breakage if traveling with the unit.

Overall since the cooling pad doesn't fit my 17 inch macbook nor does it really cool it noticeably - in combination with the other concerns such as flimsy material and battery draining power - the pad ultimately isn't really useable. I unfortunately wouldn't recommend it.

I dislike mice as input devices, so whenever possible I've used a trackball. My favourite for years was the Logitech Marble Mouse. It was much more precise (you use your fingers instead of your arm/wrist), it doesn't accidentally jigger the cursor when you let go of it, it doesn't run out or real estate (even on your knee), it doesn't need a special mouse pad, etc. The only thing I missed was a scroll wheel (I don't like thumb-based trackballs).

Last year I bought a MacBook Pro and it had a trackpad like all laptops nowadays. I usually give new trackpads a try for a couple of days before I get disappointed and run back screaming to my trusty trackball. I must have used close to two dozen trackpads over the years and all were lacking or unusable, but this one, wow, this one was something else!

When I saw that you can get an external trackpad that is even larger than the built-in MBP trackpad, I was so there!

The Magic Trackpad is basically like an iPad touch surface for your computer. It has all the trackball advantages I listed above, plus many things you can't do with either a trackball or a mouse. For instance:
- try rolling instead of swiping your finger for even more precision
- you can scroll freely in all directions, not just vertically and in notched steps like a scroll wheel
- it has gestures that are actually helpful!

Using this trackpad has increased my productivity. Some of that is probably part of OS X. For instance, I haven't used scrollbars since I started using a Mac. I also like to use multiple desktops, so changing between them with a simple gesture is just awesome.

If you are not happy with your mousing performance, or are ready to step up your game from a trackball, get the Magic Trackpad and be happier!

I wanted a laptop cooling pad in part because my Acer netbook's cooling vents are somewhat blocked when using it on my lap, in part because I wanted something a little larger to stabilize the netbook, which is far smaller than the average laptop.

After two unsuccessful experiences with a thin, inexpensive laptop cooler, I decided to give the more expensive Belkin a try. My first cooler (a very generic Chinese design with two fans) was very quiet, but flimsy; both fans died within the first 30 minutes of operation. I exchanged it for another of similar design; it was noisier, but still too flimsy for in-lap used, so I gave it to my daughter, whose laptop is generally used on a desk.

The Belkin is much more substantial and, I like the fact that its single fan is in the middle, where it sucks air between my slightly parted legs. At first, I was not enamored of the curved design (which will not sit stably on a flat surface), But I realized that it promotes very good airflow under the computer, directed straight at the hottest part of the Acer's underside, an area without vents. With the cooling pad, the underside of the Acer is actually cool to the touch -- a very effective job of cooling. Extending the folding support tilts the pad and computer to an angle that makes laptop typing more comfortable. I also appreciate the fact that edge of the pad closest to my body is somewhat padded, providing a bit of a wrist wrest.

Too soon to comment on reliability, but the Belkin pad is much more substantial than other designs that I have seen, which sacrifice stiffness for a thin profile. With a quieter fan, I would have given the Belkin 4, perhaps 5 stars. The fan isn't excessively noisy, and is inaudible when used outdoors, or with background music, but it's far from silent, and is quite noticeable in a quiet environment.
As 3 stars suggests, it was OK...

When the product arrived, I saw that the System Requirements on the box state \\"Windows 7 (32 bit).\\"  Online tech support has just confirmed that the iConnect does not work with Win 7 64 bit.  In case you are unaware, Win 7 32 bit is limited to 3 gigs of RAM. We just bought an inexpensive laptop with 64 bit & 4 gigs for just over $500.  I belive Iomega needs to be more precise with their spec sheets.

When I contacted the seller, they got right back to me the same day with a link to the Apple website. Unfortunately for me, that one was for troubleshooting. I contacted my MAC guru, and he gave me this link: [...] and told me to look for the \\"big button that says MANUALS\\" - hint: it doesn't stand out on the page, I had to kind of hunt before I saw it. I still had a little trouble, because it was not a new installation, so the setup assistant didn't pop up. I opened \\"system applications\\" then \\"Mouse\\" and at the bottom of that dialog box there is a blue button for Bluetooth set up and that worked. The mouse is much more responsive than my old wired one, so here's hoping it's the end of the problems. I would definitely buy from the seller again in the future.

I just bought my first Kindle 6/29/2011 and have not even received it yet and just purchased the extended warranty 6/30/2011. The 2-year Extended Warranty is just that, a 2-year warranty. Why do I say that when the unit has a 1-year warranty on it? Some think that it should total 3 years but that is wrong. The warranty for the unit says this..\\"This limited warranty applies only to hardware components of the Device that are not subject to accident, misuse, neglect, fire or other external causes, alterations, repair, or commercial use\\". It doesn't cover any accident damage. So if you drop the unit and it cracks the glass then that would not be covered under warranty even if you have used the unit one day. Taking it out of the box if you break it then it would not be covered. But with the Extended Warranty if you drop it or spill coffee on it and fry the unit then it will be replaced for free. So bottom lines is this, the extended warranty is a good idea. They should not of used the word \\"Extended\\" and just said 2-year warranty or insurance.

Look at it this way, you have a new car warranty that come with the purchase of a new car but if you don't have full coverage insurance and if you are in an accident the new car warranty will not replace or repair your car. The 2-year extended warranty for the Kindle is the full coverage insurance for it.

Hopefully I will not need to use the warranty, but for 2 years if my wife throws it at me and it breaks then I can get it replaced using the warranty for free. Hey, it could happen.

This product had great reviews on Amazon, and its promised features at a low price warranted those reviews.  But the actual product I received did not live up to expectations, perhaps because the product works great in some computer configurations but not others.      Specifically, the product packaging said the product was compatible with Windows 7.  But I found out that wasn't the case.  The product comes with a disk with many drivers on it, including drivers for 32 and 64 bit versions of Vista.  But there were no drivers for Windows 7.  I also checked the company's website.  While it had all the drivers on the disk shipped with the product, it also did not have Windows 7 drivers.  I tried installing the relevant Vista drivers on two machines 1) a 64 bit desktop running Window 7 Home Premium (with the drivers on the disk), and 2) a 32 bit ultraportable (a type of Netbook with more memory and a faster processor than a typical Netbook) running Windows 7 Home Premium (with the drivers downloaded from Diamond's website).  In both cases, my installer said the drivers were incompatible with the Windows 7 Home Premium operating system.    I figured that I might well be overlooking something.  After all, many Vista drivers are compatible with the Windows 7 Home Premium operating system.  Moreover, one of the Amazon reviewers for this product stated, incidentally to his review, that the product worked fine on his Windows 7 computer.  I remain open to the possibility that the version of the product I got is compatible with Windows 7 in at least one configuration.    Based on such a theory, I went to Diamond's website and found its support section.   As is often the case, there was no telephone number to call for tech support.  No problem, I'm used to that.  I saw no articles in the knowledgebase on Windows 7 compatibility for this particular product, so this left me with two options: submit a ticket (via a web form) or chat with an online representative.  All this looked very professional, and I was suitably impressed.  I started by submitting a ticket.  Before I would be done about two weeks later, I would have submitted four of them--none receiving any reply.    Here they are:    May 21, 2010.   I purchased the HD750 to work with my Acer Windows 7 netbook. The netbook has no DVD slot, so I went to your website to download the driver. Your website offers no Windows 7 driver for the HD750, despite the fact that the box says the product works on the Windows 7 operating system. When I seek to download the second best alternative, the driver for the 32 bit Vista version, I get a fatal error message midway through installation. I have done this a half dozen time and get the error message each time. It appears to me that the Vista 32 bit version of your product won't work with my Windows 7 netbook, but I hope you'll show me that I'm wrong to jump to that conclusion. Please show me how I can install the right driver on my laptop.    May 25, 2010  Please let me know when you'll be able to get back to me on my query above.    Thank you.      May 30, 2010  It's been more than a week now before my initial email to you.     Please let me know when you'll answer my May 21 query. If I don't hear from you in the next few days, I'll request a refund from Amazon and write up my experience with your company accordingly.    June 01, 2010  I have now tried to use your support chat line about a half dozen times during business hours. This is the message I get every time after I hit the submit button: \\"Sorry! All operators in the department are currently offline.\\" After taking the trouble to fill in the chat screen, getting this reply is incredibly annoying.      Beginning around May 25, I also started attempting to enter my original ticket via a \\"chat.\\"  I figured if the ticket approach wasn't working, perhaps the chat approach would.  But, as described in my June 1, 2010 ticket, every time I tried to start a chat--and I tried this at least a half dozentimes over the course of a week--I got this message: \\"Sorry! All operators in the department are currently offline.\\"    In the end, the pseudo technical support bothered me more than the incompatibility with Windows 7 Home Premium.  I called Amazon, explained the situation, and was immediately sent a postage-prepaid form so I could return the product to Amazon and get a full refund.  Thank god for Amazon's return policy!  And shame on Diamond for promising more than it was able to deliver.
output: Inflated feature claims and pseudo technical support cast a dark light on a product that otherwise appears to excel

Instances.input:
So this is not my first Android or Samsung device but I have to say for under $250 it sure is a fun toy! I had a Kindle Fire and have switch. Why? Becuase they are both 7 inches but the Galaxy has way more feature and full Android Play store. No need to go there for this review.

Here's my observation and experience so far using it for a few days.

Display -
Obviously, AMOLED kicks rear as typical with all Samsung devices.

Screen -
Layout is a little lacking in terms of height/width adjustments. I do not like the extra spacing between the clock and the weather, should've made it a little tigher together. I felt the open spaces between widgets and icons just was useless and a waste of screen real estate..

Sound -
Much much louder than a Kindle for sure. This is awesome on flights where you sit near the engine.

Battery -
So far so good, I left it on with my WIFI on all day and came back after 9 hours of work to find it at 97%. Not bad at all. Have yet to play 2-3 movies to see if it'll hold up against what the Kindle can do on a 5hr flight. TBD

WIFI -
does not see ad-hoc wifi (wifi tethering on phones), but nothing Foxfi BT or Rooting won't solve. Not a killer deal but sucks compared to Kindle.

Signal strength is fine for work or office and locks on quick.

GPS -
Not not yet used, don't care to use it since I have a Galaxy 2 phone.

Form factor -
Love it, great size, good feel to it, light enough to not feel fatigue when holding. Though I have ordered a case and screen protector (which I always do).

Memory size -
Yes like everyone says, around 3.5GB left on internal memory. Nothing Rooting won't solve with APP to SD. :) Love the External SD option.

Charging cable , interface -
This is where I hate. Come'on Samsung don't you ever learn? Galaxy 10 and now this? Who puts in a proprietary plug (I won't name Apple... Opps I did). Also the cable is not long enough! Even the Kindle and Iconia had micro USB and both I've owned in the past.

BLOAT WARE / Software?
My other grip is no SWYPE! After using it on my G2 phone I need it, Samsung phone is Samsung, is Samsung Tablet not made by Samsung? Does the company not talk to each other and have some kind of standard on what comes with a Samsung Android device? WTFail. No Swype is sad, get up to speed and get your act together.

That's all for now. So I guess you can't have it all so I took 1 star off due to the charging cable/proprietary plug and lacking Swype.on't name Apple... Opps I did). Also the cable is not long enough! Even the Kindle and Iconia had micro USB and both I've owned in the past.

BLOAT WARE / Software?
My other grip is no SWYPE! After using it on my G2 phone I need it, Samsung phone is Samsung, is Samsung Tablet not made by Samsung? Does the company not talk to each other and have some kind of standard on what comes with a Samsung Android device? WTFail. No Swype is sad, get up to speed and get your act together.

That's all for now. So I guess you can't have it all so I took 1 star off due to the charging cable/proprietary plug and lacking Swype.
output: Very good for the money, minus a few negatives

This was my experience. I bought a NEW product from a seller. When I received it and opened it, I found there's no Setup Wizard CD inside and no factory sealed labels on product. At that moment, I knew this is a used one but I paid by NEW price. After I checked with Cisco's engineers and they proved the one I received is not a NEW product from their database record. Of course, I filed a claim to A-to-Z team and returned it. Then I paid attention on seller's description for this router, I focused on NEW, FACTORY SEALED LABEL, etc. After I re-ordered a new one and followed installation CD steps, it works with my home's network without calling Cisco's tech support.
output: Watch seller's description on this product

Instances.input:
If you're like me and the thought of \\"electronic set-up\\" (other than plugging in a hair dryer) makes you have a mild panic attack, this review is for you! If you're super tech savvy and write reviews for CNET and PC World, I'm probably not your gal.

I bought this product b/c my Linksys router crapped out. I have a MacBook from 2009, and figured I'd try Apple's most affordable router option this time around. I just plugged the cable running from my modem into the AirPort Express 802.11n and then plugged the AirPort into the wall. I walked over to my MacBook, launched the AirPort Utility (which is under Applications, then Utilities), and in less than 3 minutes, setup was complete and I was working on my new secure internet connection. I did not even need to install the CD that came with the AirPort Express.

Of course I cannot speak to the lifetime of this product, because I just bought it yesterday - but it has a year warranty which seems pretty standard. All I know is that it's set-up is akin to plugging in my hair dryer and my connection is secure. Not sure what else I'd want. That said, I do live in a small condo, so I don't have the need for long range connectivity that others may have.
Works good so far.

If the Asus shipped the Nexus 7 2nd generation tablet with a case, this would probably be it. When the advertisement says \\"Ultra Thin\\" this is no exaggeration. It is as thin as a case could be for my Nexus. The hardback provides excellent protection and the front cover opens, closes and folds with excellent functionality. The magnetic closure keeps the case closed firmly and the sleep/wake magnet works perfectly. I own two of these tablets and have the i-Blason premium leather stand/case cover on the other. I gave it an excellent rating as well for I think the quality of each is about the same. They each have their own desirable and unique characteristics. I find the i-Blason best for the office. It is thicker because the tablet slides in and out and it also has some compartments and a stylus holder. I find the  MoKu case better for traveling because it takes up very little room in my briefcase while offering excellent protection if it gets jostled around. In short, I think you can't go wrong by using this case with your Nexus 7 2nd generation. I find absolutely no negatives to report.

This is the second graphic tablet I bought. My old one is the other brand, and this new one is much better than my old one. It so sensative that you don't have to draw hard which makes me feel easy and comfortable. It's drawing  area is much larger than my old one (their prices are almost the same). Anyway, I like it very much!
