I have this mousepad for almost a month now and the quality seems to be very descent. I would definitely suggest it so someone who is looking for a simple, elegantly designed mousepad with wrist support, especially for its price.

It is quite comfortable; the anatomic bump helps keep your wrist relaxed.
The total surface is not very big (if you take into account that there is also the wrist bump) and might not be the most comfortable if you have a wide range in the motion of your mouse. On the other hand, I assume that people who move their mouse in a wide range would not find it useful to have a static wrist-resting bump like this in the first place.
At the bottom, it is covered with a glossy (sticky feeling) material that helps the mousepad stay firm (not move around). In fact it is very stable: I have a glass desk and if I want to move the mousepad (e.g. a little to the right or left), it is practically impossible to drift on the glass. I have to lift it and land it where I want it to be. This also might not be the most comfortable thing, since for example if you change sitting position on your desk (tilt chair etc), you might have to do this frequently.
On the other if you like a mousepad that does not move around, this is it (I have also tried it on wooden surfaces).
I have uploaded pictures that try to give a better idea. I hope they are helpful.

As far as shipping is concerned, the seller shipped it with USPS (first class without a tracking number) soon after the order was posted. However, the delivery was delayed (I waited more than 10 business days, i.e., two full weeks). This was probably a one time incident and cannot blame the seller.
output: Quite comfortable wrist support, relatively small area, very sticky non-slip surface adheres to the desk surface

I love the look. Very clean. Mine had a few marks on the inside that I might be able to get rid of, but I'm not perturbed. I purchased this as a means to prevent the chassis from scratches, and I'm confident it'll do the job. A few observations:

- The edges are not laser cut. Though obvious, it'll be even more obvious depending on the position of your hands. If you're prostrate with your head on a pillow in bed, you'll definitely notice. The edges are somewhat rough, and it might do you some good to smooth them out. Once done, it'll be much more comfortable to type. I had a previous Speck cover with a 2011 Macbook Pro, and I can say that the edges were much more comfortable than this one. The clasps are on the front here, and thus bear the risk of scraping your wrists depending on where you place your hands. I tend to use this sitting up and with an external keyboard and mouse, and this I'm not nearly as affected by this.

- I had to re-situate the display cover, and I am as of yet unsure of what difference was made between to the two efforts -- the second made the cover much more flush with the edges of the chassis, though not perfectly (again, I don't need it to be perfect - I just need it to cover the chassis).

- There are small nubs underneath the case that have fallen off quite easily.

Transfer speed seemed to have no difference from my Western Digital Elements external hard drives. I've never had a problem with those. Some others have stated they had some problems with THIS model. I think they may have received one that was thrown around too hard, during shipping. (I've worked for FedEx Ground and trust me...stuff gets thrown around pretty hard, which is why you DON'T want your products to be just thrown into a box and shipped) Yes, mine DID arrive \\"packed\\" that way and I was extremely pissed off and almost sent them back. Styrofoam peanuts exist for a reason, which is why they are supposed to be used. A competitor that rhymes with NewRegg rarely pulls that crap. {yes I know both companies have affiliates that sell through them and therefore are not necessarily shipped by them} Bottom line is this drive DOES run pretty hot. (Put a small item under each end, to lift it up, and that will help it run a bit cooler) Regardless, transfers are fine and the extra heat doesn't seem to hurt it's ability to function as it should. I think the price I paid was almost definitely $80.00 with free shipping. Hope this helps in at least some way. As to that douche bag who commented on how my only other review wasn't golden enough for him: I can only say his parents told him FAR too often that he was the center of the universe and no one else matters as much as him. That guy needs to grow the hell up! I bet he's incredibly lonely, with his attitude that the world should always kiss his ass. I have to laugh, when wondering what HE has ever done for me.  Talk about a self centered man-child!
output: Fine if happy with just bang for your buck; not perfection

This is a well made and good looking case.  Much better than the ones you get on eB** for $9.98.  Included in its box is a nice leatherette case, the USB cable, the manual on a mini-CD, and even its own screwdriver.  Installing the disk into the case is simple.  The USB cable has two ends to plug into the computer.  The second one is in case your computer doesn't put out enough power from a single USB outlet to power it.  If that is the case, you plug the second end into a second USB outlet.  On my IBM ThinkPad T60p I only needed the one.    Installing the case and disk on my Vista system was automatic.  You must format the disk before installing on the system.  The case itself is not recognized with an unformatted disk or no disk at all.    Yes, the case shows fingerprints and, as one reviewer suggested, it could use feet to keep it from sliding, but these are minor quibbles.  Overall, it is completely functional and easy to use.  I am very happy with it.

I bought this usb 3.0 hub because I wanted to transfer a lot of data from 2 other hard drives (1 of them a 3.0 hdd) to one bigger usb 3.0 hard drive quicker than 2.0 speeds (my laptop only having one 3.0 port). I thought this hub would be a great deal, being one of the cheapest 3.0 hubs on Amazon and with such a high rating. Knowing already that this hub is bus powered, I went ahead with purchasing it anyway because of the 3 hard drives I was going to plug in, only one was a portable drive that needed usb power, and didn't expect any problems.

The only problem I encountered was while using it was when transferring large amounts of data from a portable external drive to a desktop external drive. The transfer speed would start out normally for 3.0 hard drives but then would drop down to 10Mbps, appear to pause for a minute, and repeat for as long as the transfer went on. I thought it was possibly because the hub couldn't handle powering a portable drive while maintaining 3.0 speed between 2 drives on the same hub. Unplugging and transferring with one drive in the 3.0 port and the other on a 2.0 port turned out to be faster than on the hub.

If you plan on using even ONE portable drive on this hub, I suggest saving your money and getting a 2.0 hub or buying a 3.0 hub with external power. If everything you plan to plug in to this hub has its own external power source or is a flash drive, go ahead, this hub is perfect for you. As for me, I'm probably going to buy myself an externally powered hub..
output: I thought this hub would be a great deal, being one of the cheapest 3

I am a long time Kindle user. In fact, I bought my first one upon the initial offer. I believe it was the \\"beta\\" version. I bought and used it extensively.  It was/is a great working eBook.  I decided to upgrade for Christmas to the \\"touch\\" version.  I debated the Fire vs the 3G touch.  Since I have an Ipad and Iphone with the Kindle App, I decided to buy the 3G which is like having a paperback book but better.  I made this decision for two reasons.  Most of the books I read are just print with few pictures and maps etc. Second, the 3G is extremely light which I really like. The Fire is twice as heavy. The weight of the 3G makes it easy to read in bed or at the beach which I do often. I am completely satisfied.  It is easy to use,light and hand friendly.  If I need to see a map or picture I go to my PC or Ipad.  I guess if I did not have the Ipad, I would have gotten the Fire.  The ability to read from PC, MAC, Ipad, Iphone and keep them in sync is just amazing too.

Since I didn't want a Kindle cover that had metallic clips to secure the Kindle inside the case, my choices became limited. I was glad I made this decision because my Kindle is secure without the risk of the screen becoming non-functional (that's what I read with the metallic clips). My favorite part of the cover is that when you fold the front back, magnets hold it back. The pockets are functional.

My only two cons about this cover is that I wish it had some type of strap that made sure that the case didn't open (and possibly damage the Kindle) when it fell and that the fabric shows dirt...at least the brown and beige one does.

I am overall pleased with my purchase of this cover and would definitely recommend it to any Kindle owner who wants a functional and cute (in my opinion) case.
output: Great Cover with A Few Cons

I already have an ipad4 so I can't say I needed another tablet. But the idea of a $99 tablet that runs full windows 8.1 and includes 32G of storage that is upgradeable was just too tempting to my technology addiction. I ordered it through Microsoft, and it came in a day and a half. First question: Is it worth the money? Absolutely! Though it only has 1G of RAM, It runs windows quite well, largely due to the solid state storage. The screen is just 7" but is clear and bright. And Windows 8.1, whatever you might have heard, is a great OS for a tablet. Second question: is it useful? It is for me. Using the included MS Office365, I can access my reports anywhere there is a wifi connection, including my smart phone. It works for editing, though I don't think I want to write the whole report on the little guy.

Third question: Does it really get 8 hours from the battery? No it doesn't. But it gets 4-5 and you can use a standard car charger with the same standard Android phone mini usb. Last question: Am I glad I got it? Yes I am. It's a real Windows computer that weighs less than a pound. It works great to get online, it's a great reader, and Windows metro aps are much better developed than in the past. And it runs regular Windows programs.

I'm quite happy with, and and convinced that this little tablet is the best made and fullest featured tablet you can find at the price.
output: A full on 3/4 pound Windows 8.1 computer for 99$?

Instances.input:
Ok let me first say I love my kindle. It goes everywhere with me. I am consuming books at an incredibly fast pace and loving every minute of it. As a reader, the Kindle is perfect ! I used to think I would never get an electronic reader, that I loved the smell and feel of a real book too much. Well I was wrong. The convenience of having a library at my finger tips, all my books in one lightweight easy to carry place is a dream. In terms of business trips and vacations this is the best best best thing I could have purchased. My Kindle is the last thing I see before I go to bed every night :) I feel naked without her by my side, haha !

But there are some negatives. First of all, the power adapter port broke in about 4 months. I never found it easy to use, very wiggly, and honestly hard to fit the charger into. Well it wiggled one too many times, became loose, and stopped working. Now I called Amazon and had a NEW Kindle at my door the next day ! The customer service was awesome, one phone call, and my replacement was on it's way. But, it seems to me this is a design flaw. I hope they make a more durable port with the next version that comes out.

The other complaint I have is when I am browsing on the Web. The browser can become very slow and unresponsive. I find when that happens I need to power down and reboot the device. Maybe it is resetting the memory or something? I am not sure, but this is not for power web users. I can browse at high speed when I am on a roll, investigating some topic that interests me. It is frustrating to have to turn the device off once in a while.

I like the size, small, but not too small, and oh so portable (I can throw it in my purse). But I must admit the screen is just a tad too small for me. I didn't want something as large as a tablet, that would be unwieldy and heavy and no good for reading. But as a web browsing tool, it is not ideal. If Amazon comes out with a slightly bigger screen, I would definitely replace this one. A camera and 3G/4G service would be really nice as well.

So bottom line, I love my Kindle and can't live without it, but if an new one comes out with a slightly bigger screen, 3G/4G, a camera, and a more powerful processor, as long as the price is right, I will replace my current model.screen, I would definitely replace this one. A camera and 3G/4G service would be really nice as well.

So bottom line, I love my Kindle and can't live without it, but if an new one comes out with a slightly bigger screen, 3G/4G, a camera, and a more powerful processor, as long as the price is right, I will replace my current model.
output: Love my Kindle, but has shortcomings

The big minus for me was that these very thin stickers were on a card that didn't want to let go of them. The first few I applied took several tries to remove with a reasonable length fingernail.  After I'd finished the top row, I got the clever idea to peel away the flash that surrounded the stickers, exposing the edges. Then I could fold the card back and easily get the individual stickers loose. I did take care not to peel so far that I couldn't match the sticker to the appropriate letter--the stickers are clear except for the Hiragana character--and I got through the rest of the task in reasonably short order.  Note that these stickers are small and meant to fit on the crown of a standard key. I expect it should be fairly easy to line them up and then simply tap down with a fingertip.  I say I \\"expect\\" that because I actually applied it to an [[ASIN:B000V07N9U Apple Aluminum Keyboard]], which has key-tops much larger than a standard keyboard. The stickers did fit fairly easily, though I occasionally needed to adjust the placement after putting it down, and I frequently ended up with fingerprints on the adhesive.  Overall, though, now that they're in place, they do what I wanted them to do, which is simply to show me what key to hit when typing Hiragana.  It should be noted that these keys produce a layout for Kana typing, which is much less common than Romaji typing, which most operating systems default to when you set them to type in a Japanese character set. For the Mac, it's fairly simple to change to kana typing...as long as you know where to find the right preferences panel.
output: A bit more laborious than it needs to be, but handy when you're done with set-up.

Instances.input: This mini DisplayPort to HDMI adapter lets you connect certain recent Mac models (from 2008 and up) to HDMI displays to provide mirroring or desktop extension.  I used it to connect my 2008 MacBook Pro to a Panasonic 60\\" plasma TV. As soon as I plugged it into the TV (via a standard HDMI cable, not supplied) my Mac recognized it and offered an array of resolution settings, defaulting to 1080p.  I was disappointed to see that it did not support audio through HDMI, but found out on this Apple support page: [...] that my specific Mac does not support routing audio out the mini DisplayPort connector (it's only available on MacBook Pros from 2010 and up)    If you have a Mac laptop with mini DisplayPort connector, you should definitely get one of these: it's inexpensive and lets you connect to just about any TV or projector, which can be nice if you want to show vacation pictures or home videos to the whole family.    Very highly recommended!

Instances.input: Works well and has good fit and finish

This is an amazing mouse for my windows 8 laptop, there is vibrating scrolling and a click weel noise. These can be turned down/up or off in Microsoft intelipoint software from their site. Many people failed to mention that there is vertical and horizontal touch scrolling as well as 3 middle click buttons!! Yes, there is middle click plus extra buttons on both ends of the touch strip, which in hindsight can be programmed to your liking (forward/back buttons, shortcut buttons). It is a little smaller than my home mouse, it is mostly a mobile mouse.

I have a two monitor setup for my computer, with one monitor being 42 inches, meaning I can easily see it from my bed, while using the smaller (24 inch) monitor mainly when I'm at my desk. I bought this keyboard (along with a long USB extension cable, a mouse and a 4-port USB hub) to keep near the bed. I'm very satisfied with this, especially compared to my previous solution (a wireless keyboard and mouse), which both had connection problems from that distance.

You will notice right away that this keyboard feels heavier than you would expect it to be. It also appears to be built like a tank. I can accept the extra weight if it truly means that this keyboard is as sturdy and tough as it appears.

Pressing the Num Lock key causes several of the letters on the keyboard to be replaced by the number pad. While it can be slightly annoying to accidentally start typing numbers because the Num Lock key is activated, I like that more than having to hold the Fn key every time I want to use the number pad, like on most laptops. Overall, this feature is welcomed.

I don't like the lack of a volume control, but this is fixed with software like AutoHotkey or TyperTask (both of which I already had installed on my computer). Since the point of this device is to be as small as possible while still being a functional keyboard, I can accept this omission.

I very quickly got used to the position of the left Ctrl key. It won't be an issue unless you have trouble adapting to things in general. Perhaps I adjusted so quickly because the laptops I set up for people at work have the left Ctrl key in the same place (with the Fn key to its left). I don't use them, but I guess seeing it often enough prepared me for it! Because of the Num Lock feature, I have never actually touched the Fn key, so maybe they could have omitted it and saved themselves from the many people who complain about its position!

Overall, this keyboard is very versatile, and highly recommended.
output: Built like a tank, and works well

When you're not in a room, turn out the light! Same should apply to the Kindle.

When you turn the backlight down to ZERO on the kindle paperwhile, there is still a degree of backlight being emitted from the device. Try it. Go into a dark room, turn the kindle's backlight down to the lowest possible setting, and you'll see that there is still a glow emitted from the device. The problem is that 99% of the time I, and probably most kindle paperwhite users, am reading in sufficient light and therefore don't need the backlight on. I know. I know. It's only a little bit of light and it only uses a little bit of battery, but it just doesn't make sense. If we don't need to be using the light, let us turn it off! Trust your users/customers!

Amazon should update the software so that a setting of zero on the kindle paperwhite's backlight completely turns it off. Otherwise it's just wasteful. I'll change my review once this change has been made.

And for those who are rarely reading in the dark, choose the regular kindle until this has been fixed. Annoying.
output: When you're not in a room, turn out the light!

My husband recently had to spend an extended time in a campground that had wifi quite a way from their campsites.  Being in a rather desolate location, and alone, he was really hoping to be able to connect and watch movies.  This seemed like the perfect solution, and someone else in the campground had something similar that attached to her laptop that worked well.  This one, however, didn't improve the signal at all.  When I tried it on my own laptop, trying to figure out why it wasn't working, I wasn't able to pick up any more signal WITH it than I was without it.  Go figure.  I was so looking forward to it working, but, it didn't.  Maybe in a place where there are more networks available, you would get better signals?  I don't know that, but it wasn't the solution for our problem.  Just wish I had found the misplaced box in time to return it!
output: Seems no better than internal laptop antenna

The battery fit perfectly into the Thinkpad X200 that I have. It doesn't add much weight to the laptop and I am happy with the purchase. I get about 3-6 hrs on it, depending on what I am doing; The old battery would have been 7-9hrs (Lenovo brand). This battery is alot cheaper, and thus you get lower quality battery components to make the battery life lower. Lenovo's power manager identifies the battery as:

Full charge capacity: 43.09Wh
Current: 1.10A
Voltage: 11.77V
Wattage: 12.56W
Temp: 20C. (just booted up).
Cycle count : 4
Manufacture name: SONY
Manufacture date: 2013-08-29
First used: 2013 - 08
Device chemistry: Li-Ion
Design capacity: 47.52 Wh (sticker on battery and specs on amazon show 49Wh; so it is a bit low)
Design voltage: 10.80V.
Also, the serial number that Lenovo sees is the the same as the one that is stuck onto the battery.

As you can see, the design capacity has already dropped 4 Wh with just 4 cycle counts (thus 3 star not 4). I'll see how this continues and if the full charge capacity keeps dropping, if it seems to level off where it is then I'll bring it back up to 4 stars.

I purchased this battery on Nov 11, 2013; so it was manufactured just months before, which is good. Sometimes I see things that are years old being send out via amazon...

As per the directions send from Ankey, I plugged the battery in, dropped it to 7%, charged to full overnight, dropped to 7%, and repeated for 3 cycles to fully exercise the battery. Hopefully this will help keep the full charge capacity where it should be.

Overall, I think it is a good investment since the battery cost $36, compared to the Lenovo's $188 price, however, at the time of writing this review, the Lenovo battery is on sale down to $70... for that price, I might have grabbed the Lenovo brand instead to ensure that I got the higher hours.

If you are planning to use this for flights, then you might need to carry a spare, since the 3-6hrs is not a lot of time. From what little I've seen so far, recharge time is about 4 hours, when the laptop is running. I am not sure when it is not running.

The quality of the battery itself is good. It is completely sealed; and the blue backing, (which I thought might just be an insert) is actually glued down onto the battery.

Shipping\packaging wise, the battery comes in the box shown which is made out of very sturdy cardboard and the battery itself is surrounded by foam to prevent damage.

I would buy again if I needed to, of course based on how long it lasts with this 1Wh per cycle count trend I am hoping to see stop.
output: Decent cheap battery, unsure on how quickly I'll have to replace.

I just set this up today, so I will update this review if needs be as time goes on.

I am using it on a new Retina 15 inch Macbook Pro purchased 09/12 and running OSX 10.8.2

I am using four 3TB Seagate hard drives purchased here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005T3GRLY/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00

The installation went smoothly and was very quick and painless. I set it up as RAID 5, and the MBP immediately recognized it as a 9TB drive and asked if I wanted to initialize it. I formatted it as Mac OS Extended (Journaled) and it is showing up and behaving like any other external hdd.

I have tested data transfer to it with both USB 2.0 and USB 3.0, and both work as expected. It is able to take advantage of the USB 3.0 speed quite nicely and I am currently transferring 150GB in about 20 mins. I mention this specifically because there have been issues in the past with other Mediasonic 4-bay enclosures being able to work properly with Mac's implementation of USB 3.0. This seems to work without any issues.

I haven't had a chance to test the sleep feature on it, but will update when I have the chance.

The Mediasonic works as expected in regards to plugging and unplugging; I can eject the disk in finder, unplug it, and it will quickly turn itself off. I can then plug it back in and it will turn itself back on and initialize back in finder. I mention this because I have other external hard drive enclosures that have a very strange and specific order that they need to be switched on, plugged in, ejected, unplugged, turned off, ect. and will cause problems if the 'recipe' isnt followed. This Mediasonic works nicely like any normal self-contained external hard drive.

I won't go into the form factor/lights/sounds/etc, as other reviews have already done well in that regard, I just wanted to give a review specifically for other mac users. Feel free to comment if there is something on which you would like to specifically check or elaborate.
output: For Mac users: So far so great on new Retina Macbook Pro

So, after reading all these glowing reviews I was expecting an awesome product. After an hour of use I decided to return it for numerous reasons.

1. The space bar is sunk down below the case such that when my thumb would go to press the space bar, it would hit the case and not the key. This is because all of the keys are recessed bellow the top surface of the keyboard. A hidden cost of it being thin.

2. Build quality. The corners of the case where the silver shell and the white plastic met were not well aligned such that there was a distinct gap between the two.

3. Ergonomics. Getting the iPad into and out of the case was not smooth or graceful, frankly it was clumsy. Again, a hidden cost of it being so minimalistic

Did it function, sure. Could I type on it, sure. Did I make mistakes, constantly. The key layout (especially the bottom right + carriage return) was very annoying to me, I kept going for the shift key and hitting the up arrow, this may be a problem with me rather than the keyboard, but I could live without the arrow keys in return for a slightly more traditional arrangement down there.

What I really wanted was the Apple wireless bluetooth keyboard attached to my iPad, that is not what I got. If it was cheaper than all the competition, these things could have been forgiven, but that was not the case.

Works better than expected and here are a few reasonings for the poor reviews:

Yes, the casing is aluminum coated in rubber. The thing rubber coating is to prevent heat from the HDD creating a hot casing that may burn you. This thing stays cool after I left it in for over 2 full days of consistent use.

The casing is two aluminum plates with a plastic center to help disperse heat. The casing comes with 8 Screws: 4 tiny ones that secure the aluminum plates to the plastic center case, and 4 medium ones that secure the hard drive to the case. If you do not use all four screws, the HDD will move, and cause major problems, and most likely fail quickly.

The USB 3.0 Cable does NOT require you to use both USB ports unless you have an older computer using USB 1.1 ports AND an older style HDD. I used a 1.5TB ,2.5 inch drive in a USB 3.0 port and only needed one cable. I used the 2.0 ports, and still only needed 1 port. However, when I used the 1.1 port, I needed both to get the drive to read.

This case, although the product description is inconsistent, will accept SATA I,II, III. All of them will work and they will all work with MAC as well as PC. It accepted my 2TB pocket drive SATA III with no problem and took about 2 hours to transfer 400GB of memory... Great!!!

I have one similar to this, That I purchased from amazon, and its a Masscool brand. Model# (UHB-2221)

http://www.amazon.com/Masscool-2-5-Hard-Drive-Enclosure/dp/B005YJO6IO/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1365802300&sr=8-13&keywords=masscool

They are almost identical, other than the USB 3.0 and the Lack of the OTB button on this model. However, They both work great, and I recommend this product.

I would suggest using a different screwdriver, because I believe they have built in a torque prevention safety, that allows the metal rod of the screw driver to turn, thus not allowing the screws to be over-tightened, but if you have tounscrew them, they screwdriver will probably trip and torque setting and not do what you want.

Although the screws are small, they strip just as any other screw. If you are not careful placing them, which can be a pain, you can strip them, no different than any other Enclosure.

EXTRA PERKS:

The casing comes with a strip of adhesive plastic that lays over top of the screws to hide them, and this works great and is a nice feature if you only plan on placing an HDD in the enclosure one time.

The (leather) case is nice, and fits snug over the Enclosure to prevent scratching and whatnot.

There is also, NO DRIVERS NEEDED. !!!!
Overall, this works great and allows for convenient use.

[[ASIN:B005YJO6IO Masscool 2.5\\" Hard Drive Enclosure]]

My primary use for this monitor is gaming and general PC use or web browsing. I initially thought the 2560x1080 format was what I was looking for and purchased the 29\\" AOC Q2963PM. I found the display beautiful, but it was generally awkward for anything beyond gaming.

I decided to give the Shimian a try, wanting to minimize HUD/UI elements in-game, and also wanting to step up to an IPS panel. This is a well-reviewed monitor on many tech websites, but all of versions I saw had a white bezel and back panel. I wasn't sure what to expect, but decided the price was worth the risk.

Shipping was free via FedEx from Korea and arrived within 3 days. My only disappointment is that it ships in the retail box, but it did arrive unharmed. A couple of notes about items included in the box: a power brick and cord for a 240v wall socket are provided. The brick has a label that states it's able to handle 120-240v so I was able to plug in my previous monitor's cord into the brick and was good-to-go. An instruction manual is included, printed entirely in Korean which will do you no good, although you'll probably be fine without it.

The monitor I received is exactly as pictured above. I'd describe the thin back as almost cast iron feeling (yes, it feels that sturdy) with a stunning piece of black glass attached to the front. It's crazy-thin and when wall-mounted using a VESA mount, only extends from the wall by about an inch and 1/2. Aesthetically, it's the most beautiful monitor I've ever seen.

Powering the monitor on, I had no dead pixels (whew), but noticed quite a bit of light bleed on the top left and bottom left corners. This bothers me much less than dead or stuck pixels because I'm rarely staring at a pure black screen. On-screen menus, like the manual, are all in Korean, although a few of the settings are self-explanatory based on the images. I was able to change the color profile to sRGB without too much trouble. If there is an option to change the monitor language to English I didn't see it. (EDIT: Found it!)

My impression of overall image quality and gaming at 1440p is that everything looks incredible. I noticed about a 10-15 fps drop do to the extra pixels needing to be pushed by my graphics card, but the quality improvement made this loss acceptable. I haven't noticed ghosting, although I rarely play FPS games where this might be more of an issue. I'd describe the look of motion to be a bit more cinematic looking--but maybe this is the definition of ghosting. Either way, I actually like the look.

Wrapping things up, I highly recommend this monitor. I've heard that this is the same panel as Apple's Cinema Display (although one of their rejects since they only accept the A+ panels). Because of this, your mileage may vary. If you're lucky, you'll end up with an affordable and beautiful panel like I did. It's probably my most treasured piece of electronics right now if that gives you any indication of how impressed I am.

Like another person explained, this battery worked perfectly in my PS3 controller.  Wires were correct (pos/neg were not crossed).  Original symptoms of battery failure did not come from the controller, but from the PS3 unit saying my USB ports on the PS3 were drawing too much power (Hmm...).  Odd, I had not changed any of my devices in a year. Maybe the USB ports were failing according to some Internet searches (and thus the PS3 was bad... oh my!).  Fortunately, as of now, it seems this was just a symptom of a bad battery in my main PS3 controller (whew!).  Once I replaced the battery with this one I purchased, I no longer got the USB power problem message on the PS3 screen (thank goodness!).  I have all my PS3 devices/controllers attached and a keyboard and all looks good.  This battery seems to work perfectly, yet I cannot of course vouch for its sustainability over time.  I bought 2 batteries just in case this only lasted a few months.  The battery was cheap enough to buy a second one if the lifespan was not so great. I just wanted the controller to work AND make sure my PS3 USB ports were working again without power errors.  Thanks for the great battery!
output: Excellent replacement battery for ps3 controller (ditto)

Mine was purchase February 18th 2013. I contacted iShot Mounts 4 times, starting 3 months ago with no response.

A major flaw that needs IMMEDIATE attention is the nut at the back of the mount that connects with the bolt from any camera stand. Mine was loose after 3 times of screwing it onto the tripod. If you have purchased this mount you should immediately inspect it. The nut can easily get separated from its housing and cause the Ipad to drop and possibly sustain damage. IMHO this defect makes this mount unstable, hence unreliable. Add to that no response from the seller and I say \\"BUYER BEWARE\\".

I'm hoping iShot addresses this manufacture defect soon, as I suggested this mount to several of my musician friends. I would hate to think it's my fault their Ipad gets damaged. imagine when he starts selling a lot of mounts. There will be many upset purchasers demaning a replacement or refund.

I was told there is a warranty of several years. But if the seller never responds, which is the case, how does one obtain a warranty repair or replacement?

Edit July 26, 2013
Finally heard back from iShot. They said they were having email problems. I explained the problem with the floppy nut. They deny anyone else having this problem with their unit. Now they want me to ship it back, instead of sending me the minor part to fix it myself. I already paid a lot for the mount, considering its construction. Now I have to pay shipping to send it back, so they can fix a 50 cent part.

I will amend the review favorably, if the seller honors his warranty and either sends the parts or repairs or replaces my unit at no cost to me.
output: Still has issues with MOUNTING NUT

Instances.input: I bought this to replace an ailing Linksys super G router.  Other than having to call my cable ISP to get it working on their system, the set-up was easy.  I followed other reviewers' advice and skipped the installation disk, going right to the IP address for the router.  My difficulty was that I was not using the same PC that I used when I set up the Linksys... thus the necessity for the call to my cable company.    The router?  Flawless.  My range has improved tremendously. I haven't had a single disconnect since I installed it.  I have it set up on the second floor in my old stone house - where the cable connection comes in.  I do not have a PC connected directly to it.  The inside walls of my house are wood, and there are two all tile bathrooms in the way of things.  The reception on the first floor is now very good. My second floor PC (on the far side of the house) with a Linksys N PCI card is going full boat.  My tiny netbook eeePC on the first floor is doing great.  My Ipod Touch now connects with a strong signal everywhere in the house.  My T-Mobile wi-fi Katalyst cell phone pulls a strong signal as well.  I'm a happy camper!

I had one more problem with this laptop that doesn't warrant a lower rating since it is easy to fix. The problem I had was with the display driver installed on the laptop. After restart the laptop would boot the login screen and once logged in it would load straight to a black screen with only the cursor visable. If this happens to you, just reset the computer by hitting the recovery key (Might be F12, not sure) at the Lenovo boot screen then follow the onscreen instructions. After you have reset the laptop, go to AMD's website and install the latest display driver. Then you are done. This black screen issue can be really annoying, especially if you have just finished uninstalling all of the bloatware on this PC, because after reset you have to delete it all again. Trust me, I had to do it.

Fortunately Visitontek's drivers web site [...] does have a patched Catalyst 8.6 that works with this card. It's an old version and it's not WHQL certified, but at least it works. The real problem is you may well never be able to upgrade this driver again. Stick with a card with driver support.

I am using these on a Synology DS213 (great box!), I bought 2 originally for my NAS and ran it for about a month with no trouble at all.

So out of the blue I get a message from my box that one of the drives failed. At first, I thought it was not a big deal...drives are mechanical devices, they can fail. So I contacted WD, they sent me a replacement...that one failed immediately. Contacted them again...that one failed immediately. Currently, I am waiting for the arrival of yet another replacement and hoping for the best. But I must say, I am losing my confidence at this point.

During all this I did work with Synology to make sure it was not anything I did or the box did to the drives. They assured me that it was not a NAS problem. They even went so far as to log into my box and look at the logs to troubleshoot it.

The one thing I can say at this point, and is the reason I gave it such a good rating, is WD does send replacements with little hassle.

I'm not sure what other options there are out there, but so far I'm not impressed with this one.

UPDATE 7/11/2013 ********************************************

Just received my replacement drive, drive number four now, and it too failed.

I am now completely lost! I am now taking another look at my Synology DS213 to make sure I don't have bad bay. I just don't see how I can get 4 bad drives in a row.
output: 3 failures in less than 1 month, waiting for drive number 4.

Instances.input: I bought this product 5 months ago and I must say it was a great choice. I didn't particularly care about the looks of the hard drive when I bought it, but I now find it's really great to have an elegant and modern looking hard drive on my desk. The drive is fast and very easy to use. It has never given me any problems while trying to disconnect it (some hard drives I've used in the past have the problem of giving an error message when trying to close them via the windows \\"safely remove hardware\\" assistant). Also, the  blue indicator light is not only stylish, but very useful for seeing if the disk is working or stopped. Another great thing is that the drive is noiseless! Even when working at full speed (while transfering files or importing CD's...or when left downloading large files all night) the drive is silent. Considering the competition, I have two criticisms for this drive: its terrible software and the lack of a quick synchronization button. The backup software is hard to use, confusing, and not powerful at all. It takes ages to encrypt your files and then it is impossible to navigate through them (for example, it doesn't show thumbnails for photo files, so you have to open them one by one to find them!). Maxtor´s One-Touch drives are much better at backup because the software is much more comprehensible and the button allows for instant synch. If you don't mind synchronizing manually, or if you don't want to use this drive to make a mirror copy of your computer´s internal drive, then it is a great choice!
Not the original, but it's good so far not given any problem. My fear is that it works over time.

To start the review, I had seen this model at best buy (Cheaper BTW). I liked the touch screen option especially with Windows 8, Unfortunately when I went to buy it they were sold out so I figured Amazon is always my go to when I cant find something. I paid a little more and purchased the 3 year warranty. It arrived 2 days later (Thanks Prime) I unboxed it and first thing I wanted to try was the touchscreen, but even know best buy's exact same model had a touch screen and TQcybermall had answered someone's question to whether this was a touchscreen unit with a \\"Yes this is a touchscreen.\\" This is not a touch screen computer. First problem of many.

The keyboard..... Backlight keyboard cool, but the fact that it is completely open to suck in any dust or garbage that might fall in there is horrible. Not to mention the keys have this annoying click that only seems to be getting worse. Normally I would think hey I got a bad one (seems to be the way most of my purchases go) but that doesn't seem to be the case, rather just a flaw in the design.

The Fkeys..... Why in the world would you make the fkeys control laptop functions without pressing the function key? Maybe I'm missing something but I cant alt-f4 anything because of the display switch option or bind any of my fkeys to anything in-game without a popup adjusting volume or trying to change a track.

The Touchpad..... While its extremely big and can sense multiple touch, which is nice for Windows 8 and the whole App feel. The left and right click are not separate from the touchpad and horribly close to the edge. Making me think well maybe I'll just buy a wireless mouse, but who wants more stuff to carry around with your laptop.

The Speakers..... They sound great at higher volumes, but as soon as sound gets low it seems to be distorted or misplaced. Very annoying while playing games where sound can be the difference between a win and loss.

Its not all bad though, Ido like the fact that I can play my games on a laptop without having to scale back on graphics and the display is nice and crisp.

I'm just not happy that I spent so much to feel so cheated. In the end Id rather carry around a mouse / keyboard / headset then deal with this laptop. I guess it's my fault for not looking a little deeper at this laptop, but now that its open its mine and there is nothing I can do about it. Hopefully no one else makes the same mistake.
output: A lot of small but annoying issues.

Purchased:  July 2011  My expectations for a netbook were sufficiently low.  I have been following the developments since MIT's Nicholas Negroponte first founded the One Laptop Per Child organization (OLPC), a few years ago.  After donating a few netbooks through OLPC, I decided to get an adult netbook of my own.    I wanted something light weight with a good size keyboard and efficient power management that would allow me to securely track my finances during extended trips.  I preferred a netbook with the LINUX operating system.  My companion insisted the netbook should be able to stream Netflix videos and the Rhapsody music service.  Netflix requires the Silverlight software which only runs on the Windows operating system.  I was leaning toward ASUS hardware due to their reputation for high quality.  After a reasonable search, I settled on this ASUS/Windows machine.  The netbook has a role, but it is still not intended to replacement a full size laptop.  I am amazed at how close it comes to replacing a laptop.       WHEN READING MY HIGHLY CRITICAL REVIEW, KEEP IN MIND, AFTER ALL THE SOFTWARE AND FIRMWARE UPDATES ARE IN PLACE YOU WILL BE REASONABLY PLEASED WITH THIS NETBOOK.  Enough of my gibberish, let us get on with the review.  I purchased the ASUS eee PC 1015-PX netbook, 2 GB of RAM, ASUS mouse, ASUS external DVD reader/writer, PC-to-TV video converter, and audio cables.    THE GOOD:  - The eee PC hardware:  keyboard, screen, and basic build are excellent for a netbook.  - Windows 7 Starter Edition is more than competent operating system for a Netbook.  Once everything is updated it is a smooth running system with the familiar look and feel of your desktop.  - Windows 7 Starter Edition can stream Netflix movies, Rhapsody music, Photo Shop pictures, and run most software in the Windows ecosystem.  Videos and web content can be displayed from the netbook to a TV with a proper PC-to-TV converter.  - Windows 7 Starter Edition is not a streamline and low maintenanceoperating system, but it is a familiar interface with a plethora of software choices.  It is more than adequate for most netbook uses.  THE BAD:  - Windows 7 Starter Edition is basically a crippled version of Windows 7.  It does not support reading/writing DVD's.  Normally, I would not have a problem with this, except ASUS failed to supply a copy of the Windows installation software on external media, because Windows 7 Starter Edition can not read DVD's.  Putting the Windows recovery files on CD-Rom is unthinkable - it would take approximately 30 CD's to store the 17GB of files.  - Normally the major updates like Windows service packs are preinstalled on the PC's.  The burden of installing the Windows 7 Service Pack#1 and prior updates is passed on to the customer.  You will invest a lot of quality time getting Windows 7 up to date.   - The only audio speaker is of poor quality compared to the rest of the hardware.  Why ASUS decided to install one cheap speaker on otherwise very nice hardware is beyond me.  The audio is very nice when using external stereo spearkers.  Yes, this is the newer model and it still only has one speaker.  Beware, the one audio port serves as both an audio-out and an audio-in port.  A software switch determines whether it is in input or output mode.  - The documentation attempts to cover several different netbook models on the same pages.  It is frequently difficult to determine which model was being described.  The user guide on the PC is slightly more informative than the paper booklet.  ASUS online user forum is not helpful.  Reading some of the responses to the customers pleas for help caused me to flinch.  The forum moderators are very arrogant and belittled those lacking technical skills.    THE UGLY (It may get a little technical):  - There are no Windows 7 Starter Edition operating system DVD's included with this computer.  If the recovery files on the hard drive are destroyed, you are out of luck.  You must decide whether to purchase a +16GB thumb drive to backup the Starter Edition and recovery files or use that money to upgrade to the Home Edition and use your standard backup software - assuming you backup your current system.  Keep in mind once the recovery software (ISO) is loaded on the thumb drive you can not use the self-booting drive to store any other files.  - The installed BIOS version 1101 is horrible and caused a number of issues.  The  netbook had problems recognizing my external ASUS CD/DVD reader with the installed BIOS.  The BIOS exhibited irratic behavior when attempting to access the BIOS setup panel.  Following the instructions in the manual, the included system software directs you to the ASUS BIOS repositories on the internet, but ASUS no longer updates the firmware on the sites.  In fact, the firmware in the BIOS repositories is older than the installed BIOS.  Eventually, I found the latest BIOS (version 1301) on the ASUS support site.  Be careful, blotching a BIOS flash can leave you with a non-working computer.  Save the current BIOS first, and then do not interrupt while the BIOS is being updated.    - The hard drive can not be replaced.  There is no access panel for it.  The case has to be completely disassembled voiding the warranty in the process.  You can only hope it never fails.  CONCLUSION:  The ASUS eee PC 1015-PX is a decent piece of hardware except for the speaker and touchpad button.  It has excellent battery life.  Once all the operating system and BIOS updates are in place it is an acceptable computer for travel.  Getting this computer setup properly is no fun, but your reward is a well built and smooth running machine.    SUGGESTIONS:  - The latest BIOS and drivers are on the ASUS support site.  I would go there first.  - Plan on spending a lot of quality time updating Windows 7.  The Service Pack #1 update will not run automatically.  You will have to start it manually.  - While upgrading the memory, I had a bit of a problem finding the cover screw for the memory compartment.  It is covered by a plastic plug that is a perfect match to the case.  It looks to be part of the case, but it is not.  Just pry it off with a fine head screw driver.  Search YouTube for a video \\"ASUS eee PC Memory Upgrade\\" for installation help.  You are not authorized to perform any updates to the ASUS hardware - memory included.  Do not look to ASUS customer support for any help.  - I was able to use the built-in backup/recovery software to store the Windows 7 Starter Edition recovery files to an old 40GB hard drive sitting in an external USB HD enclosure.  Now keep in mind that entire hard drive can nolonger be used for anything other than holding the +16GB of recovery files.  The computer geeks would be better served using 3rd party software to make an image copy of the entire hard drive.  It would certainly be more space efficient.  That is my next step.  In case you were wondering, the included backup software will not write the recovery files to CD-Rom.  - I am not sure how well this netbook would work with LINUX.  Some of the key features, the audio port toggle switch and the power saving mode, are both controlled by Windows specific software.  These device specific software  components (drivers) may not exist in the LINUX world.  You may lose a lot of functionality.  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  UPDATE:  November 5, 2011  I tried the eee PC with UBUNTU Linux and touchpad issues disappeared.  I am lowering my rating to two stars for all the torture this computer has put me through.  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  *  UPDATE:  November 25, 2011  The battery died today.  I have put less than 16 hours on this netbook after applying all the Windows updates.  It is only used in between flights at the airport.
output: It works with both Netflix and Rhapsody

Update...

Just bought my second 1tb drive. The price was very good so I jumped at the chance after having loved the 1st one.

I did have a problem of my computer not recognizing the new drive. I tried everything I could think of to fix it and no luck. Thoughts of seeing bad reviews from others here where their drive didn't work ran through my head.

After reading and trying the FAQ on Iomega's website, I wanted to call them for help. Apparently to call for help costs $25 per incident. I was going to write in their forums but I noticed when others asked for help, replies were usually a day or 2 or 3 out from the question, not wanting to wait 1 to 3 days for a possible answer, I used the online chat they have. I hate the online tech support chats so I wasn't expecting much. However after explaining my situation to the guy, he was really helpful. Nothing we tried worked so he suggested reformatting the new drive and renaming it. I saw in the menus on my computer where the drive was there, but offline due to a collision conflict with another drive. But I was able to rename my new drive (I did not reformat it) and BOOM I was now able to click it online and it worked.

So for anyone out there who finds a need to purchase a second drive, and if you go with the exact same model, you will most likely get this same problem. It's an easy fix once you've done it once and I must say their support was excellent.
output: I love it (so much I bought a second one)

Instances.input: Great functional product plus its my favorite color (Pink).  The ability to stand up is the efficient part of the product.

The case is very lightweight which I like for my son, and the iPad sits securely inside. What I don't like is how the face of the iPad is very exposed. I'm fearful of him dropping it because I'm not 100% sure the case would absorb the impact. It looks as though the iPad front would take damage rather than be protected.

Broke my heart to give this 2 stars, but I have to be honest with potential buyers: I bought this item twice thinking that my ignorance broke it the first time, only to have my hopes dashed twice. While it actually worked, the mouse was perfect formwize, sizewise and in terms of performance. The not-so-obvious design flaw lay not in the mouse- I swear it's perfect, but the receiver.

The receiver protrudes about 0.5 inch from the body of my laptop, so leaving it plugged while i transported it was simply not an option. Constant tugging from the USB slot over 1 year renders the already flimsy design an accident waiting to happen, and while I'll admit I didn't take the utmost care in the first instance, I was more than careful the 2nd time around, but only managed to prolong the inevitable. Worst of all, you cannot purchase/ replace the receiver separately- what a disappointment.

Bottom line: it is perfect for the professional on the go- from compact fold and neat packing to responsive ergonomic support, but eventually, you WILL be disappointed. My 2 year old son was the winner in all of this, as he got 2 pretend flip phones out of my misery.

I am very happy with the product I received from DealBarn. It was exactly what I wanted, an Apple product, and it works perfectly. What was really helpful was that it arrived ahead of when it was expected.

Its horrible. Couldnt even fit my ipad mini .well, what do expect for something so cheap.also the amount of bubbles are critical

Love this product. The carry handle is great and it will stand up to watch movies if on hard surface. Otherwise, just prop it up the other way. It is a little loose in one spot. There is no guard for front of iPad so we bought glass protector due to reviews saying screen needs protection.

I like computers and use them all the time but I'm not networking savy. I was very fearful of leaving me home PC directly connected to our cable modem (AT&T @home) without a firewall. I also needed to connect my work laptop to the Internet and share files with the home PC. The Netgear was perfect for us.
It took about 15 minutes to set up only because @home in our area uses "static IP address". If this applies to you, don't worry, AT&T gave you this info on your original order. Also, Netgear instructions show you how to retrieve it from your PC if you can't find the paperwork. It sets up via Internet Explorer and the router prompts you to enter the information. For DHCP users, its even easier as this is the default for the router. It took longer to reboot my PC after changing its settings than setting up the router.
It was a great buy. After 1 month, we're very happy with it.
output: Great, simple router for the home

I got this as a gift early this week. I had read about it, but that was about it. I don't know if I would have bought one. Well I would now if I did not already have one. I still can't get over the clarity of the text. I love to download books on it. The speed is amazing. It is also really light.    If you plan to read in low light you need a light. Just like a real book. I wish there was a light that could easily hook on to it. A backlit screen would be nice, but I am sure it would be a huge drain on the battery . I also wish that the 'text page\\" button was smaller. I bump it all the time. It is a bit annoying.     I just can't wait for more newspapers. I am not really interested in the current ones. I would like the NJ Star Ledger. I am sure more are coming.    I say good job so far. It's a readers dream.

My wife's desk top tower finally had enough.  Because of her work as a grade school teacher she had a school assigned laptop and had come to really appreciate a laptop's utility and convenience.  We examined features, prices, etc on every laptop in the $800 and under price range and picked this model Dell from Amazon.  We've both been blown away by it's display clarity, speed, ease of use, and features like full numeric keypad, built in camera, as well as the features of the loaded Windows 7 OS.    As for Amazon's performance as a seller?  Exceptional!  I can't promise this will be your experience, but we took the \\"free shipping\\" option available at the time, and got the computer \\"the next day!\\"  This is a fine computer at a great price from an excellent retailer.

I needed an internet connection in my workshop which is 300 feet from my house.  I had no signal at the shop from my Cisco wireless n router from the house.  I set up the system using a Linksys access point feeding signal from the router to the Hawking antenna on the house.  The shop has identical antenna and Linksys access point.  This gave very low signal strength and speed.  I found EnGenius Network Device EUB9603H USB Adapter 150Mbps 600mW 802.11b/g/n.  This gave the shop computer both excellent signal strength and speed to allow normal surfing and access to network files.  I am quite satisfied with the quality of the setup at a very reasonable price for this system setup.
output: Good system, but signal booster needed for signal strength

[[VIDEOID:1190bc6218b9078d9e799416fb1d4b90]]Hah, looks like I am not the only one to be pleasantly surprised at how it fits the Samsung Tab 3 10.1\\" screen tablet! Yes, when I eyeballed the interior inset space, I was like, \\"Hmmm, I wonder...\\" Superb!

Why am I so excited? Well, ever since I started doing daily Android App video reviews, I have been on a constant search for a display that would hold my tablet at not only a decent viewing angle, but vastly more importantly, hold it rock steady so I don't get wibble-wobble as I touch, poke, perhaps energetically play a game as I demonstrate it. This is it, folks. This is it for both portrait and landscape orientations. I have finally found my solution.

Plus, I can use the little cutouts at the top for general tool purposes, and the included capacitive stylus. I must highlight this stylus... it has a generously wide 7.5mm tip with a chunky wood grip. The tip is a standard rubber (not capacitive mesh), but I have seen the few pens available in this style and tip width go easily for 10 bucks alone.

Now as I mention in my video review, I feel necessary to disclose that the unit I received does have minor cosmetic flaws. Certain imperfections are to be expected in a wood product, but there are also a couple drip lines from the finish lacquer around the interior edges. Nothing particularly discernible to the casual eye (heck, I left plenty of similar drip lines with my own lacquer work), yet as one who has been among guitar players who find even the slightest speck on a new axe maddening, I feel compelled to mention it.

Nevertheless, I am supremely happy with this stand, and for those of you who may be following my Amazon's Free App of the Day video reviews... you shall be seeing this nifty stand in constant action. :D

-- I received this as a complimentary review product with the aim of hopefully elucidating features and drawbacks that may help you ultimately decide what fits your needs and budget best.
output: My Three Month Search for "The Display Stand Solution" has Ended

Another Future: Poetry And Art In Postmodern Twilight is an anthology of critical essays about contemporary poetry, art, culture, and politics by independent scholar and poet Alan Gilbert. Divided into three sections, \\"Considering How Material Documents Can Be\\", \\"Territories and Other Forms of Knowing\\", and \\"Meaning Politics Without Regrets\\", Another Future questions the social context of modern poetry and charters a discourse for thinking about contemporary culture in terms beyond post-modernism. A scrutiny so meticulous as to resemble a documentary, Another Future is especially recommended reading for students of modern poetry.
output: An anthology of critical essays about contemporary poetry, art, culture, and politics

Instances.input: \\"My needs are simple, the BEST\\".    My interest in this device was to evaluate its capability for use within a private high school that serves the bottom socio-economic quartile.   Our goal is to increase the quantity and quality of reading done by students in an environment where we cannot afford up to date textbooks and fiction.    The product met or exceeded every technology requirement without exception.   This product received our highest value, ease of use, design, networking, and durability ratings.   Instead of buying books and placing them on shelves, we are purchasing this portable hand held digital library for students to check-out and use.  (We lack the funding to simply give each student their own unit).    Objections to the device: Old style 20th century vintage English Language Arts (ELA) teachers could not overcome the lack of physically turning pages when reading.  Apparently old style paradigms die hard for the veteran teachers.  Students embraced this digital library with energy and full enthusiasm.  (When inflexible Teachers fail to recognize the abilities of students, you can stop wondering why we have education problems in this country).    This product is superior in every way save one: Color.  For graphics, maps, illustrations, etc. the device needs color display capabilities.
Good modem for the price.  Does not work with my CenturyLink service as this is an ADSL2+ modem and CenturyLink in my area is VDSL.

I'd definitely recommend this! *Note: I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

Instances.input:
I am very pleased with this case. Really adds a nice professional look to the device, and has great all around protection. I saw some comments on the full black case about fit and alignment being slightly off, but I don't see any such issues. All cutouts (cameras, volume/mute, docking port, screen) are perfectly aligned. The elastic band is a great addition, functionally and cosmetically....iPad looks great when I carry it with my Moleskin notebook!

To be fair, I got this through the recent 50% off sale on the Belkin site, and doubt I would have paid full price, but that is just because I'm a cheapskate. It's definitely worth what Amazon is asking, though.

My experience with iPad cases overall is limited, and I'm sure there are other nice choices. But for the price, this is a fine piece of workmanship, and I would say it is well worth a look.

UPDATE: The only reason this didn't get 5 stars is because the cover doesn't actually fold all the way back. So, as a stand, it's great, as a book, it's great, but you screw up the cover if you try to fold it back on itself.

Instances.input: I have been using this SSD in a 15\\" 2.8GHz Core2Duo for past close to a year and the performance has been excellent but still I had issues using VMware fusion with mainly 32 bit XP & Windows 7. My main purpose was windows performance and I moved all my VM's to 2nd SSD and mainly using the first drive for OS and other documents and tools. The performance improved significatly. PROS:  it performs its function  protects cards well  locking mechanism works very well  it came with a weird.... cat toy? (lol) that says bluecell on it and the other end looks like a small blue bullet  small sd card slot fits very well    CONS:  poor build quality  large sd card slot fits well, but because of the poor built quality, you may find it doesn't stay secured    With the positive: I forgot I had my sd card in my back pocket while I was changing a fog light bulb on a vehicle. I sat on the card and put quite a bit of pressure on it against concrete and my sd card was still in working order and the case didn't break.    With the the negative: It appears that while in the fabrication process, the plastic was removed from the mold prior to it being completely cured. My assumption is that it was still a bit warm and the edges \\"drooped.\\" It doesn't close securely. None of the 10 items do. That, and/or the item was poorly engineered.

Instances.input: I love my Kindle 2 and I love the M-edge Prodigy Hinge Jacket in Pebbled Mocha with Saddle.  I was concerned about carrying the Kindle around without a protective cover.  After reading the reviews, I selected this cover and am very pleased with it.  The jacket is well-made, nicely padded without being bulky, and fits well in my purse or briefcase.  The leather feels nice and the stitching is well-done.  Although the package did not include directions for fastening the Kindle onto the clips, a quick look at the M-edge website gave me simple instructions.  Between the clips and the small straps on the upper and lower right sides of the cover, my Kindle fits very securely in the cover.  Now, I don't leave home without it!  And I am eagerly awaiting the M-edge book light that will fit inside the cover and make it easy to read on planes, etc. A fabulous product that I recommend without hesitation.

This case is great, just what I was looking for.  It protects the iPad, as well as looks like a book. I find the way that this case stands horizontally is superior to that design and most cases I have seen.  I used it on a long airplane trip and it never fell over, even with my two kids occasionally bumping it. It fits nicely into the case, and has never fallen out. All buttons and Cameras are accessible.

Love it !!!! Best gift I ever received .

I did not carefully read the tech specs in the detailed product info. This will NOT CHARGE an iPad Mini. Read the tech specs carefully. This is a hub only. I can transfer photo files from my iPhone 4S and Canon SX 50 easily to my Mac Air. No problems there. I have never connected more than two devices through this hub. It is so lightweight that I cannot leave it permanently connected because it flips around and causes problems. If I am careful, I can have my Le Cie Porsche connected and backing up at the same time that this is connected. I will use it to take with me around town, but for my work desk I am going to purchase the http://www.amazon.com/EasyAcc®-Charging-Smartphones-Specially-Included/dp/B00MLVTL88/ref=cm_cr_pr_product_top  Look at the video reviews for that product and read the tech specs and you will see that it is a superior product for daily use.
output: Does not charge an iPad. Read tech specs carefully.

Instances.input: This tablet is a great value. It is well built, with enough weight to keep it securely on your desk, and a smooth and finished feel. The pen is sturdy enough, though not the best I've used. Button placement on the pen is mediocre. The mouse works, but the scroll wheel is only an up/down toggle button with software scrolling. Engineering seems good, and the unit works well. The pen holder is well placed.    Overall, for the price, this is an excellent buy. However, at this price range, Genius should have considered the fact that people would be using it with the popular free software Gimp, a Photoshop alternative. The tablet does NOT currently work properly with the latest version of Gimp under Windows 7.

Instances.input: This case is very rugged and durable considering the low price. I bought another case in this price range and it fell apart immediately. The material is thick and tough, and has plenty of compartments to keep all your stuff. Shoulder strap is comfortable and it looks nice too.

I bought this hard drive for my HP 2710p at the end of may and installed it at the beginning of June. I put a clean version of Windows 7 x64 on it. My 2710p has a 1.2ghz core 2 duo with 8gb of ram. Since installing the hard drive, the hard drive light has been on constantly. Additionally, on first boot up, 80% of the time I get a \\"Disk Read Error\\" after the bios. Ctrl + Alt + Delete works every time... it's as if the HD controller doesn't \\"wake up\\" in time.

As time has progressed since June, my laptop will freeze up. At first it was a few seconds at a time. Now it's minutes at a time. I think the HD controller in the SSD is bad. I've tried to get a hold of Kingspec's service department numerous times. I've tried both emails, services@kingspec.com and info@kingspec.com. I've sent about 5 emails to both addresses and have never received a reply.

I would highly recommend NOT buying this hard drive.

I didn't think I needed the HDMI out port when I bought it, but we used it to present to a large audience with a large flat screen TV and the HDMI worked great. Both the video and audio transferred to the TV. Upgraded to Windows 8.1 and it works fine.

I have been using an iPad to read Kindle-based books since it came out.    I just bought a Kindle 3G 2nd gen because the iPad is 1) too heavy 2) can be tiresome to read in certain lighting situations.    Overall I think it's OK and better than the iPad for this purpose, but it has issues too:    1. It's too easy to hit by mistake the side buttons when holding it. I keep changing pages by mistake  2. I'm right-handed, so the left buttons (which I never use) just get in the way for me. Same could be true for a left-handed person  3. The menu system is not intuitive  4. There are no integrated side-edge LEDs to allow usage in some situations, without strapping and carrying around a cumbersome reading lamp  5. 3G-based web browsing seems to be only available to US-based customers, which kinds of sucks as 3G coverage and speeds are much more advanced in Europe    For 1 and 2 there should be settings to disable buttons and/or to allow page changes. For right-handed people, we could for example do \\"Q\\" + right buttons to change pages, and for left-handed people \\"P\\" + left buttons.

Instances.input:
I liked the design and feel of this mouse. My computer was able to find and connect to it without too much trouble. It works in Windows XP, OS X, and Ubuntu. The problem I had with it right out of the box was that the middle button was too firm and wouldn't scroll very easily. It hasn't gotten looser over time either, I have to lick my finger to get any sort of friction and get it to move. Gross, I know. The side scrolling isn't the greatest feeling either.

After about a month of using it, another problem surfaced. After clicking the left mouse button once, sometimes my computer registers two or more clicks. This is really annoying when you're deleting email because it will delete the next email in line as well, maybe more depending on how many \\"clicks\\" are registered, though I only press it once. I tried everything to see if it would go away, but it hasn't. It's too bad to. It is a nice compact little mouse. I think I'm going to get rid of it and try the newer one that is basically the same design minus the presenter feature and exchanges the scroll wheel for a track ball. [...]

Update: I ended up working with Kensginton to get another mouse. They wouldn't go for an exchange for the track ball version, but they did replace this one for free. The exact same problems arose though, so the first one wasn't defective. And I never got to try that other one with the scroll ball. I just starting using crappy netbook mouses. Someone needs to come out with an updated, more capable version of this one.

This was a gift for my electronic savy husband, this is his story...."The first time I saw & had some hands-on with this Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 in the stores I thought it should be as good or better than our Samsung Galaxy 3 cellphones our family has. WRONG!!!  SOOOO WRONG!!! I soon after purchased one & started to use it on a regular bases 3 weeks in after getting cases, screen protect, accessories which is were all the problem started. Dont get me wrong it has some nice features & quality to it but the problems surpasses the nice things that it gives it would have you pulling out your hair. Example...You could be in the middle of something like surfing the web, filling out applicants, forms or sign up for something & it kicks you off the web back to the home screen where most time you have to re-enter you info, redo your research or start from scratch. It seems to happen if the tab has to load too much info from websites or takes too long to load. NOTE...I HAVE THE MAX INTERNET SPEED MONEY CAN BUY ALSO..Checked with Amazon to have something done, i just missed my return window but I can sell my $299 mint condition tab back to them for $140, not happening. Called up Samsung to have somthing done, only to be told even thou under warranty,  I wolud have pay to ship & returned back to me. Even if I do all this, they cant guarantee that they will fix or replace it if they deem it work properly, i would hope this is not a properly working device because I would have to say this Samsung product & customer service SINKS & Amazon isnt any better for selling it on there website. As much money we spend on these products & being under warranty, we shouldn't be spending anymore to have problem devices fixed or taken care of by the sellers & manufacturer. I'm very disappointed & regrets buying this product.  BUYERS BE AWARE & STAY AWAY..."

Instances.input: This has to be the worst power supply I've ever purchased.  I purchased two of these, one for my daughter's computer and the second for a backup. Instances.input:
Works like a dream. I use a Lenovo Z510 Laptop, wanted to get rid of the stock 5400rpm Hard drive because it was the only thing holding back the overall performance. I popped this bad boy in, booted from a windows 8 install disc and it fired up with ease.
tl;dr:
1. Its FAST. Boots in less than 10 seconds and programs are just as fast (64bit versions of photoshop and illustrator both open within 15 seconds or less)
2. Its quiet. The only thing I hear from my laptop now is the fan. But of course, its a Solid State so that's expected. I'm just not used to it.
3. Its lightweight and small and easy to install. Pops right in.

Overall I love this product. No problems whatsoever. We'll see if it stands the test of time though.

First - DO NOT expect too much from this system. It is definitely better than plastic twitters, but of course not hi-fi. Enough for TV, cartoons and background music. As an example - Solo 7 delivers much better sound (not hi-fi as well, though), but Solo costs 3 times more:)
For whom it may concern - diode is so bright so I can easily walk in the room, get a cup, make coffee:))) A simple workaround for that - a gum:)

I purchased this laptop at Best Buy after speaking with a few associates about my needs. I needed a laptop that would be capable of handling running a virtual machine. I wasn't even planning on running a bunch of programs at once on top of the VM, just the VM itself with a really old program I need for work. But that's besides the point now, since I couldn't get my program to work.
The reason I'm writing this review (I don't normally review things but I hate this thing so damn much, I had to) is because this laptop lags SO MUCH. I've tried watching Netflix on it; freezes constantly. If I'm using iTunes or even just scrolling on a web page, it lags! I'm assuming this powerful "quad core" was supposed to make it so that the computer is more powerful, but it seems that it's just slowing it down! I had read about people having trouble with the Windows 8 configuration but I set my computer so that it automatically bypasses that weird "touchscreen" screen from the beginning (someone told me that it would help decrease the lag), and it's still slow! I don't even do much on it ... Seriously, just web browsing and/or using iTunes or Amazon Music Player. The "craziest" thing I've tried to do on this computer is watch Netflix and that failed. Some of these other reviews don't seem to have the same problem that I have, so feel free to prove me wrong but in my opinion, seriously, don't buy this laptop. Waste of money.

I ordered this for my new Macbook Pro with Retina Display after some extensive searching on the internet. I'm pleased to say it fits perfectly over the keyboard, and is easy to place on and remove. The keys, as keys with any cover on them, feel a bit stiff, but not unbearably so. I think it's good as protection against dust, crumbs, and oil from your fingers, but I wouldn't feel safe with spills. In comparison with a different keyboard cover I ordered online, this one is less \\"sticky,\\" as the material is uniform, and does not have an adhesive-like material on the underside. I feel more \\"safe\\" from spills with the other cover on, yet I prefer this one, as it has a nice, simple look that complements the computer well. The other cover is larger, and extends over the well of the keyboard and sits directly next to the speakers. The backlight is a bit muted, but still shines nicely through the cover.

Also, it may just be me, but I find typing very quickly to be a bit difficult with the cover on. I wish it was a bit thinner, and had some \\"stickiness\\" just along its circumference to firmly secure it into place. It's hard to describe, but by \\"stickiness\\" I'm referring to a rubbery, shiny material I found on the underside of the different cover.

Overall it's a great cover, one that feels sturdier than the moshi cleargaurd. I feel comfortable taking the cover off and tossing it on my desk. It's not flimsy, and looks easy to clean. The low price makes it easy to replace if damaged or lost.
Good...no problems.

First, I couldn't find the on-off button - It is so small and dark tht I couldn't see it the first night I tried to use it.  Then I found the page for \\"set up\\" which told me how to re-register it in my name (it was a gift) but that was no icon to take me to that page.  I spent almost 15 minutes looking for the page.  A \\"click here\\" link would have been so easy to include...I haven't tried the other features (I do enjoy reading with it) and am almost afraid to begin because of anticipated frustration.  I have used the \\"Google\\" help on my iPhone, and the Help on my computer.  You could have made it much simpler to find and use the features.

After 1 year, had only 1 scratch on it (not sure how it happened, blame my family member who was using it), though I do use a magnetic flip cover as well.  Does not smear much and easy to clean with slightly damp cloth.
