Instances.input: I got my iPad Air a little over a year ago as a gift from my kids.  They included the Zagg Folio and it seemed pretty great!  Within 3 weeks though, there was a crack forming in the corner of my screen.  Called Apple immediately and the first question they asked was "did you put it in a case?"  They refused to fix it for less than $200.  I put tape on the screen and have used it without issue for another year until the Zagg, in one week, refused to charge and then the case just fell apart because microscopic screws had fallen out of the hinge and then bent the connections.  Fine.  I ordered another Zagg this week.  This time, a Zagg Keys Cover, because it closed like the Folio.  I just received that today and within half an hour of putting my ipad into the slot, there were glass slivers all over.  Yes, it's going back, but now it's impossible to use the ipad and be able to see through the cracks, which are slowly taking over the whole screen.  Will Apple fix this?  No.  Will Zagg replace my screen?  No.  What's another $200 anyway?!  Ha!  Does anybody have any other recommendations of keyboards that will not destroy the too-thin iPad Air screen?
output: I'm afraid to buy another Zagg

This equipment is living at the top of a sailboat mast in Georgia, serving at an access point for marina guests. It has handled multiple connections from various WiFi devices without any complaints.

Update after 6 months in service ************************************

Rock solid reliability as an access point and now reconfigured to serve as a client router.

My only complaint is that the admin log in password only stores 12 characters. This is an undocumented feature as far as I can tell. It is easy to enter a password longer than 12 characters when updating the log in password and then not be able to log in to the admin page. If this happens, try entering the first 12 characters of the password you created. Otherwise the only fix is to climb the mast and reset the device.

The card is okay, but does not meet the specifications of the card I originally ordered. What I wanted was the 660 Signature2 3073 FTW card. When I ordered that card, it stated that the card would ship in 2-4 weeks.  I waited and after five weeks, contacted Amazon.  I was told that the page clearly stated that the card shipped in two to three months! The shipping time had changed AFTER I ordered the card, but now I was being told I would have to wait the additional time for my card. After sparring with Amazon over this fiasco, I finally got them to ship me this card, the 660 Signature2 3072 LE and ship it in one business day. Now, the card I originally ordered is being shown as shipping in two to four weeks again, instead of the two to three months.  Somehow, Amazon cannot seem to get that card in stock and ship it in a timely manner. Anyway,the LE version of the card which I ultimately got and am reviewing here has specs which are a little lower than the FTW, but it is much better than my old GTX-650 Superclocked. With that card, Skyrim was locking up and crashing on a regular basis, with this GTX-660 Signature2 LE, there have been no lock ups or crashes. The Livescribe Smartpen is now my indispensable tool for meeting notes. I'm fairly fast "touch typist" on a keyboard, but slow on the smaller keyboards made for tablets. Using my 15-inch MacBook Pro at meetings works for me, but it takes up too much space on our table and seems generally in the way. So, I prefer using my iPad for note taking. The Livescribe Smartpen is the perfect answer. I was disappointed to discover that it doesn't work with my iPad 2, but it does work with my iPad Mini with Retina display and with my iPhone 5, and since I take those notes on a separate pad of special paper (included), tablet or phone size doesn't matter.

The pen includes access to an app that requires a $45-per-year subscription. The first year is included, but the pro version is not required, though some may wish to have its additional features. However, it seems to me that Livescribe could have developed its own proprietary app that does not cost an additional annual fee. I haven't tried the pen with other note-taking apps, though I suspect it will work just fine. The accuracy of this smartpen is amazing. The only times I've had a problem is when my own handwriting gets sloppy--and for many of us this may happen frequently, since we rarely write anymore. I'm happy to get this practice with my handwriting, which used to be quite good.

Those who occasionally wish to take notes directly on the screen of any tablet or smart phone (without a separate paper pad) might be interested in the Adonit Jot Script Fine-Point Stylus. It will work with a variety of note-taking apps.

The bottom line: PRO: This tool is very useful to those of us who, like me, need to take notes that remain as a digital record for later reference across devices or to send to colleagues. I end up with both a digital and a hardcopy version of my notes. CON: As cool and useful as it is, the Livescribe 3 seems quite expensive to me. I realize this may be a "scale of economy" issue, but one needs to assess whether there exists a real need for this tool.my" issue, but one needs to assess whether there exists a real need for this tool.
output: One of the best tablet tools available

Me and my wife are not new for e-book reading: we both have Sony PRS-505 readers for about 2 years reading both fiction and technical books on them (yes, technical converted from PDF looks very small on 6 inch screen but we got used to it).   However, technical documentation formatted for something like A4 becomes too small on 6inch making reading painful for eyes.  This was primary reason for considering Kindle DX. Second was availability of several computer magazines in digital format:  \\"System Administrator\\" and \\"Linux Format Russian Edition\\" for example.    So we got our Kindle DX Global Wireless about one month ago.  In general I am satisfied with this device:  - large screen makes technical documentation and books much easier to read  - computer magazines mentioned above are quite readable (yes, text is quite small sometimes, but landscape mode helps and we got used to small text reading on Sony PRS 505)    On the other hand, I could not say that device is perfect:  - PDF support is quite primitive, no TOC and no links. Dictionary does not work in PDF (except if word is typed directly)  - At least one of digital magazine issue (Linux Format Russian Edition, issue 128) locks up or reboot device on page 32. But it may be some formatting specifics since this page is rendered very slowly even on PC.  - No SD/MS memory card slot. I need to attach Kindle DX to PC to load new documents on it and clean up space at the same time plus archive them somewhere else.  - No russian fonts support. While DX is not our primary device for reading fiction and magazines seems to have embedded fonts, sometimes I would like to read fiction books in Russian in mobi format. So I had to install Unicode font hack for Russian texts properly displayed.  - Device with cover attached is quite bulky and heavy to hold it comfortably and it needs to be treated carefully due to large glass screen. But it is understandable and acceptable.    So I could conclude that device is worth its money andI am quite pleased with it.    Cheers!  Timofey Kutergin, Nizhny Novgorod, Russia

Instances.input:
This is a perfect fit for the common 20W/30W/50W high-power square LED panels you see here and on other sites. Mine came with screws and thermal paste for attaching the LED. It's a little bulky but not way out of proportion to the LED.

Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to provide enough heat dissipation for a 50W LED. It might be more suitable for a 20W or 30W. With the 50W, after a few minutes of continuous operation at full power, I'm seeing the temperature at the top surface of the heat sink (nearest the LED) at about 120C, and the temperature on the LED emitter surface at 140-150C. That's too hot - the LED really needs to stay below about 50C. I think I'm going to have to look into active cooling with a fan.
output: Good fit, but doesn't seem to be enough cooling for a 50W LED

Instances.input:
this is a great full HD monitor. The color is very rich, and the dynamic contrast ratio make it very pleasing for playing games and watching movies. It comes with 2 separate video input ports, VGA and DVI, and can be switched with the 1 and 2 buttons. It also has the added benefit of built-in speakers. While these speakers are not going to deliver theater quality sound when you play games or watch movies, for average use they are quite nice.

with that said, the monitor is not without flaws. the speaker volume can be controlled with the up and down buttons, however, not sure if it is common problem, or I received a bad unit, only the down button works directly but not the up button. what I meant is if I press the volume down button, a built-in menu would show up on the screen indicating the current volume level, and I can then adjust the volume with either the up or the down button; however, if I started out by pressing the up button, nothing would happen. So in order to increase the volume, I have to press down first, and then up.

Another inconvenience is in order to mute the speakers on the volume, it takes a few button presses because it can only be done using the built-in menu. So if I am enjoying music and then the phone rings, I would always fumble in order to turn off the music, and between the 1/2 and up/down buttons, it is hard to remember which button is exit, which is select, and which is to pick another menu entry.

Another inconvience is that the monitor doesn't come with a headset jack. So if I want to listen to music but don't want to disturb others, I would have to plug my headset directly to the computer (and the headset cord is usually not that long).
output: great monitor with a few minor flaws

I've been using this lap-top at work for about 4 months now. While it looks great it is deeply disappointing on two points:

1) Both the trackpad and keyboard responsiveness on this laptop is unbearably poor. If you touch type or want to avoid using a mouse, your throughput (speed) on a zenbook will suffer greatly. I can't over emphasize this enough...gestures (both keystrokes and touchpad) will be ignored by the system.

2) The display automatically dims itself at odd times (even when plugged in) stays that way.

If you are a web-surfer or using this recreationally, you'll likely not notice these issues. If you are a technical professional, the combination of a zenbook with windows 8 is a inexcusably poor showing...
output: Discount this review at your own peril

I usually don't write reviews, but if I can prevent someone else from wasting their money, it will be worth it. I bought this item back in December, and it has already stopped working (now the end of June). I am a current medical student, and take care of my purchases. My computer, which I have had since 2008 (as well as this now useless hard drive) always stay on my desk. My room has full A/C and the item has never been dropped, nor has it gotten wet.

I back up my Mac laptop every couple of weeks and today the process didn't work. The hard drive makes a "clicking" sound when I plug it in to any power source, and it no longer registers on my Macbook or my roommates PC. Looking online, this seems to be a sign of hard drive death. As a student I don't have $50 to spend every half year to keep my documents safe. I will never purchase another item from this company.

The keyboard is solid and the blue switches are really comfortable. Solid build quality. The aluminum body and red backlit keys look amazing on my desk.  If you're in the market for a mechanical keyboard, I'd definitely recommend it.

My issue is that this router loses it's security settings every time it's rebooted.  This happens a lot in my area because we have power outages a lot, so it powers back up, doesn't reload the security settings, and thus leaves a security hole in my home network.  Kind of a bad design in my opinion.  Doing a manual reset to the correct security settings is certainly possible, but seems to be finicky (it requires a login to a web-based utility) and usually takes me a few tries to get it working correctly.  Drives my wife and I crazy.    Instead of an integrated wireless/VoIP solution, I'll spend about the same money and get a better standalone wireless router and a better standalone VoIP adapter.  This one isn't worth your money.

Instances.input: In my never-ending quest to get a good keyboard portfolio for my iPad, I ordered this the other day.  Received the case last night, returned it this morning.  It's a good looking case, and it does hold the iPad very securely, but it had some key flaws that made it unworkable for me:    *Keyboard case does not hold the Apple keyboard securely, so it slips out each time you open the case.  A simply restraining strap would have solved that problem.    *It's difficult to put it into landscape mode, and once it's in there, the bottom tends to round so it rocks back and forth slightly -- irritating when you're trying to watch a movie!      *I did like the pouch at the top; finally, someplace to put the stylus!  Unfortunately, that wasn't enough to make up for the disappoitnments.    *Finally, in order to fit the keyboard, the case is about 1 - 1 1/2 inches longer than the iPad, which made it not fit in my netbook case... I should have seen that one coming, though.    Overall, I had really high hopes for this one, but it didn't live up to it.  My search continues!  (by the way, I'm aware that there are plenty of good keyboard portfolios out there... but not having a shift key on both sides of the keyboard is a deal killer for me... so... my own pickiness is killing me.  :))

I have done a lot of research on e-readers trying to pick out the right one for me.  After deciding to order the kindle, I am quite disappointed with the product I received.  My Kindle was sent to me with a defect in the screen, it has two small bubble-like darker spots on the top of the screen (about a combined circumference of 1cm).  I am not sure if the it is a manufacture defect, or if the kindle got damaged in shipping, either way I am not impressed. These spots don't overly affect the kindle's function, but it annoying to have bought a brand-new product and have it come with a defect.  I am currently debating whether I should return it and go with a different e-reader that I am actually able to buy in a store and see that there are no defects before purchasing.    In terms of the kindle's function, I don't feel that I can give a accurate assessment as I am slightly jaded in my opinion of the kindle now. Page turns are slow, but i hear they use to be worse.  I do recommend the MEDGE bright light, it does a good job (I actually haven't used it on my kindle, but it has been working well for my paper novel that I returned to using), I like that the light has 3 different brightness settings.    In the Wi-Fi-3G debate, I chose just the Wi-Fi.  I was quite torn about which model to order, but I am quite glad that I chose the Wi-Fi.  Thinking about it, I am always around Wi-Fi at home and work.  If I am going to travel, I will just load a couple of books before I leave, to last me the trip. I don't think the 3G is necessary unless you have no or limited access to Wi-Fi. So for my purposes for the kindle, the 3G just isn't worth it.   Hope this helps!

Instances.input:
I've been using Logitech products for years, they're normally quite reliable and have good functionality. I bought this mouse to work with my corporate laptop which travels with me daily and I spend at least 7+ hrs with the mouse per day so I'm a pretty intensive user. The precision and buttons are good on this mouse, especially for its size and price. The battery life is also great. A AA battery lasts me 3-6 months, no complaints there!
My issue is that the receiver went bad on my previous M305 so I bought this one as a replacement. When the new mouse is $20 and the receiver is $10 plus $5 shipping....you end up just buying another whole mouse when it dies. Mine was plugged into my laptop and stayed in there for several months with no issue....then all of a sudden it needed to be wiggled to work. It progressively got worse and worse until it didn't work anymore. The issue was not the USB on the laptop but rather the contacts within the little receiver. I can see if I plugged this in daily that the contacts may wear out, but not staying in one place.

I was a little concerned at first about not having a Retina display, but it looks great to me and if non-Retina keeps the cost down, then why pay extra for what I don't need. Instances.input: This iPad stand is perfect from every angle, literally. I can place my iPad in portrait or landscape; I can put my third generation iPad with Retina on this stand with it in its case (I have a smartcover and a backplate from Targus on my iPad) and it fits perfectly with room to spare, I'm not sure it would be able to accommodate an Otterbox defender series for the iPad 3, let alone the first generation, but it has ample room for the iPad with or without a case. I am very pleased with the quality, the durability and the overall heaviness of this stand. I have been complemented numerous times about this stand and asked where I got it from. It was shipped quickly and arrived in perfect condition, the box is in a triangular shape and was so cool that I put it on the shelf where I keep my MacBook and iPhone / iPad boxes of all my devices. Excellent stand, very durable and extremely pleased with my purchase.

(From a gamer's perspective)
Some important things you need to know about this mouse before purchasing:

-THIS MOUSE IS EXTREMELY LIGHT. If you like mice with some extra weight to them, this mouse is not for you.

-I have very small hands and this mouse fits very comfortably in them. Larger hands may pose a problem.

-The LED display is perfect. It's bright, but not so much that it is distracting. I'm writing this review in a fully lit room and can still see all the colors vividly.

-The side buttons are incredibly easy to access and press. As gamer, if you want buttons that are a bit harder to press, I would suggest another mouse. I, however, love how easy it is to click as my former mouse took too much commitment to hit the button in important team fights when clicks had to be fast and accurate.

-The clicking noise isn't too terribly loud, but I have had quieter versions in the past.

-The scroll wheel is very easy to move, but not so much that you may accidentally hit it.
output: If you like mice with some extra weight to them

Fits my Toshiba 15.4\\" laptop nicely and I can throw my iPad or Kindle in another one of the pockets. Holds laptop charger, mouse, business cards, note pad and assorted cables.

Addressing some slight negatives
- As another mentioned, the strap hooks do squeak a little. Not too bad, but if it's a big issue, put a little powdered graphite on the connector

- The laptop sleeve does have a velcro strap to hold it in tight, and it's annoying to hook/unhook. Personally, I just never hook it. A 15\\" laptop will fit snug enough that it's pretty hard to accidentally fall out. A smaller 13\\" laptop may be another issue. I've also debated cutting the strap out completely, but for now I'll leave it in.

This black leather case for my Kindle 7\\" HDX fits well. All of the openings - for the on/off switch, volume control, speakers - are all in the right places.

As Described. Thank you.
Nice cables NO complaint
Like it so far. Can't use my bank app. But so far everything else is fine. Well worth the cost.

Bottom line - This Laptop is excellent and, as of today, it doesn't get much better than this.

Cons -
- Only 1: The touchpad (built-in mouse) is a) centered; b) too large, That combination causes the cursor to jump to a random location, when I unavoidably rest the ball of my hand on the computer when typing. If the pad were off-center and to the left, and it were smaller, that would not be an issue.
- OK, maybe another, but much less important to me than the above issue. Bang & Olufsen should be ashamed of themselves. The sound on this machine? Meeh!

Pros -
- Takes only about 4 seconds at most to boot-up, and that's after I loaded up all of my programs.
- Handles apps/programs extremely well and fast, including my Dragon Medical voice recognition software. The latter was especially important for me, as no laptop I've used has been able to run the full version of Dragon Medical without issue. This laptop, though, runs the software flawlessly and quickly (the algorithms process immediately and through the sentences onto the screen without any delay. Faster, in fact, than my HP desktop hex-core with 16mb RAM).
- Came with 8.1 Pro already installed, even though the order said it would come with 8.0 Pro alongside a free upgrade. On that issue, then, Asus under-promised and over-delivered.
- The display is pretty incredible.

Additional info -
RAID 0: For whatever reason (I've heard that it has to do more with how Windows 8.1 handles RAID 0, on this computer anyway), my two 256 SD drives (512 total) came configured with RAID 0 using the following partitions:
- Drive C: labeled \\"OS\\" is 190 gb;
- Drive D: labeled \\"Data\\" is 265 gb.
- Three additional (hidden) partitions for Health & Recovery total 21 gb.
So, this is not a traditional RAID 0 striping method: at least not they way I'm used to seeing in other computers I've had configured with RAID 0. No issue for me, as a traditional RAID 0 would have given me a single active drive of 256 gb of effective space, while instead I have two active partitions totaling 455 gb of effective space.

Tech Support: I found tech support to be excellent. I realize that other reviewers had a different experience than me.
- First, locating the number to tech support was easy.
- Second, they answered the phone late at night.
- Third, the person who answered the phone was surprisingly knowledgeable, without having to transfer me to someone else.
- Fourth, after my questions were answered, upon learning that this was my first Windows 8 experience (coming from Windows 7 Ultimate), the tech support individual volunteered to show me some quick tips and tricks to minimize frustration and improve my learning curve.

Keyboard - I type about 150 WPM. No issue on this machine. Nothing weird about the keys or the configuration. One previous reviewer said something about the \\"Delete key\\" being odd. Not so on the computer that I was sent. The delete key is just like any other key on that top row. All good, all normal.

Wireless - Connects instantly - even when coming out of sleep mode.

Gaming - Not my area of expertise, as I'm not a serious computer gamer. I have an Addams Family Pinball machine at home that I've never tired of.

Aesthetics: Let's face it, the subtle-sapphire casing is drop dead gorgeous.

Weight - This machine is svelte and light. I only regret that I can't make that same claim.
output: Really, it doesn't get much better than this.  Not as of July 2014, anyway.

This headset just broke on me just now so I thought I'd make a review to warn other people about this product to NOT get it. I only tried putting it on and it snapped. You're better off paying extra for headsets that go over the top of your head instead the back of your neck.

I bought this from my local Fry's store and after a few hours of using, I noticed that headset pinches the top of your ears. I would generally have to move it in a different position because it would get uncomfortable when gaming and I don't even have a big head. Even my $7 mic (which broke after 4 years of use) from Wal-Mart lasted longer than this!

I would not recommend this product.

Pros:
-Good sound quality
-Good mic

I was looking for a case for a [[ASIN:B00829THO6 Seagate Backup Plus 1 TB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive STBU1000100 (Black)]] that I've recently bought. I wasn't looking for a neoprene sleeve but rather an actual clam shell type. I found many similar products by other brands but they where either more expensive or reviews mentioned that it did not fit my particular drive. So I went ahead with this DRIVE LOGIC brand based on reviews and price, and let me say I am very happy with it. Overall the case feels solid enough to protect my drive from accidental bumps or waist height falls. The external pouch is a made of neoprene which holds any extra cable you might need with your drive. The zipper is of a high quality type. Inside there is an elastic strap which holds the drive securely over the soft memory foam. And, on the opposite side there is a mesh pouch for a small cable (I do not recommend using this pouch for very large cables since the connector might scratch the drive). My only complain is that there is no memory foam on the lid side or a separator so if you where to press the case hard enough, the cable or the same lid will come into contact with the drive. But I am quite happy with my purchase, I highly recommend this case if you have a Seagate Backup Plus portable drive or any other of similar dimensions.

Pics uploaded.
output: Just what a portable drive needs.

I've had this mouse for almost six months now and it has not given me a single problem. Great for those games that have an extensive amount of keys to push. The software is great as well, easy to use and fun to play around with.
The Razor is fun and fast.   Great gaming mouse.   When used for regular browsing, I find it takes a little time  to git used to the the response of the mouse.

I only need a mouse for basic needs, and, to eliminate radio buttons (freeing up USB ports), I went with a bluetooth mouse. I love HP products and found this mouse, taking a chance after reading that most reviews were happy. I'm happy too.It works perfectly! So far, I have not needed to change the battery. I never shut it off and I use it everyday at work and at home. The only minor glitch is that it takes 1-2 seconds to wake up, so you're clicking randomly to do that if you've been away from your computer. Another is, you have to wait for your OS (W7 in my case) to find the mouse when loading. A radio operates the second the pointer appears on-screen, prior to logging in.  Those are very minor issues and probably would occur with any bluetooth mouse. I LOVE this mouse. I gave 4 stars to sensitivity and battery life for just those reasons. One last point, if you loose the connection with this mouse, sometimes, the sync button and/or turn it on/off does not work. I typically hibernate my computer, but have to restart to get it going - rarely does this happen. I still recommend this mouse!!!    Good luck

Although I really like my CM Storm Quickfire XT, it didn't seem to be a good option for a quiet office due to the clicky nature of the keys. After some research, I decided to try the Quiet Pro. Overall, I'm very pleased. The feel is very good, though the Quickfire's feel is a bit better. But the Quiet Pro is perfect for a quiet office... just slightly noisier than a membrane keyboard and MUCH quieter than the Quickfire. So a small reduction in feel for a major reduction in noise seems to be a very workable compromise.

When you hold it, the Quiet Pro has a similar solid feel to that of the Quickfire, which projects a quality image. Yes, the Quiet Pro isn't cheap, but it's one of a few keyboards that combines quiet operation with the great typing feel of mechanical switches.

BTW, I listened to several Youtube videos that demonstrated the level of noise of several different keyboards. Now that I have a Quiet Pro of my own, I have to say that it's quieter than most of the videos indicate.
output: Great keyboard... works well when quiet is needed.

I needed the ability to connect my laptop and desktop computers to one printer so that I would not have to download the very large software package that comes with the printer.  When I went to a local office supple retailer I was told it was not possible to connect two computers to through a hub or switch to a printer.  After doing some on line research I found the Belkin USB Switch.  It was extremely easly to hook up and reasonably priced[[ASIN:B000EJUCVE Belkin F1U200V 4-Port USB Switch]].  The lighted switch buttons makes it easy to keep track of which computer is connected to the printer.  One computer operates on Windows Visa and the other on Windows 7 and there is no conflict between the two and the switch in communicating with the printer.  I tried the networking sharing option on the computers and that was getting so complicated I just gave up trying.  The Belkin switch elimates trying to set up networking sharing and simlifies the ability to print documents from two computer to one printer without having to disconnect and reconnect each computer to the printer or to save what you need to print on a flash drive then installing it on the computer that is connected to the printer.

I wanted a headset for two reasons.
1. Audio input for hobby video projects (e.g., recording voice tracks, voice chat for collaborations on Skype)
2. Listening to music online without not bothering anyone else in the house

That's all I wanted, and this headset just got the job done.

I'm no audiophile, so I can't really comment on the sound. I have a fairly expensive stereo system in my room, so naturally the sound quality that this headset offers pales in comparison, but I wasn't looking for that. The sound quality is adequate, the recording quality is acceptable. The headset will pick up a lot of background noise when it records, but that can be easily remedied by a quick filter on audio software.

I think I bought the headset for $15 at Walmart. I've had this headset for about 3 years now, and it's also very important to me that this headset is durable. Other people in my house have sat on it, thrown it on the floor, and rolled over the cord with the chair, but it still works perfectly.

All in all, I'm very happy with my purchase. =D

I have had two kindle fires in the last four years and both have had problems with their charging outlets and chargers themselves. The first one i had lasted for about a year before it started being touchy with being charged. You would have to hold the charger at a specific angle to get it to stay charging and after a while it just stopped charging all together.

The next Kindle fire i received was from the company and it was to replace the first one due to the warranty i had. I still have this one and it still charges but a few months back or so it stopped charging and i checked the charger itself and it turned out it became too small of an appliance to produce a charge. So i had to start using a droid phone charger to actually get it to charge.

But despite all the charging defects the device holds up to its purpose and is very easy to use. It has great features and a crystal clear image produced on the screen. I would recommend this device to anyone but as long as they are fair warned about the charging defects that could occur.
output: Easy to Use But Defects Present

I would have given it 4.5 stars (if Amazon allowed) due to one odd glitch while recording (explanation in the cons) but since this is better than the Dazzle and the DVD player I used to record gameplay, I decided that a 5 star is a good rating for it!

Details
----------
Before I get into the pros and cons, I would like to explain packaging and such. I ordered this around mid-August for $159.99 and it arrived by USPS (mail) in a small cardboard box with Amazon tape on it. After removing the cardboard box, I took out the actual HD PVR 1212 box and was impressed with the firm packaging. They had put everything in the box just right so nothing could move around and possibly break. When I first used it, the quality was excellent and the performance was perfect!

Review
---------
Pros:
+Records up to 1080i (kind of a con but it is still clear)
+Software is really good.
+Unlike Dazzle you can still play on your television

Cons:
-Screen goes out randomly while recording. (Doesn't happen often)
-USB is a bit short, but the component cable's length makes up for it.
-No HDMI slots (there are HDMI to Component cables though so it is alright)

Conclusion
--------------
Excellent product, really glad I bought it! There is really no need to buy an expensive one such as the newer model (green LED light) and it is affordable.

If you want to see it in action, visit my YouTube channel: SAKsurvivors

First, I realize, the AMD supporters will rally and exclaim \\"The 290x wasn't supposed to complete with this card! It was supposed to complete with the 780!\\". That's great but thanks to Litecoin, and Bitcoin miners, the 290x is pretty much the same price as the 580 ti now. Price advantage gone.
Also AMD fan boys will exclaim how mantle has a bright future. That it alone, will make it a worthy by over Nvidia. Well the problem with that is simple, AMD had said it will work with Nvidia to license Mantle. So advantage in technology gone.
This card is just amazing, and the reviewers that say different are either, AMD fanboys, got unlucky and got a defective card (happens with any card) or they are bottlenecked by their CPU, don't get the performance and thinks it's the graphics card due to poor tech knowledge.
During the Elder Scrolls Online beta, my 290X, during large scale PVP battles, I am talking too many people to count on screen, got eaten alive, I'm talking dropping to 5 frame rates. Now, you will hear some people say differently, but it my case, it was horrible. There was also nothing wrong with the card, and my processor was overclocked to 4.7.
So, I used the 780ti, and let me say, the large scale PVP battles, were as smooth as butter over 80fps. I don't have a 144mhz monitor for nothing, I expect a silky, smooth look, with maxed out settings. The 780ti was able to do this, and the 290x got eaten alive.
Also there were other periods in the game, during PVE, where the 290x would struggle and drop frame rates again, random dips, with fog. The 780 ti never showed a slight drop in frame rates my whole play through. This is just one example, of many, where the 780ti is the best card.

So the choice is simple, you wait, and upgrade when Maxwell comes out in full force. Or you buy this right now. If you want the best game experience, this is the very best card you can buy.

Don't pay attention to the lack of availability of the 290x. That isn't a sign, it's a great card, or gamers are buying it like hotcakes. The bitcoin and litecoin miners, are buying all the cards out. To put into mining rigs.
All of that sums up to, 780ti is the best card money can buy right now, if price is not a concern.

If money is a concern, but you want a high end card? I still feel the 780, is a better choice over the 290x, even if the 290x's price wasn't inflated. It uses less power, runs much cooler, and is many times faster.
Please keep in mind, I have a Nvidia rig, and my brother has a AMD rig I built myself. I'm only going off what I have seen for myself. I'm a fan of Nvidia despite their infamous price gouging for a reason, the results in my personal experience. Those are different with people.
For instance my 8350 fx, I love it to death, and runs like a dream at 4.7mhz. I suffer no bottleneck either. Intel fanboys would disagree with me completely. Instances.input:
I purchased this laptop card together with a Netgear WGR614 Wireless 802.11g Router, and a Netgear WG121 Wireless 802.11g USB Adapter for my desktop PC. But after many hours of use this is how reality pans out as far as it's usefulness goes.

Here's my usage situation:
I have complimentary dsl internet provided by my neighbor across the street who let me plug the wireless router in to her connection, placing it in the window. I have the usb adapter on my desktop and the card in my laptop, both about 160ft from the router through two stucco walls.

Most days the WG511 laptop card is lucky to be getting 50% signal strength no matter where I move or place it in the room. (which is quite limited due to having to actually be able to use the keyboard on the laptop. Better signal is useless if you have to hold the laptop over your head to get it.)

At 50% to 80% signal strength the card limits the webs speed & is drasticly reduced to in my opinion, barely acceptable. (Although it is still better than dial up)

While the USB adapter in the same room almost always has 75% or above signal strength, occationally needing a minor turn or adjustment of less than an inch movement to dial it in to it's best. So in reality, most of the time when I don't want butt slow internet I have to unplug my USB adapter and use it instead of the poor performing WG511 laptop card.

Even when the WG511 is getting a useable signal, I found it is unstable because when you sit in front of the laptop and place your hands on the keyboard, (near the side card bus slots on my laptop) you using it, often also interfears with the signal. Get up and walk away and it returns to useable. (Alot of good that is) If you have a choice, & it matters, go with a usb adapter (on a usb cable) for best signal performance useability.

On the positive side:
The WG511 was simple enough to use and setup for me.
And it does perform well for transfering files between my desktop and laptop (or visaversa) when used in computer to computer \\"ADHOCK\\" mode. Although it's faster even then if I take the laptop across the srteet and do it there. The signal recieving capability of the WG511 is just kinda weak I guess. And it worsens the farther you get from the router with little option for adjustment or improvement.

If I had it to do all over again, I'd have just bought two USB adapters.Hope you find this info helpful to your situation
output: Netgear WG511 Wireless 802.11g PC Card - Ehh it's okay but not wonderful

Finally settled on this Kingwin external docking station with a Seagate drive for my imac, after trying a few others combos.    With a Western Digital Caviar Green 1 TB (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001IEZX3G) in a Bytecc T-202BK 2 slot docking station ([...]) I would get the \\"Device Removal\\" warning often and networked machines could not maintain a connection to the share.    I tried a Seagate 1TB 32MB SATA drive, and thought that was working, but after a couple of days I got the random \\"Device Removal\\" warnings. Wasn't as frequent as with the WD Caviar Green, though.    I tried the \\"SIIG Cool Dual SATA to USB 2.0\\" dock ([...]) with the Seagate drive and it worked fine, but the fan was too loud to have by the computer.    I finally switched to the Kingwin \\"EZ-Dock 2\\" dock ([...]) which doesn't have a fan, and it has worked fine so far.     Summary: Kingwin + Seagate seems like the winning combination for external SATA docks. The Bytecc SATA/USB external docking station has problems with Leopard. The WD Green drives might also have general problems, I'll see if I can test it with the Kingwin now. The WD Green did seem quieter than the Seagate.    Hoping the next iMac has an ESATA port. Wonder if a firewire instead of USB external dock would be faster. [yes, I bet it would be, but I can't find any docking stations like this that have firewire]
output: Works great, quieter than others. Possible problems with WD Caviar Green drives.

BUILT's Slim Cover is a well-made product that fits my Kindle Touch snugly and securely. While I did have a bit of a struggle with the elastic mesh corners, which are different than the straps I am used to, I now know that my Kindle isn't going anywhere. The grey pattern on a black background is a nice, subtle design and should appeal to many. The fabric has a nice feel, and even though it's squishy, the case feels like it would protect the Kindle from most impacts. Since I don't buy or use leather products, and many other non-fabric cases have a smell (this one doesn't), I'm glad that there's another option. The case is very light-weight and features an indent on the front where the strap fits securely when closed. Unfortunately, the hands-free design only works in landscape mode and not on portrait which is how I prefer to read. However, it worked quite well on my counter when I had to use it for a recipe and the silicone held perfectly fine. The ports and on/off button are easily accessible, so no problems there. For once I believe the price is reasonable, and unlike others I've come across, the quality is top-notch so I'd definitely recommend this Built case for your Kindle.
output: A nice, well-made case for your Kindle

I'm very happy with this device which I use to do my Time Machine backups on my MacBook Pro.  Just plug it in and walk away, when you come back, your computer is backed up and if you use a computer a lot and you aren't backing up regularly, you're making a mistake.  If you do regular backups, it is likely that there will come a time that you'll be really glad you do them.  This device makes it fast and easy.

The external quality materials are ver y good and resistent to shocks and bad weather conditions, however I expected it to be faster. I make the comparisons in time with cheaper pen drives, transferring small files, larger ones or a mix of them. However, the best ratio was 2:1 which I expected to be a higher ratio.
output: Good quality, speed not as expected

I can see why this is a good choice for artists or people taking notes as the clear disc gives you ample view of the screen and is very precise. But anytime you have to tap it just feels clunky. Contact with the screen is noticeably loud and unless you come down at the exact same angle every time you're going to hit with the edge first (which sometimes registers and sometimes doesn't) and get the telltale click as it flips to make flat contact.

The cap and inline clip seem clever at first but don't perform in a satisfactory manner. The cap doesn't cinch down when on the back and considering it sits the the crook of your thumb is very prone to spinning itself loose. The angle on the clip is much too sharp to use smoothly so inserting/removing the stylus from the edge of a pocket takes 2 or 3 seconds longer than it should.

As a sidenote the tip of mine bent after only a few days use then broke off completely when I tried to bend it back. I don't know if that was caused by the cap catching the disc or if I did something dumb but $20 for less than a week of slightly frustrating use was in no way worth it.
output: Great for artists, middling for everyday use.

Instances.input:
My husband gave me a Kindle Fire for Christmas last year. I had wanted a Kindle for some time, and knew that I would use it a lot, but I had no idea that I would use it so much. I have downloaded over 65 books, and I love that you can search for free kindle books in addition to the ones that I purchase. Color magazines are bright and easily read. I like to read at night before going to sleep. By lowering the brightness setting, I don't wake up my husband. Apps are easy to search, purchase, download, and use. I take my Kindle with me everywhere - it has a permanent place in my purse. Menial tasks like laundry and servicing my car are now great opportunities to catch up on books. I also have an iphone, and I find that I use my Kindle much more often. Highly recommend.

One complaint that many have is that the power button is on the bottom of the Kindle and it easy to accidentally shut the Fire off. This was also a problem for me at first, but now I know that its there and I never accidentally hit the button.

Not only would I recommend the Kindle Fire, but I have recommended it to several friends and family members. :)

We initially loved this Kindle (why I gave it 2 stars).  After about six months it started resetting itself and stopped charging.  It was replaced and soon after the replacement device started doing the same.  It was replaced numerous times.  One of the times it was shipped to an old address on my account and created a total mess- AFTER the tech confirmed the correct address.  The only way to charge the device was to turn it off and let it charge.  Still did not charge quickly and died very fast.
output: Constant Issues- Had to replace multiple times

I bought this with a bit of hesitation. I was mostly interested in the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 7in, but I wasn't quite ready to pay that much.  After using this tablet for a few hours, I really didn't like it and decided to return it and get the Galaxy Tab 4 instead.  * It does feel worth its cost -- that is, it feels cheap. * The screen has a really high reflective quality, to the point that on a black screen I saw myself as if I were looking into a mirror. It took a good amount of focus to look at what the screen was trying to display rather than my reflection. * I don't like how the 3 Android buttons (back, home, and task-switcher) are not actual buttons on the tablet but rather buttons on the screen * The memory (RAM) is a bit low * This isn't a very popular device so doesn't have a lot of resources about e.g. rooting it  Again, this is my opinion based on that I was looking to get a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4. I understand that might not be fair, but if anyone else is considering this over the Tab 4, I would definitely suggest just paying $100 more and getting what you really want.

Adding this to a computer is very straightforward if you have previous experience opening your box and adding a card.  You need to first look at your computer board to make sure you can install a PCI Express receiver slot that fits this adapter.  It took 5 minutes to install, and the setup using instructions included took an additional 5-10 minutes, moving very carefully and slowly.  Instructions are well executed.  Entire experience was painless and easy.  Reception is good from D-Link DIR-655 Extreme N wireless router, but not at the speed I was hoping for.  Traveling through a ceiling and one or two walls seems to prevent N speeds.  Pretty much always at 54 Mbs speed, not anywhere near the possible 300 Mbs advertised.  Using Comcast High Speed Internet cable connection, which has not been reliable in the last 1 month of installation.  Goes out every couple of days or so.  Needs to be unplugged from power, and reconnected and always comes back on.  My previous 3 year old Belkin G router almost NEVER lost its connection, which has caused me concern.  Only difference is that the G router was connected to a pc, and the N router was relocated and not connected to a pc.  I don't think that configuration should affect the connection. So, the DWA-556 adapter is working fine, when the router is working, except I cannot get the anticipated N speed of \\"up to 300 Mbs\\".
output: D-Link DWA-556 PCI Express N desktop adapter

WARNING: it does take two slots on the back of your computer. it only takes one pci express slot, but the card is so thick that it has 2 metal brackets instead of just one, where you connect your monitors.  also it is 11 inches long. make sure it will fit before buying.        current build:  Dell XPS 420  vista 32 bit home premium  3G of Ram  Intel quad core processor Q6600 @ 2.4GHz  XFX Radeon HD5870 1024mb DDR5  320 gb hard drive  Thermal take black widow 850w power supply

The main issues that I found with this product was the poor quality of the power supply and also the sd card.

The power supply only supplies the minimum amps, so with any fluctuation in the load you will have problems.

The SD card was advertised as a 4 GB and the one I received was 1 GB, which is not enough space to actually run an os with NOOBS, It created a lot of issues.

Apart from that I was pretty happy with the Raspberry Pi itself, and would purchase one again, but probably not from this seller. If the seller were to offer a replacement of the SD card with the proper advertised memory I would be much happier and give it a 4 star rating.
output: Raspberry Pi is great, the extras...not so great

I can see why many people have found themselves happy with this device, it is very responsive, allows you to do most things you can do with any other tablet, and is clearly made of quality parts.

Though there are few downsides, they were significant enough for me to warrant 2 stars. At this point, I simply find the device disappointing. My issues are as follows:
1) There is so little content. Seriously, aside from the kindle reading app and adobe, I doubt I've spent more than an hour (in total) on any available app.
2) Most recently I learned that pdf files cannot be downloaded from EPUB. I'm a graduates student who frequently uses research databases for multiple purposes. This is seriously the issue that sent me over the edge with this device. It's usefulness has since reduced to simply reading pdf files that I've downloaded on separate devices.

For not much more you can purchase a quality device that can accomplish much of what the Kindle fire can, and more.

I have been a loyal customer of Amazon's and I truly hope they give me a reason to keep this device before I can manage to upgrade to something better.

Instances.input: I have the original iPad and wireless keyboard and case. I recently got an iPad 2 and saw the upgraded wireless keyboard and case model. I jumped on it since it looked the same and had a \\"Shift\\" key on the right side of the keyboard.  Things I like:  The keyboard is good.   Shift key on the right side.  Caps lock indicator on the keyboard.  What I don't like:  The case and keyboard got bigger adding more bulk. Abound 1/2\\". It doesn't sound like much, but after using the original case it feels like a lot. (The iPad 2 is smaller than the iPad 1, so this is not a good feature)  The case is made of a slippery material. It's slipped out of my hand twice already. I don't like the way the material feels either. Kind of like wet fingers on a dry newspaper. *ick*  The ability to orientate is nice, but a pain when I'm trying to take notes. The iPad will move when writing, which can become a real annoyance.  The keyboard is made out of a hard plastic which doesn't give it much flexibility.   When the case is in the keyboard mode it doesn't have the same stability as the original case. It wobbles quite a bit when I use the touchscreen. It's not as good using it on my lap as the original case.  When I flip it around to put the iPad in reading mode it's very bulky. More so then the original case.  When I carry the case it feels awkward. Uneven somehow. It's hard to describe, but it was annoying.  All these issues were enough for me to go back to using the original case. With some strategic placement of thin bubble wrap, the original case will work just fine.  This case is actually very good and will work for most people. The keyboard is great and will let people whip up some really long emails.  If you think you can handle the bulk then I'd recommend you go for this case. You might like it.
Great combination

So at first I thought this was going to be great.  It was relatively easy for me to set up and quick.  Downloading and connections were fast.  But then we realized how buggy and disconnected this router was.  Have not had much issue with keeping connectivity with all our laptops, but smartphones and tablets had spotty Wi-Fi, at best.  Our devices would show great connections available, hook up to those connections, then promptly drop the Wi-Fi and say that none was available.  Only to have it show up again minutes later.  Keeps booting us off whatever we are working on.  I would suggest it's the phones or the tablets, since our laptops haven't experience many issues, but we can pick up Wi-Fi easily in other locations without dropping connections.  I have even tried contacting ASUS without getting any real help, other than to push this button or that one. Swapped out with another one, just to make sure it wasn't a defective router.  And, tried finding solutions on the Web (when I could keep a connection).  It has been too much of a headache to deal with.  Love the price, like the distance and speed (when it works), but wouldn't recommend this unless you are a super IT person who knows all the in's and out's of getting this to work.
output: Re-Reviewed after a router replacement and weeks of tweeking

Instances.input: upgraded from a kindle keyboard.  HUGE difference.  Love this new kindle.  The screen backlight is fantastic, haven't noticed any dim spots or yellowing like previously described. I have searched for many mechanical keyboards since I never had a mechanical keyboard. I chose this one because I always dreamed of typing a stiff keyboard that makes you feel you are typing a keyboard, not rubbing your hands on something and wasn't willing to spend my fortune on buying a keyboard that can cost more than $250 like Happy Hacking keyboard.    I was initially annoyed by some loose spring-like noises across modifier keys (backspace,enter, and two shift keys, fortunately not spacebar), but I guess they (supported by metal bars underneath) constructed differently from other 83 keys, so I understood that. And once I began to use the keyboard and I got used to it and noises from the modifier keys didn't to seem to bother me much as it did in the beginning.    So far, I like the feeling of typing: stiff and solid. WASD customer service was also prompt and recommended me to use grease to dampen noises from modifier keys. I know Cherry Clear is not common, but I've always wanted to have a stiffer keyboard and think many people who want a stiff keyboard with less noise than blue/green may like it.    Additionally, you can also switch back and forth from a Window to Mac computer easily; Alt becomes Command. Looking minimalistic, yet elegant along with controllable backlight doesn't hurt either.     A decent product.
output: not rubbing your hands on something and wasn't willing to spend my fortune on buying a keyboard that can cost more than $250 lik

Okay, so how many laptops can you find with a 15.6\\" screen, 1080p resolution, and a decent graphics chipset for under $1000? Not many! This laptop met all three of these needs for me. It came with enough RAM that I don't need to upgrade it until the 8GB of SODIMM modules become ridiculously cheap. The video chipset M96XT (AKA Radeon 4670) has pretty decent performance [...]. There are just way too many other laptops out there that have 1080p screens and an Intel GMA chipset, or low resolution 1280x800 screens with decent video chipsets. This laptop has both high resolution and a good chipset.    I recently took it to a LAN party to play Team Fortress 2 and it ran beautifully with all the settings turned up to high (60fps+). My last laptop died because the CFL backlight failed, with the LED backlight that should never be a problem. It's also super bright. I usually have it set to a quarter of the brightness and it's still pretty bright.    If you don't like the disk I/O speed (I think it's fine) you can always put a SSD in this as it's a standard SATA disk drive. There are USB ports on the left AND one eSATA/USB on the right, so you can use either one.    My laptop actually did have a gigabit network adapter (not the 10/100 listed here) but no jumbo frames support :( Typical with Broadcom.    Oh, and Windows 7, 64bit is amazing. You have the full 4GB of system memory and 1GB of video.    Cons?:  No scroll lock button, no pause/break button. Not sure how if there is some hidden Fn shortcut to get these. But who uses these really? There's no Fn num-pad, but really, I never used that. The wireless enable/disable switch is a capacitive touch button right above the keyboard. It's easy to accidentally hit it and turn the wireless off and not realize it.

I intended to use this as a permanent connection \\"to\\" my hub so that I don't have to connect the devices from work directly to the hub. That way the ports in the hub won't wear off. This product is perfect for that because of its price, the reviews and no shipping cost. In following up, the seller told me it is shipped from Hongkong which takes more than a month. That is how they can deliver without the shipping cost. I think they should have specified that.

So, I recommend that you get this from another vendor if you need it fast.
output: If you want it quick don't buy this if it the shipping is free

Instances.input: I have been a fan of Corsair for their high quality stuff for a long time, and the H80i is no exception. I was limited by space when choosing between this and the H100i, as the double long radiator wouldn't fit in my case, but I have no regrets buying this over other closed-loop water coolers. Previous to buying this, I was using the intel stock cooler on my i5-4670k (stock clock), and I saw temp reductions from 80-100C on BF3 to temps around 40-60C, which is an incredible improvement over the stock cooler. This comes with two of the SP-120L fans, and being a fan of the SP-120's I was happy to see this came with everything I needed to have it in push/pull. Aesthetically, this cooler looks great too, and I would recommend this to anyone not looking to spend a ton of money on a custom loop, but who want to see drastic temperature decreases on their cpu.

Don't be duped by the hype about expensive HDMI cables.  Nobody should spend more than this on an HDMI cable.  Search for CNET's "Why all HDMI cables are the same" articles.  Don't believe them?  Check Consumer Reports.  Any well-made High Speed (C2) HDMI cable will carry 1080p, 3D, 4K -- why do you think you need this? -- video (60Hz, 120Hz, 240Hz TV doesn't matter) and digital audio.  The HDMI TMDS standard uses two sets of wires to transmit the signal, one out of phase with the other.  The receiver inverts one set and combines it with the other, thereby cancelling any in-phase noise that is picked up along the cable, just as balanced audio cable does.  If you need extremely long cable, you may need heavier gauge cable.  If you move your components around frequently, you may want a more limp cable and you'll have to pay for it.  For the usual 6-10ft cable and components that stay put, spend your money on better components or more movies.
output: Well-made, durable cable does the job

Instances.input: The new technology advances which allow this chip to processes RAW files and no longer requires a router make this product very interesting; both issues were previously show-stoppers for me. While high on the cool list, it's not very high on my business priority list; every purchase decision is a business decision. My 4 star rating is based on what I believe this technology can provide both amateur and pro photographers.     Understand that these chips provide the ability for peer-to-peer communications with another Wi-Fi device, namely a computer.  This is Wi-Fi. Wi-Fi data transfer is by it's very nature v-e-r-y  s-l-o-w. If you want faster transfer rates you will have to shoot tethered, using copper wire to transfer data from camera to PC.  Do not expect this technology to do more than it is capable of or you will be very disappointed.  I would respectively argue in that case that the problem is not so much the product or technology as your expectations.    I would not advise attempting to use this technology as a main method to upload photographs to a PC under all circumstances, and I do fault the company for advertising it as a workflow replacement for card readers without acknowledging it won't work in extreme circumstances such as continuous shooting mode. I personally would -=NEVER=- want it to delete the files once uploaded as one reviewer suggested!  What if something went wrong with the wireless transfer?  This would only be a viable solution if the images were not important to me (which is pretty much never).    This tool would be extremely useful in situations such as when teaching classes and giving demos - take the image, have it upload while you're talking, and setup Adobe Lightroom to automatically pull it in and project on the wall for discussion purposes. It would work equally well in a studio or school setting (or whenever you're doing mass photography of a line of people) such as described by another poster who was shooting dance school kids.  Iassume the image capture rate is slow enough to allow reasonable data transfer.  It's a nice replacement to tethered shooting in some situations. It is NOT a single solution for all things.  Think before you buy.

Instances.input: We purchased our Netgear ReadyNAS 1100 2TB system on 12/15/2008 from Amazon.com - BTW: very smooth ordering, no issues there. After having one of my experienced programmers setup this equipment for automated backups, w/in a few days of running the ReadyNAS it's sending us daily automated messages indicating disk 4: \\"Reallocated sector count has increased in the last day.\\" Basically, one of our four 500GB Seagate disks (Western Digital are much more reliable) is going bad w/in a few days of cranking this thing on. After contacting Netgear, we were told the disk is going bad and that they would happily replace it. Here's the good stuff. Even though today is 1/20/09 and we purchased the thing on 12/15/08 (that's just over 30 days ago), we'll have to pay $20 to have Netgear ship us a new drive so that we can then, ship the old one back. Now, $20 is a drop in the hat with all the equipment and it doesn't buy a happy meal from Micky D's for a family, but since when does purchasing a close to $2000 piece of equipment cost a penny more to fix when the hunk of junk doesn't work w/in a few days of having it up and running? We also called Netgear prior to purchasing this unit and went to their presales area via telephone. None of our questions could be answered by their Indian speaking reps... like speaking with a zoo animal. All I can say is that Netgear is pathetically disappointing and I regret spending 4K on this ReadyNAS and their switches over the last month.

Apparently, and according to what is advertised as technical support, there are a number of additional provisions that apply before one can get installation assistance. These involve the date of manufacture of the router, the date of purchase of the router, and the time period that has elapsed since purchase. Prior to purchase of the product you are expected to ascertain the date of manufacture of the router. Routers manufactured too far in the past, according to NETGEAR protocol, could invalidate your chances of getting installation assistance. In that case, the installation assistance people will demand that you provide them with a copy of proof of purchase (i.e. the receipt) prior to them spending the 5 minutes helping you to set up your router. If you do not have sufficient proof of purchase you will be invited to purchase, for approximately the cost of the router, an assistance plan where these same people will supposedly help you install your router. The same applies to a time period (90 days was my case) between purchasing and attempting to set-up your router. A delay in installation may make their promise of installation assistance invalid, according to their protocols, which of course you will not know at the time of purchase.

Oh wait. The 90 day thing is in very very small print on the side of the box. The promise of installation assistance is in large print on the front of the box.

Good luck.
output: WARNING:  Technical support is worse than a joke

Instances.input:
I wish I did my homework before buying this. It is not worth returning either. It was too good to be true.
I would need to spend more money to hopefully get this too work for example additional: presets, driver software, and plug-ins written specifically for Adobe Premiere Pro.. Might as well get the right stuff. This adapter is useless. I might as well buy a laptop that is compliant.
Here is why: To capture DV video, your computer must be able to connect to a DV device using IEEE 1394 (FireWire/i.Link). For detailed instructions on connecting your device, see your device documentation. Adobe Premiere Pro's built-in DV support relies on DV support in the operating system. To provide DV support through their operating systems, Microsoft requires IEEE 1394 interfaces that are compliant with the OHCI specification. Many computers include OHCI-compliant IEEE 1394 ports on the computer, and almost all current IEEE 1394 cards are OHCI-compliant. IEEE 1394 interfaces that are not supported by the operating system require their own presets, driver software, and plug-ins written specifically for Adobe Premiere Pro. If your computer does not have a built-in IEEE 1394 interface, you can purchase a hardware capture card that provides the interface (see your computer's documentation).
output: Will not work, read the following specs needed............

Instances.input: I ordered an Apple MacBook Pro and AppleCare at the same time.  When my computer arrived, I went right online to register the AppleCare to my computer.  The registration screen first tells me that I have to send in my proof-of-purchase documents for both the AppleCare and my MacBook, then the screen freezes and I am not able to enter my personal information in order to find out what to do with those documents.  Tried that twice on two different computers, same problem.  Ended up having to call Apple.  Got through pretty quickly, but seems like the computer I ordered was in their system as being sold in November or December.  Who knows? Then was told I needed to fax in the docs. No access to scanner or fax and I was so angry at this point I was about to throw the whole lot in a box and send it back to them.  The CS agent, sensing my ire, agreed to let me take a picture of the documents and email them from my phone -- which I did and the computer was finally registered the next day.  Not sure I would do that again.  I bought the MacBook because I was sick of the rigamarole at Dell... I expected Apple to be 100% better.  Well, hey, I did get an English-speaking tech the first time I called and didn't have to ask to be transferred, but I would rather have not spent 2+ hours trying to do something that should have taken 5 minutes.  Very disappointed.

I like the aesthetics of this card reader, as it looks sleek on my desk, but there's honestly not much else good about it.  As is so typical with CF card readers, it's extremely difficult to get a CF card in the slot without bending the pins.  I have to keep a mini screwdriver on my desk now so that I can bend the pins back in an attempt not to damage the reader or my card.  It terrifies me just a little every time I upload.  The other issue is the magnetic stand - it does hold the reader at a practical angle, but it's not strong enough to do so securely.  Every time I brush it with my hand on my desk, it falls over.  I'm already thinking about replacing this with the Lexar Workflow slot-system card reader.

I have been using Ubiquiti products for quite some time.  These, like most of their products, deliver an incredible value and great performance for a low price.  That low price point comes at the expense of two things; support and serviceability.  They don't have replaceable radio cards like some other professional access points, but the total cost of one of these is cheaper than the average radio.  There is almost no real customer support, though their forums have a lot of great information.  I wouldn't recommend them to a user that has no knowledge of networking, or that would likely need to call someone to assist in setting these up.  For an experienced user, though, they are a great buy.  I have switched from using Cisco, Mikrotik, and others to using just these for most situations.  They don't handle roaming between AP's as seamlessly as Cisco, but they are 1/10th of the price.  They are suitable for everything but VOIP in this respect.  The controller is simple, but will handle most situations just fine.  I use them with multiple VLANs in many places with no issues.  I have also used them to provide WiFi coverage to the county fairgrounds with great success, and in a number of businesses.  They integrate well with their other Access Points, such as their UAP-outdoor and UAP-pro to provide a well-rounded solution suitable for most.  They are also rock solid, requiring no reboots further effort.  Set it and forget it.
output: Excellent performance for a great price

Instances.input: I found that this little stylus works very well on my Kindle Fire. I use it all the time and it makes it easier to make selection on the screen. Speaker choices for those with limited bookshelf or desk space continue to multiply and impress. These Logitech Z323 speakers (Black), from the Amazon Vine Program, look good on my mahogany desk or its matching credenza. The right speaker has the power/volume knob. Both the left and right speakers plug directly into the sub-woofer; no daisy-chaining here.

The sub-woofer is a compact cube, roughly 8\\"x 8\\" x 5\\". From its home under my desk it delivers rich bass without overpowering the satellite speakers. The satellite speakers stand just over 7\\" tall and are slightly over 3\\" deep. They have a nice curve and a shiny black finish on the business side of the speakers.

Hooking up everything is straightforward and easy. As indicated, they will handle Ipod like devices as well as devices using RCA cables.

But it is the sound that sells speakers. And these have great sound. Keeping in mind the size and intended use of the speakers,it is hard to find any fault with them. They easily fill my office space, about 12' x 18'ft with all the sound I would ever want in such a space. At half volume the speakers are outright loud. And they do not sound muddy. Highs and lows complement each other, the sound is spacious for such tiny speakers. They are great and I use them every day.

In an era where 5.1 and 7.1 are ubiquitous and where most homes seem to have some sort of a many speaker setup, it is refreshing to hear great sound from a small three piece set.

Instances.input:
I would consider myself a techy and have owned many devices; ipad (3rd gen), ipod touch, nexus s, galaxy nexus, galaxy tab 8.9, nexus 7, galaxy note 2 and now my galaxy note 8.

SIZE FACTOR (I wear a large sized glove)
I think the Note 8 has finally found the size sweet spot. The Note 8 is comfortable to hold in the portrait and landscape position. I found the galaxy 8.9 and especially the iPad to be awkward and cumbersome to hold. In the landscape position I found it difficult to cover the entire space of the iPad and tab 8.9. I did like the size of the nexus 7 but chose to sell mine on Glyde to upgrade to the note 8. The Note 8 feels very comfortable to hold despite it being plastic. I do not have a problem with plastic phones or tablets because I always put a screen cover and case on my devices to protect them.

SOFTWARE
I was not a fan of Samsung's earlier renditions of its Touchwiz interface on my galaxy tab (8.9). In fact, I still think that stock android is ideal but I just install the nova launcher app (see link below) and run that on top of Touchwiz which is the main reason to go with an android device, customization! I had toiled with the idea of purchasing the Note 8 because I thought it was overpriced. So after a trip to BB, I tried to force myself to get an iPad mini but still felt like I was using the same operating system I had on my iPod touch from 4 years ago. Apple might get better apps at first but they all migrate to Android eventually and Android has so many customization apps available it is hard to get bored. Apples control issues will be its undoing imo, and have severely limited what these devices are capable of doing. Does Samsung copy Apple? I think they do copy some aspects of Apple like the messaging app and touch keyboards looks eerily similar and the presence of a home button. I think Apple makes superior looking devices but Samsung and Android have superior software.

DISPLAY
This is another reason I chose the Note 8 instead of the iPad mini which I also think is the perfect size. I strongly considered waiting for a retina display to come out for the iPad mini but could not justify moving backwards to an iOS device. Also after I put a iPad retnia display next to the iPad mini I did not notice enough of a difference to justify the added bulk and expense that comes with the retina display. The display on the Note 8 is absolutely gorgeous! It is one of the most vibrant screens I have ever seen.

MISC
The s pen is an added bonus but the addition of an micro sd card slot that is not hidden inside the device is another reason not to overlook the Note 8. Both of these options make photo editing easier in my opinion. I have a micro sd card adapter in my camera and all I have to do is pop it in the Note 8 and photos are loaded into the gallery. The s pen is cool but I have not had enough time with the device to review its effectiveness. The multiscreen ability of the Note 8 is one of its better features. It has a limited amount of apps that function with the multi screen ability but all of the main ones like chrome browser, facebook, maps and all of the samsung apps function. I purchased the device at BB and made sure they price matched the Amazon price.
CONCLUSION
I can honestly say that I am completely happy with my purchase and despite the high price of the Note 8 I feel that I did not want to compromise with my tablet. The Galaxy Note 8 is by far the best tablet/phone I have owned so far.

Instances.input:
I've wanted a product like this to exist for more than a decade. I imagined a device like a Palm Pilot or maybe a little bigger that could connect to a computer to display low-priority or infrequently-changing information without taking up the \\"expensive\\" real estate of my main monitors.

That's pretty much what this device (and its class of devices) is, and if you approach it from that angle, you will be very pleased.

First off, and I'm sure others have said this, but take it seriously: DO NOT BUY THIS MONITOR FOR VIDEO, GAMES, OR ANYTHING ELSE THAT REQUIRES A LOT OF ON-SCREEN MOTION.

Basically, as long as you do not have a lot of the picture on the screen changing at any one time, it behaves like almost any monitor, but when a significant amount of the picture changes, you will lose frame rate and the image will be corrupted until it stabilizes.

With that out of the way:

PROS:
* Great for displaying web pages and documentation off of my laptop-- reference material I would otherwise want to print out.

* The picture is very crisp and the colors are vibrant.

* If expectations are right, price is a bargain.

* Supporting portrait and landscape makes it very flexible.

* If you've used multiple monitor setups in Windows before, this is just another monitor as far as Windows is concerned.

CONS:
* Form factor is oddly shaped (it's not flat in the back) and size of screen v. resolution is less than ideal (I would have preferred a smaller screen with the same resolution).

* Has needed two USB ports each place I've used it (though it claims it may only need both on older laptops).

* USB connection to monitor is in an awkward location under the kickstand-- a little tricky to plug in and can't be plugged in with the kickstand closed.

* In portrait mode, monitor is a little unstable on its kickstand.
output: Almost perfect for what it's designed for..

I'm impressed with the Dell Inspiron 660s computer (with Windows 8) which I recently purchased. This computer is both fast and physically compact compared to the computer that I previously owned (Dell XPS 410 with Windows Vista). Although the Windows 8 operating system interface is quite different from the Windows Vista interface, with the help of the online tutorial I was able to comfortably navigate the system within a relatively short time. I have. however, encountered a few inconveniences, as follows:
1. My Internet Service Provider (ISP) uses Post Office Protocol (POP) for my e-mail account. However, the Windows 8 e-mail application is incompatible with POP. WIndows 8 does support Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) and EAS; but my ISP doesn't support either of these protocols. Accordingly, I am not able to use Windows 8's sophisticated e-mail application unless I decide to change my ISP. In the interim I am able to access my e-mail account directly via my ISP's web page, and this works OK for now.
2. The documentation that comes with the Inspiron 660s is rather skimpy, consisting of a "Quick Start Guide' plus 'Warranty, Safety, and Regulatory Information". For the most part, the steps outlined in the 'Quick Start Guide' are very simple and sufficient to enable the user to get started quickly. But this document doesn't indicate where the CD eject button is located or how to insert/eject a CD (either via hardware or software using the mouse); I had to discover this information via trial and error.
Overall, though, I am enjoying my Dell Inspiron 660s---it's a powerful little machine!

I got the E4200 router to replace my aging WRT54GS router.  I may be going back to the old one!  The E4200 has issues - every few days it loses its Internet connection.  It seems the only way to recover from this is to shut down the cable modem for a few minutes and then start it back up.  After searching the Cisco forums I found that this is a very common problem with the E4200 which started with firmware version 1.0.02.  The latest version, 1.0.03 which I am running, still has the issue. According to posts on the forum, people are going back to firmware version 1.0.01 which apparently does not have this problem.  I guess I try that next before I start to look for a new router!  It's very disappointing that Cisco has not addressed the issue considering the number of people that have posted about it!

Instances.input: [[ASIN:B000FI73MA Kindle: Amazon's Wireless Reading Device]]    I love my Kindle, I just wish the battery lasted longer, but thank goodness it does warn you before the battery dies.  The ease of obtaining a new book to read is amazing and very fast.  The technology is very user friendly.  I have recommended this product to all my family and friends.

What amazed me the most about this kindle was the sound. It has really great quality sound. I can use this in a classroom and the speakers have enough power to be heard in each corner and clearly. My students were very surprised to be able to hear it in the back of the class. The picture quality is also a great feature of this version. It is an improvement over the previous generation. It is very crisp and clear. The device is lightweight enough to be held during a movie and not feel like a weight or get tiring. The processor is very fast compared to the smaller models. It loads webpages very quick and doesn't get bogged down. I'd you are looking for a new device then I would recommend any Kindle Fire tablet, if you are looking for one that can give you performance and portability then go with this one. Goodwill not be disappointed.
