I have Squaretrade on all my electronics and I had never had to use it on any of my purchases. A little over a year ago I bought a Samsung laptop which started having charger port issues, I opened a claim and the Squaretrade rep on the phone gave me my repair options, I chose to take the laptop to a local repair place. The laptop started slowing down and acting weird, thinking I had a virus I told the repair folks to clean it up while it was there. They discovered a bad hard drive and replaced it for me. I told Squaretrade what had occured and there was no problem, I was reimbursed in full for the whole repair. But ofcourse that wasn't the end of the story, got the newly repaired laptop and went about the tedious task of getting all the data and software back up when I tripped the cord and it yanked the laptop and hot tea spilled over the keyboard. Dead laptop, I was near being a wreck by the time I called Squaretrade,  didn't think they'd cover it but they sent a box out within two days and they tried to fix it but couldn't and they covered me for the whole amount. I detest changing laptops, the whole putting software back on, and bringing it back to where it's just right, but Squaretrade atleast made it less of a headache than it could have been.

Instances.input:
This monitor is beautiful. Then you start tweaking the settings and realize not so much. I received 2 monitors one being a replacement for the 1st cross shipped net day air - ridiculously easy with Amazon. Sadly that was my best experience with both of these monitors. The first seemed great but was not pacakaged with additional shipping buffer. The Styrofoam in the original case is this and the monitor seems to get pressure on it during shipping. The first monitor had two broken corners in the top where you could touch is gently and hear 'click, click' as well as a discoloration corner to corner in the top left. The second arrived with a speaker making a pop sound 2-3 times on bootup each time. None of my other speakers used with this exact same configuration have ever done this. The monitor is connected via its native displayport to displayport on my radeon 6850HD. There is no such cable that comes with this monitor even though the native output is via the displayport. Instead they provide you with a mini-display port to displayport cable, a DVI-D and HDMI wiith Ethernet. They also provide a green aux to aux cable for speaker output from a different source than the display output if needed.

The second monitor Seemed ok other than the speaker issue which was annoying but ok I can deal with the occasional pop sound during a boot. Nope, this carried onto youtube, Spotify, and any other music source I tried. Also, I started to dork with the settings under the speaker bar and saw that the grid display is showing a single blown pixel in the upper right quadrant. Amazingly enough the 1st monitor has this as well. I thought to myself wow what are the odds. *note* You do not see this "blown" pixel in normal display conditions. Only when switching to grid mode. THis is not part of an alignment technique to my knowledge and is seemingly defective engineering. You'd have to call ASUS but good luck. I have had a rather poor experience withthem trying to return the monitor. I presumed that this would be done by the manufacturer and not the vendor. That was 7 days of non-sense in which they said I would be liable for repairs when I clearly requested a cross ship as the warranty of the device suggests is available for the first 30 days. Finally I came to amazon who within 2 minutes of clicking had a cross ship next day air on the way. It is my fault for not trying amazon first but I work with pos systems and almost 99% of the time any RMA is done with the manufacturer and not the distribution company. Again my fault.

In a nutshell - 2 defective monitors both with blown pixels in the top right quadrant visible in grid view. One had pressure damage to the top left and right corners. The second had a bad speaker with the same blown pixel. Id try something else. AOC is similar and less expensive. Or suck it up and go with a 27" WQHL which is the route I will be taking upon return.

LOVE my new Kindle 3G!     No more hand cramps from holding a paperback or hardback book for or hours @ a time.  I can eat and read @ the same time, without devoting one hand to the book and the other to a fork!  I have had my kindle for less than 45 days now and have read 4 books so far! I recommend the kindle to any person 30 years and older that was brought up to value books and the pages that rest between the covers. I first wanted to protest this particular technology and wondered who would invent something that would lessen the value of a book, But I was wrong, and am willing to admit such! I did hours and months of research of other e-books available and believe I made the right choice.    The Kindle is a space saver for those of us that have thousands of books already and no space available on the many book cases in our homes. The selections available for many of the authors we like may not be there, but it's a perfect time to select a new writer to put under your belt and read something that you thought about reading before, but never did.    The designers have provided ample font selections for those of us that need large print, the ease of turning the page, a built in dictionary (would have preferred Webster), slender enough for a purse, brief case or shoulder bag. I take it everywhere! It's great what are you waiting for, go and get yours; you won't be disappointed.
The product delivered with in very short time.   The kindle was a gift for my friend and she was happy with the kindle.

Instances.input: I am not tech savvy, don't have either an e-reader or another tablet, but having been wanting an affordable tablet for months now, so the Fire is perfect for me.  I am very tired of hoisting my laptop and bag over my shoulder to go down to Starbucks for some relaxing web-browsing away from the furkids on the weekends.  The 7 inch Fire goes right into my purse and it is very easy to handle in a sitting position.  I use the landscape view, so the power button was never an issue for me.  Don't need the memory card, can't possibly read 1,000 books in my lifetime (I'm 53), so that isn't an issue either.    No children, so no worries abt the password or privacy issues.  Dogs cannot use a credit card, another plus of four-legged creatures.   I hate retail shopping and do alot of buying over Amazon whenever I can.  For example, I buy my dogs all their bullysticks and dental chews from Amazon, it's much cheaper.  Already a prime member so it's a no-brainer to get a Fire.    I fly only 2-3 times a year, but now when I leave for x-mas, I will download a video the day before and have it for the flight.  Also my new Stepen King novel.  Will read and watch a few movies while at my mom's house, where there is no internet...just hop down to the coffee shop and download a few more if I run out.  Regarding the airlines, to me it's no biggie to rent...the airlines charge you 5 bucks to watch one of their mediocre movies on their inflight tablets, so I come out ahead any way you look at it.  And I won't do it often enough that it will become an expensive habit.  The picture is beautiful.  I'm using the cream background, larger margin and font on the e-reader, and am having no problems with eyestrain, but I only read a few pages at night before I go to bed.    This device may not be for customers who demand marathon and varied use from their tablet, but for the casual user, as a source of entertainment, it can't be beat.  Halleluia, or however you spell it.

I purchased this mouse pad in a combo deal along with the Mionix Naos 3200. I received both items exactly 3 days ago. I was very impressed with both the mouse pad and the Naos 3200 upon first use, and I am still extremely happy with the performance of the Naos 3200. However, after just 3 days of use the Sargas 320's microfiber top is already separating from the rubber base below. This clearly occurs because, unlike some mouse pads, the Sargas 320's top layer is not sewn around the perimeter to the bottom layer, instead relying on the adhesive substance between the two layers. This is insufficient to keep the mouse pad together. Overtime, this separation will worsen and catch on my wrist whenever I try to use this product (it does so already).

Despite the durability issues, the glide of this mouse pad is very good. it is topped with a silky microfiber material which allows for a very smooth glide. The mouse pad itself is pretty thin (around 3mm tall)and lacks the rigidity of most any other mouse pad I have used so far (it will lay flat because it is so limp). The rubber bottom sufficiently holds the mouse pad in place on my plastic desk, and if it weren't for the fact that this pad is literally falling after just a few hours of use, this product would be a 4 or even 5 star one.

I brought these speakers along with a Soundblaster Audigy 2 card to replace two HP Pavilion Polk speakers. I am not disappointed with this purchase. Not only are they affordable for a 6-speaker system, but they sound amazing too. I'm not an audiophile or anything like that, so I don't know the nitty gritty details, but I trust my ears and they proved to be a huge improvement.
It took me a while to connect these things to the Audigy 2. Unfortunately the card's plugs arent color-coordinated with the speaker's cables, so it was somewhat of a challenge, but once I got it right I enjoyed listening to music a lot more than before.
These are surround-sound speakers. Unfortunately my setup doesn't allow me to place the rear speakers behind me, so I opted to put them on the side instead. Amazingly, it still sounds like surround sound.
The subwoofer is a welcome bonus too. I live in an apartment building, so I have to set the volume pretty low, but I can still feel the vibrations underneath my feet. I haven't tried it at full power, but I wager it would shake the wall on the opposite side of the room. It's incredible how much realism a subwoofer adds to a listening experience, especially with DVD movies.
I agree with the reviewer who said the blue light on the center speaker is annoying. If you like to watch movies or play games in a dark environment and the thing is right in front of your eyes, it distracts from the monitor. It's not a big deal though, I just put some black tape over it and I got back to enjoying the multimedia.
DVD's really sound good on these speakers. You can actually hear sound move from one speaker to another and cycle, depending on the movie. I've never had that experience with two speakers. In fact, you can hear sounds you've never heard before too! It's really amazing.
Games also sound great, though not all support six speaker systems. Most support four, and you can hear the difference, but the sound is still better than with two speakers. It's a fantastic consolation that games like GTA 3 and Vice City sound absolutely fabulous now. It actually feels like you have a sound system in the computer-generated car.
Now, they're not THX certified, as if I know what that means. The only place I've heard THX is in a movie theater and even then, I wouldn't want to get that at home. It would bother too many people to turn it up that loud. At least it gives me an incentive to go to the movies more often. Nevertheless, if you're not an audiophile and you're looking for an affordable upgrade that will make your world rock, literally and metaphorically, these speakers are a good solution.with two speakers. Instances.input: Love the speed USB 3.0 gets for compatible devices. Maybe the manufacturer's will start building their computers with only USB 3.0's! EAsy to set up and use.

I am really pleased with this latest version of ReadyNAS. Having read a few of the early reviews I must say I was a bit nervous about the experience ahead of me. There seems to be an odd divide in the reviews I could find. Press reviews seem universally positive and tend to point out the numerous advanced features that you can only get from ReadyNAS. The user reviews are more mixed- 80% are consistent with the professional reviews and gush about the amazing new features while the other 20% were either testing a really early version of the operating system or maybe they just have an axe to grind.

Anyway, set-up could not have been easier. With the ReadyCLOUD web portal, after powering up the device and connecting to my router, it was just a matter of clicking few buttons and I was up and running. Although the local admin page offers deeper functionality, this ReadyCLOUD offering is slick as I can now access my files and even create new shares from any browser, anywhere. As the local admin and ReadyCLOUD look almost identical, the only issue I encountered was keeping track of whether I was accessing my data locally or through the cloud.

I had several years' worth of photos, videos and documents that I immediately moved to the device from a collection of PC's and USB drives. Transfers were zippy and I couldn't believe how little noise there was considering the box was performing under a fair amount of stress.

For most of my data I went ahead and enabled to automatic protection through the cool snapshot feature. So far, I've only had to restore one file, but this feature could be a lifesaver if I ever accidentally delete the wrong file. It feels good knowing I can go back to file versions from any point-in-time. Having the files automatically protected against viruses is another bonus. I purchased a NAS because I wanted my data protected against any kind of device or drive failure. Between the automatic RAID protection, the snapshots andeven the anti-virus I have never felt more confident about the safety of my files.

Aside from being a stable repository for my files, I use the ReadyNAS to stream media throughout my house. We have been using the built-in PLEX server and there have been no problems watching video files on the TV, laptops or mobile devices. Even better, my wife and I can watch different programs at the same time.

I have only downloaded one app for the device, but I was shocked at how many were available and how easy they were to find and download.

I was very much on the fence about investing in a NAS, but this ReadyNAS product has exceeded my expectations in every way.

Instances.input:
I bought this for my early 2011 macbook pro and mid 2009 mbp and it works great but there are some steps to getting the drive up to date and working.
**UPDATE** works great with Mountain Lion 10.8

Here are some instructions on what to do for people who want to know about making this drive work with the mbp.

0. Backup all data you want from your old drive because you wont have it anymore after you remove it
1. take out old drive and replace with your new SSD (look for youtube videos on how to do this)
2. power on the laptop while holding the \\"option\\" key
3. connect the the internet and choose internet recovery
4. when you get into the install screen open disk utilities and select the drive
5. create a new (1 partition) and format your new drive as Mac OS Journaled
6. close disk utility and install Lion onto the drive

ok great now your drive is working and the OS is installed, but the drive is NOT updated to the latest firmware (helps to drive work at its best)
(just a warning this is more advanced)

7. goto OCZ's website for the latest vertex 4 firmware (please read all their instructions on how to update, below is my self-experienced abridged version)
8. download their OCZ Tools utility and burn it to a disk (dvd or CD, i used toast to do this but you can use disk utility also-> for help google \\"burn iso image osx\\")
9. restart computer holding option key again and choose to boot from the disk
10. wait for computer to reboot, your touchpad and Wifi wont work... so you need to plug in a USB mouse and connect via ethernet (MUST have net for this to work)
11. click the mac update tool on the bottom bar
12. make sure it is asking to update the vertex 4 (will say y/n)
13. say yes to setting to AHCI and do a normal update
14. after it is done it will ask you to press \\"S\\" and repeat the process 1 time as of 6/26/12 (start back @ step 9)
15. if everything is updated and everything is clear on being completed, shutdown the tool and restart the computer normally
16. YOU DID IT!!! easy right? enjoy instant loads and a now much cooler (temp.) and nearly silent laptop

The product itself is a 5 star product, just the installing and updating is not easy for a casual user hence the -1 starng is updated and everything is clear on being completed, shutdown the tool and restart the computer normally
16. YOU DID IT!!! easy right? enjoy instant loads and a now much cooler (temp.) and nearly silent laptop

The product itself is a 5 star product, just the installing and updating is not easy for a casual user hence the -1 star
output: Great for macbook pro w/Lion and ML!

We buy this mouse for every new computer workstation at the office, and I purchased one myself after getting used to it. Over time, the middle click started to fail in the order we purchased them. Then mine failed. It is annoying because all our employees are used to middle clicking to open new tabs in browser windows.

There are two workarounds

1) Hold down the middle button, with a little extra force, until it registers
2) Clean it. Logitech says it voids the warranty but I did it anyway. I'm terrible with my hands but a youtube video showed how to take apart this exact model, clean it, and it is good as new.

I bought this mouse a few years ago in-store. I loved it then; I love it now. I have this thing for cool things: Tron, sportcar Infinitis, and Nissan Z's. Well, this is the coolest mouse I have ever had/seen. In fact it matches my laptop, well, too; both are silver. Despite that, though, I would not deny the mouse if my laptop was black or another color. The silver is slick, and each of the colors are each really cool, appealing, vibrant, clear, and glowing. As in I don't tire in looking at them. The particular shades are pleasing. It's like whoever made it was me-- or had me in mind. Since it's perfectly cool just rotating colors, being able to control it to stay on a single color is a neat bonus feature. It is small and portable. It's also the perfect size for me--I have small hands. This mouse makes me happy. Every time I look at it I commend myself for my incredibly smart purchase, and for a good price, too. If it was for twice the price I would have been happy with my buy. I would say it couldn't have gotten better. It is the best mouse I could have chanced upon and it far exceeds any expectations I could have had.
Performance-wise, it is faultless. The clicks are quiet and the scrolling wheel simply works well, too. The laser actually impressively works on about any surface. It has a retractable cord which can be fixed at any length; this part might take a little practice. It doesn't make a difference, though, to how so very, very conveniently cool it is and all in all there is nothing whatever wrong with it. I'm glad I own it and I would be significantly, significantly disappointed if it was lost or damaged (what a despairing thought!).
Basically, I recommend this mouse. Its performance is to be relied upon, and its appearance exceeds all. If you like glowing, cool, silvery things, you will like it.

Instances.input: If you have to move a lot of data between computers or wish to carry a lot of software or music or movies or backups around in your pocket (and protect it with hardware-based encryption), this may be the drive for you.  It's small and light enough to fit in your shirt pocket (though I wouldn't recommend that) and it has a large, 500GB capacity!  The drive gets its power through the USB cable, so there is no separate power cable to carry or plug in - only a small USB cable (which is included).  Just plug the drive into your laptop or desktop computer's USB port, install the included encryption driver and go.  About the only thing not impressive about this drive is that it's not the fastest drive in the world - its speed is limited by both the USB 2.0 connection and the slow, low RPM (low power) drive itself - so the high capacity and portability has some trade-offs.  The included USB cable is really short (18\\"), so if you need a bit more length, you'll have to purchase a separate USB to Micro USB cable.  Finally, just plugging the drive in prompts Windows to request for the installation of Western Digital's SES device driver to your PC.  The SES device driver handles the drive's optional 256-bit hardware encryption.  I have no use for the encryption, so I didn't wish to install the SES driver.  Unfortunately, if you do that, you'll be prompted to install the driver whenever you plug the drive in or restart your system.  I never allowed it to install and I don't want it to install so I disabled the SES device in Windows' device manager to stop the prompts.  The average person may not know how to do that.  All in all, if you can live with the relatively low speed, or if you want a portable drive with encrypted data, or you need to move or carry a lot of data or backups around, especially for a laptop, this may be the drive for you.
output: Large capacity (for 2010), ultra portable hard drive

Instances.input: Before I actually review the product, I should mention that I bought this 12.1 inch laptop sleeve for my 11.6 inch laptop (Alienware M11x R2) knowing that my laptop is a little big for an 11.6 inch. I was still a little worried when I compared the dimensions of the laptop to the product dimensions listed on the Amazon product page. The Alienware M11x is 11.25 x 9.19 x 1.29 inches (LxWxH). For comparison a 13.3 inch MacBook is around 12.78 x 8.92 x 1.08 (LxWxH), which shows that this 11.6 inch laptop while not as long and rectangular is actually a little wider (from trackpad side to hinge side) than even an average 13.3 inch, making it a little more squarer even though the screen is 16:9 widescreen. This is what worried me.    When I compared the dimensions though...  The Alienware M11x is 11.25 x 9.19 x 1.29 inches (LxWxH).  And the description on Amazon says the \\"Product Dimensions\\" are 12.4 x 9.4 x 1.5 inches (LxWxH).    And yes, I realize that this is the PRODUCT dimensions as in the dimensions of the exterior, NOT what it can fit inside, which is why I was worried that it still might not be big enough.    However it came today, and surprisingly my laptop just barely fits, it's pretty snug right now but from what I've read in these reviews, if it fits a little tight it should loosen up a bit the more you use it, since the neoprene material is somewhat stretchy. Hopefully, this will happen for mine over the next few weeks.    After looking at the packaging though, it DOES have the \\"Max Dimensions\\" listed that WERE NOT LISTED on the Amazon page, so here they are for those of you who aren't sure if your laptop will fit: 11.8 x 8.7 x 1.5 inches (LxWxH). As I mentioned, though, my laptop is just under the max length and height but is actually .5 inches too wide (9.19 vs 8.7 inches) but it barely fits, still I wouldn't recommend this if you laptop is 9 inches wide or wider though, I'd say that is the absolute max, otherwise get the 13.3 version of this case. Also it'sworth mentioning that the packaging says \\" 10-12.1\\" Netbooks & Laptops \\" which makes it sounds more like most laptops from 10 inch up to 12.1 inch max and less like this sleeve is made specifically for 12.1 inch laptops, which sort of makes sense, just thought I'd mention it.    As for the sleeve itself though, since it's just barely big enough for my laptop, I seriously doubt I could fit the power adapter or a wireless mouse in the outer pocket, which isn't a problem for me though because I bought this mostly so I can put the laptop in my backpack without having to worry about it getting damaged, and on the off chance I really need to take the power adapter I would probably put it in my bag separately anyways. I can definitely see myself using that extra pocket for some SD cards though or my USB cable/charger for my phone, so not totally useless. I should mention though, that this is the only extra pocket, so if you are looking to carry a bunch of stuff around with you in this thing, you might want to look elsewhere. And as for the \\"smell\\" that some people mentioned, I don't think it's necessarily a bad smell, I actually kind of like the smell, I'd compare it to the smell of the inside of a brand new pair shoes. And at least for mine, it's not as noticeable as some have mentioned, even if I put my nose up to it from 12 inches away I can't smell anything.    Overall, I really like it, I gave it 5 stars because it does exactly what it's supposed to, and at a decent price. I am satisfied, and I would recommend this to someone looking for a little more protection when carrying their laptop around with them in a bag or backpack, or if you just want to use the handles, and aren't necessarily looking for an extra full on bag to carry around just for a laptop. However, make sure to check your laptop's dimensions and compare it to the \\"max dimensions\\" that I listed to see if this sleeve will be big enough for you.
output: Absolutely love it, but beware: max laptop dimensions according to the packaging are 11.8 x 8.7 x 1.5 inches.

Instances.input:
My 2-star rating is because I couldn't get this 5.1 amp Trio Pace to work in my car. The charger has a tiny blue light to one side of the three USB ports. That blue light came on, so I presume juice was getting through. But I tried my Galaxy S5 phone on all three of the USB ports, and none of them worked. The product description on this page states that this charger works for that phone.

I received this product free in exchange for a review. I contacted the seller to say my product didn't work, but haven't heard back. I do not know enough about electronics to posit what may be wrong, so I'll leave it at that. If I hear back from the seller, I will revise my review on this point.

On another note, I didn't think that this was the most conveniently shaped car charger. My car charger port is recessed on the lower dash, The lower "arm" of the Trio Pace 5.1 is only 1 5/8" long, which wasn't long enough to stick out of the recessed space. This isn't necessarily bad, but it just means its not as convenient as car chargers with longer arms. If your charger port is more conveniently located, you won't have that problem. The arm itself is 5/8" x 1" wide.

I received a free sample for review.

Happy Reader
output: Size/Shape Not Optimum and Wouldn't Work For My Phone

Instances.input: Exactly what we needed!

Since March of 2010 Pogoplug users have been asking the company to modify the the logon script for the website so it would allow interfacing with two very popular password managers: 1Password and Lastpass. They company has failed to respond to this request. Instead the company choses to edit the posts of their users when they complain about the issue instead of responding with something constructive like \\"we're working on it,\\" or \\"there's a technical reason why this can't be done right now.\\"    This is only one example. Users have issued requests for changes in file and folder permissions to no avail.    The shame about this is the product is pretty neat. It really allows you to build an economical cloud using your own high-speed Internet. For me, however, the inaction of the company ruined the user experience.    I highly recommend looking into a service like Memopal, which offers economical cloud-based file storage and sharing instead of Pogoplug.
output: Has potential, but the company is not responsive to customer needs.

I have purchased almost a dozen NAS devices for SAN backups and most of them have been quite solid. For disaster recovery purposes, I have my SAN contents copied to two NAS units per volume for failover, with one set of NAS units always off-site.    This Sonnet looked like a good buy and I, too, was happy with the look. With five 750GB SATA hard drives mine is a 3TB solution using disk striping and keeping one drive as a spare. One issue with this unit is that, while it uses a multipath 3124 chip, only on Windows Server 2003 can you implement software based RAID-5. On XP you are limited to disk striping or mirroring using Disk Manager in Windows after your've made these PASS-THRU disks.    The biggest problem with this unit, however, is the poorly designed drive caddies and back-plane. These disks are removable, but they shouldn't be since the connection to the backplane is so 'iffy'. In fact, if I move this unit from one location to another I have to always re-seat one or more drives before the SATA card on the server or workstation can see it.    Unless you are willing to play with the drives, popping them in and out until you get a good connection with the backplane, I would pass on this unit. Much more reliable units are the MicroNet SR4 (4TB) SATA units available for under $800. They can take a lot more handling because the drives are integral to the unit. This means if a drive fails you live with it or send the entire unit back for repair, but I've not see any issues with these, especially if you use RAID-5 with the SilImage Raid program included. An array on these units configured as RAID-5 is recognized by Windows Server as a single volume which is what you want.    Also recommended are the Sans Digital TowerRAID TR5M-B units. They do have drive caddies, but are much better built. The trhoughput on these is much better than the earlier units Sans Digital put out.
output: A nice looking external SATA enclosure with a fatal flaw - poor internals

Good:

The screen is really great. We watch TVs and movies on it all the time. Apart from the size it is way better image wise and more convenient to use than a normal TV. If we knew ahead of time that this would replace our TV, we would have gotten the 27in in a heartbeat. We'll probably cancel our cable TV subscription because of it.

Pretty decent speakers: I was thinking I had to hook this up to a good speaker system. I was surprised that the speakers they come with are more than adequate for me. They're slightly better than our LCD TVs.

Easy to use: with App Store and OSX, there's not much you need to do with Macs aside from installing more memory and general maintenance.

Easy to move around: Light with a good form factor.

Easy to upgrade memory. I recommend upgrading it to the full 16 GB right away for speed. If you don't know how, just look for videos on Youtube. That's what I did.

Price: This is a way better deal than the 27in models in terms of pure price and speed. However I really want that extra 6 inches for the screen now, and I would have liked a larger hard drive.

Fast: Assuming you have installed the extra memory (Crucial is a great dependable place to buy it from), this computer is pretty fast. The quad core processor is more than enough for my needs. I can work and play video games from Valve's Steam store and Apple's App Store.

This is something most people already know about, but since this misconception is still out there, I want to add that - Yes, you can use 2 button mice. In fact Mac OS X has allowed the use of a 2nd mouse button (right click) for years now.

Windows works fine on it. I use both VM Ware and Boot Camp for Windows games (though more and more games are coming out for the Mac ever since they switched to Intel chips).

Apple stores provide training. They have both free classes and one on one training for $100 / year. This is really great if you suck at computers. If you're the family tech support person, this is also really really awesome. Ever since I converted my family to using Apple, I've had a lot less tech support calls from my family. Everyone wins.

Beautiful: It's a nice sleek looking product.

Bad:

It is extremely hard to upgrade the hard drive. Too many parts to take apart. I highly recommend buying an iMac with as much space as you'll need. Yes it has a thunderbolt port, but it's new technology and as of right now there aren't many good external hard drives with this technology at a good price. As of today, it is hard to find anything decent below four hundred.

Unfortunately there's another myth I'm going to have to destroy: \\"Macs are virtually un-hackable\\". Yes Macs are inherently more secure than Windows XP because of its Unix / BSD background, and also if you only use Apple's App Store to install apps. However it isn't foolproof and its growing popularity will make it a nice target for hackers. In fact it's already happening and I would be surprised if Apple can keep up with the threats without ultimately recommending virus & spyware protection. You need to install anti-virus software now. (Just don't install Norton garbage or anything from Symantec.) Still it's less maintenance than a PC. (I still own and use Windows machines - XP and Win 7)

Since we're on the subject of security, by default Macs aren't setup to be more secure. It's a good idea to change the settings to enable the built-in firewall, as well as a user login, and creating a separate account admin privileges (and disabling admin privileges for everyday use accounts - yes this is annoying but it will save you a lot more headaches in the long run). They have videos on Youtube to do this.

If you're interested in the latest and greatest hardcore PC video games, you're not going to be happy with a Mac. You'll probably have to get a Windows PC. In myopinion, this is one area I think that will still take a few years more for Apple to catch up with MS. Both the Apple App Store and Valve's Steam are making this less of an issue.

I don't know why but I don't really like the Magic Mouse or the wireless keyboard that came with it, so I just bought a larger wired Apple keyboard and I use a cheap Microsoft mouse with scroll wheel. The 2nd mouse button and scroll wheel work great!

Summary:

This is perfect for a dorm, but if you're beyond college I would highly recommend splurging a little extra for the 27in iMac and getting one with a bigger hard drive. It is totally worth it as a replacement for the TV in the bedroom. I hope that they eventually will make a 32in version one day.

Also tried subscribing to New York Times and Boston Globe, which worked OK (though not my cup of tea for normal times.)    Main complaint I have is:  my home in Vermont is outside Kindle (ATT) wireless coverage area -- total dead zone -- and transferring content to the device via PC/USB is a moderate hassle.  On my return from vacation, I found that the latest Kindle model -- at the same price -- has *WiFi* in addition to WhisperNet access, which would be ideal for home use.  ::sigh::
output: Awesome reader, wish I'd waited a few weeks

I have promoted this device to just about every person I know that complains about their WiFi signal trying to reach out to their devices in other locations in the house or outside, etc. This was the easiest, convenient and efficient device to extend your WiFi. Truly, if you can't install this there are more serious issues than your WiFi.

It practically installs itself. If you can plug it into your wall socket near your base computer/router setup, power it up, follow a few on screen commands this device shows on it's screen, & POOF!....It has captured your WiFi signal into this device. Now unplug from the wall and take to your location where you want the WiFi signal extended to. Plug it into the wall to power it up.

Take your computer, tablet, phone, whatever you are trying to get a signal on and find the WiFi provided by your router that has the additional name with "Almond" by it. Choose that one to bring your signal to your device. DONE DEAL! That EASY!

Instances.input:
This is an extensive review that compares this Seagate 2 TB Hard Drive with many other hard drives that I have owned. I do own this Seagate Hard Drive. I also present insight into the performance of this Hard Drive compared to what else is available.

For the last 5 years, I've purchased only Western Digital brand hard drives. I've owned 2 WD Passport external hard drives (750 GB 3.5\\" & 320 GB 2.5\\"), 3 1TB Caviar Green drives, 1 1TB Caviar Black drive, 2 1.5TB Caviar Green drives (64 MB cache & 32 MB cache versions), and 1 320 GB WD drive. All of these have worked or still are working flawlessly. I have not experienced a single drive failure or overheating problem. I have run these drives in an LG NAS Blu-ray unit, a desktop, and as external storage for 2 laptops, and even a DVD player with USB. I am overjoyed with Western Digital hard drives and do not plan on using other brands.

5 years ago, I owned a Seagate Hard Drive that failed the week after the limited 90 day warranty ended. I lost all of my data and was offered no compassion from Seagate. I had to junk the drive. Luckily I had a stack of DVDs backing up about 90% of my files. So my past experience with Seagate is not very positive, but I will give this drive a non-bias review.

I always recommend using additional methods of data back-up for irreplaceable files, storing the back-ups in different physical locations (office, home, parents' house, etc). I have recently invested in a Blu-ray Recorder as prices for BD-R discs have dropped to about $0.10 per GB - comparable to Hard Drive storage prices at the time of writing this review. At 25GB per Blu-ray disc, this is an ideal media for storing back-up files off site - very easy to transport or ship.

I was given this Seagate 2 TB Hard Drive and thought that a review would be helpful because of my extensive experience with other hard drives.

1) 2 TB data. Great storage size. Not much to say here. Price per GB is comparable to other brands.

2) 32 MB cache size. This is the standard cache size at the time of writing this review. However recently a 64 MB cache size has been released. For about the same price per GB of this Seagate drive, I purchased a WD 1.5TB with 64 MB cache size (bought on sale). I recommend a higher cache size because it allows for faster data transfer speed.

3) 5900 RPM disc spin. Non-\\"eco\\" hard drives spin at 7200 RPM for significantly faster data transfer rates. 5900 RPM does reduce heat and energy consumption and is acceptable for hard drives that are used to store files, and not to run software. Seagate gets a positive review for a relatively fast \\"eco\\" spin rate - faster than the traditional 5400 RPM. However Western Digital has been using a variable spin rate of 5400-7200 RPM in their Caviar Green drives for over 2 years. \\"Better late than never\\" is a good slogan for this Seagate drive.

4) Reported high failure rate of this drive. My own Seagate 2 TB drive is running without problems as an eSATA connected external HDD. However this HDD has been plagued with reviewers experiencing disc failure - with approximately 30% of reviewers reporting drive failure. Compare this to Western Digital drives that show about 1-2% drive failures from Amazon.com reviewers. 30% is far too high. Maybe Seagate needs to modify their hardware or perhaps Amazon's \\"frustration free packaging\\" is at fault. Either way, a failure rate this high must be taken seriously by Seagate and buyers.

5) Loud noise for an \\"eco\\" hard drive. Eco drives are designed to run on low power with a lower noise compared to faster spinning hard drives. Compared to my Wester Digital drives, which I cannot even hear spin in my NAS unit, this Seagate is louder. Not louder than a standard 7200 RPM drive, but louder than comparable eco-drives that spin around 5400 RPM.

My personal conclusion is that this hard driveis just a run-of-the-mill hard drive that has started out on the wrong foot. High failure rates, average performance scores, and nothing to set it apart from the competition. Personally, I have been overjoyed with the performance of my Wester Digital hard drives. This Seagate has given me nothing to get excited about. So I will continue to be faithful to Western Digital and recommend WD until my own experience convinces me otherwise.igh failure rates, average performance scores, and nothing to set it apart from the competition. Personally, I have been overjoyed with the performance of my Wester Digital hard drives. This Seagate has given me nothing to get excited about. So I will continue to be faithful to Western Digital and recommend WD until my own experience convinces me otherwise.
output: Decent Hard Drive, but I'd considered another brand

Instances.input: I've owned three of these headsets over the years and it's always the workhorse that I go back to. I'm a gamer and a movie watcher when it comes to my computer usage and the one thing I love the most about this headset is how it feels like it's not there. I've had "better" higher-priced headsets such as ones from the Steel Series, but there is definitely no behind-the-head headset that is more comfortable and light for the PC. The microphone is also superb, letting your voice come clear and crisp and the sound quality is good, although you won't get the bass or sound quality that you'd expect for avid music virtuosos. The lifespan of these headsets for me have been approximately 3 years a piece or so (one of mine broke due to misplacement that caused physical damage). I highly recommend this headset for people looking for a great budget headset who can afford to spend a little more than $10 cheap headset (that will undoubtedly break within a few months to a year), but don't want to fork over anymore for something serviceable for gaming and chatting needs.
output: Comfort and quality at a great price

Like all extended batteries, you can not expect it to fit the design of your laptop perfectly. I'm happy Sony at least made it extend downwards, keeping the laptop in a downward like angle, as opposed to making extend backwards. I prefer the Vaio P be on a little angle, besides, I think it makes it easier to type, as opposed to having the battery extend backwards and not allowing the Vaio P to fit into one of it's designed cases. ...yes, even with this battery, the Vaio P will fit comfortably into any of the cases Sony has designed for it, even the leather one.

As for performance, and again, like any battery out there, don't expect it to last as long as Sony promises, unless you really dim the screen to like nothing, turn off the wireless, speakers, etc... By dimming the screen to about 3 bars (still comfortable for me, the Vaio P has a SUPER bright LCD) and wireless off, I get about 6 hours, with the same settings plus a Sprint USB Internet Card I get about 5 1/2 hours.

Before I purchased the battery, I Googled images, but found none showing the battery on the laptop, so I'll post images of what that looks like, for future shoppers. ...as well as images of what the laptop will look like while in the leather Sony case with this battery on it.

I was iffy about giving it 5 stars, since the battery is a bit heavy (not SUPER heavy, but I'm sure it could be lighter), but it does it's job pretty well, and it's just a battery (can't believe I'm reviewing a battery LOL).
output: It's a battery - it's ugly, but it works

I have recently purchased the Encore 8 tablet at DealFisher through Amazon.

After some days of testing, i am quite satisfied with the product. To my opinion, the device does well the job of a Windows tablet (considering the handling limitations of Windows OS in comparison with Android). For instance, a pen is very necesary for full productivity.

However it is worth mentioning here some potential issues for the use of that tablet as a GPS device to make mobile cartography in the field:
- The device is quite heavy and difficult to handle, especialy for an outdoor use.
- I regret that GNSS does not function as a NMEA device. However, Centrafuse Localizer software allows to work with Arcpad mobile GIS software, but this software is sometime buggy. I have tested the geolocation accuracy which results very aleatory (in comparison with DGPS and even with a classic garmin trecking GPS).

It is also important to notice that the Intel Atom Z3740 is basically a 1,33 GHz procesor and not a 1.86 GHz (as stipulated by Amazon specs): see http://ark.intel.com/products/76759/Intel-Atom-Processor-Z3740-2M-Cache-up-to-1_86-GHz
output: Encore 8 as GPS device for fieldwork

I bought one of these for my office at a leading electronics store in New York last summer.  I was so impressed with it, I purchased another one from Amazon in the fall for my home office after Hurricane Sandy forced me to work out of home for 7 weeks because my office in lower Manhattan was inaccessible.  This stand is terrific.  I use it for my third generation iPad.  You can use your iPad in portrait (my preference) or landscape mode.  More importantly, the Satechi allows you to position your iPad at the super-precise height AND angle you want.  Most stands will give you just a few limited options as to viewing/working angle, and few out there allow you to choose a perferred height.  The stand is very sturdy, so it won't tip over (unless you try to position your iPad at some ridiculous angle of something like 10-20 degrees so that you're trying to set your iPad almost parallel to your desk, but who's going to do that anyway?).  I'm extremely pleased with the Satechi stand and highly recommend it.  It's not cheap, but you WON'T be disappointed.
output: The Best iPad Stand Out There.  Period.

I had ordered an HTPC from Assassin several weeks ago. After telling Ben what I needed, within a few weeks, I got my new custom HTPC in the mail. Unfortunately, it was clear from the beginning that the unit had fallen out of the box during transit. All the components inside the unit were all scrambled and loose. And, the fan was ripped and broken from the mother board. Of course, I was heartbroken.

However, Ben has been outstanding throughout this entire ordeal. He apologized and agreed to build me an entirely new HTPC from scratch! It looks like Assassin has to eat the entire loss. (I feel really bad about this because I know it's a lot of money. But, at the same time, it wasn't my fault.)

With respect to the service, it's been great. I ask them a question from time to time. And, it's clear that they are busy but they do get back to you. I've upgraded my order a bit in order to increase the money they make but it's impossible for them to make up what they will lose.

Instances.input:
Maybe I've just been lucky with these wireless adaptors since I've only had issues with one in the last 5 years or so. The TP-Link TL-WDN3200 was not the one I experienced problems with, although not heavily used, it has yet to let me down.

My application is to a Panasonic DMP-BDT220 Integrated Wi-Fi 3D Blu-ray DVD Player. It was easier to set up the Blu-ray player with this unit and connect wirelessly to my router than to mess with CAT 5 cable connected to the receiver through a cable, which with all I have going into the receiver may have required some kind of additional router.

As I said it is not used frequently but is great for downloading music and movies. Internet surfing is a little slow but I believe that to be the Blu-ray player rather than the TP-Link TL-WDN3200. Unfortunately I'm in a small town and the best we can get is a 6 meg internet connection which may also have contributed to the download speed and unfortunately is too slow for streaming video.

Overall, you can't go wrong with the TP-Link TL-WDN3200.

Does everything I want and more. I have to deal with several USB keys for installation of various OSes and running utilities and diagnostics and I wanted a hub that was portable enough to slip in my bag while leaving the USB keys plugged in. I didn't want to fool around with a key wallet, and swapping out keys all the time.

This hub works with or without the external power, so I can just grab it an go. It uses a standard mini-USB to connect to the PC.

I have used every kind of device on it with no problems at all; MP3 players, cameras, 2TB external disks, a MagicJack, a Windows Phone, a USB headset, as well as USB keys from 128MB up to 32GB. I've had no trouble with connecting any device side-by-side with any other; some hubs have the ports too closely spaced to get two odd-sized devices next to each other. Being able to use the swing-up ports for my mouse RF receiver and the MagicJack is nice as well.

I ran tests with HD tune on a number of USB devices (2.0 and 3.0, although the hub doesn't support 3.0) and detected no difference in performance between hub-connected and direct-connected devices. I was impressed that the Logitech USB headset and the MagicJack both worked perfectly, because these have often been flaky with hub; they usually liked to be plugged in directly.

I *will* buy this brand again the next time I need a hub. A USB 3.0 version perhaps?

So far, awesome. After two weeks of use, this has been amazing in both terms of range and stability. My older TP-Link suffered from stability issues from day one (even after loading DD-WRT), needing near weekly reboots. Additionally, in my 3 story home the TP-Link required placement on the main floor in order to provide coverage to the furthest areas of my smaller (~2200 sq ft) home's Foscam cameras. Even then, the connection to these cameras was laggy and unstable.

Upgrading to this router changed that. I was able to place the router back in the basement utility closet (with the rest of my tech gear), and the range and throughput to my remote foscams is excellent, with very limited lag. Additionally, the one time I had internet connectivity issues, the router's firmware helped me identify the issue as being related to my CenturyLink modem.

Overall, I'm extremely pleased with my short-term gains from upgrading to this router.
output: Great range, super stable even with stock firmware

Instances.input:
It is somewhat inaccurate to compare with a tablet or laptop - this one has both. It is indeed a full fledge computer with a side order of \\"tablet\\".

Of course, we all reserve the right of playing with many different toys! I have. One thing I like about tablets is the \\"app player\\" function. With Windows 8, this slate has it too. The app variety is small compared with Android, and infantile compared with iThings, but it is growing and so far quality is trumping quantity. There is also a program called BlueStacks which enables android apps in windows.

Then there is the computer side. This baby can do anything my laptop can do (it even includes the free docking keyboard). Touch screen and uber-portability are awesome features. All my programs from many years back work flawlessly. Using a stylus helps with the less in-your-face touch menus in the desktop side.

Regarding the storage capacity, 32GB great for tablets but is not a lot for computing, but there are several ways around it. The easiest and cheapest is to use its full size SD card slot. Fast cards are priced very reasonably; you can double the storage capacity for less than $20. I have gone as far up as 64 GB with not compatibility issues. For the geekier crowd, changing the internal drive for a much bigger one is not very difficult and increasingly affordable.

This slate deserves 5 stars in form, functionality and reasonable price point.

I don' normally give a five star rating, but in this case it truly is worthy of a five star rating. I received the HD a full business day early. This may not sound like a big deal, but the day it should have been delivered was on Monday. I got it on Friday. Packaging was top notch. I installed the HD and OS within an hour and was playing Star Wars, The Old Republic that night! WOOHOO!!!!

There's a lot to love about this tablet. Bare bones Android for one. Very good forward firing speakers. Clever stylus. Micro-SD slot. Micro HDMI out.
Build is just average and what you'd expect at the price point.
ONE irritation for me. The micro-usb port is a bit of a pain to access because it's mounted on the slope of a bevel. I fumble with it so much that I'm afraid I'll break it one day.
Otherwise...love it.
output: Chose this over the Nexus 7 and I'm Happy

This is an excellent case for the following reasons:

1) Protective: The neoprene inside will protect the Kindle DX from scratches and the usual bumps. (It isn't strong enough to protect from sharp blows to the screen, or dropping.)
2) Zipper zips sufficiently far around that you can get the Kindle in and out very easily, and without the zipper causing a scratch. (Which it wouldn't anyway, as it is plastic, and the teeth are on the outside of case when unzipped, away from where you'd be sliding the Kindle in or out.)
3) Feels good to carry. The Kindle is snug enough that it doesn't slide around inside it, and both the cloth parts and faux leather parts of the outside of the cover feel good on the hands.
4) Fits the Kindle DX well. In fact, even if you have the Kindle in a silicone sleeve it will still fit (very snugly) inside the case. (But the silicone sleeve is unnecessary if you have the case, I took mine off. It also doesn't slide as easily in or out with the silicone sleeve on.)
5) Looks clean and simple, not ostentatious, and is also light.

Possible improvement for future revisions of this product:

1) A little half-pocket inside to slip a business card into so that when you leave your Kindle behind in a cafe the new owner can know who to thank.

(This review doesn't have a \\"Amazon verified purchase\\" tag because I received it as a gift from someone who bought it at Amazon.com.)
output: This is an excellent, comfortable case.

Instances.input: I needed to elevate a monstrous HP DV8 laptop, which has an 18.4 inch screen. This seems to be the only stand on the market that can accomodate something over 17 inches wide. It is very sturdy and well-built. A neatly tucked USB cable is built in and is the primary means of connecting the wireless keyboard and the USB Hub. Only inconveniences: a) the stand is up or down and not fully adjustable; and b) the stand blocks the front of the laptop preventing IR remote access on mine.     The keyboard is well-above average, with ample wrist rest and multi-media functions. It has all the necessary functionality (including volume control and video/audio playback functions), along with good signal reach and low power consumption (I haven't changed the batteries yet, after two months use).     Overall, this is a solid buy. I couldn't be happier. Just add a mouse and you're good to go.

I recenlty received this as a gift from my parents as a replacement laptop for personal use and shool coursework. Most of use is for editing, browsing internet and watching online videos. This laptop is equipped with an AMD A8 Quad core and my last one was a 3rd Gen Intel i5. So far, I haven't felt that much of a difference. It's really thin, sleek and light, yet powerful to run most of programs I installed without a glitch. Another nice thing is it has a separate number keys which I would prefer to have. I'm happy with the product at a price under $500, with a large RAM and hard drive capacity. Toshiba will be always my first pick.
output: Another nice thing is it has a separate number keys which ...

After watching my computer tell me I should order a new battery for many months, I finally did so. I ordered this Anker battery through Amazon. It arrived promptly, fit perfectly, and has so far exceeded my expectations for how long it lasts between charges. I fully charge the battery once a day, although it is not yet fully discharged when I plug it in. I use the computer a number of times each day, and do not put it to sleep or shut it off between uses, although the screen does shut off after 10 minutes inactivity.  Not only am I very pleased with the battery itself, but also happy that it was half the price of any other place I found to purchase a similar battery for my computer.
It's well built but one complaint I have about it that light

The majority of 4 and 5 star reviews here pretty much capture our brief experience with this tablet. We give it 4 instead of 5 for 3 reasons: while we like the size of the tablet and holds nicely in your hand for reading, it's thicker and heavier than we thought it would be. Lighter than our previous Fire HD but a bit heavy/bulky for a small tablet/device. Similarly, the Amazon cover has an odd fit. The edge of the device is slightly exposed above the edge of the cover and I've never seen a cover that fits likes that. The face cover (the origami portion) folds over it but isn't flush to the edge. It's just kind of weird. Finally, the touchscreen does not seem as responsive as our previous Fire HD or other tablets/devices we own or have owned. As some other reviewers have indicated it seems to take multiple touches sometimes. Also, the glide function doesn't work nearly as well as it did on the previous model, could be due to screen size but more likely related to the responsiveness issue.    All that being said we are very satisfied with the device as a whole. The size is good (like I said it's comfortable to hold), the screen resolution is excellent and the cameras are adequate. It boots up WAY faster and the new OS is a big step forward (even though Amazon gives you less control over device settings now it seems) and reading on it is a good experience overall. No, the sound is not as good as the EXCELLENT Dolby stereo sound on our other model, but better than my phone and smoother quality than my iPad Mini, though not as loud.
output: The majority of 4 and 5 star reviews here pretty much capture our brief experience with this tablet

Instances.input: This seems to work as well as my original battery.  An inexpensive way to get power back to your laptop.
It helps out a lot.

It actually blows my mind how well this cooling solution works. I've only ever used stock coolers before, and I would get idle temperatures 10-15C above my room temperature (~40-45C). I don't know if it's this H60, or my processor (i5 4670K) or a combination of both that lets me get really good temperatures, but I am idling at 29-30C in a 24C room (or rather, 88-90F in a 74F room) Under load it also only gets to about 48-50C. I am very happy with how well it performs.

It also looks good. The directions to uninstall could have been clearer, but I figured it out. One thing to note for people installing it (on at least intel sockets) is that the backplate is NOT secure until you put the heatsink and bracket thing on as well. Even with the standoffs fully screwed in the backplate will wiggle around. I spent a bit of time trying to figure out if this was correct because I didn't want to mess up the preapplied thermal paste if it was wrong. But it does work like that.

I admit that the case is a little heavy, but it is sturdy. My four year old niece can handle the case with no problem. She has dropped it about four or five times and no damage has been done to the IPAD. I do not think it really takes away from the quality of the picture too much. It's a trade off for the good protection it offers.

The picture saving speed after picture was taken is a little faster but not a whole lot.  For an armature photography like me I am happy with the current speed.  I knew there is other card out there which will give you supper fast.  If you have the buck, then go for that.
After 2 min set up works very well on my Panasonic plasma TV for lass > $20 instead of Panasonic dongle for $70.

Instances.input: I'm not please with this product for the follow reason. The protective coating on the end of the cord has separated from end of the plug exposing the wiring. Would not recommend you buy this product. Would rather purchase the cord from Dell and pay the mark up price than the discount price.

I really love the Kindle Fire HD. I am not a big apple fan so wasn't interested in an ipad, had considered a google tablet but read mixed reviews on some aspects of it, so I decided on the Kindle Fire HD. I did have some concerns. I had tried one out at a kiosk at a mall around Christmas time and it seemed clunky (slow, screen freezing) and some of the reviews are negative with comments on charging issues and inability to connect via Wifi. Still, I took a risk knowing I could return it thru amazon.

Delievery is perfect when ordered thru amazon, it is already setup for you on your amazon account. Email, facebook, twitter apps all easy to setup and default to your login's so you just tap the icon and you are in your account. Netflix App - works great. A coworker and I were on a business trip, he with his ipad, me with my kindle. I watched several netflix movies over the hotels Wifi (some freezeups as it streamed but nothing beyond minor annoyance). His ipad couldn't stream anything at all. We were in adjacent rooms so we should have been nearly the same distance from the wireless router.

I've also downloaded a number of movies via Amazon and they play back great. First one I downloaded the HD version and it looked great, but true HD costs $1 more. Next movies I downloaded were SD movies and they looked just as good. I also like that I can connect an HDMI cable from the kindle to my TV. I do this in hotel rooms on business travel - super cool. On airplanes the small screen is just fine and the sound thru headphones is great. SD movies also download a lot faster. HD took about 8 hours, SD took about an hour. Just plan ahead of course.

I find web surfing to be sufficient on the silk browser. If you try to tap links too quickly before the page fully loads it might lock up and have to be restarted. Don't know if this is the fault of the browser or the kindle. The biggest hurdle is the smaller screen but zooming in is intuitiveand fast.

the only true negative I would say is I'm not thrilled with Amazon prime's options of free movies. I didn't realize at first you could only stream them, not download and watch later. And their selections are not much different, certainly not any better, than Netflix. I will likely cancel amazon prime. What IS the differentiator over Netflix is the options for downloading just released movies that were recently in the theater. You can get those without amazon prime. Trust me, I really wanted to appreciate amazon prime but if you have a Netflix account it is not much different (well, the free two day shipping I suppose but I rarely need something that bad - not worth $80 a year).

I will agree that lack of any written directions is odd and although I consider myself tech savy, accessing some things was not obvious. I did figure it out via reading posts online. Others have complained about the power button and volume tabs being flush with the device so they are hard to find. Trust me, get a cover/case for the kindle and most of them have touch points that make it pretty obvious where the buttons are. I'd think even without a case you eventually learn. I found it frustrating at first too and after 5 weeks the buttons are a breeze to find.

I think a front and rear facing camera would be an improvement, but I have taken a lof of pics with the camera pointed forward, just have to know where the button is to take the pic on the screen. It can be awkward but do-able. I post a lot more pics on facebook now!

I would highly recommend this product. Ideal if you want it for light web browsing and entertainment (movies, tv shows).

I've used Logitech gaming mice, I've use Saitek gaming mice, I've used Razer gaming mice and the result is the same; Microsoft has created the defacto standard for gaming accessories. To start, the mouse is both wired and wireless, offering a hybrid form of charging the onboard battery on-the-fly, without disrupting game play. Above all, the actual construction of the mouse it's self is my favorite part, offering up quality responsiveness and a good weight with quality componentry - even the scroll wheel is a metal wheel rather than a plastic one. The mouse has a few adjustable features including the mouse feet, but overall the size and fit of the mouse should be solid for those with very large hands or small alike. I myself have wide, thick hands and find the feel just find with no stress on any specific joint or tendon.

The responsiveness of this mouse is another great feature and is completely programmable within the Intellipoint software - Which should be downloaded new rather than using the generally outdated versions that come prepackaged. With the 3 sensitivity settings (adjusted by the 3 buttons under the scroll wheel) you can make on-the-fly changes in game to use the desired sensitivity with little hassle. The battery gauge on the thumb side of the mouse displays batter life and mouse sensitivity visually, letting you know the exact DPI the mouse is currently using. This mouse does not need a special pad or surface, but I did purchase the WOW!Pad @ [...] and find the surface is perfect for high precision game play and twitch-style gaming.

Lastly, I keep the receiver quite close, being within 24\\" of the mouse, but even at greater distances the responsiveness of the wireless action was superb and rivaled the responsiveness of the Logitech and Razer mice I've used in the past. As far as quality goes, I'd much rather use the X8 than any other current gaming mouse that I've found. Not one other mouse offers the same feature base with the quality to go along with, and this after I've gone through 4x Razer Diamondbacks, 4x Logitech G5s and numerous other mice over the years. I'm hoping I've found the last mouse I need to buy, or at least until a further updated version arrives! Happy gaming!to go along with, and this after I've gone through 4x Razer Diamondbacks, 4x Logitech G5s and numerous other mice over the years. I'm hoping I've found the last mouse I need to buy, or at least until a further updated version arrives! Happy gaming!

Pros: its a working mouse.

Cons: HORRIBLE Horrible horrible build quality. this mouse feels like if you play a game where you smash the mouse button or use a semi auto weapon it will crush under your fingers. [but why the helicopter would you be playing a game on here???]
Mouse buttons started to not function, had to press a billion times or incredibly, INCREDIBLY hard for 1 click.

this mouse would make a great mouse if yours dies and you need something temporarily for browsing the web or business.
but there is literally no point in buying this online. if it was at an airport or trainstation and you just need it for a little that would make sense. but to purchase this online is dumb. when there are plenty of other options....

First off I bought mine from here at Amazon through the seller \\"TDC direct\\" for under $4 shipped! Great Product! Superb price!    These are crystal clear and lay down great! Let me just say that I have put on 20+ screen protectors such as these and can now get them on quick and easy with no air bubbles or particles under it, in fact you cannot tell they are even on there when I'm done! I have found that first it starts with a good product like these, then its all in the application! I use a very simple method using filtered water ( straight out of the pure drinking water filter) and here is how I do it.    Perfect results Installation:    Step #1 Wash your hands and the area where your working by wiping down and making sure its clear of any animal hair, lint, dust etc.    Step #2 Rinse a container large enough to fit your protector in submerged and fill with filtered water (like a plastic glad container)    Step #3 Get everything your using for the instal including the protector and product wiped down with a damp cloth (like a well rinsed dish cloth)    Step #4 Next rinse your hands really well under the sink and again with a little filtered water.    Step #5 Using the filtered water on your damp hands rinse the screen on your product (if it has any skin oil or is dirty use a drop of dish soap first and rinse repeatedly then start again at the top) do this like your swiping like a windshield wiper (don't worry about a little water on you device it wont hurt it!)    Step #6 Next: There are three layers of plastic on each protector the first labeled \\"step one\\" take of now, it is the bottom throw away layer! and then use the filtered water in container to rinse the protector just like you did the product screen but this time you can fully submerge the protector to make sure you have cleared any dust or particles from it making sure the bottom surface is absolutely clean by using a wiping motion with your hand repeatedly.     Step #7 Apply filtered water to your now cleaned product screen with your damp hand and with the protector dripping wet straight out of the water set it on to your device and center it. next use a squeegee working your way from the center out pushing the water and air out (i use a little rubber squeegee to do this but a thin peace of plastic with a straight smooth edge like a battery cover off a TV remote works just as good)    Step #8 If you screw up and there is something under the protector like a peace of lint or particle or its not on straight, don't worry just take it off and start over by washing thoroughly and re-applying it as many times as it takes making sure to rinse and fallow the above steps again, these protectors are fully reusable! You can even go back and fix an old application using this method.    Step #9 Make sure you get all the air and water pushed out the best you can. If you can see a tiny water bubble or two don't worry, it will evaporate after a couple days. FYI: Stubborn air bubbles I have found are usually lint or a particle and require a redo.    Step #10 Carefully pull the top protective layer of plastic off leaving the center thicker protector in place. Next dry everything and your done! Shweew you did it! :). Again remember there are three layers to each protector the bottom and top are thinner and get thrown away they are just there to keep the middle \\"Screen protector\\" clean.    Sounds like allot LOL but it really is simple if you just get and keep everything clean.    Hope that helps.    PS: With a sharp pare of scissors you can cut the extra two protectors into screen protectors for your camera, phone or whatever... just make sure when you cut, that you hold them bottom side of the protector down and also mark (a thin sharpie marker works good) top/bottom before you cut ;)
output: Excellent product! Application is key! Read 10 easy steps below!

Instances.input:
I receive my Linksys EA4500 router along with AE3000 wireless adapter. Great combination, Let me just say if you are in the market for a wireless router this is a definite recommendation. It a little pricey (the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars), but its worth the cost. I bought the router for $150 or so. So, if you find it under $150 go for it...I received it on 14 Sep 2012, setup was effortless and no problems a month later. I spent approx 1 hour, but I also took the took the time to read all instructions/directions. Started with my desktop (main PC), then added: laptop, wireless printer, smart-tv, smart-phone, PS3. The install process could probably be done in less than 15 min, but I like to take my time when installing new hardware. The cisco graphical user interface application is very user friendly and for those that are a little more advance the web-interface is also very user friendly. My previous router was a linksys wrt54g, so if you have a linksys router you are already familiar with the web-user interface. After 5 years of use, it finally started to drop my connection many times a day depending on use.

As far as setting it up, I used 95% of the default settings, again simplicity at its best and did not have any issues. The \\"guest\\" wireless network works great and is very user friendly.

-Range excellent, I live a a typical 3 bedroom single de-attached home. I five bars in every room, patio out back, in front of home-curbside, when moving about with my laptop. (using my built-in wifi device)

-Internet speed, I notice increased speed/transfer with this router compared to my previous one.

-As far as the other stuff this router does, I haven't played with it yet. For instance, using it as a media hub, connecting a USB hard-drive to stream media...but maybe sometime before the year is out. :)
output: Best home router I ever owned!!!

I purchased this router to stream video wirelessly to a Linksys DMA 2100 Media Center Extender. I also purchased a Linksys 610N USB Dual Band Wireless notebook card. Setting up these three products was fairly complicated and required several calls to the Linksys Customer Support Center. Once all the issues were resolved, I was able to stream HD video content wirelessly to the Media Extender in my living room using the 5 GHZ band, while connecting wirelessly on my notebook to the internet using the 2.4 GHZ band. I've encountered no interference issues and the range of the 5 GHZ band is sufficient to watch HD video in my living room about 75 feet from the router without glitches or stuttering. This product is well-designed, with an efficient and quiet fan, comfortable padding, and good sound quality. The only drawback is its weight, while contributing to its stability, makes the unit cumbersome, and might limit its usability under some circumstances.    Before purchasing, you should consider its size -- the padded rests on both sides are substantial and the unit could easily fill the distance between the armrests on a coach flight or your favorite chair.     I was pleased with the sound quality - good mid and bass response, quite an upgrade from the soft and tinny sound from my Macbook's internal speakers. Of note; the USB connector cord is built-in, with a finite length. You cannot readily substitute a longer generic cord.  This should not be much of a problem.    Finally, when sitting on my couch, with my Macbook opened fully, I sometimes cannot get the best angle for viewing the screen. A squirm sometimes cures that, but again, it's something to consider, depending on how far your laptop opens, screen viewing offset, etc.    Logitech designs and builds quality products, and this is no exception.  It is solid, with excellent fit and finish of all components. If the size, weight, and viewing angle issues are not problems for you, the improved sound, unit cooling, and comfort make for a good upgrade alternative to the \\"fan-only\\" type of unit.    PROS: Good cooling, silent fan, good sound quality, solid construction, well-designed and built.  CONS: Weight and size
output: Works quite well, but a bit heavy

When I first played dota, csgo, a.c black flag, watch dogs, my jaw dropped at how stunning the game looked. Could I go back to 1080p.. NO WAY! Once you see what you've been missing (gaming wise) you can never go back. I did purchase a gtx 970 because I thought my gtx 760 couldn't run 4k effectively, but both cards did well, but I'm glad I upgraded. The 970 on almost max settings in assassins creed held at about 45-50 fps. That's not even in SLI! If your are on the fence about getting this monitor I would say go for it, you can't get a better brand or sexier picture. It's just a great leap in technology and I will soon order another for a dual monitor setup. Now back to 4k gaming I must go.

First, this is a nice design. It runs quietly, stays cool, and looks nice. The on/off switch on the front is a plus as well.

However, the original enclosure I received turned out to be faulty. When I inserted my new 1.5tB hard drive into it, plugged in the cables, and turned it on, the drive started up, but nothing showed in the computer, either as a volume or in the disk utility (Mac OS X). After about 30 seconds or so, the enclosure automatically shut down, so that was it for diagnosis. I then tried it out on a friend's Windows computer, and the same thing happened. So we tried the drive directly, using SATA to USB and power connectors, and it showed up, which suggests the problem must be in the enclosure. Yet the new enclosure worked with a previously formatted drive. Nonetheless, after playing with various combinations I finally concluded that the enclosure must be defunct and returned it for a replacement.

The replacement arrived in two days (very good service from Amazon) and works perfectly. I'm happy with the result.

So it was a minor hassle, but fine in the end. It's good to be aware that even a relatively simple device like an enclosure can be DOA.

Instances.input:
I've been using the case cover for 4 days now. Here are my impressions...

THE FIT:
I'm impressed at how well it fits the retina Macbook Pro... snapped right on and, so far, has stayed in place.

THE LOOK:
It looks pretty good.. It's a matte black plastic with a rubber look/feel. The Apple logo will shine through the plastic, but not very noticeably in a bright room (or outdoors) or when you have the screen brightness turned down. The biggest downside is that the plastic shows fingerprint smudges... I can live with that, I guess... just need to wipe it clean everything now and then. I'm not a big fan of the 4 rubber feet on the bottom, they add a little unnecessary thickness the MBP (although it might help with cooling by allowing more air circulating) ... I'd rather they left 4 holes for the MacBook's built in feet to stick through.

THE FEEL:
I like the rubber'ish feel of the plastic. I don't like that there are some sharp edges around the side of the case (sort of like little sharp edges left from how the case was made... I've tried filing them down a little and that helped some).

Overall it does the job of keeping the case protected. I may not use it forever, but for now its fine.
output: Fits good, some sharp edges. does the job
